headline: Amazon's Risky Christmas
abstract: Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon.com, comments on major expansion of popular Internet site's distribution capacity, what he calls fastest in peacetime history, for upcoming holiday season; millions of people are expected to make their first online shopping purchases this holiday season, but Amazon now has stiff competition; photos; graphs (L)

headline: The Redesign of an Auto Analyst
abstract: Maryann N Keller, formerly much-feared auto-company analyst, is now president of unit of Priceline.com that brokers sale of automobiles; Priceline makes money as broker; customers bid for vehicles online and agree to pay Web site $50 if they buy; Priceline forwards bids to nearby dealers, who pay it $200 if lead turns into sale; Priceline is growing rapidly, but it still loses money as Internet start-up; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; Economists wonder if commodity prices will remain strong.
abstract: Market Place column on whether commodity prices will remain strong in year 2000; notes Bridge/Commodity Research index of 17 commodities rose for year, up 6.7 percent through Jan 28; graph; chart (M)

headline: 3 Phone Companies Meet Estimates on Profit
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp, BellSouth Corp and Sprint Communications Co meet third-quarter estimates on profit; Sprint says profit fell 13 percent; net income fell to $359 million from $415 million a year ago; revenue rose 7.4 percent, to $4.34 billion, from $4.04 billion; Bell Atlantic says profit rose to $1.2 billion from $1.09 billion in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 5 percent, to $8.3 billion; BellSouth says profit rose to $972 million from net income of $814 million last year; revenue rose 9.4 percent, to record $6.42 billion (M)

headline: United Drops 'Rising' Campaign
abstract: United Airlines is scrapping its 'Rising' campaign after only two years and is looking for replacement from its roster advertising agencies, Fallon McElligott and Young & Rubicam (S)

headline: Business Travel; The biggest dampener of celebrations this New Year's Eve is turning out to be inflated prices.
abstract: Biggest dampener of celebrations this New Year's Eve has proved to be highly inflated pric tags for parties and entertainment packages; many people who booked reservations for New Year's Eve 1999 as early 1998, before rates for parties and cruises were established, were among first to cancel when it came time to put down deposit (M)

headline: Web Buying: Is It Safe?
abstract: Q. When you buy something online, how do they make sure credit card information is safe from computer hackers?    A. E-commerce Web sites usually use data encryption methods to ensure the safety of your financial information. When you type in your credit card number and hit the button to submit it to the company, the information is encrypted for travel across the Internet. Even if the number is intercepted, it will be scrambled and useless to most people. The site you were doing business with can decrypt the information with a special password once it arrives.

headline: TARMAC ACCEPTS NEW BID
abstract: Tarmac PLC agrees to sweetened takeover offer of 1.2 billion pounds by Anglo American (S)

headline: Weber McGinn Buys Barbour Griffith
abstract: Weber McGinn, Arlington, Va, unit of Weber Public Relations Worldwide, acquires Barbour Griffith & Rogers in Washington, a leading government lobbyist (S)

headline: Janus Fund Manager Plans to Step Down
abstract: Janus Capital Corp says James Craig is stepping down as manager of its flagship $33 billion Janus Fund to become firm's research director; Craig will continue to serve as chief investment officer of Janus Capital; Blaine Rollins, Craig's assistant on Janus Fund, will take over as portfolio manager in January (S)

headline: Pinball Line Closing Down
abstract: WMS Industries announces that it is closing its pinball division; decision means that Stern Pinball will be only remaining pinball maker; Russ Jensen, amateur pinball historian, says possibility exists that pinball may not live into next millennium; WMS profile (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Vstream, Boulder, Colo., a Web-based business communications company, to the Greco Ethridge Group, Boston, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

headline: Sometimes, an Outside Director is Comfortable in the Chief's Chair
abstract: Article explores reasons why big companies do not usually hire board members as executives; assesses uncertainties that accompany more common tactic of hiring outside executives who are not on boards of directors; photo (M)

headline: Russia Reacts Angrily Over Western Criticism on Chechnya
abstract: Russian officials react angrily to Western condemnation of military tactics in Chechnya; warns threats to impose sanctions or interrupt aid are unacceptable; several officials insist Russia is feeling effects of criticism through decision by International Monetary Fund to postpone delivery of $640 million credit (M)

headline: Argentina's New Chief Wins $2 Billion Increase in Taxes
abstract: Argentina's Congress gives Pres Fernando de la Rua his most important victory by raising taxes more than $2 billion to counteract expanding budget deficit; that and $1.4 billion cut in spending enacted days ago should reassure foreign investors, and should lower interest rates to speed business expansion; passage of economic package should help dispel fears that de la Rua will be unable to work with Senate controlled by former Pres Carlos Saul Menem's Justicialist Party (M)

headline: U.S. Backs Away From Bid To Cut Off Aid to Russia
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say United States will not seek to block economic aid to Russia as punishment for drive against separatist rebels in Chechnya; says US backs World Bank decision to release $100 million loan package; approval raises Russian hopes that US will not block much larger International Monetary Fund aid package (M)

headline: Is the Dollar Leaving Canada Feeling Drained?; Capital Is Fleeing to the South As U.S. Companies Look North
abstract: Americans are buying Canadian companies at record pace, taking advantage of economy newly open to foreign investment and Canadian dollar trading near historic lows; KPMG Corporate Finance survey shows in first nine months of 1999, American companies bought 181 companies for $24 billion, double amount spent in year-earlier period; some recent acquisitions noted; American investors are also getting into Canadian stocks; in first seven months of year, Americans increased their Canadian stockholdings by $6.5 billion, sevenfold increase over corresponding period two years ago; Canadians are funneling their money in US; Statistics Canada says as of August, Canadians had, for first time on record, more money invested in foreign stock markets than in Canadian markets; Canadians, investing largely in American shares, now own at least $57 billion of foreign stocks; graph; photo (M)

headline: A Crash Course in History
abstract: Museum of American Financial History on Wall Street is scene of party observing great stock market crash of 1929 (S)

headline: Jerusalem Memo; Israeli Press Serves Scandal du Jour, in Hefty Dollops
abstract: There are so many scandals in Israel that one newspaper on Nov 26 ran full-page scandal guide with boxes for every major affair, its suspects, its allegations and status of investigation (M)

headline: Risk Growing For U.N. Staff In the Field
abstract: United Nations Security Council votes to send team of 30 civilians to maintain UN presence in Angola, described as Africa's most dangerous country; country has had virtually constant civil war since independence came in 1975 (S)

headline: U.S. Wields Defter Weapon Against Iraq: Concrete Bomb
abstract: US military officials say fighter jets patrolling northern Iraq, wary of killing civilians, are using laser-guided bombs filled with concrete instead of explosives and dropping them on military targets near populared areas; map; photo (M)

headline: As Data About Readers Grows, Newspapers Ask: Now What?
abstract: Web sites are providing newspapers with new feedback about their readers and those readers' tastes that is far more detailed than gross circulation figures and surveys on which they have long depended; how that information is used is likely to reshape the business of newspapering, online and off; one core question is how willing publishers should be to marry data about audience preferences to the technologies that allow them to accommodate and customize those preferences; chart; photo (M)

headline: RON MOTLEY
abstract: Contents of briefcase of Ron Motley, partner in Ness Motley Loadhold Richardson & Poole law firm in Charleston, SC, described; photos (S)

headline: Indonesia Releases Bank Audit, Hastening I.M.F. Help
abstract: Indonesia's Parliament publishes long-awaited report on banking scandal that helped bring down administration of former Pres B J Habibie, and International Monetary Fund says move clears way for it to resume $43 billion economic rescue package by middle of December; World Bank and newly elected Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, speaker of Parliament, Akbar Tanung, agree not to wait for two committees to deliberate report; senior economics minister, Kwik Kian Gie, gives report to IMF's Asia-Pacific director, Hubert Neiss; release of report is likely to help allay foreign investor concerns about Indonesia's commitment to economic change (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Ticketmaster Tries to Stir The Passions of Eventgoers
abstract: Ticketmaster Online is putting music store inside its ticket shop; users can buy more than 150,000 items, including CD's and memorabiliia about their favorite artists, at Ticketmaster Online-CitySearch site; photo (S)

headline: 50's Riddle Returns in Treaty Debate
abstract: US Senate, in debating historic treaty that would ban all underground nuclear testing, is reliving one of most divisive arguments of cold war: do international arms control treaties enhance or imperil America's nuclear deterrent; photo (News analysis) (M)

headline: Executive Is Moving To San Francisco
abstract: Barrie Hedge is named to new post of chairman at McCann-Erickson/A&L, agency formed recently by the merger of Anderson & Lembke and San Francisco office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising (S)

headline: Mullen Selected By Lending Tree
abstract: Lending Tree Inc awards its first advertising account to Mullen Advertising; billings estimated at $50 million (S)

headline: Big Tobacco's Newest Billboards Are on the Pages of Its Magazines
abstract: Three big tobacco companies--Brown & Williamson, Philip Morris and R J Reynolds Tobacco--enter into custom publishing ventures with Time Inc, Hearst Magazines, Hachette Filipacchi Magazines and EMAP Petersen under which the publishers print magazines for the tobacco companies, which then distribute them free to customers or for nominal subscription rates; magazine publishers, which limit tobacco advertising in their consumer magazines, enjoy guaranteed profit-makers that have generated $650 million for the magazine industry so far this year; magazines are rich with cigarette advertising, and their articles portray smoking as a glamourous activity, although guidelines keep articles from appealing to teenagers (M)

headline: OIL PROFITS
abstract: Brazil's Petroleo Brasileiro SA says earnings more than tripled to $186 million (US) in third quarter (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EARTHGRAINS CO.,  St. Louis, said it would close a plant in Johnson City, Tenn., and cut 95 jobs to streamline operations.

headline: With Berger in Catbird Seat, Albright's Star Dims
abstract: Sec Madeleine Albright has been effectively eclipsed in last six months by Samuel R Berger, national security adviser who enjoys proximity to Oval Office and personal relationship with Pres Clinton; Berger has influenced every recent issue, from China's entry into WTO, to Chechnya and Clinton's trip to Europe; Albright is at center of plans for Israeli-Syrian peace talks, but analysts suggest she carries less weight as administration's policy emphasis shifts away from Balkans and Europe, her strengths, to China, Russia, Middle East and Ireland, where special envoy George Mitchell reported to Berger and Clinton; Berger and Albright insist they work in seamless coordination; photos (M)

headline: Rubin May Leave as State Dept. Spokesman
abstract: James P Rubin, chief spokesman at State Department and one of Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright's closest and most powerful advisers, may resign in spring of 2000 (S)

headline: On Hopeful Soil, Arafat and Barak Chase an Old Dream
abstract: Pres Clinton presides over two-day summit of Israeli and Palestinian leaders in Oslo, where they recommit themselves to forging framework peace agreement by February 2000; the two sides begin devising approach to move forward at quickened pace; Arafat welcomes Barak to be partner in making of peace in paying homage to late Prime Min Yitzhak Rabin; says he considers fate of Jerusalem and of Jewish settlements in West Bank to be most crucial issues; Barak reportedly makes clear to Clinton that if there is overall deal, he is willing to give deep compromises; photos (M)

headline: BRAZIL MOVE TO SAVE JOBS
abstract: Brazil's lower house of Congress approves bill prohibiting self-service gasoline stations; bill's supporters hope to save jobs of about 300,000 attendants at 27,000 gas stations (S)

headline: Can 'Neurobics' Do for the Brain What Aerobics Do for Lungs?
abstract: Article on dispute over efficacy of 'neurobics,' brain teasers, puzzles and cognitive exercises that some business people tout as means to enhance employee job performance; some neurobiologists hold that hobbies such as reading or playing piano that do not involve passive participation are enough to enhance brain functioning; photo; chart (M)a

headline: CITATION ACCEPTS AMENDED PURCHASE PACT FROM KELSO
abstract: Citation Corp accepts amended agreement to be acquired by New York investment firm Kelso & Co, reducing purchase price to about $620 million in cash and debt; transaction values Citation shares at $17 each, down from $18.10 in earlier deal (S)

headline: Muni Offering on Web Pays Off
abstract: Pittsburgh officials report receiving twice as many bidders as expected for sale of $55 million in general obligation bonds offered directly to investors online (S)

headline: Tivo Rises 24% In Its Second Day
abstract: Shares of Tivo Inc rises 24 percent in their second day of trading; shares rise $7.0625, to $37, trading of 3.9 million shares (S)9

headline: Thriving on the Keyboard
abstract: Norma Johnson letter responds to Sept 30 article on effect of early computer use on children's learning of basic skills; says computer is nothing more than tool and users provide the brains and imagination

headline: INDIA INSURANCE BILL ADVANCES
abstract: Long-debated legislation that would end state-run monopoly in India's insurance business and open it to foreign companies passes first hurdle in Parliament, winning majority in lower house (S)

headline: TRIPOINT GLOBAL TO ACQUIRE VERTEX COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: TriPoint Global Communications agrees to acquire Vertex Communications Corp for $22 a share, or $118.7 million (S)

headline: Salton Pays $137.5 Million For George Foreman's Name
abstract: Salton Inc, housewares maker, will pay $137.5 million in cash and stock for worldwide rights to use name and image of George Foreman, the former heavyweight boxing champion, to sell its food-preparation products, including indoor and outdoor grills; expects significant rise in income because it will no longer have to pay Foreman 60 percent of profits from sale of Foreman products; an analyst estimates that Foreman's total income from his association with Salton will exceed $150 million; photo (M)

headline: For Online Shoppers, a Virtual Mall as Big as All Cyberspace
abstract: Sampling of popular places to shop online, with examples of what each sells; photo (M)

headline: Handspring Finds More Fits, Fewer Starts in Visor Delivery
abstract: Hundreds of people who were among the first to order new handheld Visor, Palm Pilot-like digital assistant, are still waiting for delivery; Visor's maker, Handspring, Silicon Valley start-up, posts letter of apology on its Web site (www.handspring.com); contends fixes are under way; Visor PDA photo (M)

headline: Chechens Say They Were Shot At in Safe Corridor
abstract: Desperate civilians fleeing blistering Russian bombardment of Grozny say they had to run gantlet of gunfire in 'humanitarian corridor' set up by Russian Army; it is not clear who was doing shooting; refugees interviewed at checkpoint six miles from Grozny say bus full of refugees was riddled with machine-gun fire, leaving four people wounded, and at least one car bursts into flames (M)

headline: Ross Roy Changing Its Name and Focus
abstract: Ross Roy Communications changes name to InterOne Marketing Group; will relocate from Bloomfield Hills, Mich, to nearby Troy and will re-focus business strategy (S)

headline: Cnet Shifts Duties To Leagas Delaney
abstract: Cnet Inc, which offers on-line and television programming about computers and high technology, is unexpectedly shifting duties for creating TV and radio commercials that are central part of its $100 million marketing campaign to San Francisco office of Leagas Delaney from Citron Haligman Bedecarre Euro RSCG (S)

headline: BRAZILIAN SHARE SALE
abstract: Chemical company Grupo Ultra becames first Brazilian company to issue stock in international markets in nearly two years, with $201.7 million offering (S)

headline: Goodbye Cold Calling; Hello Cross-Selling
abstract: New financial services law is expected to create wave of consolidation among banks, insurance companies and securities brokerages; merged companies will face challenge of making acquisitions pay off by selling more products and more types of products to growing list of customers, and 'cross-selling' will occur in a market that is being redefined by the Internet; charts of online banking and brokerage services (M)

headline: Russians Balk at Opening Nuclear Sites to U.S. Eyes
abstract: Russian authorities bar US Amb James F Collins from gala opening of US-financed business center in Krasnoyarsk-26, one of Russia's closed nuclear cities; also bar him from bringing top science adviser or inspecting other American-Russian projects at site; dispute attributed to frustration of Russians over restrictions placed on visits to US Energy Dept's headquarters and laboratories, sheer number of American visitors to Russian weapons complex, residual distruct of American intentions within Ministry of Atomic Energy and influence of Russia's internal security service, which is no friend of expanded cooperation with West; map (M)

headline: FRANCE TELECOM SHARES PLUMMET
abstract: France Telecom shares fall 8 percent after company's expanion plans in Germany's profitable wireless phone market are thwarted when BellSouth and the Dutch phone company Royal KPN exercise a pre-emptive right to acquire the 60.25 percent interest in E-Plus Mobilfunk that France Telecom planned to acquire from Veba AG and RWE AG (S)

headline: ACCRUE TO ACQUIRE NEOVISTA FOR $140 MILLION
abstract: Accrue Software Inc acquires NeoVista Software Inc for about $140.3 million in stock (S)

headline: FOX-PAINE TO BUY WATKINS-JOHNSON FOR $270 MILLION
abstract: Fox-Paine & Co acquires Watkins-Johnson Co for about $270 million (S)

headline: U.N. Council in Rare Accord: Fight Terrorism
abstract: UN Security Council, in rare accord, unanimously adopts resolution to wage common fight against terrorism everywhere (S)

headline: OLD NATIONAL SEEKING TO EXPAND IN INDIANA
abstract: Old National Bancorp will acquire Permanent Bancorp for about $92 million in stock (S)

headline: COMPASS BANCSHARES TO ACQUIRE MEGABANK FINANCIAL
abstract: Compass Bancshares Inc agrees to acquire MegaBank Financial Corp for stock valued at $96 million (S)

headline: Three weddings and a funeral: deals are made and a small specialty agency closes shop.
abstract: Advertising column focuses on acquisition of NFO Worldwide by Interpublic Group of Companies, of Vivid Studios by Modem Media.Poppe Tyson, of Sive/Young & Rubicam by Powers & Associates and closing of Mulryan/Nash--small New York shop specializing in campaigns aimed at gay and lesbian customers (M)

headline: Offer for Air Canada to Exclude American Stake
abstract: Onex Corp, faced with virtually certain defeat of its plan to buy Canada's two major airlines and merge them, raises its offer for Air Canada by more than half and takes steps to insure that new, merged carrier is Canadian-controlled by removing American Airlines as important partner; Onex wanted to consolidate Air Canada with Canadian Airlines; AMR Corp, American Airline's parent, which was to have owned 15 percent of merged airline, will have no interest under revised plan (M)

headline: Two Years Before the Mast (and the Computer)
abstract: Thousands, perhaps millions, of students in global network of classes are following progress of nearly completed two-year sailboat journey around world by way of e-mail and crew's Web site; Heather Halstead, project creator and co-captain, has created online curriculum center that helps teachers use crew's experiences to learn and teach about world cultures and more; she comments, interview; map; photos (M)

headline: Letting Footnotes Generate a Cybertrail
abstract: Twelve scientific and scholarly publishers will announce electronic reference-linking service that will allow researchers to move easily from citation in journal article to content of that article with click of mouse (S)

headline: Pope Will Plunge Into a Bramble Bush (the Mideast) in March
abstract: Vatican says Pope John Paul II will fulfill longstanding desire to visit biblical sites during Holy Year by traveling to Middle East in March 2000; has received invitations from both Israeli and Palestinian officials, but papal planning has been roiled by disagreements between local Catholic clergy and Israeli and Palestinian officials, notably in Nazareth where Israeli officials gave Muslims permission to build mosque next to city's main Catholic shrine (M)

headline: Venezuela Struggles to Calculate Toll From Floods and Mudslides
abstract: Venezuelan authorities struggle to rescue survivors of coastal mudslides and flooding; estimates of dead vary widely, reflecting chaotic conditions (S)

headline: Turbulent Talks, Converging Currencies
abstract: Billowing tear gas and shattering plate glass brought an unaccustomed atmosphere of chaos and menace to the World Trade Organization talks in Seattle last week, but the currency markets seemed headed for an unexpected and somewhat eerie simplicity: one euro to the dollar, one penny to the yen, give or take.     Two unrelated forces -- a flood of money into the long-battered Japanese stock market and a hunt for growth by Europeans who see dimming prospects at home -- combined to push exchange rates close to both milestones last week. The euro slipped briefly below one-for-one parity several times during trading Thursday and Friday before finishing the week at $1.0017, while the yen made its closest approach to 100 to the dollar, a level not seen since 1995, on Tuesday; by week's end a dollar bought 102.53 yen.

headline: Top TV Station in San Francisco Is Sold
abstract: Young Broadcasting Inc agrees to acquire KRON-TV, top-rated San Francisco television station, from Chronicle Publishing Co for $823 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Business Travel; The best and the worst in a magazine's survey of phone response times at frequent-flier programs.
abstract: Inside Flyer magazine survey of response times of airline representatives in frequent-flier program telephone service centers finds that Southwest Airlines and Alaska Airlines did poorest job in responding to their customers, while America West and UAL's United Airlines did the best; ratings of some other airlines noted; Continental Airlines and America West, which have code-sharing agreement, now issue so-called electronic interline tickets for each other; travelers whose itinerary involves both airlines may use electronic ticket for entire trip; Leading Hotels of the World, global marketer of luxury hotels, has established new sales organization, Leading Small Hotels of the World, for luxury boutique hotels with 100 or fewer guest rooms; report from Merrill Lynch on hotel loyalty programs operated by Marriott International, Hilton Hotels and Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide rates Marriott number 1 (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: U.N. Troops' New Focus: Militias in West Timor
abstract: International forces o

headline: ITALY SELLING UTILITY SHARES
abstract: Italy Selling Utility Shares***Italian Government beginning Oct 25 will sell 19.8 percent of former national energy company Enel SpA, or 2.4 billion shares, at price of $3.60 and $4.50 (US) (S)

headline: BACK IN JAPAN'S CARD MARKET
abstract: Citigroup will buy credit card company Diners Club Japan, marking return to Japanese credit card market; agrees to purchase 60 percent stake in Diners Club Japan owned by Fuji Bank and 40 percent owned by travel agency Japan Travel Bureau for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Web Portal for the Arts Promotes Genre-Hopping
abstract: Artand Culture.com, portal site for all things aesthetic, is set to make debut on Web; each entry on artists, performers and cultural movements includes incisive essay and small set of links to related sites; site hopes to spur visitors to explore subjects beyond their usual enthusiasms; table of sites; photo (M)

headline: PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS TO TRIM 1,000 POSITIONS
abstract: Pricewaterhous eCoopers is cutting 1,000 support jobs in US to reduce costs as it plans to invest billions of dollars to expand services it offers; firm will dismiss 700 to 750 employees in US, and 250 jobs will be eliminated through attrition and hiring freeze already in place; cuts will save about $91 million (S)

headline: The Super Bowl is attracting a crowd of new competitors.
abstract: Advertising column on mad scramble by Internet companies to increase recognition of their brand names by advertising heavily on Super Bowl Sunday, typically biggest day of year for Madison Avenue; chart (M)

headline: BRITISH INQUIRY ON PUB DRINKS
abstract: Britain's Trade and Industry Department, which rules on antitrust issues, calls for inquiry into bar prices for soft drinks, saying they are more than triple price in supermarkets; department also orders pub and bar-keepers to make drink costs more visible (S)

headline: West Bank Shooting Starts What Accords Could Not
abstract: September 19 shootout between Palestinian factions at wedding in Nablus focuses attention on problem of weapons proliferation in West Bank and Gaza Strip and propels Palestinian authorities to hunt down thousands of illegal weapons whose seizure has been required by every peace accord since 1995; several Palestinian officials, increasingly concerned about militarization of Palestinian society, are sounding alarm; addressing problem is challenge for Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, who risks backlash in enforcing any crackdown; complicating problem is Arafat's outsized security forces, which have amassed and abused illegal guns; Israeli security officials and some Palestinians say shootout shows Palestinian Authority has limited ability and limited desire to confiscate weapons; only several hundred weapons are held legally in West Bank and Gaza; illegal cache, estimated at between 30,000 to 40,000 weapons, are smuggled into Gaza and West Bank from Jordan and Egypt, stolen from Israeli soldiers or purchased from Israeli criminals; photo; map (M)

headline: London Journal; They're at It Again: Barbs Fly Across the Channel
abstract: Tensions escalete between Britain and France over refusal by France to allow imports of British beef because of health concerns stemming from outbreak of mad cow disease; photos (M)

headline: FINANCIER RELEASED, WITH CONDITIONS
abstract: Giancarlo Parretti, Italian financier who was arrested earlier in month in Orvieto, Italy, and held for extradition to US on fraud charges related to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, is released from jail by court in Orvieto but ordered not to leave Italy and to report three times a week to local police officials, pending court decision on extradition request; photo (S)

headline: Deal for Allegheny Banks
abstract: F&M National Corp acquires State Bank of the Alleghenies for $53.3 million in stock (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Profit at Apple Computer Beats Reduced Estimates  After warning last month of an earnings shortfall, Apple Computer reported results for its fourth quarter that exceeded revised estimates. Apple executives also predicted strong sales for the quarter ended in December.

headline: Dell Has Quarterly Earnings That Meet Revised Estimates
abstract: Dell Computer Corp reports third-quarter earnings that meet analysts' revised estimates; says earnings for quarter ended Oct 29 were $289 million, down 25 percent from $384 million a year earlier; sales rose 41 percent, to $6.78 billion from $4.82 billion; chairman-chief executive Michael Dell comments (M)

headline: Hijackers Demand That India Release Cleric and Kashmiris
abstract: Hijackers of Indian Airlines flight now on ground in Afghanistan demand that India release Maulana Masood Azhar, a Pakistani Muslim cleric supportive of Kashmiri independence from Indian rule, and several Kashmiri fighters being held in Indian jails (M)

headline: The Shipwreck in Seattle
abstract: David E Sanger analysis of Clinton administration's miscalculations in pursuing global trade talks in Seattle; says administration chose a spectacularly bad moment to pick this particular fight (M)

headline: Nike Identifies Plants Abroad Making Goods For Universities
abstract: Nike Inc, in significant concession to anti-sweatshop movement on college campuses, becomes first large apparel company to disclose names and sites of dozens of its overseas factories; student groups praise Nike for its disclosures about factories in Bangladesh, China, Guatemala, Thailand and other countries; last spring, students held demonstrations at Harvard, Yale, Princeton and dozens of other colleges and universities, demanding that universities force companies making apparel with school logos to disclose names and addresses of their factories; manufacturers produce $2.5 billion worth of goods each year bearing names of hundreds of colleges; Nike discloses names of 41 overseas factories it uses to make athletic gear for Duke, Georgetown, University of Michigan, University of North Carolina and University of Arizona; disclosures are expected to place considerable pressure on other apparel makers to follow suit (M)

headline: Saks Fifth Avenue Selects New Chief
abstract: Saks Inc names Christina Johnson president and chief executive of its Saks Fifth Avenue department-stores division, replacing Philip Miller, who will continue as chairman of retail chain; Johnson will become first woman chief executive when appointment takes effect on Feb 1 (S)

headline: Germany Fails in Effort To Keep Builder Afloat
abstract: FRANKFURT—  The German construction company Philipp Holzmann AG filed for insolvency Tuesday after last-minute intervention by Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder failed to convince banks to support a 4.3 billion Deutsche mark bailout.

headline: Catbird Seat on Great European Phone Deal Is in Hong Kong
abstract: Article discusses how Li Ka-Shing, billionaire developer and chairman of conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa, has profited from Vodafone's attempted takeover of Mannesmann because of his company's deal to sell Orange PLC to Mannesmann; photo (M)

headline: Translating S.U.V. Into European; Re-engineering The Old World
abstract: Europe is still far behind US in sales of sport utility vehicles, but European buyers are snapping them up as automakers introduce smaller models; after several years of relative stability, European sales of high-riding sport utilities surged 26 percent last year, four times rate of overall passenger vehicle market, to 464,400; this year, they are expected to grow another 21 percent, to roughly 564,200, again four times pace of overall market; chart shows top-sellers of sport utility vehicles in US and Europe; photos (M)

headline: RCN to Acquire 21st Century Telecom Group
abstract: RCN Corp agrees to acquire 21st Century Telecom Group for $260 million in stock; RCN is biggest concern competing against regional Bell companies in local telephone markets for residential customers; 21st Century is small local communications carrier based in Chicago, market where RCN has not had major presence; RCN is expected to assume 21st Century's debt of $250 million in addition to stock swap (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar edges up against most other currencies in thin trading; in New York, euro settles at $1.0129, down from $1.0136 on Dec 23; dollar trades at 102.35 yen, up from 102.12 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: U.S. Urges Pakistani Army To Restore Democracy Soon
abstract: Clinton Administration urges Pakistani military to restore democratic government as quickly as possible, but at same time officials acknowledge that Prime Min Nawaz Sharif's rule has been increasingly corrupt and autocratic; overthrow of Sharif is latest in series of turbulent events on subcontinent that have left Administration fearful that Islamic militancy will strengthen in Pakistan (M)

headline: White House, Citing Fraud Charge, Seeks to Block Russian Loan
abstract: White House officials call on independent Export-Import Bank of United States to delay or cancel pending $500 million loan package to Russia; officials say that aid, in form of loan guarantees to Russian oil company for purchase of American equipment, should be blocked because of allegations that Russian company, Tyumen Oil Co, had defrauded foreign investors in another deal (M)

headline: Writer Jailed in Malaysia Is Released After Serving Four Weeks
abstract: Murray Hiebert, Canadian reporter for Far Eastern Economic Review, is freed from jail in Malaysia after serving four weeks for contempt of court for 1997 article; says he was treated better than typical prisoner; leaves nation; jailing could have lingering impact in nation where critics say Government uses courts to bully news organizations; article suggested suit against school where Hiebert's wife held post moved unusually quickly through courts because it was brought by judge's wife (M)

headline: The Literary Myth Updated With High-Tech Presentation
abstract: J C Herz reviews Shadow Man computer game from Acclaim, which features mythical hero Mike LeRoi; CD-ROM is available for Windows 95 and 98 and costs $44.95 (M)

headline: Linking Wall Street To the Ski Slopes
abstract: Vail Resorts signs three-year deal with DLJ Direct, online unit of Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, for services that include slopeside Internet stock trading at four Vail resorts: Keystone, Breckenridge, Beaver Creek and Vail (S)

headline: OFFER FOR EXPLOSIVES MAKER
abstract: Scandinavian buyout firm Industri Kapital plans to offer 5.3 billion kroner, or $670 million, for Dyno ASA, world's largest second-largest maker of explosives (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: STILL OPTIMISTIC -- Former Senator George J. Mitchell met with political leaders in Belfast in what appeared to be the final sessions of his seven-week-old review intended to end a stalemate over guerrilla disarmament. David Trimble, head of the Ulster Unionists, said: ''Unlike some others, we have not written the review off. We are still here to see if progress can be made.'' Gerry Adams, head of Sinn Fein, the political ally of the Irish Republican Army, said there was still ''a tiny possibility of a breakthrough.''   Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: JIANG ENDS VISIT -- President Jiang Zemin ended a five-day visit to Britain with a speech at Cambridge University rejecting the demands of protesters, who dogged his appearances, that China change its policies on Tibet and human rights. He argued that countries with different social systems should treat one another as equals. Mr. Jiang is on a 17-day tour to Britain, France, Portugal, Algeria, Morocco and Saudi Arabia.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: PINOCHET APPEALS -- Lawyers for Gen. Augusto Pinochet filed an appeal with the High Court challenging a magistrate's decision approving a Spanish application for the extradition of the 83-year-old former Chilean dictator to Madrid to stand trial on torture charges. The step is likely to carry the case, which is now more than a year old, well into the new year.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    BOSNIA: TOP EDITOR WOUNDED -- The editor-in-chief of a leading independent newspaper in the Serb-run part of Bosnia was seriously wounded when a bomb exploded as he opened his car door. Zeljko Kopanja, of Nezavisne Novine, was taken to a hospital not far from the Bosnian Serb government complex. Doctors amputated his legs and his life was reported to be in danger.   (AP)    TURKEY: LEGISLATOR FREE TO LEAVE -- In a reversal, a court ruled that Merve Kavakci, who was elected to Parliament this year but denied her seat because she sought to take her oath of office while wearing a Muslim head scarf, is free to leave the country if she pleases. An earlier decision forbade her to do so. Ms. Kavakci, 31, was stripped of her Turkish citizenship after it was learned that she had obtained an American passport.   Stephen Kinzer (NYT)    GREECE: DOCTORS' GROUP PROTESTED -- Officials protested a decision by Doctors Without Borders to sever ties with its Greek branch for taking part in an aid mission to Kosovo. The group, this year's Nobel Peace Prize winner, denied that the Greeks were expelled because they mostly aided Serbs in Kosovo. The Greeks violated the group's guidelines for unrestricted movement, said a group official. They also broke the group's code of neutrality by entering Kosovo under a mission negotiated by Greek officials, he said.   (AP)    AFRICA    ANGOLA: REBELS CONFIRM LOSSES -- Unita rebels acknowledged the loss of two of their strongholds, Bailundo and Andulo. A Unita spokesman, Alcides Sakala, said Angolan forces had also seized the town of Lumbala Nguimbo, 120 miles from Zambia, in Moxico Province.   (Reuters)    THE AMERICAS    PERU: JAIL VISITS CUT -- The Government has suspended humanitarian visits to three jailed Marxist guerrillas in the second month of a hunger strike in demand for better prison conditions for political prisoners. The three leaders of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, who are being held in a prison in the port of Callao, were last visited by Red Cross doctors more than a week ago.   Clifford Krauss (NYT)    ARGENTINA: POLLS FAVOR OPPOSITION -- Two days before the presidential vote, final polls indicate that Mayor Fernando de la Rua of Buenos Aires will win an easy first-round victory to end 10 years of Justicialist party rule. A Gallup poll showed the opposition Alianza coalition candidate with 51 percent of the vote and the Buenos Aires Governor Eduardo Duhalde, a Justicialist, with 34 percent. The poll, which questioned 1,787 people, had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.   Clifford Krauss (NYT)    MEXICO: 2 MORE RUN FOR MAYOR -- Prominent politicians from two opposition parties have added their names to a lengthening list of candidates for Mayor of Mexico City. Andres Lopez Obrador, a former president of the Party of the Democratic Revolution, the main leftist party, and Santiago Creel, a congressional deputy from the center-right National Action Party, have begun campaigning for the vote on July 2, when Mexicans will also elect a President.   Sam Dillon (NYT)    ASIA    INDIA: SLAIN PREMIER CHARGED -- After more than a decade, federal prosecutors have finally charged the slain Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, left, in a kickback scheme in an arms deal with the Swedish company Bofors. Also charged were Martin Ardbo, a former chief of the company, and an Italian businessman, Ottavio Quattrocchi, a friend of Mr. Gandhi's. The case has been a part of India's political landscape since 1989, when it played a role in Mr. Gandhi's election defeat.   Barry Bearak (NYT)    MIDDLE EAST    ISRAEL: SETTLEMENT CLEARED -- The Settlers Council has dismantled an uninhabited illegal outpost in the West Bank that protesting yeshiva students prevented from being torn down. In an agreement with Prime Minister Ehud Barak, the council agreed to help evacuate 12 settlements, and by week's end 5 had been cleared, settlers announced.   Deborah Sontag (NYT)    EGYPT: MOVE ON ABU NIDAL REPORTED -- Egypt has closed the Cairo office of the Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal and seized his group's bank accounts, a major Arabic newspaper reported. Abu Nidal sent a letter of complaint to the Government, the London-based daily Asharq Al-Awsat said, addding that the letter's authenticity was verified by a senior member of Abu Nidal's Fatah Revolutionary Council.   (AP)      Compiled by Terence Neilan

headline: JUNO SHARES FALL ON NEWS OF AN ADDITIONAL STOCK SALE
abstract: Juno Online Services Inc, whose shares surged more than fourfold this week after company offered free Internet access, says it will sell additional shares; announcement results in stock falling $15.0625, to $46.1875 (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: ZHIRINOVSKY TO TRY AGAIN  The Russian nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky said he might form a new party to get back on the ballot for the December parliamentary election. The Central Election Commission disqualified Mr. Zhirinovsky's Liberal Democratic Party from the vote, saying senior officials had failed to declare all of their property. Mr. Zhirinvosky said he might submit a new list of candidates, forge a new bloc or perhaps even create a new party.  Michael R. Gordon (NYT)    NORTHERN IRELAND: MANDELSON ON THE JOB  Peter Mandelson spent his first full day as Northern Ireland Secretary, meeting in Belfast with the leaders of the Ulster Unionists, the largest Protestant party, and Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A. Mr. Mandelson, left, Prime Minister Tony Blair's closest confidant who is returning to Government 10 months after being forced out in a financial scandal, was accompanied by Mo Mowlam, his predecessor.  Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: FARMERS STRIKE BACK  Farmers in Plymouth blocked French trucks from bringing produce into England to protest France's refusal to comply with the European Union's Aug. 1 decision to lift the ban on imports of British beef. France says its own food safety experts doubt the European Commission's finding that British beef is fully free of the mad cow disease that prompted the 1996 ban.  Warren Hoge (NYT)    IRELAND: 6 TIED TO I.R.A. ARMS  The police arrested six people in three counties in connection with what they said was an operation to smuggle arms from the United States to the Irish Republican Army. The I.R.A. is in the third year of a cease-fire and says it has not sanctioned the import of any weapons.  Warren Hoge (NYT)    ITALY: ANDREOTTI DENIES MAFIA MEETING  Acquitted last month of charges that he conspired with the Mafia in a 1979 murder, former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, 80, dismissed a Palermo prosecutor's claim that in 1987 he met and kissed Salvatore (The Beast) Riina, a convicted Mafia boss. ''If I as Prime Minister really went to a home of a person under house arrest to meet with a man known to be a Mafia chief on the run,'' Mr. Andreotti told the jurors, ''then this court should not only condemn me but lock me up in a psychiatric prison.''  Alesssandra Stanley (NYT)    THE AMERICAS    PERU: REBELS END JAIL PROTEST  Fifty imprisoned Marxist guerrillas ended a three-week hunger strike in a high-security prison in the Andean city of Arequipa without winning concessions from authorities to improve prison conditions. It was the most aggressive public action by the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement since its guerrillas took hundreds of hostages in a raid on the Japanese Ambassador's residence three years ago.  Clifford Krauss (NYT)    BRAZIL: TROOPS GUARD ENERGY SITE  Maneuvers by some 2,500 state military policemen have begun in the area of a hydroelectric power complex that is the focal point of a dispute between the central Government and the state of Minas Gerais. The governor opposes the sale of Government-owned energy companies to private interests.  Larry Rohter (NYT)    ASIA    INDIA: GANDHI STILL PARTY LEADER  The Congress Party president, Sonia Gandhi, was unanimously chosen to lead the party in Parliament, despite the party's searing defeat in national elections. She did not say, however, whether she will appoint herself or someone else to serve as day-to-day leader of the opposition on the floor of the lower house. Ms. Gandhi, who will be making her debut in Parliament, accepted responsibility for the party's defeat.  Celia W. Dugger (NYT)    KAZAKHSTAN: NEW PREMIER PICKED  A former Foreign Minister known in the West as an economic reformer, Kasymhomart Tokayev, left, has been chosen as the new Prime Minister. He takes over at a time when citizens remain poor despite the country's vast oil and gas resources. Ultimate power in the Central Asian nation lies with the autocratic President, Nursultan Nazarbayev.  Stephen Kinzer (NYT)    MIDDLE EAST    YEMEN: KHAT BANNED FROM SKIES  The national airline has banned the chewing of khat on its flights, an official newspaper reported. The step is the latest in a national campaign against the mild stimulant, a bitter leaf that is widely chewed by rich and poor alike in Yemen.  Douglas Jehl (NYT)    ISRAEL: SETTLEMENTS FACE AX  Prime Minister Ehud Barak announced that 15 of 42 unauthorized Jewish settlements built in the West Bank in the last year are to be dismantled, public television reported. He made the announcement at a meeting with the Settlers' Council, which tried to persuade him to legalize the outposts, the television said.  (Agence France-Presse)    PALESTINIANS: NEW WEB ADDRESS  Palestinians striving for a state will be asserting independence on the Internet, ending their addresses with ''.ps'' to signify a Palestinian state, an official said. Palestinians have been using ''.wg'' at the end of their Internet addresses to signify the West Bank and Gaza. Israeli addresses end in ''.il.''  (Reuters)    AFRICA    NIGERIA: ABACHA SON TIED TO MURDER  A Nigerian official says a son of the former military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, is to be charged with murder, BBC News reported. Mohammed Abacha is to appear in court this week. President Olusegun Obasanjo confirmed last week that Mohammed Abacha had been detained for what he called heinous crimes. He gave no details but reports say they include the killing of Kudirat Abiola, a wife of the late opposition leader, Moshood Abiola. She died when her car was ambushed in Lagos in 1996.

headline: Rite Aid Announces Inquiry By the S.E.C. Into Accounting
abstract: Rite Aid Corp, troubled drugstore chain, says Securities and Exchange Commission has started formal investigation into its accounting practices and that its former auditors, KPMG International, resigned last week becaue they could no longer believe management; says it intends to cooperate fully with probe (M)

headline: NEUBERGER BERMAN'S OFFERING IS PRICED AT $32 A SHARE
abstract: Neuberger Berman Inc's initial public offering is priced at $32 a share, valuing firm at $1.6 billion (S)

headline: Small Designers Cater to Need for Personal Touch : The Quest for Individuality
abstract: PARIS—  Could it be that Gucci is not the only role model for fashion success? Could it be that mega-brands, luxury conglomerates and being bought out by Prada are not the only daydreams of today's fashion designers?

headline: BRAZILIAN LENDING INITIATIVES
abstract: Brazil's central bank announces several measures to encourage country's banks to increase lending; tax on consumer loans is lowered to 1.5 percent from 6 percent, reserve requirements on time deposits are reduced to zero from 10 percent, and legislation will be changed to allow banks to seize defaulted debtors' assets more easily (S)

headline: Millennium Set To Buy Leukosite
abstract: Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc acquires Leukosite Inc in stock swap valued at $635 million (S)

headline: Gunmen Kill Son of Kaunda, Former President of Zambia
abstract: Wezi Kaunda, rising political figure in Zambia and son of former Pres Kenneth D Kaunda, is fatally shot in Lusaka; police arrest suspect (M)

headline: New TV Software Allows Instant Language Translations
abstract: GlobalTV, created by Multilingual Media, is based on proprietary translation software that takes words typed for closed captions and almost instantaneously translates them into different languages (S)

headline: FRUIT OF THE LOOM SEEKS CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
abstract: Fruit of the Loom Ltd, maker of underwear and T-shirts, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after reporting five consecutive quarters of losses; lists $258.3 million in assets and $72.3 million in debt (S)

headline: Anyone Can Whistle?
abstract: Charles Schwab & Co head Charles Schwab says his effort to whistle in one of company's television commercials had to be electronically enhanced because it was not loud enough; photo (S)

headline: Canada Files Complaint Against YBM Offering
abstract: Ontario Securities Commission, Canada's top securities regulator, files complaint against YBM Magnex International and its senior managers and directors, including Ontario's former Premier David Peterson, accusing them of failing to disclose negative information about company's business in share offering prospectus in 1997; commission says its underwriters did not tell investors that auditor Deloitte & Touche had refused to sign YBM's 1997 accounts or undertake further work until in-depth investigation had been completed (M)

headline: YOUTHSTREAM TO ACQUIRE SIXDEGREES FOR $125 MILLION
abstract: YouthStream Media Networks acquires community Web site operator sixdegrees inc for $125 million in stock (S)

headline: Amazon's Risky Christmas
abstract: Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon.com, comments on major expansion of popular Internet site's distribution capacity, what he calls fastest in peacetime history, for upcoming holiday season; millions of people are expected to make their first online shopping purchases this holiday season, but Amazon now has stiff competition; photos; graphs (L)

headline: The Redesign of an Auto Analyst
abstract: Maryann N Keller, formerly much-feared auto-company analyst, is now president of unit of Priceline.com that brokers sale of automobiles; Priceline makes money as broker; customers bid for vehicles online and agree to pay Web site $50 if they buy; Priceline forwards bids to nearby dealers, who pay it $200 if lead turns into sale; Priceline is growing rapidly, but it still loses money as Internet start-up; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; Economists wonder if commodity prices will remain strong.
abstract: Market Place column on whether commodity prices will remain strong in year 2000; notes Bridge/Commodity Research index of 17 commodities rose for year, up 6.7 percent through Jan 28; graph; chart (M)

headline: 3 Phone Companies Meet Estimates on Profit
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp, BellSouth Corp and Sprint Communications Co meet third-quarter estimates on profit; Sprint says profit fell 13 percent; net income fell to $359 million from $415 million a year ago; revenue rose 7.4 percent, to $4.34 billion, from $4.04 billion; Bell Atlantic says profit rose to $1.2 billion from $1.09 billion in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 5 percent, to $8.3 billion; BellSouth says profit rose to $972 million from net income of $814 million last year; revenue rose 9.4 percent, to record $6.42 billion (M)

headline: United Drops 'Rising' Campaign
abstract: United Airlines is scrapping its 'Rising' campaign after only two years and is looking for replacement from its roster advertising agencies, Fallon McElligott and Young & Rubicam (S)

headline: Business Travel; The biggest dampener of celebrations this New Year's Eve is turning out to be inflated prices.
abstract: Biggest dampener of celebrations this New Year's Eve has proved to be highly inflated pric tags for parties and entertainment packages; many people who booked reservations for New Year's Eve 1999 as early 1998, before rates for parties and cruises were established, were among first to cancel when it came time to put down deposit (M)

headline: Web Buying: Is It Safe?
abstract: Q. When you buy something online, how do they make sure credit card information is safe from computer hackers?    A. E-commerce Web sites usually use data encryption methods to ensure the safety of your financial information. When you type in your credit card number and hit the button to submit it to the company, the information is encrypted for travel across the Internet. Even if the number is intercepted, it will be scrambled and useless to most people. The site you were doing business with can decrypt the information with a special password once it arrives.

headline: TARMAC ACCEPTS NEW BID
abstract: Tarmac PLC agrees to sweetened takeover offer of 1.2 billion pounds by Anglo American (S)

headline: Weber McGinn Buys Barbour Griffith
abstract: Weber McGinn, Arlington, Va, unit of Weber Public Relations Worldwide, acquires Barbour Griffith & Rogers in Washington, a leading government lobbyist (S)

headline: Janus Fund Manager Plans to Step Down
abstract: Janus Capital Corp says James Craig is stepping down as manager of its flagship $33 billion Janus Fund to become firm's research director; Craig will continue to serve as chief investment officer of Janus Capital; Blaine Rollins, Craig's assistant on Janus Fund, will take over as portfolio manager in January (S)

headline: BRIGHTENED MALAYSIA OUTLOOK
abstract: Moody's Investors Service raises its outlook on Malaysia's credit ratings from stable to positive, citing relative strength of country's financial system and its resilience in aftermath of financial crisis that started two years ago (S)

headline: Taking Shelter
abstract: Data trends show that growing use of corporate tax shelters is opening huge gap between profits that companies report to investors and those reported on corporate income tax returns; graph (M)

headline: Latin Markets Surge, With Mexico's Up 5.73%
abstract: Latin

headline: REXAM SELLS BOWATER WINDOWS UNIT FOR $203 MILLION
abstract: Rexam PLC sells its Bowater Windows Ltd unit to management-led buyout group for $203 million; other major participant in buyout is L&G Ventures, private equity arm of Legal and General Group PLC (S)

headline: Rush-Hour Rail Crash in West London Kills at Least 26
abstract: Two commuter trains collide and burst into flames during morning rush hour in London, killing at least 26 people and severely injuring scores more; similar crash occurred in same area two years ago; search for victims is suspended at night, awaiting arrival of heavy equipment; photo (M)

headline: Job Cutbacks Made At FCB New York
abstract: FCB New York has reduced its staff of about 820 employees by less than 5 percent as part of reorganization intended to improve efficiency (S)

headline: SAGENT TECHNOLOGY TO BUY QUALITATIVE MARKETING
abstract: Sagent Technology Inc acquires Qualitative Marketing Software Inc for $70 million in stock (S)

headline: 3 TV News Operations Unite To Provide Video to Affiliates
abstract: News operations of ABC, CBS and Fox agree to form cooperative service to supply video pictures of news events to affiliated stations of each network, but NBC News is expressly excluded; shared services, to be called Network News Service, will mainly involve video from news scenes; only rarely will coverage include voices of any reporters (M)

headline: MOBILE SATELLITE MERGER
abstract: Australia's largest telecommunications concern, Telstra Corp, and Dutch telecommunications company, Royal KPN NV, will merge their mobile satellite businesses early next year; KPN will have 65 percent stake in new company, while Telstra will own rest; graph (S)

headline: Workers Ready to Cash In as U.P.S. Goes Public
abstract: 125,000 shareholders of United Parcel Service, most current or retired employees, are poised to cash in on company's decision to go public and many could realize profits of tens of thousands of dollars; approximately 66,000 shareholders work on hourly basis, and additional 40,000 are managers, who at one point in careers wore company's signature brown uniforms; spokesman for Teamsters union, which has many of company's 205,000 unionized employees as members, says much of profit derived from stock sale will be realized by managers, who have been eligible to buy stock; biggest initial public stock offering ever on November 9, priced 109.4 million Class B shares at $50 per share; price jumped to $68.125 in less than 24 hours, increasing company's market capitalization by approximately $20 billion, to more than $81 billion; photos (M)

headline: ELCOM SHARES INCREASE 88% AFTER DEAL WITH VISA
abstract: Shares of Elcom International Inc jump 88 percent after it teams with Visa International Inc to offer online-commerce software (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: When Being Wrong Won't Hurt; Economists' Ideas Are Valued More Than Their Forecasts
abstract: Article on how Wall Street economists' forecasts can be wrong but their ideas are still valued; says forecasters' money-making product is stream of good ideas on economy that money managers use to attract clients who then trade through firm or compensate it in other ways, adding to profits; holds even predictions that go astray might still contain some economic insights; John Lipsky, chief economist at Chase Manhattan, and Robert J Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Co, comment; graphs (M)

headline: MOVEMENT IN CANADIAN AIRLINE DEAL
abstract: Directors of Canadian Airlines Corp says $63 million offer by Air Canada is fair; but board does not recommend acceptance or rejection of bid to shareholders because it says some of Air Canada's takeover terms will not be met and because Canadian Airlines is still seeking alternative investors (S)

headline: Criminal Inquiry to Look Into Funds Donated Secretly to Kohl
abstract: German prosecutors say they will begin criminal investigation into secret political funds maintained by former Chancellor Helmut Kohl; Kohl has admitted that he accepted $1 million in secret political contributions and managed them in secret bank accounts, in apparent violation of German laws requiring full disclosure of political contributions; says he never enriched himself personally, and refuses to name people who contributed money; scandal has exposed politicians in all major parties to intense new scrutiny (M)

headline: Dmitri Likhachev Dies at 92; Protector of Russia's Heritage
abstract: Dmitri Likhac

headline: Treasury Prices Rise a 3rd Day as Inflation Fears Ease
abstract: Bond yields fell for the third consecutive day yesterday after government reports showed a rise in productivity and a drop in labor costs, easing concern about inflation.    The price of the 30-year bond rose 17/32 , to 991/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.20 percent from 6.24 percent on Monday.

headline: For Many Pakistanis, Coup Opens to Applause
abstract: If there is such a thing as a good coup, this one is winning raves in the bazaars of Rawalpindi.    A decade of crooked and incompetent civilian rule before the takeover this week, a decade of competently brutal dictatorship before that, and life keeps getting harder for Pakistan's 138 million souls. A Pakistani poet, Faiz Ahmed Faiz, once was asked what would become of his nation. ''My great fear,'' he said, ''is that nothing will happen. Things will go on the way they are.''

headline: A Growing Market for Mansions of the Sea
abstract: Julie Flaherty Vicarious Consumption column on luxury yachts on view at Fort Lauderdale International Boat Show and what buyers are looking for; photos (M)

headline: Daimler and Aerospatiale to Merge Their Aerospace Businesses
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG of Germany and Aerospatiale Matra SA of France agree to merge their aerospace businesses into European giant with about $22 billion in annual sales; new company, to be called European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Co, will be world's third-largest; it would essentially control Airbus Industrie, Boeing Co's rival in commercial aircraft production, as well as Arianespace SA, world's biggest rocket-launching company; Germany's Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and France's Prime Min Lionel Jospin take part in signing ceremony in Strasbourg, France; French Government, which owns 48 percent of Aerospatiale, will sell shares to lower its stake in new company to just 15 percent; Government will still have veto over decisions on mergers, strategic alliances or additional stock offerings; DaimlerChrysler has right to sell its 50 percent stake back to French after three years if it is unhappy with results; financial terms of complicated deal noted; merger is expected to put new pressure on US arms contractors; chart; photos (M)

headline: COOKSON TO BUY ASARCO UNIT
abstract: Cookson Group acquires chemical business from Asarco Inc for $50 million (S)

headline: Wall Street's Embrace of Diversity Lauded Despite Its Poor Record
abstract: Study from United States Commission on Civil Rights states firms on Wall Street deserve credit for having started to embrace diversity despite their poor track record on hiring and promoting women and minorities; commission applauds efforts of some firms--Citigroup, Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co--to recruit more women and minorities and to consider them for promotion to high-paying jobs (M)

headline: F.T.C. Decides Not to Ban Nuclear Ads
abstract: FTC finds that nuclear industry ads have made unsubstantiated claims about benefits of nuclear power, but will not ban ads because they were aimed in part at 'opinion leaders' and thus were political speech protected by Constitution, rather than commercial ads; ban was sought by Natural Resources Defense Council and Better Business Bureau (M)

headline: FINOVA TO BUY FREMONT'S COMMERCIAL LENDING UNIT
abstract: Finova Group to buy Fremont Financial Corp, unit of Fremont General Corp, for $765 million in cash (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SOVEREIGN SPECIALTY CHEMICALS L.P.,  a closely held maker of adhesives, sealants and coatings, agreed to sell 75 percent of its stake in Sovereign Specialty Chemicals Inc. for an undisclosed price. The buyer is a group led by AEA Investors Inc., New York, which was founded by families that included the Rockefellers, Mellons and Harrimans.

headline: Coty Consolidates At Optimum Media
abstract: As expected, Coty Inc. in New York, part of Joh. A. Benckiser, a fragrance and personal-care products company, has consolidated its United States media planning and buying account at Optimum Media in New York, which already handles media in China, Russia and Britain. Competitive Media Reporting, a unit of VNU N.V., put United States spending last year at $40 million.    Robert Geller & Associates in New York had previously handled domestic responsibilities. Arthur Gallego, an external spokesman for Coty, said the company also had plans to consolidate various international media duties with Optimum Media in the future, like its German media buying account, which had been handled by More Media in Dusseldorf, Germany, part of Publicis S.A. Creative duties will continue to be divided among several New York agencies. Optimum Media is part of the DDB Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group.

headline: TENET TO END MANAGEMENT OF DOCTORS' PRACTICES
abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp, second-largest United States hospital manager, says that it is shedding money-losing business of managing doctors' practices and might take a charge against third-quarter earnings for move (S)

headline: An Unlikely Home For Economic Boom
abstract: Ten years after the Berlin Wall came down, economic buoyancy seems wildly at odds with eastern Germany's enduring image of shuttered factories and stagnant growth. Eastern joblessness is still 18 percent, twice as high as in the west.    But in the midst of this despair something else has happened. Parts of the east have become magnets for entrepreneurs and high-technology start-up companies. In Saxony, eastern Germany's most populous state, industrial production is climbing at double-digit rates, faster than all of western Germany.

headline: Appeals Court Hands Intel A Key Antitrust Victory
abstract: US Appeals Court hands Intel Corp key victory in its antitrust battles, lifting order that required chip maker to share patented microprocessor technology with Integraph Corp; 2-0 decision holds that Intel probably did not violate antitrust laws when, because of patent dispute, it withheld product information and samples from Intergraph (M)

headline: Republicans Plan to Offer A Party Line To the Internet
abstract: Republican National Committee hopes to raise money, embrace supporters and bypass news media by offering subscriptions to 'family friendly' Internet service that will deliver party's messages directly to supporters; party officials say they will market Internet access to registered Republicans, political donors and subscribers of political publications--target audience of 8 million people; party will receive small portion of monthly subscription fees as donations; Joe Andrew, national chairman of Democratic National Committee, claims Republicans' new Internet service is purely fund-raising mechanism; says Democrats are more interested in building 'communities of interest' online using tools like Web sites and e-mail (M)

headline: Monsanto Says Its Profit Fell 54% in Quarter
abstract: Monsanto Co reports its third-quarter profit fell 54 percent to $35 million, from $76 million a year ago; sales rose 14 percent to $1.95 billion from $1.71 billion (M)

headline: A Delay in the Security Council Blocks Relief Aid for Afghanistan
abstract: Relief agency, Doctors Without Borders, says it is unable to fly medicine and other relief goods into Afghanistan because of delay by UN Security Council in granting permission; appeals to council to act (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Neuvis Inc., Shelton, Conn., an e-business development company, to Merkley Newman Harty, New York, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $18 million.    * Simplewine.com, Fairfield, Conn., an online wine retailer, to Frierson Mee & Kraft, New York, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.

headline: Technology Issues Lead Nasdaq to 5th Consecutive Rise
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 46.88 points, or 1.57 percent, to close at record 3,028.51; Dow Jones industrial average edges up 27.22 points, to 10,609.06; Standard & Poor's 500-stock indedx gains 7.19 points, to 1,354.93; graph; chart (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Online Holiday Shopping Cuts Into Traditional Sales  Online holiday shopping is increasingly cutting into the business of traditional retailers this year, with preliminary indications that seasonal Internet sales may nearly triple from last year. Visa estimates that Internet shoppers using its cards will have spent $1.47 billion this November and December, 179 percent more than in those months last year.    In the overall retail market, that figure is still small -- 1.74 percent of Visa's retail sales -- but it signals a troublesome phenomenon for traditional retailers, experts say. Stores are finding that their best customers are the quickest to move online. [Page A1.]

headline: For Luxury Brands, Bottom-Line Problem Is Growth : High-Stakes Acquisitions Race
abstract: MILAN—  The big news sweeping the fashion and luxury goods market today is not who's wearing what but who's buying what, in the high-stakes race for global leadership.

headline: U.S. Is Investigating Charter Hospitals
abstract: Magellan Health Services Inc says Justice Department is conducting nationwide Medicare fraud investigation of Charter psychiatric hospitals, in which Magellan holds 10 percent stake; Magellan manages psychiatric health plans, and Charter Behavioral Health Systems LLC also face Justice Department investigation into whether psychiatric hospitals failed to provide medically necessary treatment; government has not filed any charges against Magellan (S)

headline: About the Tables
abstract: Because of computer problems at Morningstar Inc., which provides mutual fund data, the mutual fund tables were unavailable today.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after Saudi Arabia said OPEC would not increase supply before it meets in March to reconsider its limits on exports. In New York, crude oil for January delivery rose 85 cents, to $26.66 a barrel.

headline: A Consummate Insider Leaps Far From Moscow
abstract: Boris A Berezovsky, Russia's most versatile tycoon, is campaigning for seat in Russian Parliament from Karachevo-Cherkessia, to puzzlement of 300,000 people who make up multiethnic electorate of tiny, neglected region in unruly north Caucasus; Berezovsky has played behind-the-scenes role in Kremlin's endless intrigues; having been pushed out of series of government jobs over last few years, he says he now wants to hold official position, independent of Russian government, that will provide platform for his main political goal: keeping Russia's liberal economic reforms on track; Berezovsky is running in district that has previously voted for Communists, his archrivals; his victory will be assured if one or both of region's leaders back his candidacy; photo; map (M)

headline: Shares of G.M. and Hughes Jump on Hopes of a Stake Sale
abstract: Speculation that the General Motors Corporation might spin off part of its stake in Hughes Electronics, or even become the target of a takeover bid, led to heavy trading yesterday in G.M. shares and G.M.'s tracking stock in Hughes. But a meeting of G.M.'s board adjourned yesterday afternoon with only an announcement of a factory investment.    After rising sharply on Friday, G.M. shares closed at $76.50, up 75 cents yesterday, on volume nearly double the daily average. The G.M. class H shares, which track its stake in Hughes, soared $5, to $94.6875.

headline: U.S. Indicts Money Manager on Fraud and Kickback Charges
abstract: Alan B Bond, Wall Street money manager, is indicted on federal charges that he took $6.9 million in kickbacks from commissions paid to brokers to whom he had steered his clients' investments; Bond runs his own investment company; government contends that Bond used three brokerage firms from 1993 to 1998 to execute Nasdaq stock trades on behalf of his clients, then took kickbacks of 57 perent to 80 percent from commissions at those firms; Robert I Spruill, broker who worked at all three brokerage firms, is charged with conspiracy and fraud charges for his role in suspected scheme; government contends he set up dummy corporation, Satchmo Inc, which was used to funnel commission kickbacks to Bond (M)

headline: Putting It All Together: Help for Toy Assembly
abstract: Netoy.com, Web-based toy retailer, will introduce this month series of animated drawings and assembly directions on its site (www.netoy,com) for harried parents for whom phrase 'some assembly required' strikes terror into their hearts (S)

headline: Fractured Serbian Opposition Unites in Demanding Early Vote
abstract: Weakened democratic opposition in Serbia, under pressure from Washington and fizzling of protests against Pres Slobodan Milosevic, unites in demanding early elections under watchful eye of foreign monitors; in a setback for Clinton Administration, such elections would not remove Milosevic; elected in 1997 to four-year term by Yugoslav Parliament, he controls a Government considered unlikely to call parliamentary elections due in 2000 before next spring; hpoto (M)

headline: Bigger Media Voices
abstract: Alliance for Community Media executive director Bunnie Riedel on September 12 article on media megamergers holds loss of diversity results in diminishment of information sources (S)1

headline: Wired Revolution Helps Guerrillas : Latest Technology Links Jungle Rebels
abstract: BANGKOK—  After fleeing into the Burmese jungle on foot as military police closed in on his home, Sonny Mahinder soon found himself immersed in a world for which physics classes had not prepared him.

headline: G.M. Director Who Led '92 Management Shake-Up Sets Retirement
abstract: John G Smale, who led 1992 management shake-up at General Motors Corp, plans to retire in May 2000; chairman John F Smith Jr is likely to retire at same time; photo (M)

headline: TALKS ON WINE LABEL DISPUTE
abstract: European Union and South Africa plan meeting to resolve dispute involving use of terms like port and sherry on labels of South African-produced wines and spirits; Spain and Portugal have held up European trade accord with South Africa over issue, arguing that South Africa should not use terms that have been traditionally European; Finland, which holds European Union presidency, hopes to convince two European countries that South Africa will phase out terms over 12 years (S)

headline: FIRST STERLING AND MAIN STREET BANKS AGREE TO MERGE
abstract: First Sterling Banks will acquire Main Street Banks for stock valued at $115.9 million (S)

headline: DISNEY'S GO.COM REPORTS A LOSS OF $1.06 BILLION
abstract: Walt Disney Co's Go.com, which combines Infoseek Corp with Disney's other Internet assets, loses $1.06 billion in its 1999 fiscal year, compared with $991 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Robert A. Swanson, 52, Co-Founder of Genentech
abstract: Robert A. Swanson, who co-founded Genentech Inc. and played a pivotal role in creating the biotechnology industry, died Monday at his home in Hillsborough, Calif., after a yearlong battle with brain cancer. He was 52.     The death was announced by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which Mr. Swanson had attended. A spokeswoman for Genentech said the company had no comment, in deference to the wishes of Mr. Swanson's family.

headline: McDonald's Shifts Payouts To One a Year
abstract: McDonald's Corp says it will pay its final quarterly dividend, 4.875 cents a share, on Dec 15; it will convert to annual dividend beginning in December 2000, with amount to be decided by board then (M)

headline: In Search Of Values In Laggard Small Caps
abstract: Excerpts from conversation with John H Laporte, lead portolio manager of T Rowe Price New Horizons, on prospects for small-cap funds in new year; photo (M)

headline: Macao Journal; Packing Up, Portugal Polishes Image
abstract: Departing Portuguese, who will return vest-pocket colony of Macao to China, are busy polishing image by tidying up after themselves prior to December 19 handover ceremonies; efforts include prosecution of Wan Kuok-Koi, 45-year-old Chinese man suspected of being most powerful organized crime leader in Macao; photo (M)

headline: And the Band Plays On: A Big Stretch for MP3
abstract: HanGo Electronics' new MP3 player, Personal JukeBox, carries 81 hours of high-quality digital music, far more than most other MP3 players on market; photo (S)

headline: U.S. VERSUS MICROSOFT: THE JUDGE -- Man in the News; Finding Fault With Microsoft -- In His Biggest Trial, a Judge Makes His Opinions Clear
abstract: Man in the News article on Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, presiding judge in Microsoft Corp antitrust case; chart; photo (M)

headline: A Hard-Line Palestinian Returns to the West Bank
abstract: Mustafa Zubari, leading Palestinian radical known as Abu Ali Mustafa, returns to West Bank from Damascus, Syria, after 32 years in exile; ends years of estrangement from Yasir Arafat; is deputy chief of Popular Front for Liberation of Palestine, and one few Palestinian leaders who has remained committed to armed struggle against Israel; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50       Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00       Federal funds   5.75   5.63   4.58       3-month T-bills   5.09   5.14   4.58       6-month T-bills   5.32   5.30   4.35       10-yr. T-infl.   4.16   4.14   3.74       10-yr. T-note   6.19   6.18   4.58       30-yr. T-bond   6.29   6.29   5.02       Telephone bd.   8.20   8.20   6.80       Municipal bds.   6.11   6.11   5.10          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: SBC In Wireless Purchase
abstract: SBC Communications acquires Radiofone Inc, adding 200,000 wireless-telephone companies in Louisiana and Michigan (S)

headline: IBERIA SELLS 40 PERCENT
abstract: Spanish state-owned airline Iberia sells 9 percent stake to British Airways, 1 percent to AMR Corp's American Airlines and another 30 percent to five Spanish concerns for total of about $1.1 billion (S)

headline: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES INCREASING STOCK REPURCHASE
abstract: Continental Airlines will increase its stock repurchase by $400 million, to $1.2 billion, because of its gain from sale of stake in Amadeus reservations system (S)

headline: Panel to Focus On U.S. Bank And Deposits By Africans
abstract: Citigroup's handling of bank accounts controlled by Gabon Pres Omar Bongo and by two sons of late Nigerian dictator Gen Sani Abacha is expected to come under scrutiny in Congressional hearings that begin on Nov 9; accounts are part of broader examination by Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations into how Citigroup and other major banks have handled private accounts for foreign officials and their relatives (M)

headline: Satellite TV Compromise Passes House
abstract: US House approves bill that would give satellite television companies right to broadcast local channels, providing cable companies with competition; measure is before Senate, which has deadline of Dec 2 for acting on that proposal; measure paves way for viewers in New York and Los Angeles to begin receiving local programs on their dishes; once measure is approved, satellite dish owners in other cities should be able to tune into local affiliates of NBC, CBS, ABC and Fox within six months; 10 million households own satellite dishes; Sen Patrick J Leahy, who helped push legislation, comments; bill is approved after bowing to objection by Sen Phil Gramm (M)

headline: NEW YORK LIFE TO ACQUIRE MEXICAN INSURER
abstract: The New York Life Insurance Company, the seventh-largest life insurer in the United States, said yesterday that it would pay $570 million to acquire Mexico's third-largest insurer, Seguros Monterrey Aetna S.A., from Grupo Financiero Bancomer S. A. and Aetna Inc. to expand its business in Mexico. Bancomer, Mexico's second-largest banking group, said it would receive $290 million for its 51 percent stake in the insurance venture. New York Life gains a subsidiary that sells life, health, property and casualty policies in a growing insurance market where insurance premiums proportional to economic output are less than in other Latin American countries. Aetna rose $1.8125, to $59.5625. Seguros Monterrey has 23 percent of Mexico's individual life insurance business.

headline: Calling at Random
