abstract: Howard L Funk letter responds to Oct 21 article on how user's modem inadvertently dialed 911; says he experienced similar problem in setting up his computer

headline: Carnival Makes Takeover Bid For Norwegian Cruise's Parent
abstract: Carnival Corp makes $1.7 billion cash takeover offer for NCL Holding, corporate parent of Norwegian Cruise Line (S)

headline: Hachette Partnership With Phase 2 Media
abstract: Hachette Filipacchi Media acquires equity interest in Phase 2 Media; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Stories Sought
abstract: New York Times is seeking stories on whether consumers are doing their Christmas holiday shopping on line (S)8

headline: Blair and Chirac Want Europe to Have Rapid Reaction Capability : EU Force No Threat To NATO, Allies Say
abstract: LONDON—  Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Jacques Chirac of France called Thursday for the creation of a European crisis intervention force, a historic step that they insisted would strengthen Europe's military capability and complement, rather than compete with, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: World Bank Suspects Russian Passed Data to Moscow Bank
abstract: World Bank says it is launching investigation 'as a matter of urgency' into actions of former member of Russia's delegation to international development institution who is suspected of passing insider information to a major Russian bank; investigation, which is being aided by Washington law firm, will focus on whether official, Leonid Grigoriev, was secretly receiving information from Inkombank, Moscow bank that has since had its license revoked, in return for information about World Bank's plans to aid Russian economy (M)

headline: Boeing to Buy Some of Its Jets and Lease Them
abstract: Boeing Co, in latest bid to lift anemic profits, announces ambitious and risky deal to buy 44 of its 757-model passenger jets, convert them to cargo planes and lease them to DHL International Ltd; agreement calls for Boeing to supply airplanes and to perform all but most routine maintenance on fleet for 15-year-length of contract (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; Settlement talks in the Microsoft case hinge on a question: Are the laws of government or software supreme?
abstract: THE first round of settlement talks between Microsoft and the Justice Department has begun. And at this defining moment, all parties would do well to step back and meditate upon a much larger issue that the trial has raised.    That issue is not whether Microsoft should be divided and conquered, nor whether it will be granted the freedom to choose whether to add an Internet browser or other features to its Windows operating system.

headline: Is the Party Ending? 2 Views in Europe
abstract: AS the euro hovers at virtual parity with dollar, European fund managers and equity strategists are engaged in a  great stock-market debate: Is Europe looking at a glass half full, or one brimming with frothy valuations?    Almost a year after the common currency's introduction, there is a large degree of unanimity between Europe's bulls and bears. Both groups see that cultural changes in Continental Europeans' attitudes toward investment have begun pushing money out of low-earning bank deposits and into mutual funds. And they agree that Europe's merger frenzy is unlikely to abate.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Managed-Care Company To Let Doctors Have Say  United Health Group has decided to give decision-making power over patient care back to physicians, breaking with a longstanding element of managed care that has infuriated many doctors and frustrated their patients.    The managed-care company, which insures 14.5 million people, including 8.7 million in health maintenance organizations and other managed-care units, said the new rules were being applied nationally. [Page A1.]

headline: Baldwin to Sell 2 Units
abstract: Baldwin Piano and Organ Co says it will sell its two retail financing units, Keyboard Acceptance Corp and Signature Leasing Corp, to Deutsche Financial Services, unit of Deutsche Bank, for $35 million (S)

headline: How World Stock Markets Fared in the Third Quarter
abstract: Article on how world stock markets fared in third quarter of 1999; graphs; charts (M)

headline: J. P. Morgan to Take Korean Brokerage Stake
abstract: J P Morgan & Co agrees to take 10 percent stake in SK Securities Co, settling $380 million lawsuit and ending more than year of legal wrangling with several Korean financial institutions over losses in derivative securities; J P Morgan will invest $85 million in SK Securities through share sale that is partly aimed at raising money to pay Morgan unspecified settlement fee; agreement is intended to end legal disputes between Morgan and SK Securities, Housing and Commercial Bank, Daehan Investment Trust Co and Korea Investment Trust Co; only outstanding dispute for more than $100 million yet to be settled is with Boram Bank, which was taken over by Hana Bank in January (M)

headline: Tired of being a villain, Philip Morris works on its image.
abstract: Philip Morris Companies, nation's number 3 advertiser, which spends more than $2 billion a year, is undertaking extensive, expensive multimedia campaign meant to help burnish its corporate image; primary goal is to counter critics who object to company's tobacco operations; campaign has estimated budget of $100 million; photo (M)

headline: New Reports Back Claims of Attack on Chechen Refugee Convoy
abstract: New accounts from survivors bolster charges that Russian soldiers killed some 40 civilians on Dec 3 in an attack on convoy of refugees from Grozny, Chechnya; Russian troops complete their encirclement of city (M)

headline: FRESH AMERICA HALTS ITS BID FOR FRESHPOINT
abstract: Fresh America Halts Its Bid For Fr8

headline: COMANY BRIEFS
abstract: EATON CORP.,  Cleveland, the second largest maker of hydraulic equipment, agreed to sell its agricultural cylinder business to closely held Hyco International Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline: Making It Easy to Find Where the Money Goes
abstract: Hank Eskin, database programming consultant, develops Web site called Where's George (www.wheresgeorge.com) that enables people to track movement of any money they spend; users type in their Zip codes and serial numbers of any US demonination up to $100; they then write www.wheresgeorge.com on the bills, spend them and hope that future owners will visit site and update bills' travel history; Eskin photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Vulcan Agrees to Invest, $1.7 Billion in RCN  Vulcan Ventures, making its biggest move yet into the telecommunications industry, has agreed to invest about $1.7 billion in the RCN Corporation. Vulcan, the investment shop controlled by Paul Allen, is expected to announce the deal today.    RCN, based in Princeton, N.J., is the biggest of the companies competing against the regional Bell carriers in local phone markets for the business of residential consumers rather than corporate customers. [Page C2.]

headline: EATON'S BANKRUPTCY PLAN
abstract: Shareholders and creditors of T Eaton Co are to vote on Nov 19 on debt payment plan that would permit some operations to be sold to Sears Canada Inc for about $41 million (US); Eaton is expected to have about $360 million (Canadian) from asset sales to pay off debts totaling $430 million (Canadian) (S)

headline: NEWBRIDGE REVISES TERMS OF STANFORD TELECOM DEAL
abstract: Newbridge Networks Corp revises its agreement to buy Stanford Telecommunications Inc after drop in its share price causes original bid to fall through; Newbridge will now pay $34.22 a share in cash; it offered to pay as much as $490 million in stock when agreement was announced on June 22, but its shares have fallen 33 percent since then (S)

headline: Scotland's Technology Nexus; Silicon Glen Blend: Equal Parts Theory and Practice
abstract: Scotland's manufacturing and engineering industries are growing and it is producing more than its fair share of computer science and technology graduates; but academics are being encouraged to cooperate on commercial ventures to keep more home-grown talent working at home; John Dunlop, professor of electronic systems engineering at Strathclyde University in Glasgow, and David Milne, managing director of Wolfson Microelectronics, semiconductor design company in Edinburgh, comment; graph; photos (M)

headline: Caracas Journal; Hospitals Blighted by a Venezuelan Disease, Graft
abstract: Corruption, inefficiency, featherbedding and political patronage system that have crippled Venezuela in recent years have extended to nation's hospital system; at hospitals across Venezuela so much equipment and supplies have simply disappeared--and so little money is available to replace them--that many patients, to their outrage, are now forced to bring their own sheets, syringes and medicine, and 'moral renovation' of public services has become national crusade; photos (M)

headline: E*TRADE GROUP IS BUYING ITS SECOND EUROPEAN AFFILIATE
abstract: E*Trade Group acquires E*Traÿ

headline: Online Help for Inquiring Young Minds
abstract: Online Help for Inquiring Young Minds

headline: 2 Finalists Named In Domino's Review
abstract: Domino's Pizza said yesterday that it had named two finalists in a review for the national creative-development part of its account, with billings estimated at $120 million.    Tim McIntyre, vice president for communications at Domino's in Ann Arbor, Mich., identified the finalists as Deutsch Inc. in New York and J. Walter Thompson in Chicago, part of the WPP Group P.L.C. J. Walter Thompson in Detroit currently handles media buying and regional marketing for Domino's.

headline: Iomega Sees Quarterly Loss
abstract: Iomega Corp says it will lay off about 140 workers and take $25 million to $30 million charge; will take about $20 million of charge in third quarter, resulting in pretax loss of $5 million in quarter; will stop production at Avranches, France, plant (S)

headline: Homegrocer.com Selects Wieden
abstract: Homegrocer.com awards its first national branding account to Wieden & Kennedy; company plans to spend $120 million in next year on advertising (S)

headline: As Jakarta Hopes for a Peaceful Transition, Even a Street Rally Turns Polite
abstract: Indonesia enters final stage of political transformation that began 16 months ago with fall of Pres Suharto amid guarded optimism that People's Consultative Assembly, nation's highest legislative body, will be able to elect new President and set stage for democracy without further bloodshed; students hold polite rally in capital of Jakarta, recently roiled by violent protests, to demand that assembly push for political reforms; fighting breaks out again between Muslims and Christians on Ambon Island, 1,440 miles to east; photo (M)

headline: Pledges of Extradition Accompany Colombian Drug Arrests
abstract: Justice Department says Colombia has arrested Alejandro Bernal Madrigal, head of nation's largest cocaine trafficking ring, and other drug traffickers and pledged to move quickly to extradite them to United States; say Medellin cartel member Fabio Ochoa was among 30 other suspects arrested in raids in Colombia and Mexico; suspects were recently secretly indicted by Federal grand jury in Miami; Colombia has not extradited drug suspects to US since 1990; Amb Luis Alberto Moreno comments, news conference and interview; photo (M)

headline: S. Thondaman of Sri Lanka, a Tamil Leader
abstract: Savumiamoorthy Thondaman, Sri Lankan trade unionist and political figure who was leader of minority Tamils of Indian origin, dies at age 86 or 87; photo (M)

headline: 10 Years After Revolt, Little Glee in Romania
abstract: Fewer than 100 people attend wreath-laying ceremony in Bucharest, Romania, to commemorate 10th anniversary of demonstrations that lead to end of dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu; Ion Iliescu, Romania's president from 1989 to 1996 and leading in polls for next year's vote, says people are disappointed, and dissatisfied with life that is worse than it was in 1989; says people in power now are not those who were connected with revolution (M)

headline: DUANE READE AND BERGEN BRUNSWIG AGREE TO SUPPLY PACT
abstract: Drugstore chain Duane Reade Inc agrees to buy about $1 billion of products from Bergen Brunswig Drug Co, pharmaceutical distributor, under five-year agreement; Duane Reade says deal will help cut costs (S)

headline: Baby Steps Toward Accord On Social Security
abstract: Richard W Stevenson Economic View column on recent small steps that have been taken to deal with Social Security's long-term financial shortfall (M)

headline: EU Sets Up Framework On Crime and Refugees
abstract: TAMPERE, Finland—  The European Union now has the bare bones of a common judicial and immigration policy that seeks to make life tougher for organized criminals while providing more equitable treatment for refugees.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HIGH RIVER L.P., -- Washington, an investment partnership controlled by the financier Carl C. Icahn, said that it sold its 14 percent stake in the Philip Services Corp. to Jack Gumpert Wasserman for $1.5 million.    HERSHEY FOODS CORP., -- Hershey, Pa., will spend $23 million to acquire and renovate a former chocolate factory outside Philadelphia.

headline: A PLAN IS IN WORKS TO PUT OFF A VOTE ON TEST BAN PACT
abstract: White House signals willingness to accept in principle plan to delay Senate vote on nuclear test ban treaty until after Pres Clinton leaves office amid indications that supporters lack two-thirds majority needed to approve it; Republican Sen John Warner and Democratic counterpart Sen Daniel Patrick Moynihan draft letter to majority leader Sen Trent Lott and minority leader Tom Daschle requesting that Senate action be delayed until 107th Congress convenes in 2001; move follows letter from Pres Clinton to Democratic and Republican leaders; Clinton aides insist giving tacit approval to plan to postpone vote does not foreclose Administration's ability to raise issue; photo (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: CROWN BOOKS, Landover, Md., named Charles R. Cumello president and chief executive, succeeding the interim chief executive, Steve Panagos, who remains director. Mr. Cumello had previously been president and chief executive at Waldenbooks.

headline: Of Mice and Genes: A Merger Is Killed by Soaring Valuation
abstract: Cell Genesys directors rescind recommendation that company be sold to Genzyme General Corp for $350 million in stock; reason is that Cell Genesys stake in Abgenix, worth about $130 million when merger was announced in October, has nearly tripled in value, to about $370 million, because of Abgenix's XenoMouse technology (S)

headline: U.S. Study Finds Lack of Control In U.N. Food Aid to North Korea
abstract: Report to Congress by General Accounting Office finds UN's World Food Program is not able to adequately monitor what happens to food aid donated by US to North Korea (S)

headline: Rocket Attack on U.S. and U.N. Offices in Pakistan Fails
abstract: Unknown attackers fire rockets at American diplomatic and UN buildings in Islamabad, Pakistan, injuring one person; attack comes two days before UN economic sanctions will take effect against neighboring Afghanistan if Taliban government fails to turn over Osama bin Laden, Saudi national accused by US of masterminding bombings of American embassies in Tanzania and Kenya in 1998 in which 224 people died; Taliban denies any involvement in attacks; maps; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    IRAN: PAPER BOUNCES BACK -- Less than three weeks after a press court closed the reformist newspaper Neshat for ''insulting Islam,'' the editors and reporters involved in its publication used another publishing license to begin a new daily, Asr-e Azadegan, that is almost identical in layout, content and editorial line. The new paper is the fourth the reformist group has put out in the past 16 months, after three predecessors, including Neshat, were ordered closed. Neshat's editor, Mashallah Shamsolvaezin, will be editor of the new daily.   John F. Burns (NYT)    IRAN: U.S. REJECTED ON RELIGION -- Iran has rejected a State Department report that designated Iran and four other countries violators of religious freedoms. The official news agency quoted a Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying that ''followers of divine religions practice their religion in complete freedom'' in Iran, and dismissing the accusation that Bahais had been persecuted.   John F. Burns (NYT)

headline: BIG WHOLESALE GROCERY OPERATION TO ELIMINATE JOBS
abstract: Fleming Companies, one of biggest US wholesale grocery operations, plans to cut 700 jobs, or almost 2 percent of its work force, to cut costs (M)

headline: Sharper Growth Seen In Spending on Ads
abstract: Advertising spending will grow more robustly than had been anticipated, according to the head of a leading media services agency, as a result of the spending burst by the dot-coms in traditional media and renewed confidence in the economy.    ''We know every boom must end, but the outlook is still good,'' said John Perriss, chairman and chief executive at Zenith Media Worldwide in London, a joint venture of the Cordiant Communications Group and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. Mr. Perriss is to discuss his forecasts this morning at the opening session of the annual Paine Webber Media Conference in New York.

headline: Digital Video Camera Is Freed Of Its Tether to the PC
abstract: Cams, tech slang for tiny video cameras for personal computers, are available in all sorts of shapes and styles; latest, Video Blaster Webcam Go, from Creative Labs, is the first to free itself from its wired connection to the PC; it can be used in variety of ways, for individual pictures and snippets of motion pictures, easily uploaded to Internet or E-mail; photo (S)

headline: Barak, in a First for Top Israeli, Meets Arafat in the West Bank
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak, first Israeli leader to venture into Palestinian-controlled city for peace meeting, holds productive talks with Yasir Arafat in private home in West Bank; two leaders talk for three hours, essentially resolving two issues that had been deadlocked: Israeli transfer of 5 percent of West Bank, which will now take place within week, and Israeli release of more prisoners as gesture for Ramadan; both sides say atmosphere during talks was open, and that they would now accelerate talks, including more sessions between Barak and Arafat, in preparation for possible meeting in United States in February; map showing 1967 ceasefire lines between Syria and Israel, correcting Dec 17 map (M)

headline: GREAT-WEST LIFECO TO BUY AN ALLMERICA UNIT
abstract: Great-West Lifeco Inc, Canada, agrees to buy Allmerica Financial Corp's group life and health insurance business for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: Prosperity as Redemption For a Boomer Generation
abstract: EVERYBODY knows that journalism thrives on bad news: natural disasters, wars, financial crashes. Where would newspapers be without them?    So when a book comes along titled ''The Long Boom: A Vision For the Coming Age of Prosperity,'' the natural reaction of any self-respecting economics reporter or editor is to examine it with a jaundiced eye.

headline: Kmart Is Joining Yahoo in Deal to Create New Internet Shopping Site
abstract: Kmart Corp is teaming up with Yahoo to create new company called Bluelight.com that will provide free access to Internet and co-branded shopping site; neither Kmart nor Yahoo will make cash investment in new company; Softbank Venture Capital put up $62.5 million to get company started; Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc also put up undisclosed sum; Kmart will own 60 percent of new venture (M)

headline: Just Before Indonesia's Finale, the Cast Is Changing
abstract: Rapid political maneuvering makes outcome of electoral assembly vote to chose Indonesia's next President uncertain; Megawati Sukarnoputri remains by far most popular choice outside assembly; Pres B J Habibie's party may dump increasingly unpopular leader before vote; Gen Wiranto, apparently rejecting Habibie's invitation to be running mate, says he will not be candidate for President or Vice Present, television speech; breakaway faction of Habibie's party is in talks to form coalition with Megawati; photo (M)

headline: Martin/Williams Wins Top Honors
abstract: Martin/Williams Advertising takes top honors, winning two awards, at Creative Excellence in Business Advertising awards sponsored by American Business Press (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: American Standard Chooses an Outsider
abstract: American Standard Companies names Frederic Poses chairman and chief executive to replace Emmanuel Kampouris, who is retiring; company says it plans to sell its medical systems division (S)

headline: The Real Retail Revolution: It's Wal-Mart, Not the Net
abstract: Greatest revolution in retailing in recent years comes not from much-hyped Internet shopping but from giant discounter Wal-Mart Stores, which is expected to garner roughly seven percent of US retail market in 1999 with a combination of brand products, good merchandising and low prices that has reshaped retail landscape; photos (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: Borrowing By Consumers Up in August
abstract: Federal Reserve figures show consumer borrowing in August rose by $10.8 billion to total of $1.37 trillion; increase is bigger than $6.6 billion expected by analysts and means consumer debt has been growing at annual rate of 9.6 percent as of August, compared with 7.9 percent in July and 5.4 percent in 1998; credit card and other revolving debt increased $4.3 billion in August after rising $5.9 billion during July; Labor Department reports jobless claims increased 10,000, to seasonally adjusted 312,000 for week ended Oct 2; claims in week ended Sept 25 are revised to 302,000, first time in 10 weeks that claims surpassed 300,000; graph on consumer borrowing (M)

headline: Mazda Adds To Doner Assignment
abstract: Mazda Motor Corp expands its relationship with Doner by awarding the agency duties on its consolidated Australian account along with Clemenger Harvie in Melbourne; billings are estimated at $13 million (S)

headline: Venture Capital Crooning
abstract: If Timothy C. Draper's efforts to ingratiate himself in New York last week offer any evidence, transplanting the Silicon Valley ethos even to the financially fertile soil of Manhattan will yield an uncertain harvest. To celebrate plans for his Draper Fisher Jurvetson venture capital firm to open a New York branch, he got the crowd at a New York Venture Group breakfast to sing along with the words he handed out to ''New York, New York.'' His last two verses:       We'll build a new brand    Some Web-based hot app    Throw in some viral marketing    And it's a wrap.    If we can leave no doubt    I.P.O. take it out    We'll all get rich!    The In-ter-net.      When his quavering off-key croaking was done, the critics pounced. ''We hope you didn't come to New York for a Broadway career,'' one questioner said.    Mr. Draper, having said that New York's legal, financial and media businesses were headed for extinction, and that the Internet was a better long-term growth play than any other organized religion, for once turned modest. ''I'll keep my day job,'' he answered.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: HITLER'S BUNKER UNEARTHED -- Construction workers near the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin have found remnants of Hitler's bunker, Berlin city officials said. Though the site has been known for years, it was sealed off by the Russian Army and the former East German Government throughout the cold war. City officials now have to decide what they will do, but said they hope to avoid interrupting the construction of new Government buildings and a street nearby.   Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)    BRITAIN: PLEA FOR PINOCHET REJECTED -- On the eve of the first anniversary of the arrest in London of Gen. August Pinochet, 83, Britain said it could not grant a new formal request from Chile to release him on grounds of his age and failing health. A spokeswoman for Home Secretary Jack Straw said he could not take any action at all until legal proceedings were finished. A London court ruled last week that the former Chilean dictator could be extradited to Spain to stand trial on torture charges.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: MODERATE INFLATION IN TAIWAN
abstract: Taiwan's inflation slowed in September, with consumer price index rising by unadjusted 0.59 percent from year earlier, to 103.40 (S)

headline: Colombia Rebels Add Journalists to List of Prospective Hostages
abstract: Left wing Colombia guerrillas withsraw immunity formerly granted to press, as focus of civil conflict shifts from battlefield to negotiating table, and have started kidnapping journalists attempting to cover their activities (M)

headline: Rate Worry Erodes Prices Of Treasuries
abstract: Treasury yields rise to four week highs; price of 30-year bond fell 5/32 to 98 31/32; its yield rose to 6.20 percent from 6.19 percent; graph (M)

headline: THE MONEY MOVERS: A special report; Tracking How Pair Went From Russia to Riches
abstract: Rapid transformation of self-effacing Russian emigre Peter Berlin from small-time businessman to key player in alleged Russian money laundering scheme detailed; Berlin and his Benex International Co allegedly moved over $7 billion over three years, with aid of accounts at Bank of New York, where Berlin's wife, Lucy Edwards, was officer; United States investigators suspect Berlin's transformation was orchestrated by someone in Russia with ties to business or political leaders; Edwards' role remains unclear; chronology of events; photo (M)

headline: Raising a Yellow Flag On a Pension Tax Break
abstract: With a tax break for lump-sum pension payouts due to expire at the end of the  year, many retirees or other people leaving a job may be tempted to pull their money out of employer-sponsored plans to take advantage of the provision, known as five-year averaging.    But Mark Watson, a partner in the Washington national tax office of KPMG Peat Marwick, has a word of caution. Generally, he said, it is best to roll over the money into an individual retirement account or to leave it in the plan, taking out only what you need to live on each year.

headline: Where Most See Ramparts, North Korea Imagines a Wall
abstract: North Korean diplomat Chu Chang Hun uses rare news conference in Beijing to rail against nonexistent 150-mile-long concrete 'wall of division' that South Koreans supposedly erected 20 years ago across buffer zone between North and South (S)

headline: KIMBERLY-CLARK AGREES TO BUY SAFESKIN
abstract: Kimberly-Clark Corp acquires Safeskin Corp for about $850 million to add sales of disposable medical gloves to its expanding health care products business (S)

headline: PRIZE ENERGY AGREES TO ACQUIRE VISTA ENERGY RESOURCES
abstract: Prize Energy Corp acquires Vista Energy Resources Inc; combined enterprise will be named Prize Energy and be 84 percent owned by Prize Energy shareholders (S)

headline: A Gain for Arabs in East Jerusalem
abstract: Israeli Interior Min Natan Sharansky ends Israeli policy of stripping thousands of Palestinians from East Jerusalem of right to live there; practice was denounced by human rights groups and Palestinians as 'quiet deportation' intended to curb Arab population growth in area, whose future is to be determined in Israel-Palestinian talks on permanent peace (S)

headline: Abidjan Journal; Political Woman Goes From Ivory Tower to Street
abstract: Henriette Diabate, well-bred member of Ivory Coast's elite and mother of country's opposition party, emerges as central figure in country's deepening political crisis; has been jailed, along with other party leaders, for leading demonstration and sit-in in capital of Abidjan in defiance of Govt; photo (M)

headline: Shifts Continue At Conde Nast
abstract: Conde Nast Publications names Nina Lawrence publisher of Bride's magazine, Deborah Fine publisher of Glamour, and Lori Burgess publisher of Mademoiselle (S)

headline: Day of Contrition at The Los Angeles Times
abstract: Los Angeles Times publisher Kathryn M Downing, faced with rebellion by distraught and angry staff members, tells staff that she intends to take steps to keep news content of paper free from any appearance of commercial influence; Downing says her own 'fundamental misunderstanding' of editorial principles led her to sign agreement sharing profits of Oct 10 issue of The Times's Sunday magazine with Staples Center, focus of all articles in that issue; acknowledgment and apology are carried in news article in Oct 28 business section of paper (M)

headline: GOODRICH MOVES TO DISMISS 24% OF ITS WORK FORCE
abstract: B F Goodrich Co says it will dismiss 500 workers, close one plant and partly close another to cut costs (S)

headline: Compressed Data; The PC Industry Shows Strong Growth
abstract: Personal computer industry continues to show significant global growth, with third-quarter shipments of machines increasing by 23.2 percent over comparable quarter last year; chart (S)

headline: A Low-Key Iraq War Turns Low-Tech Too
abstract: American fighter jets patrolling northern Iraq are using an innovative new weapon against President Saddam Hussein: concrete. Wary of killing civilians, the Air Force has begun filling 2,000-pound laser-guided bombs with concrete instead of explosives and dropping them on military targets near populated areas, American officials say.     Concrete bombs, whose use has not previously been disclosed, minimize the risk that explosive bomb fragments will kill or wound Iraqi civilians. And using them helps the military avoid playing into what American officials believe is Mr. Hussein's main objective in challenging the ''no flight'' zones over his country: to foment sympathy by publicizing civilian casualties.

headline: Ford Motor Posts Record Sales For Model Year Just Ended
abstract: Ford Motor Co reports sales for 1999 model year rose 4.9 percent, to record 4,117,792 million vehicles; reports market share fell to 24.6 percent, from 25.6 percent in 1998 model year; says Sept sales fell 1.1 percent from brisk 1998 period; foreign auto makers report gains in United States market share; big winners include Kia, Hyundai and Daewoo of South Korea and Volkswagen AG; Japanese auto makers collectively gained 0.1 percentage point of market share in year, to 23.7 percent; graph of US light vehicle sales; tables (M)

headline: Yen Falls Against Dollar; Global Markets Extend Rally
abstract: Yen falls against dollar after Bank of Japan sells currency in bid to keep economic recovery on track; stock prices hit record highs in Hong Kong, London and Paris (S)

headline: Ford Goes Global in Effort to Control the Clock
abstract: Ford Motor Co, in unusual stunt, is buying estimated $10 million of commercial time on dozens of national and pan-regional TV networks to run single, two-minute spot; ad will run on Nov 1 at 9 PM; it is believed to be most widespread use of one commercial at one time by giant advertiser, which will include showing ad on two Web sites; Ford's ambitious effort to present commercial to millions of people at same hour is emblematic of extraordinary steps being taken by major marketers to stand out in cluttered media landscape; emotional commercial will feature 13-year-old soprano Charlotte Church; photos (M)

headline: Personal Incomes in October Had Largest Rise Since 1994
abstract: Commerce Department reports personal incomes in October rose at fastest pace in five and half years; incomes rose 1.3 percent after no change in September; personal spending grew 0.6 percent, topping 0.5 percent in September; spending has risen at 7.4 percent annual rate in first 10 months of year, compared with 6.8 percent year earlier; graph (M)

headline: Coca-Cola Tests Find No Problem
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says its initial tests on drinks that Belgian schoolchildren said last week made them sick indicate no problems with beverages; four Belgian teen-agers said they felt ill after drinking Coca-Cola and Fanta; drinks were produced at two separate bottling plants in Belgium and Britain (S)

headline: Lawmakers Reject Clinton Changes to Finance-Overhaul Bill
abstract: Senate and House lawmakers moved tonight toward completion of a bill overhauling the nation's financial system. But the measure still failed to satisfy President Clinton's concerns about adequately protecting consumers and minorities.

headline: 2 More Firms Will Expand Trading Hours
abstract: DLJ Direct Inc, on-line brokerage unit of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc, and brokerage unit of Fidelity Investments say they will offer up to four hours of extra stock trading daily within next month; morning session is expected to run from 8 to 9:15 AM, with evening trading from 4:15 to 7 PM (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: TRANSFER OF POWER  Queen Elizabeth gave her formal approval to the law ending 27 years of direct rule of Ulster, the last step in a speeded-up procedure transferring power to the Northern Ireland Assembly in Belfast. Today, the new legislature is to hold its first meeting, the Irish Republic is to renounce its claim on the North, and an I.R.A. representative is to make contact with a panel charged with disarming paramilitary groups.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    RUSSIA: TYCOON FACES NEW INQUIRY  Weeks after dropping an embezzlement case against Boris A. Berezovsky, prosecutors say they hope to revive charges that he laundered Aeroflot profits in Swiss bank accounts. Mr. Berezovsky, who is widely said to secretly control Aeroflot, ridiculed the charges by the leftist-backed prosecutor's office, which has focused its inquiries on allies of President Boris N. Yeltsin.    Michael Wines (NYT)    BOSNIA: U.N. FACES LEGAL ACTION FOR MASSACRE  The Mothers of Srebrenica, an association of relatives of thousands of Muslims killed by Bosnian Serbs in 1995, said they would take legal action against United Nations officials for failing to stop the killing. In a report last month, the United Nations blamed itself for failing to prevent the deaths.   (Reuters)    TURKEY: EX-GENERAL MAY SEEK OFFICE  A retired general, Cevik Bir, said he might run for president next year. General Bir became prominent for his role in the military-led effort that forced the resignation in 1997 of Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, who was considered pro-Islamic. Critics said the general's election would increase military influence in politics.   Stephen Kinzer (NYT)    ASIA    EAST TIMOR: AN EXILE RETURNS  Jose Ramos Horta, the Nobel Peace laureate, returned to East Timor, ending 24 years of exile. Greeted by a crowd of thousands of cheering supporters, he called for reconciliation, appealed to other Portuguese-speaking nations to help rebuild East Timor, and praised the United Nations for helping to guide the province toward independence. Under Suharto, who ruled Indonesia until May 1998, Mr. Ramos Horta, who helped form an independent government after Portugal ended colonial rule in 1974, left East Timor to drum up diplomatic support three days before Indonesia invaded on Dec. 7, 1975.   (AP)    MIDDLE EAST    IRAN: JAILED REFORMER WON'T SEEK APPEAL  Abdollah Nouri, the Shiite Muslim cleric jailed for religious and political dissent, has rejected all calls to appeal against his conviction, said his lawyer, Mohsen Rohami. ''I believed the Special Court and its jury to be illegitimate and unlawful from the very beginning,'' he quoted Mr. Nouri as saying in remarks published in pro-reform newspapers. ''They did not listen to my defense in the original case. How do you expect they will they take my defense into account upon an appeal?''   (Reuters)    THE AMERICAS    BRAZIL: WORK RELEASE FOR AMAZON KILLER  Darci Alves Pereira, the rancher convicted of killing Chico Mendes, an outspoken defender of the Amazon rain forest, has been admitted to a work release program. Prosecutors strongly opposed the decision, citing Mr. Pereira's escape in 1993 and the three years he spent in hiding until his recapture. But a judge ruled that Mr. Pereira, who has served 7 years of a 19-year sentence, had been a model prisoner.   Larry Rohter (NYT)    ARGENTINA: OFFICIAL'S IMMUNITY BLOCKED  The lower house of Congress blocked the swearing in of Antonio Bussi, the former military governor of Tucuman province, as a member of the House of Deputies to assure that he does not have immunity in cases of alleged corruption and human rights violations during the military rule from 1976 to 1983. He is under investigation for involvement in the disappearance of a year-old girl after her mother was seized by soldiers.    Clifford Krauss (NYT)    MEXICO: THE PRI RESHUFFLES  Top campaign aides to Francisco Labastida, the presidential candidate of Mexico's governing party, known as the PRI, assumed senior party posts. Jose Gonzalez Fernandez left the PRI presidency to become Health Minister. Dulce Maria Sauri, who had held the party's No. 2 post of secretary general, assumed the presidency. Esteban Moctezuma, a former interior minister, replaced Ms. Sauri, but will continue to head Mr. Labastida's campaign.   Sam Dillon (NYT)    AFRICA    NAMIBIA: VOTING ENDS  Polls closed after two days of voting that were marred by minor problems but judged by foreign observers to be fair. President Sam Nujoma, whose party has ruled since independence from South Africa 10 years ago, is expected to win a third term, but his party, facing its first formidable challenge, may lose its two-thirds majority in parliament. Final results are expected by this weekend.   Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)    BURUNDI: MANDELA TO MEDIATE  Nelson Mandela, the former president of South Africa, agreed to mediate in an effort to end Burundi's civil war. Mr. Mandela replaces former the Tanzanian president, Julius Nyerere, who died in October. At least 150,000 people have died in the war since 1993.    Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)    SOUTH AFRICA: TENSION IN THE MILITARY  Hoping to prevent violence between black and white soldiers, Defense Minister Mosiuoa Lekota appointed a special commission to investigate the September shooting spree in which a black soldier killed six white soldiers and a white civilian at the Tempe military base. The commission will also assess the extent to which racial tensions threaten military cohesion at other bases.     Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

headline: Telecom Italia Shares Rise After Spinoff Plan Is Abandoned
abstract: Shares in Telecom Italia S.p.A. and the companies that acquired it last spring climbed today after a decision to abandon a plan to strip the company, Italy's biggest phone provider, of its profitable cellular phone unit.    On the Milan exchange, shares in Telecom Italia and Telecom Italia Mobile, the cellular phone unit, as well as Tecnost S.p.A., the company through which Olivetti S.p.A. bought Telecom Italia, rose 4 percent to 5 percent in heavy trading early in the day. Shares of Telecom Italia finished up 0.19 euro, or 1.8 percent, to 10.37 euros, while shares in the mobile unit added 0.25 euro, or 3.7 percent, to 7.18 euros. Tecnost climbed 0.09 euro, or 4.6 percent, to 2.23 euros. Olivetti gained slightly, rising 0.01 euro, to 2.16 euros.

headline: Vertical Typing Easy on Wrists
abstract: Recent study by Cornell University on repetitive stress injuries that result from typing on personal computer keyboard for long periods of time, supports the idea that problem may be prevented or treated by having people use a vertical keyboard design that lets them hold their hands in more comfortable position; Prof Alan Hedge, who conducted research, comments (M)

headline: Editor Explores Unintended, and Negative, Side of Technology
abstract: Interview with Stephen L Talbott, editor of NetFuture, e-mail newsletter that examines unintended, and usually negative, impact of technology on society; he cites decision to spend no more than half of workday at computer by writing in longhand; photo (M)

headline: AIR MERGER ADVANCES
abstract: Merger of Canada's two major airlines advances when AMR Corp agrees to sell its stake in Canadian Airlines to Air Canada and more than half of Canadian's shares are tendered to $63 bid by its larger rival, AMR, which has one-third of Canadian Airlines' equity (S)

headline: Despite U.S. Protests, U.N. Relief Aide in Baghdad Is to Stay On
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan asks Hans von Sponeck, agency's relief coordinator for Iraq, to stay for another year, despite pressure from US and Britain to dismiss him for allegedly exceeding role by criticizing economic sanctions against Baghdad (M)

headline: SAINSBURY'S PROFIT DROPS
abstract: Britain's intense supermarket war began to show its effect as J. Sainsbury P.L.C., Britain's second-largest food retailer, said its first-half profit dropped 29 percent. J. Sainsbury has been trying to fight off competition from Asda Group, which Wal-Mart bought in June, and Tesco, Britain's largest food retailer. The supermarkets have been aggressively cutting their prices. Pretax profit after reorganization costs of 55 million [pounds] fell to 297 million [pounds] from 421 million [pounds] a year ago.   Andrew Ross Sorkin

headline: Serb Rejects Dead Son's Medal, and the Whole War
abstract: Last week, eight months after his 20-year-old son was killed in Kosovo, Dusan Vukovic lashed out at the man he holds responsible: President Slobodan Milosevic.     When he was presented with a posthumous medal for his son,  Aleksandar, at a televised ceremony in his home town, Mr. Vukovic refused to take it, and demanded that it be sent back to Mr. Milosevic.

headline: Microsoft Unveils Tax Product But Bill Gates Can't Use It
abstract: Microsoft Corp, through its efforts with Arthur Andersen & Co,introduces its Microsoft TaxSaver sofware this week; cost of software varies from $19.95 to $44.95 depending on version; photo (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Cocoa prices decline 2.2 percent as market doubts farmers in Ivory Coast will disrupt exports next week; in New York, March contract falls $19, to $840 metric ton; graphs (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises against dollar as European stocks surge and strong economic results are reported throughout the region; in New York, euro closes at $1.01360, up from $1.00084; graph (S)

headline: Have Drums, Will Build A Solidly Perfect Business
abstract: Interview with Gerald Kearby, co-founder and chief executive of Liquid Audio Inc, provider of Internet software for digital delivery of music; photo (The Boss column) (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: SCIENTOLOGY LOSES LICENSE -- A Moscow city court has revoked the license of the Church of Scientology, saying the organization violated registration laws, and perhaps tax laws, by listing bogus founders of the sect's local branch. Tax police raided the sect's center this year. Scientology officials said the revocation, which was applauded by the Russian Orthodox Church, was politically driven.   Michael Wines (NYT)    FRANCE: BEEF DECISION DUE -- The European Commission in Brussels said it was examining a four-inch-thick report that France has submitted to back up its decision to maintain an embargo on British beef in breach of European Union policy. The commission said its scientists would have an initial evaluation of the report ready by next Thursday. The beef embargo was imposed three-and-a-half years ago because of what became known as mad cow disease.   Suzanne Daley (NYT)

headline: Protests Falter as Belgrade Turns the Law Against the Opposition
abstract: Demonstrations against Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic appear to flounder, with opposition leaders unsure how to respond to his willingness to use police and arbitrary legal system to defend himself (M)

headline: Trade Pact With China: Hold the Applause
abstract: Excerpts from conversation with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter chief economist Stephen S Roach, who comments on impact recent US-Chinese trade agreement may have on market (M)

headline: People
abstract: Kevin C Clark is named chief executive at Screaming Media, succeeding Jay Chist, who will remain chairman (S)

headline: NATWEST SAVINGS PROMISED
abstract: Bank of Scotland PLC, in effort to persuade investors to back its $34 billion hostile bid for National Westminster Bank PLC, says acquisition, if completed, would create $1.7 billion (US) in savings a year through cost-cutting measures; Bank of Scotland chief executive Peter Burt says his bank could squeeze more out of takeover than any other possible counterbidders; Natwest chairman Sir David Rowland says most of savings would have been achieved by bank's own cost-cutting plan and that Bank of Scotland's bid offers 'high risk for scant reward'; photo (S)

headline: Ivory Coast's Leader Offers Signs of Democratic Revival
abstract: Flights to Ivory Coast resume after first coup in country's 39 years of independence, and dusk-to-dawn curfew is lifted; businesses operate normally, but banks are forbidden to transfer money abroad; Gen Robert Guei, coup's leader, gathers country's political parties and invites them to nominate members for his cabinet, raising hopes that democracy might be restored; but Guei issues subtle warning to political parties to 'avoid troubles'; still in question is how spontaneous military's mutiny was; Gen Guei's junta is full of supporters of Alassane Ouattara, former prime minister who had hoped to run against ousted Pres Henri Konan Bedie, but was being excluded on ground that he was not really citizen of Ivory Coast; there have been no demonstrations demanding Bedie's restoration; map (M)

headline: I.R.A. Pledges To Help Disarm Ulster Fighters
abstract: Irish Republican Army says it 'unequivocally' backs Northern Ireland peace accord, and will appoint go-between to panel charged with disarming paramilitaries; long-awaited statement makes no reference to actual turnover of weapons and conditions naming of middleman on establishment of new power-sharing Northern Ireland government called for in 1998 agreement, but omits previous defiant claim that group has no intention of ever disarming; comes after considerable concessions by Ulster Unionist Party, which had insisted that disarmament precede setting up of local parliament; represents most dramatic move yet in choreographed series of reciprocal conciliatory statements and pledges from all sides in peace talks, chaired by former US Senator George J Mitchell; is welcomed by supporters of accord as significant step forward, but denounced by opponents who object to moving ahead with Catholic-Protestant coalition without any turnover of arms beforehand (M)

headline: World Court Chief Faults U.S. Over Its U.N. Dues
abstract: Justice Stephen M Schwebel, US judge who serves as president of World Court, says that there is 'no question' that US is legally obliged to pay past assessments it owes United Nations (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Earnings for Marks & Spencer Slide 43%
abstract: Marks & Spencer, troubled British retailer, reports 43 percent drop in first-half earnings and announces major restructuring that includes property sales and use of cheaper overseas suppliers; company earned 192.8 million pounds, or about $322 million, in first six months of fiscal year ended Sept 25, down from 337.4 million pounds a year earlier; sales fell to 3.7 billion pounds, or about $6.18 billion, from 3.8 billion pounds a year ago (M)

headline: NTL to Buy Cablecom in a $3.7 Billion Deal
abstract: NTL Inc, Britain's largest cable concern, expands its foothold in Continental Europe with $3.76 billion deal to buy Cablecom Group, Switzerland's leading cable television operator; purchase gives 1.28 million subscribers in Switzerland, accounting for 53 percent of cable market there; as part of deal, NTL also will get Cablecom's SwissOnline subsidiary, one of most popular Web sites in Switzerland (M)

headline: TRAINMAKER CUTS JOBS
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG will cut 16 percent of work force at its Adtranz unit, halving production capacity, in another effort to turn around unit, which is world's biggest train maker; company will take charge of ($197 million) against earnings this year to carry out plan (S)

headline: Gates Advocates Competition, but He Has His Doubters
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman William Gates tries to portray Microsoft as company that wants to give consumers choices in how they use computers and get on line, speech to annual Comdex technology conference, Las Vegas, Nev; but many of those attending express doubts about whether Microsoft is truly embracing idea of competition; photo (M)

headline: Russian Vote Bolsters Pro-Yeltsin Camp in Parliament
abstract: Progovernment parties do better than expected in Russia's parliamentary elections, providing Pres Boris N Yeltsin with a more compliant legislature for his last six months in office and Prime Min Vladimir V Putin with a firm launching pad for the presidency; Communist Party, bulwark of anti-Yeltsin opposition, could still emerge as country's largest single party, with about 25 percent of vote, but progovernment coalition, buoyed by its backing of popular war in Chechnya and by ferocious propaganda campaign waged by Kremlin and its allies, may actually gain a tenuous majority in the Duma, the lower house of Parliament; progovernment gains come at expense of center-left anti-Kremlin alliance headed by former Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov and Mayor Yuri M Luzhkov of Moscow; Luzhkov does win re-election; photo (M)

headline: AT&T's Move May Provide Sharper View Of Leadership
abstract: The early jockeying to succeed AT&T's chairman, C. Michael Armstrong, begins in earnest today.    At a meeting with hundreds of investors and financial analysts today in New York, AT&T intends to announce the most sweeping management changes since Mr. Armstrong took over two years ago, according to executives close to the company.

headline: BRITISH TELECOM CUTS RATES
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC will again cut cost of Internet calls; cuts will let Internet-access providers charge clients a flat rate for access to Internet by January (S)

headline: MOVEMENT IN BANK PRIVATIZATION
abstract: Brazilian government, in agreement that removes obstacle to privatization of large Brazilian bank, Banco de Estado de Sao Paulo, eases payment conditions on almost $1 billion of debt obligations owed by state of Sao Paulo (S)

headline: Leonard S. Shoen, 83, Founder Of U-Haul, the Trailer Company
abstract: Leonard S Shoen, founder of trailer company called U-Haul, dies after driving his car into utility pole near Las Vegas, Nev; he was 83 years old; coroner's office rules death a suicide; photo (M)

headline: Media Talk; Mythic City Editor Is Brought Back to Life
abstract: Pronouncements by mythic New York Herald Tribune city editor Stanley Walker about newspaper industry noted in light of reissue of his 1934 book City Editor; photo (M)

headline: Vodafone Bids $106 Billion for Mannesmann and Is Rebuffed
abstract: Mannesmann AG, German telecommunications giant, rejects as too low, friendly takeover offer of $106.4 billion by Vodafone Airtouch of Britain, possibly setting stage for largest hostile takeover attempt ever and potential trans-Atlantic bidding war (M)

headline: Tokyo Journal; Be Tall and Chic as You Wobble to the Orthopedist
abstract: Young style-conscious women in Japan continue to favor shoes and boots with soles as thick as eight inches despite mounting injuries attributed to fashion; photo (M)

headline: Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, 68, A Former Airline Executive
abstract: Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, president of the American Geographical Society and a former airline executive, died of lung cancer on Monday at Stamford Hospital in Stamford, Conn., his daughter Anne Calder said. He was 68 and lived in Stamford.    A native New Yorker, Mr. Lloyd-Jones received his early education at the Horace Mann School for Boys. For a quarter of a century, from 1957 until 1982, he held a number of senior posts in finance, planning and operations at American Airlines and was elected to the company's board in 1971.

headline: Looking Outward, Japan Again Considers a Simpler Yen
abstract: Plans to knock two zeros off Japanese yen are gaining favor in Japan once again; Mikio Aoki, Japanese government's chief spokesman, says three-party coalition is considering changing denomination of currency, proposal that has come up numerous times over last few decades, but this time there is strong momentum behind it; government's efforts to promote yen as international currency are increasing in urgency as Europe's single currency gains in popularity among investors and international corporations; change has been pet project of Liberal Party, which has been threatening to leave three-party governing coalition; changing currency would probably spur economic activity and spending, if only temporarily, a goal that has been government's primary focus for much of last decade; in changing denomination, 100 yen would become one yen (M)

headline: RMC MAKES OFFER FOR RUGBY
abstract: RMC Group will acquire Rugby Group for 896 million pounds, or $1.45 billion; graph (S)

headline: Merrill Lynch Has Trouble Processing Trading Orders
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co is struggling to handle customers' trades; for about three hours on Nov 9, brokers cannot process orders to buy or sell stocks of companies traded on Nasdaq Stock Market during that exchange's busiest day ever; some of 14,000 brokers complain that failure is latest of several technical problems firm has had as it prepares for start of new service, Merrill Lynch Direct, on Dec 1 (M)

headline: MANAGEMENT: Soothing Savage Structures; A Leaderless Orchestra Offers Lessons for Business
abstract: Members of Orpheus, orchestra with no conductor and ultimate flat, nonhierarchical organization, explain to students at Baruch College in New York City their success without ever having onstage boss; group has become living, and entertaining, microcosm of management theory that has been transforming corporate America throughout 1990's; hundreds of American companies are trying to become 'flatter' by removing management layers between top executives and people in field; movement began as effort to cut costs, but it has picked up steam, even during current economic expansion, as executives try to reshape their companies to react quickly to technological change; differences between command and control structure and flat structure discussed; chart; drawings; photo (M)

headline: For Chechnya's Civilians, Broken Bodies and Lives
abstract: Russia has vowed that war in Chechnya will be different from previous conflict, which ended in stalemate in 1996 and led to at least 30,000 deaths, mostly civilians; says its quarrel is only with Islamic insurgents, whom it also blames for terrorist attacks that have killed about 300 people in Moscow and other Russian cities, and promises victory over separatist republic while avoiding civilian casualties; Chechens who have fled into Ingushetia portray situation as in some ways more desperate than during earlier war; map; photo (M)

headline: It Seemed Easy: Sell Shampoo To the Chinese
abstract: IT seemed a good idea at the time. When a business acquaintance named Jerome Axelrod approached John Paul DeJoria, the co-founder of the Paul Mitchell line of hair-care products, with a plan for distributing the company's shampoos, detanglers and sculpting sprays in the People's Republic of China, Mr. DeJoria jumped at the chance.     After all, why not have somebody you know -- someone you trust -- act as your representative in what is potentially one of the biggest consumer products markets in the world?

headline: Hearings Offer View Into Private Banking
abstract: Citibank's handling of large private accounts will be subject of hearings by Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations into vulnerability of private banking to money laundering; hearings, whose witnesses will include Citibank executives and federal regulators will offer first detailed public look at most secretive look at global financial system in which wealthy customers are afforded extra discretion and care; committee is looking into accounts tied to prominent foreign political leaders and their families, including Gabon president Omar Bongo, who deposited $50 million into private Citibank account in 1997 (M)

headline: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES BUYS STAKE IN REGIONAL CARRIER
abstract: Continental Airlines Inc acquires 28 percent stake in closely held Gulfstream International Airlines Inc as part of new 10-year agreement between carriers (S)

headline: Municipal Bonds Can Provide a Hedge, and Its Thorns Are Limited
abstract: Article offers advice on buying municipal bonds, which have become attractive for investors seeking to limit risk in their portfolios; charts (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: ITALIAN GAS UTILITY IN BRAZIL
abstract: Brazil's hopes of increasing natural gas consumption are lifted after Eni SpA of Italy agrees to pay $143 million for concession to build natural gas grid in country's industrialized southeast; Eni outbids CMS Energy, Enron Corp and Gas Natural SA of Spain for right to construct gas distribution network on interior Sao Paulo state; Eni will use gas from recently completed Bolivia-to-Brazil gas pipeline (S)

headline: DIANE ARCHER
abstract: AS president of the Manhattan-based Medicare Rights Center, Diane Archer travels around the country as a spokeswoman and omsbudswoman for older adults and the disabled. Her main concern is that as health costs soar and Medicare payments lag, retired people now spend 19 percent of their income, on average, for items, like drugs, that are not covered by Medicare.     The nonprofit center, which she helped start 10 years ago, fielded 57,000 calls seeking help last year. On recent business trips, she has met with retired government workers in Wenatchee, Wash., state and local Medicare experts in Cincinnati and consumer education colleagues in the nation's capital.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50       Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00       Federal funds   5.44   5.58   4.67       3-month T-bills   5.08   5.08   4.35       6-month T-bills   5.28   5.32   4.34       10-yr. T-infl.   4.16   4.16   3.80       10-yr. T-note   6.16   6.23   4.62       30-yr. T-bond   6.25   6.32   5.04       Telephone bd.   8.17   8.20   6.78       Municipal bds.   6.10   6.11   5.11        (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Chase Manhattan must cut its revenue after discovering some nonexistent trading profits.
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp says its fourth-quarter trading revenue will be reduced by $60 million after bank found it booked nonexistent trading profits; bank has dismissed currency trader involved in matter; bank officials decline to identify trader or say why he was dismissed; but people inside bank say that senior currency trader named Christopher Goggins was dismissed last week after internal audit found he had been exploiting flaw in bank's systems to post gains on long-term trades that bank could not realize; Chase says no money was embezzled from bank and that no customer funds were affected (Market Place column) (M)

headline: BB&T TO BUY FIRST BANKING FOR $123.6 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: BB&T Corp, acquires First Banking Co of Southeast Georgia for $123.6 million in stock (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS: for JUAN SOMAVIA; Making Markets Work for All
abstract: FOR decades, the International Labor Organization has been derided as an ineffectual, anticapitalistic talking shop, when it has been noticed at all. But its  new director-general, Juan Somavia, is intent on changing all that.    With 2,300 employees and a $480 million budget, the Geneva-based organization, an agency of the United Nations, has broad responsibilities, among them leading the worldwide fight against abuse of child labor, promoting job creation in poor countries and defending workers' rights to form unions. Mr. Somavia arrived in March believing that the organization need not be anti-business to achieve its objectives.

headline: Avon Steps Up Buyback
abstract: Avon Products Inc is speeding up its $1.1 billion stock-buyback program to finish in fourth quarter because its shares are cheap; Avon will repurchase $500 million of common stock in quarter (S)

headline: About the Tables
abstract: The Times is revising its stock market tables today to reflect later trading hours.     The main tables, which begin on Page C20, will continue to show prices for the regular trading session. For the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange, that runs from 9:30 a.m., Eastern time, through the close of the Pacific Exchange, at 4:30 p.m. For the Nasdaq stock market, it is through 4 p.m.     A supplemental table, on Page C20, shows the 30 most active stocks in trading from the end of regular trading through 6:35 p.m., as well as the top 25 percentage gainers and decliners.

headline: I.B.M. to Announce a New Record for Storage Density on Magnetic Disks
abstract: International Business Machines will announce that its engineers have set new record in magnetic-disk storage density, squeezing 35 billion bits of data in square inch; this immense storage density would make it possible to pack as much as three hours and 15 minutes of video per square inch or as much as week's listening time of high-fidelity music in same space; IBM achievement comes less than five months after company announced ability to store 20 billion bits per square inch, record that Seagate Technology Inc and several Japanese manufacturers subsequently edged past (M)

headline: Pasting Eyeballs to Screen With a Wearable Television
abstract: Olympus America's Eye-Trek personal television display is worn like a visor and has an LCD television screen in front of each eye, providing the effect of watching a 62-inch screen from a distance of six and a half feet; photo (S)

headline: Fearing Millennial Action, Israel Is Ready to Oust 20 Christians
abstract: Israeli authorities round up members of two Christian groups living on slopes of Mount of Olives and orders 20 deported out of fear of possible outburst of millennium-related violence; groups have been living quietly on Mount of Olives for several years, promoting visions of millennial apocalypse (M)

headline: Russian Businessman Under Investigation Is Detained in Hungary
abstract: Anatoly Bykov, chairman of aluminum factory in Siberia, is detained in Hungary at request of Russian law enforcement authorities, who have opened criminal investigation of his finances; articles in Russian press suggest Bykov has laundered money and has organized contract killings; he denies allegations (M)

headline: At Lancome, campaigns for the new year will show models with freckles and all.
abstract: L'Oreal will significantly revamp marketing efforts for its popular Lancome line of beauty products for new year, projecting more natural look (M)

headline: Ukraine's Election Seems Rigged to Favor Sitting President
abstract: Ukraine is poised to re-elect Pres Leonid M Kuchma on Oct 31; political analysts say presidential campaign has been rigged to favor Kuchma, who is running on five-year record of economic decline; photo (M)

headline: Boeing Agrees to Settle Case Charging Bias in Salaries
abstract: Boeing Co agrees to pay at least $4.5 million to women and minority employees who Government says are paid less than their white male counterparts; settlement is largest ever under Labor Department affirmative action compliance program; Boeing agrees to examine pay of all its nonunion employees over next four years and make further adjustments if it finds evidence of pay disparities based on formula agreed upon with Labor Department; $4.5 million covers back pay and raises for about 4,400 women and 1,000 minority workers at 10 Boeing operations (M)

headline: Pfizer and Celera in Deal
abstract: Pfizer will buy genetic information from the Celera Genomics Group, a gene-mapping company that is a unit of the PE Corporation, and collaborate on research under a five-year agreement. Pfizer will gain access to Celera's genetic databases until 2005. The databases include three billion base pairs of human DNA, or about 75 percent of all human genetic information. Celera and Pfizer will also collaborate to discover gene-based therapies. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: TheStreet.com Co-Founder to Forgo Salary
abstract: TheStreet.com says that its co-founder and contributing editor, James J Cramer, has agreed to take stock options instead of his salary of $275,000 next year (S)

headline: Atmel to Buy Chip Plant
abstract: Atmel Corp plans to buy plant in Irving, Tex, from Hitachi Semiconductor America Inc for undisclosed price to increase its production of advanced chips (S)

abstract: HARDCOVER     THIS   LAST     MONTH   MONTH                1+   2   WHO MOVED MY CHEESE? by Spencer Johnson (Putnam, $19.95). headline: MICHAEL C. RULTTGERS
abstract: Contents of briefcase of Michael C Ruettgers, president and

headline: AT&T and Charter Plan Cable Swaps
abstract: AT&T Corp, soon to be largest US cable television company, and Charter Communications Inc, say they will swap cable systems serving about 1.3 million customers as they consolidate regional service areas (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: The Pitfalls In Hospitals' Cost-Cutting
abstract: Health Network America chairman Stephen A Kardos letter on Milt Freudenheim's October 31 article on hospital cost-cutting measures contends that hospital administrators and doctors often abandon their role as patients' defenders and advocates (S)

headline: CLINTON KICKS OFF CAMPAIGN TO PASS NUCLEAR TEST BAN
abstract: Pres Clinton begins intense weeklong campaign to persuade Republican-controlled Senate to embrace Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty banning testing of nuclear weapons, one of his top foreign policy goals, but acknowledges he lacks votes for passage; meets with top national security advisers in first of string of public events in support of treaty; says Senate decision will be crucial since it will affect welfare of American people well into next century; urges Americans to pay close attention; says since nuclear tests are no longer needed, it is strongly in US interest to achieve agreements preventing other countries from testing and deploying weapons; proponents say treaty, which has support of more than 150 other nations, will deter further development and refining of nuclear weapons; opponents say it will mainly serve to tie hands of US; argue that its provisions cannot be adequately verified; US stopped nuclear testing in 1992 and maintains weapons through sophisticated computer models; photo (M)

headline: German Company Standing Firm Against Vodafone
abstract: Mannesmann AG chairman Klaus Esser is determined to fight Vodafone Airtouch PLC's takeover, arguing that British company will bring nothing to Mannesmann shareholders and that two companies' strategies are fundamentally incompatible (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: PAPON DISAPPEARS -- Maurice Papon, 89, convicted last year of complicity in Nazi crimes against humanity for his role in ordering the deportation of Jews from Bordeaux, has disappeared from his home near Paris on the eve of an appeals hearing. A Bordeaux court ruled he would have to start serving his 10-year prison sentence before the appeal could be heard next Thursday. Mr. Papon's lawyer said he knew where his client was but would not say whether he would surrender.   Craig R. Whitney (NYT)    BELGIUM: ROBERTSON MOVES IN -- Lord Robertson took office as NATO's new Secretary General, saying he would focus the alliance's efforts on strengthening Europe's defense role, building closer ties with Russia and creating conditions for lasting peace in the Balkans. ''I look forward to a pretty heavy workload,'' Lord Robertson said.   (AP)

headline: Talks With China Near, Clinton Says
abstract: Pres Clinton confirms that he is seeking to re-start negotiations with China over its entry into the World Trade Organization; says if deal is struck in coming weeks, he believes Congress will approve it (S)

headline: London Journal; The Mayoral Frolics: What a Cast of Characters!
abstract: Campaign for first directly elected mayor of London, Eng, has caught British politicians ill-prepared, with embarrassing consequences all around; there has been resignation of one candidate because of sex scandal and barring of another for his confessed serial adultery; because personality is playing more important role than party voting habits, contest has attracted hopefuls from nontraditional sectors; among them are two baronesses, gay rights activist, punk rock entrepreneur, Internet millionaire, novelist Jeffrey Archer and actress Glenda Jackson; photos (M)

headline: Insurers Urge Auto Makers To Stress Making Cars Safer
abstract: Study by Institute for Highway Safety says designing cars that provide more protection for their occupants will do more for automotive safety than designing sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks that are less lethal to car occupants in collisions; holds there are still many more cars on road than sport utility vehicles or pickups, so cars will hit other cars or roadside objects more often than they are involved in crashes with big light truck; says auto makers' safety budgets should be used on sturdier passenger compartments in cars and other such features (M)

headline: Trying On Clothes in a Virtual Dressing Room
abstract: New software program from Broderbund, Cosmopolitan Fashion Makeover Deluxe, allows women to try on clothes on line before ordering them from Macy's Web site, using 3-D rendering technology called My Virtual Model to createon-screen figures; photo (M)

headline: Russian Court Ruling Is New Blow to Foreign Investment
abstract: Russia's shaky foreign-investment reputation weakens further when court in St Peterburg rules that 255-year-old Lomonosov porcelain factory be renationalized, annulling majority stake held by executives of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co and United States-Russia Investment Fund; investment fund plans to appeal ruling; court's decision is latest in series of disputes over last year that have eroded foreigners' investments in Russian companies (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ernst & Young Agrees To Settle Cendant Suit  Ernst & Young has agreed to pay $335 million to settle charges that it failed in its responsibilities when it certified financial statements that inflated the profits of Cendant, which operates Ramada Inn hotels and Avis car rental agencies.    The settlement was the largest ever by an accounting firm accused of improper practices by shareholders, although Ernst & Young paid more than $400 million in 1992 in penalties and fines to settle claims of Federal agencies growing out of the savings and loan crisis. Ernst & Young said in a statement that it had done nothing wrong, but accounting experts said it was a sad day for the accounting profession and that perhaps new procedures were needed. [Page A1.]

headline: U.S. Gasoline Price Up
abstract: The retail price of gasoline in the United States rose to its highest in three and a half years, $1.269 a gallon, in the week ended today, a government survey showed, as crude oil surged to its highest price in almost nine years. The average pump price for regular self-service gasoline rose 1.8 cents, as prices increased in all parts of the country except the Rocky Mountains, according to an Energy Department survey of 800 filling stations. That was the highest since the week ended June 3, 1996.

headline: Head of Marketing Quits Conde Nast
abstract: Catherine Viscardi Johnson resigns unexpectedly as executive vice president for sales and marketing at Conde Nast Publications (S)

headline: NORTEL NETWORKS FORMS AN ALLIANCE WITH MICROSOFT
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp plans to announce alliance with Microsoft Corp that will make much of Nortel's networking code available to outside developers; Nortel also intends to announce price cuts of as much as 50 percent for many of data networking products that it has developed with Bay Networks Inc, which it acquired in 1998 (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PSINET INC.,  Herndon, Va., a provider of Internet services to businesses, agreed to buy part of the nationwide fiber optic network of IXC Communications Inc., Austin, Tex., to offer services in more markets. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Former Leader of National Auto Regains Control of the Company
abstract: Sam J Frankino, former chairman of National Auto Credit Inc who quit after company's auditors resigned and integrity of company's financial statements was challenged, wins court fight in Delaware allowing him to regain control of company; Chancellor William B Chandler III rules that because chairman Frankino controls majority of company's stock he has right to amend corporate bylaws to eliminate one that requires 80 percent vote of shareholders to change makeup of board (M)

headline: Inside the Flashy Shoe That Encourages Children to Step on It
abstract: Popular battery-powered children's sneakers that blink when in use have maintained steady market share since their introduction by LA Gear in 1992; Robert Greenberg, who created LA Gear and became co-founder of another company Sketchers in 1992, says lighted sneakers account for 5 percent to 10 percent of sales of children's shoes; most, if not all, lighted sneakers use system developed in late 1980's by Nicholas Rodgers, Canadian inventor; photo of lighted sneaker and its mechanics (M)

headline: Turkey Faces A Quandary On Rebellions By Its Friends
abstract: Turks overwhelmingly support desire of people in Kosovo and Chechnya to establish their political independence, but if their government were to express that view, it would certainly face difficult question: if people in Kosovo or Chechnya deserve autonomy or independence, why not Kurds in Turkey? (M)

headline: Coke Assigns Larger Roles To 3 Officers
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says three top executives will assume greater authority, apparently setting up succession contest for top job and easing some criticism that chairman and chief executive, M Douglas Ivester, lacks second in command; changes increase responsibilities of senior vice presidents Jack L Stahl and Douglas N Daft, as well as those of chief financial officer, James E Chestnut (M)

headline: Peru's Leader to Seek a 3rd Term, Capping a Long Legal Battle
abstract: Pres Alberto K Fujimori of Peru announces his candidacy for unprecedented third term, arguing that his country needs him to guarantee end to terrorism and to complete its economic recovery; Fujimori has spent four years of legal and political manuevering to overcome constitutional bar against three consecutive presidential terms; Fujimori is credited with ending control of two guerrilla groups, but his often autocratic methods have attracted widespread criticism among human rights groups (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BOSNIA: LOCAL LEADERS DISMISSED -- International authorities administering Bosnia dismissed 22 local officials for obstructing the enforcement of the 1995 peace agreement and hindering the return of refugees. The officials, who include Muslims, Serbs and Croats, were told they have been removed from office and banned from running in municipal elections next year.   (AP)

headline: AVANT IS PAYING $24 MILLION TO ACQUIRE ANALOGY
abstract: Avant Corp agrees to buy Analogy Inc for $2.48 a share in cash, or $24 million (S)

headline: Dozens More From Sect Arrested in Beijing
abstract: Dozens more followers of Falun Gong spiritual movement are detained in Beijing, some dragged away shouting, on fifth day of protests while hundreds and perhaps thousands of fugitive believers are reportedly hidden around city; photo (M)

headline: Coke Promotion Is Halted
abstract: Coca-Cola says it will end promotion in Belgium after court rules company abused its position as nation's largest maker of soft drinks; Coke says it will appeal court ruling, though it will comply; starting in September, Coke gave free drinks and sold beverages at discount to about 60,000 cafes, sports centers and smaller retailers that was intended as apology to retailers after recall and ban on Coca-Cola's drinks this year; Chaudfontaine, European distributor of soft drinks, filed complaint (S)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.27   5.35        3-month T-bills   4.99   4.94   4.42        6-month T-bills   5.09   5.05   4.36        10-yr.
