abstract: Luciano Soprani, Italian fashion designer, dies at age 53; photo (M)

headline: Big Day Looms In Stock Offer By Developer Of Optic Links
abstract: Sycamore Networks Inc is expected to raise more than $280 million in initial public offering; issue is priced at $38 a share, which would give company market value of about $3 billion; company is perhaps leading member of new breed of companies that are developing next generation of optical networking technology; it is also first to offer stock to public; explosion in demand for data communications generally and Internet services specifically has required old-line communications carriers to design their networks for data from ground up; dominant optical communications technology is known as Sonet, for synchronous optical network, and though latest Sonet networks can transmit billions of bits of digital information a second, they are inflexible in some ways (M)

headline: U.S. Steps Up Pressure on Taliban to Deliver Osama bin Laden
abstract: United States envoy Michael A Sheehan meets with Taliban representative Abdul Hakeem Mujahid at United Nations to step up pressure on Afghanistan's ruling Islamic movement to turn over Osama bin Laden for trial in US; bin Laden is sought in connection with 1998 bombings of US Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC.,  New York, agreed to buy the closely held Podell Industries, Los Angeles, for an undisclosed sum to add brands to its contemporary women's clothing business.

headline: Israel Eases Secrecy Over Nuclear Whistle-Blower's Trial
abstract: Israel, pre-empting court challenge, lets newspaper publish censored excerpts from classified transcript of treason trial 12 years ago of Mordechai Vanunu, who serves 18-year prison term for blowing whistle on Israel's secret nuclear program; release signals Israel's growing awareness that it can no longer maintain absolute silence about whether it has nuclear arms; photo (M)

headline: U.S. EFFORT TO ADD LABOR STANDARDS TO AGENDA FAILS
abstract: Clinton administration fails to rally broad support among nations to add labor standards to World Trade Organization agenda, threatening its most important goal at Seattle meeting that has been plagued by sometimes violent protests; struggles to work out compromise that would have trade organization set up study group on labor standards; Pres Clinton stuns delegates when he says trade group should use sanctions to enforce labor rights around world (M)

headline: Paying the Price For Avoiding Japan
abstract: Morningstar Inc survey finds that some foreign stock funds that steered clear of Japan and that performed best for five years ending in 1998 are now lagging behind other funds in Nikkei-225 stock index category (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: PINOCHET'S HEALTH  Gen. Augusto Pinochet was excused for health reasons from having to appear in person at Friday's reading of a court decision on a Spanish request to extradite him to Madrid on torture charges. A doctor said the 83-year-old former Chilean dictator suffered two small strokes in September. Requiring him to attend would put him ''under great strain,'' Dr. Michael Loxton said, and the magistrate said he was ''satisfied'' with the explanation.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Compressed Data; Hand-Held Wireless Data Gets a Flat-Rate Test
abstract: OmniSky Corp, spinoff of 3Com's Palm Computing division, will offer small radio modem that attaches to Palm V hand-held computers, in partnership with AT&T; new service is based on AT&T Wireless Services' cellular digital packet data network and is intended to offer range of services similar to that now provided by Palm's wireless Palm VII hand-held computer and growing range of pagers and cell phones connected to Internet (M)

headline: Disney Posts 71% Decline In 4th-Quarter Earnings
abstract: Walt Disney Co reports net income for its fourth quarter ended Sept 30 fell 71 percent, to $85 million, compared with $296 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue fell 6 percent, to $5.8 billion from $6.15 billion; for full year, earnings fell 30 percent, to $1.30 billion compared with $1.85 billion in previous year; revenue increased 2 percent, to $23.4 billion; chairman Michael D Eisner says he is shifting company's emphasis away from adding new businesses and properties, something he has done aggressively since taking over 15 years ago, and toward improving profits from existing businesses (M)

headline: Snubbed by the West, Tudjman Receives a Posthumous Rebuke
abstract: Croatian Pres Franjo Tudjman is buried in somber ceremony, mourned by tens of thousands of Croats to whom he helped deliver independence, and by less-than-stellar panoply of foreign dignitaries (S)

headline: Inflation Is Still The Only Real Threat
abstract: Tom Redburn Economic View column assesses factors that may result in American economic downturn; holds that, of handful of usual causes, stock market collapse is only one worth serious consideration (M)

headline: Revamping the Variable Annuity to Make It More Competitive
abstract: Article describes how variable annuity, combination of mutual fund and insurance policy, works and notes changes that are making them more affordable and less complicated to understand (M)

headline: Disarm Timor Militias, U.S. Warns Indonesia
abstract: SINGAPORE—  As soldiers of the Australian-led force in East Timor prepared to move toward the sensitive border with Indonesia, Defense Secretary William Cohen of the United States warned the Indonesian military Thursday that it must disarm militias responsible for violence in the disputed territory.

headline: Talks on Ulster Stop to Let Mediator Seek Counsel
abstract: Former US senator George J Mitchell suspends nine-week-old mission to unblock deadlocked Northern Ireland peace accord; cites need to brief Pres Clinton and British and Irish prime ministers, Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, before reconvening talks in Belfast on November 8 (S)

headline: Democracy Sprouts in Kyrgyzstan's Hostile Soil
abstract: Idea of popular sovereignty appears to take hold in Kyrgzstan, where autocracy has long been tradition, and remote landlocked Central Asian nation could become first democracy in area's long and brutal history; Pres Askar Akayev vows parliamentary and presidential elections, scheduled for 2000, will be fair and transparent, but while citizens seem to admire his dedication to democratic principles, many consider him too weak for job; in eight years as President, he has been unable to return people to living standards during Soviet days and some of his close relatives and leading supporters have enriched themselves at public expense; Islamic guerrillas have begun campaign in south that could threaten national and regional stability; map; photos (M)

headline: In China, Visions Of Internet Riches In a PC-Short Land
abstract: Even as China reaches outside itself to become a full-fledged member of the club of trading nations, outside world is reaching deeper into China through the Internet; foreign investors are pouring tens of millions of dollars into Chinese Internet companies, despite uncertainty over government regulations on foreign ownership and dissemination of information and questions about how long it will take cash-based economy to enter digital age; photo (M)

headline: BROWSER
abstract: Eclectic listing of Web sites and events

headline: BENETTON SHARES SURGE
abstract: Benetton Group SpA surges as much as 8.5 percent after chairman Luciano Benetton says company will sell products on Internet next year; graph (S)

headline: Where's the Beef? On the Plate; Steaks, Roasts and Hamburgers Making a Comeback
abstract: Beef is making comeback after 20 years in which consumers steadily defected to chicken; over last few years, demand and price stabilized; analysts expect consumption to increase further this year even as beef prices are going up; consumer spending for beef is expected to reach $48.6 billion in 1999, $2 billion more than 1998; contributing factors are strong economy and new attitudes about fat, in part because of encouragement of books recommending higher-fat diets; photo; diagram (M)

headline: Media Talk; Hachette Plans to Buy the Rest of George
abstract: Hachette Filipacchi plans to buy 50 percent stake in George magazine that family of late John F Kennedy Jr still owns, and to invest more than $10 million in magazine in next year; Jack W Kliger, Hachette's chief executive, says sad outgrowth of Kennedy's death in July was that it provided unintended marketing bonanza for magazine; photo (M)

headline: Rising Star in French Cabinet Falls in a Corruption Inquiry
abstract: French government of Prime Min Lionel Jospin suffers major blow when Finance Min Dominique Strauss-Kahn, one of its rising stars, resigns in face of growing accusations of corruption stemming from investigation of his role as lawyer in questionable property deal in mid-1990's, for which he allegedly was paid $100,000 for doing no work (S)

headline: Criticism on a Different Runway
abstract: Ralph Lauren's entry, 1938 Bugatti 57SC Atlantic, painted black, is declared winner of annual concours d'elegance for antique cars at Rockefeller Center; jury chairman Murray Livingstone Smith suggests that car, which failed to start, be repainted its original blue; photo (S)

headline: Have Laptop, Will Upload for Dinner
abstract: Workplace article on Web sites for finding free-lance employment; photo of Mike Phillips, animation artist who returned to home town in Ontario, andnow seeks assignments by way of cyberspace; booming economy and low unemployment spurs employers to seek out new ways to find skilled workers (S)

headline: Account Awarded For Migraine Drug
abstract: Pfizer Inc awards assignment to create campaigns aimed at consumers for Relpax, anti-migraine drug awaiting approval from Food and Drug Administration, to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications; billings estimated at $40 million (S)

headline: Will Gift Lists Click?
abstract: Online gift registries have sprouted in last year, with goal of being single online destination for gift recipients, gift givers and online retailers who can satisfy needs of both; sampling of sites (M)

headline: Talks on China Trade Deal In Peril, the U.S. Side Says
abstract: Trade representative Charlene Barshefsky and other US officials in Beijing express pessimism about prospects for long-sought deal to get China into World Trade Organization (M)

headline: Executives Are Shifted At 3 Agencies
abstract: Executives at three agencies are taking new roles.    Howard Sherman, 42, president at Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will leave after more than eight years to join Shepardson Stern & Kaminsky in New York as executive vice president, a new post heading the advertising division.

headline: INDONESIA'S ADVANCES AND SETBACKS
abstract: Indonesia's economics minister, Kwik Kian Gie, told executives in Singapore that his nation's economy would grow 3 percent next year, with retail sales and exports already recovering strongly. But he said that the enormous cost of bailing out the nation's banks would amount to 4 percent of Indonesia's gross domestic product and that the government would expedite the sale of state assets, including its majority stakes in Telekomunikasi Indonesia and the Indonesian Satellite Corporation, to help defray the bailout costs.     Wayne Arnold

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises against dollar on speculation European Central Bank may raise its benchmark lending rates soon; in New York, euro settles at $1.0710, up from $1.0697; graph; chart (S)

headline: Defending the Stone
abstract: Alex Kolker letter on Oct 21 article on computer game The Stone says he disagrees with many criticisms about the game

headline: Rite Aid Calls Earnings Forecast Inaccurate
abstract: Rite Aid Corp tells analysts and investors not to rely on forecasts for profit and cash flow made last month; company's stock falls $2.5625, to $5.375; forecasts were made Oct 11 by Matin L Grass, who was then chairman; he was ousted by company's directors one week later; spokeswoman Karen Rugen says company was contacted by enforcement arm of Securities and Exchange Commission, but declines to give specifics (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Breakup of Microsoft? Possibly, but Investors Shrug It Off
abstract: Investors shrug off possibility that Microsoft Corp may have to break up in light of Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's finding that company is a monopoly; Microsoft's stock falls $1.625 a share, to close at $90, which is more than $87 a share reached in after-hours trading on Nov 5, after decision was known (Market Place column) (M)

headline: BRAZIL EUROBOND SALE
abstract: Brazilian government, in move that will provide central bank with foreign currency to help prevent weakening of real, Brazil's currency, sells 600 million euros, or about $620 million, worth of two-year bonds in international markets (S)

headline: Los Angeles Times Issues Unsparing Report on Itself
abstract: Los Angeles Times publishes unsparing account of its controversial, ill-fated profit-sharing deal with Staples Center, local sports arena; report details deal's incremental evolution, haphazard way editors realized what was happening and failure of newsroom leadership to quash it; its findings discussed (M)

headline: Calendars Made for Sharing, For the Online and Handheld Set
abstract: Internet calendar craze moves to handheld devices; WeSync.com lets user create online calendar to share with family and friends by synching it to Palm Pilot or other device running Palm Operating System (S)

headline: FRENCH JOBLESSNESS DROPS
abstract: Unemployment rate in France drops in November to 10.8 percent, its lowest rate in seven years, as mounting business confidence encourages fresh hiring (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    ITALY: GO-AHEAD FOR D'ALEMA -- Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema narrowly received agreement from the lower house of Parliament to start a new administration. The vote was 310 to 287, with 18 abstentions. His new center-left coalition is smaller, but perhaps more cohesive, than the one he started out with 14 months ago. ''It worries me that my government is born of a slimmer majority,'' Mr. D'Alema told the legislature. ''But it is better than continuing to live with constant bickering.''   Alessandra Stanley (NYT)    NORTHERN IRELAND: PRISONER FURLOUGH -- Some 335 prisoners, mostly convicted terrorists and murderers, were sent home for Christmas from prisons around Northern Ireland. As a sign of confidence in the region's efforts to establish peace, the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, allowed eight prisoners not eligible for the usual parole program to go home as well. The prisoners are to return in 12 days.   Sarah Lyall (NYT)

headline: My Transforming Moments
abstract: Oxygen Media Inc chairman and chief executive Geraldine Laybourne discusses some transforming moments in her managerial career (The Boss column); photo (M)

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Members to Get On-Line Access And Discounts
abstract: AFL-CIO plans to offer heavily discounted computers and on-line service to 13 million union members through iBelong, new company; sees affordable access helping to tie unions more closely to their members and making it easier to mobilize rank and file in labor's struggles via E-mail (M)

headline: Rapper Attitude in Designer Diamonds and Furs : Ghetto Fabulous Goes Global
abstract: WASHINGTON—  The origins of the phrase "ghetto fabulous" are murky at best. Some suggest that its roots reach back to the first time the term ghetto was used to describe downtrodden communities populated by a single ethnic group. But the notion of ghetto fabulous did not become a popular one, did not enter the phrase book of cultural slang, until the hip-hop generation left its apartments, tenements and track houses and headed straight for designer boutiques.

headline: Microsoft and Ericsson To Create Wireless Venture
abstract: Ericsson AB, Sweden, and Microsoft Corp to set up joint-venture company to market and deliver mobile e-mail and other Internet services for wireless network operators; under terms of agreement, Ericsson will provide its Wireless Application Protocal to Microsoft and will adopt Microsoft's Mobile Explorer, new version of its Internet browser, in future cellular phones (M)

headline: Health Insurer Shares Fall on Threat of Suits
abstract: Shares of Aetna Inc and United Healthcare Corp and other major health insurers fall amid reports that trial lawyers are preparing lawsuits on hehalf of managed-care patients; analysts say lawsuits could hurt companies' ability to control health care costs; industry critics say health plans skimp on care to improve profits (M)

headline: Civilian Police Force Brings New Problems in Haiti
abstract: Haiti's fledgling United Nations-trained civilian police force is seen as relatively respectful of human rights, unlike brutal and corrupt army it replaced; lacks ample weapons and resources army once had and must at times scramble to meet its basic needs; struggles to maintain order while people complain increasingly about crime; photo (M)

headline: Tax Returns Of Charities To Be Posted On the Web
abstract: Philanthropic Research Inc to post on its Web site charities' detailed tax returns, giving quick and easy access for first time to comprehensive details on how charities use their money; Ford, Kellogg and Mellon foundations, which fund project, expect scrutiny to spur major changes in charitable world's financial practices; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: FEWER JOBLESS GERMANS
abstract: German unemployment dropped slightly in October, but gap between western and eastern Germany continued to widen; overall unemployment rate remained unchanged at 10.5 percent, but rate increased slightly, to 18.3 percent, in east and declined slightly, to 8.6 percent, in the west (S)

headline: Vastogirardi Journal; Blissful Bachelorhood and the Shrinking Village
abstract: Vastogirardi, small village of 823 people in southern Italy, has seen its population shrink by two-thirds in past 30 years as younger people have defected to better jobs and bigger towns; is in many ways typical of rural areas throughout Europe, where migration from small towns and falling birth rates are producing devastating demographic shifts; Mayor Vincenzo Venditti, aghast at number of adult men and women who show no desire to marry and have children, has threatened to levy tax on unmarried people; photos; map (M)

headline: Media Talk; Marital Woes Threaten Radio Star's Image
abstract: Radio analysts are concerned that Howard Stern's breakup with wife, Alison, will upset chemistry of his top-rated radio talk show; cite importance of tension between his on-air tone of promiscuity and his real-life marital fidelity; Stern candidly discussed breakup on show; photos (M)

headline: AIRBUS GETS FRENCH ORDER
abstract: Air France SA will buy eight Airbus Industrie jets for use on long-haul routes; Air France will place order for 8 of A330-200's and may take as many as 13, giving deal value of as much as $1.6 billion (S)

headline: Russia to Cut Its Military Forces in Georgia
abstract: In a move that will blunt Russia's influence in the Caucasus, Russia has agreed to slash its military forces in Georgia.    The agreement was negotiated last week in Istanbul during the summit meeting of the Organization for Cooperation and Security in Europe and completed even as Russia pressed ahead with its military campaign in Chechnya, Georgia's neighbor.

headline: BRITISH AIRWAYS JET ORDER
abstract: British Airways PLC will by 12 100-seat Airbus A318 single-aisle jets, with combined list price of $450 million, to replace its fleet of 180-seat Boeing 757s; British Airways chooses Airbus planes over Boeing Co's new 106-seat 717 airplane (S)

headline: Sprint's News Shakes Up Kansas City
abstract: Sprint Corp tries to reassure employees in Kansas City that pending acquisition by MCI Worldcom will not lead to substantial cutbacks in operations; recently dedicated $920 million headquarters complex (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Some Leaders Resist Call To Attend Trade Meeting  President Clinton has quietly tried -- and failed -- to persuade leaders of major countries to attend a huge trade conference in Seattle next week in order to break deadlocks over politically sensitive economic issues like workers' rights, agricultural subsidies and America's self-proclaimed authority to block low-cost imports.

headline: A Battle-Scarred Burger Warrior
abstract: Profile of Robert J Nugent and company he founded, Foodmaker Inc; company, having suffered losses after 1993 food poisoning crisis at Jack in the Box fast-food franchises, is changing its name to Jack in the Box Inc; its revitalization efforts described; photo (M)

headline: George Eversman, 72, Executive With Long Career in Advertising
abstract: George H Eversman, advertising executive in New York and Detroit who helped US Marine Corps with its recruitment efforts, dies at age 72; photo (M)

headline: The Borgs Are Loose And Coming for You
abstract: Cyborg, acronym for cybernetic organism, refers to being that is part machine, part human; cyborgs of today, who call themselves borgs for short, wear their computers almost continuously; small plastic display devices attache to their eyeglasses, cables hang behind their ears; each one carries two-pound computer with wireless modem in black sidepack; handheld keypad, called a Twiddler, hangs at their sides; three borgs visit Internet World, computer trade show in Manhattan, to demonstrate benefits of wearable computers; photos (M)

headline: Tearing Down The Facade of 'Vitamins Inc.'
abstract: Article details major vitamin conspiracy by top executives at some of world's largest drug companies, who met secretly to carve up world markets, orchestrate price increases and, in process, defraud world's biggest food companies, including Kellogg, Coca-Cola and Nestle; chronology; photos (L)

headline: A Recovering Nerd
abstract: Kathleen B Earley, At&T's president for data and Internet services, discusses her life as workaholic; interview; photo (S)

headline: Rara Avis at G.M.: A Director From Japan
abstract: Nobuyuki Idei, Sony chief executive named to board of General Motors, joins only handful of Asian executives who are directors of US companies; photo (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: A French Paradox at Work; 35-Hour Week May Turn Out to Be Best for Employers
abstract: France, already among most generous of nations in providing vacation time and short workdays, has instituted 35-hour workweek for 39 hours of pay in hopes of reducing unemployment; opponents say program will do little to dent French jobless rate; shorter workweek, implemented by Prime Min Lionel Jospin's leftist coalition, could result in kind of housecleaning in French workplace that will tear cobwebs from French industry and lead to more productive and flexible work force; last month, some 30,000 industrialists and executives gathered in Paris deploring policy; they said it will cost too much and destroy France's competitiveness; recent poll found that less than 10 percent of France's citizens believe they are going to benefit from shorter workweeks; most people suspect they will be inconvenienced; there is little proof that shorter workweek has created many jobs; graph; photos (M)

headline: Apple Computer Rolls Out New Assemblage of iMacs
abstract: Apple Computer Inc unveils new family of iMac computers, including entry-level model priced below $1,000; co-founder and interim chief executive Steven Jobs demonstrates new features before audience of several thousand Apple employees in Cupertino, Calif (S)

headline: U.S. Once Deployed 12,000 Atom Arms In 2 Dozen Nations
abstract: Article in Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, that is based on secret Defense Department document, says US stored 12,000 of 38 different types of nuclear weapons and components in at least 23 countries and five American territories during cold war--including Morocco, Japan, Iceland, Puerto Rico and Cuba; while other declassified documents made it clear that US deployed nuclear weapons and materials overseas, document confirms how widespread deployments were and highlights America's overriding dependence at time on worldwide network of weapons of mass destruction (M)

headline: From the Candidates, a Deafening Silence
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's findings that Microsoft Corp is monopoly that has stifled competition has left crop of presidential candidates speechless; Vice Pres Al Gore, former Sen Bill Bradley and Gov George W Bush decline comment; Sen John McCain cannot be reached for comment (M)

headline: The Communist Party: Holding Fast to a Well-Worn Theme
abstract: THE SCENE -- A muscular worker's arm in a plaid shirt slams a hard hat on a table atop a copy of a Communist newspaper. An arm attired in a white shirt with gold cufflinks and a Rolex watch follows, depositing a mobile phone on the table. Sleeves rolled up, the two begin to arm wrestle. As years flash on the screen -- 1991, 1993, 1995 -- the white-shirted arm slowly presses the worker's arm downward. By 1997, the worker begins to come back, and the white-shirted figure tries to overcome him with both hands. But as 1999 flashes by, the worker wins.    THE SCRIPT -- A Soviet war medal appears on the screen, and to the sound of a war anthem, an announcer intones: ''For victory! The Communist Party of the Russian Federation!''

headline: A Policy Shift On Serbia Tied To a Free Vote
abstract: Clinton administration, in move to strengthen opposition to Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, will end economic sanctions against Serbia as soon as free election is held; feels new strategy should enable opposition to put more pressure on Milosevic; delegation of Serbian opposition leaders visiting Washington pressed for policy change, arguing that it would allow them to increase popular pressure on Milosevic to call election they are certain they can win; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Palladium prices climb to record after Russia, which produces two-thirds of world's supply, raises export tax; in New York, palladium for March delivery rises $5.65 an ounce, to $430.65; graph; chart (S)

headline: Big Theft, Small Theft: Is There a Difference?
abstract: Jeffrey Seglin The Right Thing column on employee theft, differences between petty pilfering and serious stealing and damage that can occur when companies treat all cases alike; drawing (M)

headline: New Indonesian Assembly Begins Trying to Organize Next Election
abstract: Indonesia's new national Assembly convenes; decides that presidential selection should be conducted in Oct instead of Nov, as originally planned (M)

headline: At Closed-End Muni Funds, Insiders Are Often Buyers
abstract: at closed-end muni f

headline: Board Reports Rise in Index Of Indicators
abstract: Conference Board reports index of leading economic indicators rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November, second consecutive monthly gain and higher than rise of two-tenths of 1 percent analysts had expected; graph; chart (M)

headline: Electronic Retailing to a Truly Mass Market Is Expected
abstract: Online retailing has so far been province of more affluent, better-educated people who are likelist to have personal computers, but demographic and technological trends seem likely to make electronic retailing a truly mass market in coming years; several analysts comment; drawing (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of November 7 article about effect of Americans With Disabilities Act on employees with depression, which misidentified Equal Employment Opportunity Commission as government agency that receives complaints from disabled workers (S)

headline: Paying for Peace Is Clinton's Challenge
abstract: Any agreement reached in Israel-Syria talks is certain to entail huge costs--to monitor security arrangements, to relocate Israeli settlers and to bolster Syrian economy; United States will bear lion's share of burden, if past is any guide (M)

headline: DEAL FOR TEMPLE-INLAND'S PAPERBOARD MILL
abstract: Westvaco Corp to acquire Temple-Inland Inc's bleached paperboard business for $625 million; also plans to cut 300 jobs in its packaging operations as part of cost-cutting program (S)

headline: Incognito Spinmeisters Battle On-Line Critics
abstract: Small industry is emerging among consultants who specialize in spinning on-line discussions to favor positions of companies and interest groups; some firms recruit scientists and other experts to voice clients' perspectives in on-line discussions; this has made people taking part in on-line discussions suspicious; questions about participants' identities and affiliations are becoming more common; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Post-Suharto Dawn
abstract: Analysis: Indonesia has anointed its new leaders, and now finds itself facing even more daunting task of redefining and reconstructing nation whose institutions, politics, economy and sense of purpose had been bankrupted by long rule of former Pres Suharto; agenda now must be defined by need to overcome his legacy of repression and military ruleand corruption; photo (M)

headline: TAKEOVER OFFER IS REJECTED
abstract: News Communications and Media PLC of Britain rejects cash offer for whole company from Gannett Co; graph (S)

headline: Ex-Publisher Assails Paper In Los Angeles
abstract: Otis Chandler, former president of Los Angeles Times and former chairman of Times Mirror, its parent company, offers sweeping denunciation of newspaper's current management for its 'unrealistic and impossible' circulation goals, its 'unbelievably stupid and unprofessional' agreement to share profits with management of Staples sports center, and its contribution to decline in morale among newspaper's staff; Chandler, in letter to newspaper's staff, denounces publisher Kathryn M Downing and Times Mirror chief executive Mark H Willes (M)

headline: Investors Can Taste a Nasdaq 4,000
abstract: investors ca

headline: Shares Show Wide Gains As Interest Rate Fears Ease
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 128.23 points, to 10,401.23; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 21.79 points, to 1,304.60; Nasdaq composite index rises 59.12 points, or 2.2 percent, to 2,795.97; graph; tables (M)

headline: Updating the Record Album
abstract: Letter by R D Streeter responds to Dec 9 article on transferring long-playing records to compact disc format; says earlier method of using audio cassettes was not properly considered

headline: GTE AGREES TO SELL MORE PHONE LINES TO CITIZENS UTILITIES
abstract: GTE Corp, local telephone company being acquired by Bell Atlantic Corp, agrees to sell 106,850 phone lines in Illinois to Citizens Utilities Co for $303 million (S)

headline: Squeezing an Album Cover to Fit in a Jewel Case
abstract: Advice oÈ

headline: Storing Your Life in a Virtual Desktop; Web-Based Storage and Software Reinvents an Old Idea, the Network Computer
abstract: Old idea, the network computer, is being revived to protect against crashes and make files accessible from almost anywhere; such virtual desktops allow users to have constant access to their files, their address books and their calendars; so far, virtual-desktop services are mostly available in bits and pieces; packages discussed; photos; drawing (M)

headline: SWAZILAND SUGAR
abstract: Royal Swaziland Sugar Corp makes offer to buy rival, Mhlume Sugar Co, for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: MEDICAL MANAGER TO ACQUIRE PHYSICIAN COMPUTER
abstract: The Medical Manager Corporation, an Internet company and software maker focusing on the health-care market, agreed yesterday to buy Physician Computer Network Inc. for $53 million in cash and stock. Physician Computer, a seller of software for doctors' offices, said it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The company, based in Morris Plains, N.J., said its reorganization plan included the sale of its assets to Medical Manager. Medical Manager, based in Elmwood Park, N.J., said it would pay $15.5 million in cash and $37.5 million in stock. It will also assume an undisclosed amount of liabilities of Physician Computer.

headline: SANWA TO CUT 1,000
abstract: Brokerage affiliates of Sanwa Bank Ltd--Universal Securities Co, Dai-Ichi Securities Co, Taiheiyo Securities Co and Towa Securities Co--say they will cut nearly 1,000 employees and almost third of their branches next April; combined brokerage firm, Tsubasa Securities Co, will have almost 3,700 employees and 128 branch offices, down from 168 (S)

headline: Wheelchair Maker Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Graham-Field Health Products Inc, leading maker of wheelchairs, files for bankruptcy protection from creditors after failed attempts to sell company, which has had five consecutive quarters of losses (S)

headline: SINGAPORE BROKERAGE MERGER
abstract: Vickers Ballas Holdings and GK Goh Holdings, two of Singapore's leading brokerage firms, merge to form biggest brokerage firm on island state; new firm will be called Goh, Vickers, with Goh Geok Khim as executive chairman (S)

headline: Madison Avenue Plays the Millennium for Laughs
abstract: Advertising industry embraces millennium marketing with fervor and with humor; worries about what Year 2000 might bring, particularly in terms of potential problems with computers, are being played down or played for laughs in almost every advertising campaign centered on millennium; photo (M)

headline: London's Fashion Tribes Find Inspiration on Dancefloor : Glamour Comes Back to the Club
abstract: LONDON—  Nightclubbing hasn't profoundly influenced fashion since Bianca Jagger shook her Halston-clad booty in the '70s New York superclub Studio 54. When disco died, champagne, cocaine and glamour were replaced by jeans, T-shirts and a pocket full of E. You could not — and, God forbid, would not — dance to nosebleed-inducing techno music in anything more than a tight, white pair of Calvins.

headline: Treasury Prices Keep Rising; 30-Year's Yield Slips to 6.10%
abstract: US Treasury bond prices gain for third consecutive session; price of 30-year Treasury bond rises 16/32, to 100 12/32; yield falls to 6.10 percent from 6.13 percent; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: SYBASE TO PURCHASE CREATOR OF FINANCIAL WEB SITES
abstract: Sybase To Purchase Creator of Financi

headline: Ivory Coast Coup Draws French Reply
abstract: France says it wants to send small numbers of troops to Ivory Coast to protect Henri Konan Bedie, ousted president, and to evacuate roughly 20,000 French nationals should that become necessary, but country's new ruler, Gen Robert Guei, refuses entry to French reinforcements; Bedie has reportedly taken sanctuary with French garrison (M)

headline: Lord Group Names A New President
abstract: Roger Chiocchi is named president and chief operating officer at Lord Group, assuming duties from Jim Hood, who has been chief executive for last four years (S)

headline: HERSHEY REDUCES ITS EARNINGS ESTIMATE FOR THIS YEAR
abstract: Hershey Foods Corp warns that its profit for 1999 will miss forecasts as problems stemming from new computer system hurt business (S)

headline: Despite Conditions, Many Turks See Destiny In Closer Tie to Europe
abstract: Turks welcome European Union's declaration that Turkey is a candidate state destined to join the union on the basis of the same criteria as applied to the other candidate states (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Herbert E. Ehlers and David G. Shell; Heritage Capital Appreciation Fund
abstract: SOMETIMES, Herbert E. Ehlers and David G. Shell sound as if they would rather be venture capitalists than money managers.    ''In a capitalist society like America, wealth is created through long-term ownership of growing businesses,'' said Mr. Ehlers, co-lead portfolio manager with Mr. Shell of the $287.1 million Heritage Capital Appreciation fund in Tampa, Fla. ''We talk about buying businesses, not shares of stock.''

headline: Four Agencies Make Deals in Health Care
abstract: Cordiant Communications Group in London agrees to acquire Healthworld Corp in New York for stock valued at about $185.4 million; Grey Healthcare Group, part of Grey Advertising, acquires Consumer Health Sciences; terms undisclosed; Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide acquires Feinstein Kean Partners; terms undisclosed; Lowe Healthcare Worldwide acquires International Pharmaceutical Research; terms undisclosed (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises on signs that OPEC kept close to its production limits last month as it sought to trim world inventories; in New York, crude oil for December delivery rises 17 cents, to $22.56 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: High Bond Yields Hurt Dow, But Technology Shares Rise  Rising long-term interest rates hurt some segments of the stock market as concerns mounted about what Federal Reserve policy makers might do about interest rates at a meeting today. The yield on the 30-year Treasury rose to 6.44 percent from 6.37 percent on Friday.

headline: VERTICALNET TO ACQUIRE NECX EXCHANGE
abstract: VerticalNet Inc acquires Necx Exchange LLC for $105 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: MURDOCH LOOKS TO GERMANY
abstract: News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch says British Sky Broadcasting, pay-TV company in which News Corp owns 40 percent stake, is in talks to buy 25 percent stake in Premiere World, German pay-TV company controlled by Kirch Group (S)

headline: Japan Replaces Leader Of Bank-Overhaul Agency
abstract: Michio Ochi, Japan's former Economic Planning Agency chief, will replace Hakuo Yanagisawa, widely respected head of special Financial Reconstruction Commission that is in charge of reorganizing country's banks; analysts say move may be sign that Government is no longer aggressive in pursuing further reforms of banking system (S)

headline: Talks Continue on Ford Motor Contract
abstract: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers union and the Ford Motor Company continued their talks over a new labor contract past a midnight Friday deadline.    Earlier this week, the union told Ford that it would end the current contract at 11:59 P.M. on Friday and would call a strike if no agreement had been reached by then on a contract covering 101,000 unionized workers.

headline: Xerox Warns That Results Will Be Short Of Projections
abstract: Xerox Corp warns analysts that its third-quarter results will be dismal; says revenue will not top $4.61 billion in reported in quarter last year, and its earnings could be as much as 12 percent it earned in third quarter of 1998 (M)a

headline: Reporter Gets A Subpoena On Interview In '95 Killing
abstract: Trish O'Kane, writer for quarterly magazine Intelligence Report, which is published by Southern Poverty Law Center, has been subpoenaed to provide tape recordings and notes of interview with Randall Lee Rojas, accused with two others of beating black man, Milton Walker Jr, to death in 1995 in California in allegedly racially motivated crime; she reportedly told Federal investigator that Rojas admitted committing a murder; prosecutors decided not to seek subpoena, which was sought by Rojas's co-defendants; magazine will fight subpoena (M)

headline: U.S. Agrees To Pay China $28 Million For Bombing
abstract: US will pay China $28 million in compensation for damage to Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, which was bombed by NATO warplanes during air war against Serbia; China will pay US $2.87 million for damage to American Embassy and other diplomatic buildings during week of anti-American demonstrations that followed bombing (M)

headline: Broadcaster in Buyback
abstract: Sinclair Broadcast Group plans to buy back up to $300 million of its common stock (S)

headline: SONY STOCK SPLIT
abstract: Sony Corp's board approves two-for-one stock split effective May 19, 2000, after threefold surge in its shares this year; graph (S)

headline: In Strong Pursuit of Luxury; But U.S. Designers Are Passed By in Race to Consolidate
abstract: European fashion houses are being acquired at frenzy pace at high prices; Hermes recently bought 36 percent of Jean Paul Gaultier for $26 million; Fendi sold itself to LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton and Prada for $1 billion, and names like Armani are seen as takeover targets; analysts suggest that Calvin Klein, which is on the block, may not receive same impressive multiples that are going to European counterparts; American companies have reputation for being too loose with their labels, applying name to array of products other than apparel; other recent mergers in industry noted; charts; photos (M)

headline: Amazon Sues Big Bookseller Over System For Shopping
abstract: Amazon.com sues rival Internet book and music seller Barnesandnoble.com, accusing it of illegally copying Amazon's patented checkout system and demanding immediate end to its use; if Amazon.com is successful in suit, it could have broad ramifications for development of E-commerce; retailers that use variations of popular 'one click' checkout method, which allows customers to make repeat purchases with one click of mouse instead of having to fill out credit card and billing information with each shopping trip, could be forced to desist or pay licensing fee to Amazon.com (M)

headline: NORTHGATE EXPLORATION TO ACQUIRE A ROYAL OAK MINE
abstract: Northgate Exploration agrees to buy Kemess gold and copper mine in northern British Columbia for $180 million; Kemess is one of three mines belonging to Royal Oak Mines, insolvent company based in Kirkland, Wash (S)

headline: That Reminds Me . . .
abstract: Marriott Hotels executive J W Marriott Jr, accepting 1999 Albert Schweitzer Leadership Award, recounts story about a gentleman at a restaurant to illustrate his concern with service; photo (M)

headline: G.M. Is Said to Be in Talks To Buy Engines From Honda
abstract: General Motors Corp is talking with Honda Motor Co about three-way deal in which GM would use engines designed by Honda in cars GM builds in North America; negotiations also involve Isuzu Motors; Fuji Heavy Industries, maker of Subaru cars, has acknowledged that it is discussing alliance with GM, in which GM would take minority equity stake in Fuji; GM is not negotiating to take equity position in Honda (M)

headline: BRAZIL UTILITY SHAKE-UP
abstract: Representatives of minority shareholders in Companhia Energetica de Minas Gerais (Cemig), Brazilian electric utility controlled by Minas Gerais state, are ousted in display of anti-privatization ire by Gov Itamar Franco, former President; Cemig executives--from AES Corp, Southern Co and Grupo Opportunity--are dismissed after state court ruled their 1997 purchase of voting-rights stake in Cemig for about $1 billion did not give them veto power over investment decisions; investors plan to appeal decision (S)

headline: In Occupied Chechnya, Order Without Allegiance
abstract: As the Russian Army closes in on Chechnya's besieged capital, Grozny, it is using a fresh strategy: promising Chechens that their bedraggled towns will be spared a relentless bombardment if they surrender, then attempting to secure loyalty by restoring services like gas and electricity.    But this month's capture of Gudermes, the bleak but strategically important second largest city in Chechnya, shows that it is one thing to scare Chechen civilians into submission, and quite another to win their allegiance.

headline: Understatement, at $5 Billion
abstract: Profile of Warren A Stephens of Little Rock, Ark, who, following his father's stroke about a year ago, is effectively in charge of Stephens Inc investment firm and other family interests; photo (M)

headline: Partnership, From Cradle To Campus
abstract: ON college campuses, there are now ''nonsmoking'' dorms and ''quiet study'' dorms. But with fresh-faced undergraduates increasingly armed with laptops, cell phones, Palm Pilots and -- most important -- ideas, it won't be long before there are ''entrepreneurs only'' halls, too.     And with all the software and Internet companies being spawned by intrepid undergrads, you may soon be reading of sizable alumni contributions from chief executives with the ink barely dry on their diplomas.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Raises Interest Rates On Concern About Inflation  The Federal Reserve raised the federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent, saying that the combination of strong growth and low unemployment had left the economy vulnerable to inflation.    It was the third time this year that the central bank has raised rates to slow the economy, and the move clearly signaled that the Fed's growing faith in technology's ability to improve efficiency and temper inflationary pressures has its limits. [Page A1.]

headline: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Pop Goes the Classroom
abstract: Profs Marianne M Jennings-Stephen K Happel article questions use of TV stars and tycoons, such as Oprah Winfrey and Michael Milken, as business school educators; says they fear that higher education is being reduce to little more than talk-show format; drawing (M)

headline: BANK REJECTS TAKEOVER BID
abstract: South Africa's Standard Bank rejects $4.4 billion takeover bid by Nedcor, saying proposed stock merger undervalues Standard; graph (S)

headline: BETTING ON A TURNAROUND
abstract: Nissan Motor Co chief operating officer Carlos Ghosn says company's executive committee, including Ghosn, will resign if Nissan fails to post profit in year ending in March 2001; photo (S)

headline: E.D.S. TO SELL COMPUTER SERVICES UNIT TO WILLIS STEIN
abstract: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation plans to sell its community banking-services business to the closely held Chicago investment firm Willis Stein & Partners L.P. The two companies have not agreed on a sale price, an E.D.S. spokeswoman said. The E.D.S. unit, which had $142 million in sales last year, provides computer services to about 500 small independent banks. After the sale, the division will be based in Dallas and operate as an independent company. E.D.S. shares fell $3.25 each, to $66.75, in New York Stock Exchange trading. The announcement was made after the close of United States markets.

headline: TURKEY IS INVITED TO APPLY FOR SEAT IN EUROPEAN UNION
abstract: European Union accepts Turkey as a candidate for membership and also agrees to a plan to bring in more of the formerly Communist nations of Eastern and Central Europe; will review its common strategy on Russia in view of its moves in Chechnya, apply trade terms more strictly, suspend some provisions of a partnership agrement and shift funds from technical programs to 'humanitarian needs' created by Chechen crisis; Turkey welcomes European offer, but balks at some of terms for its admittance; photo (M)

headline: From Reindeer to Noisemakers, Party Supplies on the Internet
abstract: Web sites help with party planning and sell party goods; photo (M)

headline: HONG KONG PHONE STAKE
abstract: Japan's NTT Mobile Communications Network will buy stake in Hong Kong's Hutchison Telephone Co, mobiel phone venture owned by Hutchison Whampoa and Motorola; Motorola's interest in company will be reduced to 25.1 percent from 30 percent after acquisition (S)

headline: Overseas Money Flows In, Lifting Latin Stock Markets
abstract: Stock markets in Latin America are on the rise, fueled by overseas investment money; rally could be indication of return to economic growth in many of region's countries next year; much of rally has been fueled by relief over potential interest rate increases in US; graphs (M)

headline: OTIS TO INVEST IN LG
abstract: South Korean conglomerate

headline: Carter, Proclaiming 'It's Yours,' Celebrates New Era for Panama
abstract: US hands over full sovereignty and control over Panama Canal to Panama, ending nearly century of American dominance; former Pres Jimmy Carter, who negotiated transfer with Gen Omar Torrijos in 1977, signs handover documents with Pres Mireya Moscoso at Miraflores Locks; says treaties represent passage to new relationship between Panama and US; voices hope that cooperation will continue with investment as Panama begins transformation of US military bases into businesses; Moscoso pledges to meet challenges that come with treaties; Panamanian officials are slighted by absence of Pres Clinton at ceremonies; some US politicians, opposed to canal's transfer, warn Panamanian government could endanger waterway's security through poor management and awarding of concessions to Hong Kong port operating company; maps; photo (M)

headline: Managing Editor Will Remain With The Wall Street Journal
abstract: Wall Street Journal's managing editor Paul E Steiger turns down offer to head all financial news operations at CNN; company and Independent Association of Publishers' Employees/Communications Workers of America Local 1096 end more than seven months of sometimes tense negotiations with agreement to resolve volatile issue of retirement benefits; provisions of agreement noted (M)

headline: It's agency hunting season for everything from beauty products to boysenberry jam.
abstract: Many marketers are naming or changing advertising agencies; some specific changes discussed (M)

headline: News of Possibly Breaking Even Ignites Advanced Micro Shares
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc says it might break even in fourth quarter, news that sends it shares up 23 percent; shares rise $5.25, to $28.25; forecast surprises many analysts, who had expected a loss (M)

headline: Doubting Rescuers, Banker Suffocated
abstract: Investigators said yesterday in Monte Carlo that the billionaire banker Edmond Safra, barricaded in a bathroom during an attack on his penthouse apartment, died of smoke inhalation because he apparently mistook police officers and firefighters for intruders and refused to come out. Mr. Safra had a cell phone with him when he took refuge in the bathroom and spoke from there with his wife, who encouraged him to come out, a prosecutor said. But Mr. Safra heard banging on the walls and believed intruders were still after him.      Article, Page 16.

headline: DAEWOO BOND LOSSES TO BE SHARED
abstract: South Korea's top financial watchdog agency Financial Supervisory Commission says nation's brokerage firms will share losses from Daewoo bonds held by investment trusts; largest brokerage firms--securities firms affiliated with Hyundai Motor, Samsung Group and Daewoo--are expected to suffer heavy losses because of their exposure to bonds issued by ailing conglomerates (S)

headline: QUESTION OF EVIDENCE: A special report.; To Bomb Sudan Plant, or Not: A Year Later, Debates Rankle
abstract: James Risen, in special report Question of Evidence, contends that Clinton's Administration's decision to bomb pharmaceutical plant in Sudan 14 months ago was far more difficult to make than it has acknowledged and there were numerous voices of dissent; examination of decision, based on interviews with key participants, shows that officials throughout Government raised doubts up to eve of attack about whether US had sufficient information linking factory to either chemical weapons or to Osama bin Laden, Saudi exile they blame for blowing up US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania; national security adviser Samuel R Berger, who played pivotal role in approving strike, says he was not aware of any questions about strength of evidence before attack; some officials say that Sec of State Madeleine K Albright and Under Sec of State Thomas R Pickering encouraged State Dept intelligence analysts to kill report being drafted that said bombing was not justified; map; photos (M)

headline: Lobbyist Turns to Internet To Influence Policy Makers
abstract: Richard Cook, lobbyist for satellite company PanAmSat, contends that company's competitors are outspending him 5 to 1 on issue of privatization of access to satellite services; says he will use Internet to give his client better chance for equal access to important Congressional offices; he has started campaign on Internet directed toward busy Congressional aides; his tactic is departure from conventional Internet campaigning, in which goal is to generate hundreds of e-mail messages to Congressional offices to show support for issue; Cook's campaign focuses solely on policy makers and their aides; photo (M)

headline: Telecommuting to Pick Up as Workers Iron Out Kinks
abstract: Thousands of employees who tried working from home part time during 1990's have returned to the office full time, but experts say this is lull before a new telecommuting storm driven by demographics, tight labor market and technological advances; drawing (M)

headline: Cruise Line Account Goes to Arnold
abstract: Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines, part of Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd, awards its integrated marketing account to Arnold Communications; billings estimated at more than $50 million (S)

headline: Media Talk; No Good Way to Break the Bad News
abstract: Mortimer B Zuckerman says he delivered news that he was selling Atlantic Monthly to magazine's writers and editors over speakerphone after he learned that news was about to be published elsewhere, before he could get to Boston to deliver news personally (S)

headline: Unesco's New Director Is Envoy From Japan, Its Biggest Donor
abstract: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization nominates Amb Koichiro Matsuura as director general; Japan, largest contributor to Unesco budget, lobbied strongly for him; election brings to surface widespread unhappiness with way current director general, Federico Mayor Zaragoza, runs organization (M)

headline: Internet Users Step Into the World of van Gogh
abstract: Intel Corp's free art gallery Web site allows users to 'enter' two of van Gogh's most famous canvases, The Yellow House and The Bedroom, and to look under van Gogh's bed, or walk across street from house and see it as artist may have seen it as he walked home; photo (S)

headline: Lazard and Daiwa Expand Japan Link
abstract: Lazard Brothers & Co in London and Daiwa Securities SB Capital Markets say they expanded their relationship to serve each other's clients in Japan; two companies will offer joint mergers and acquisitions, restructuring and other financial advice services (S)

headline: From a Giant Job to an Internet Fledgling
abstract: Broadband Sports Inc, fledgling Internet company, hires Richard D Nanula as its chairman and chief executive; Nanula resigned as president and chief operating officer of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc in April; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Plans to Crack Down On I.R.S. Agent Misdeeds  Urged by Congress to get tough on abuse of taxpayers, a new team of Treasury agents plans a sharp increase in investigations of I.R.S. employees for misconduct. Indeed, the number of cases expected to be opened against I.R.S. employees will soon nearly equal the number of cases of suspected of tax crimes.    The I.R.S. goal has stirred worries even within the inspector general's own staff that investigators are being forced to search for far more misdeeds than may exist. [Page A1.]

headline: BUSINESS SENTIMENT IMPROVES
abstract: Japan's index of economic sentiment at businesses rose in July-September quarter to its highest in more than two year as companies cut inventories and excess production capacity (S)

headline: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
abstract: Excerpt from earlier article on Dick Hyman's Century of Jazz Piano, interactive CD-ROM in which Dick Hyman traces history of jazz (S)

headline: Kenneth L. Schnitzer, 70, Dies; Innovative Houston Developer
abstract: Kenneth L Schnitzer, visionary Texas real estate developer and civic leader whose 30 commercial buildings form much of Houston skyline, dies at age 70; photos (M)

headline: Cell Phones Designed to Call Only a Single Number: 911
abstract: SecureArt offers sleek cell phone, the Magnavox Mobile911 that company official says provides first two rules of self-defense: ability to dial only one number: 911, and can also emit a siren noise by pressing button on the unit; telephone, which costs $199, does not require cellular phone service or additional fees because of its limited functions; unit photo (S)

headline: NESTLE SELLS FROZEN FOODS UNIT
abstract: World Business Briefing: Nestle Sells Frozen Foods Unit**

headline: Military Technology to Help You Guide Your Personal Tank
abstract: Military night-vision technology is making its way into American automobiles to enable drivers to see fives times as far as they can usually see with headlights, and even enables them to see objects hidden by darkness or obscured by trees by monitoring for infrared radiation; new system is offerd to buyers of Cadillac's new DeVille sedan as a $2,000 option; was developed by Raytheon Co; sketch describing how technology works (M)

headline: SEOUL TO ISSUE BONDS
abstract: South Korean government will issue up to five trillion won ($4.22 billion) of won-denominated government bonds to keep local currency from rising too fast against dollar; Finance Ministry is working to reduce oversupply of dollars caused by recent influx of foreign investment funds (S)

headline: INVESTIGATORS DIG FOR MASS GRAVES AT MEXICO BORDER
abstract: Mexican authorities, backed by FBI investigators, begin excavating sites near Texas border they believe may hold bodies of scores of Mexicans and Americans who disappeared in last several years, possible victims of drug traffickers; search is prompted by tip from informer, identified as former Mexican police officer, who reportedly acknowledged complicity in several killings and identified locations on outskirts of Cuidad Juarez, across from El Paso, as site of at least two mass graves where as many as 200 people may be buried; some those killed reportedly were providing information to US law enforcement agencies (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Edward Boches, executive creative director at Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass., part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to chief creative officer. He succeeds Paul Silverman, who was named to the new post of founding creative officer.    * Silvana Imperiali was named to the new post of chief operating officer at Real Media Inc., New York. She had been marketing director at Publicitas/Globe Media, New York.

headline: Where On-Line Traders Find Satisfaction
abstract: Who's happiest with their E-broker? On-line brokerage customers of Fidelity Investments, according to a new survey by Spectrem Group and NFO Interactive, two market research firms.    The study, conducted in June, polled 857 on-line investors. It first asked investors  what they considered the most important attributes of their E-brokers' Web sites. If the answer was, say, speed of execution, the survey then asked them how satisfied they were on that count.

headline: STUNG BY DEBATE, INDONESIAN LEADER ENDS ELECTION BID
abstract: Indonesia's Pres B J Habibie, who succeeded Pres Suharto after forced resignation in May 1998, withdraws Presidential election bid after newly elected National Assembly condemns his record and rejects his recent state of the nation address; says he is satisfied with his term in office and is happy that democracy has started in Indonesia; decision leaves opposition leader Megawati Sukarnoputri and Muslim leader Abdurrahman Wahid as opponents in Presidential election; assembly votes to accept results of August 30 referendum, in which 87.5 percent of people of East Timor voted for independence; photos (M)

headline: Flavors Are the Same, but New iMacs Have Some Spice
abstract: Peter H Lewis (State of the Art) column evaluates three new iMac models from Apple Computer; says among new models' one drawback is lack of removable storage device, while on plus side, iMacs offer number of advanced features not found on any other home computer; prices range from $999 to $1,499 (M)

headline: WebTV Puts It All Together
abstract: State of the Art column on latest television set-top box powered by WebTV Networks, subsidiary of Microsoft Corp; box can seamlessly make conventional television set function like at least three different devices: Internet-linked computer, television set with satellite service and enhanced digital video recorder; new service easily merges these functions, allowing viewers to not only watch television programs but also interact with them in real time; photos (M)

headline: East Timorese Celebrate in Their Newly Freed Capital
abstract: East Timor begins rebirth with huge and solemn religious procession in capital of Dili led by Roman Catholic Bishop Carlos Felipe Ximenes Belo, hours after departure of remaining contingent of Indonesian soldiers; photo (M)

headline: SENATE KILLS TEST BAN TREATY IN CRUSHING LOSS FOR CLINTON; EVOKES VERSAILLES PACT DEFEAT
abstract: Senate, in crushing defeat for Pres Clinton, rejects treatty banning all underground nuclear arms testing, 51-48; vote comes after Sen Trent Lott rebuffs Clinton's personal plea to delay action for national security reasons; defeat is first for international security pact since 1920 defeat of Versaille Treaty; Clinton scores vote, mostly along party lines, as 'reckless' and 'partisan' act; says he will continue to seek testing ban; photos (M)

headline: Irate at Mannesmann Deal, Vodafone Weighs Response
abstract: Vodafone Airtouch PLC is privately considering range of options including hostile bid for Mannesmann AG after German company's move to acquire Orange PLC, number 3 British wireless operator, for $33 billion; Vodafone's chief executive Christopher Gent is said to be furious at Mannesmann (M)

headline: Spiffing Up a Dirty Business; Russia's Oil Barons Say Wildcatter Capitalism Era Is Over
abstract: Russia's major oil corporations, born in rough-and-tumble world of backroom political deals, claim to be making effort to escape their murky pasts; new mantra of Russian oil companies is same one invoked in realm of Western business: corporate strategies, transparent finances, independent directors and professional managers; not everyone is ready to believe that transformations are much more than symbolic; Sibneft, Russia's sixth-largest oil company, is test case of whether industry can reinvent itself, or whether it really wants to; recent changes at company detailed; chart; drawing (M)

headline: BID FOR AEROSPACE COMPANY
abstract: Swedish aerospace company Saab makes cash bid of 179 kronor a share, worth about $600 million, for military-materials company Celsius (S)

headline: JOSTENS, MAKER OF CLASS RINGS, AGREES TO BUYOUT
abstract: Jostens Inc accepts $850 million buyout from company controlled by Investcorp; takeover group includes Jostens management (S)

headline: Ousted I.R.S. Collector Charges Favoritism
abstract: Peter W Coons, ousted federal tax collector for northern California, charges Robert Ah Nee, top Internal Revenue Service official in San Francisco, repeatedly gave wealthy and politically connected taxpayers unwarranted breaks, including reduced tax bills, refunds and deferred payments in 1996 and 1997; levels charges in testimony before administrative law judge for Merit Systems Protection Board at hearing to get back job under federal law that protects whistle-blowers; was dismissed for allegedly misusing government computers and for lying to investigators about it; acknowledges misuse of computers, but says charges are smokescreen for his removal; says he stood in way of pattern of favoritism for wealthy, especially those represented by former IRS executives and federal prosecutors; photo (M)

headline: Sale of Shares Reaps Triple the Goal Set by Hong Kong
abstract: Hong Kong government's offering called Tracker Fund of Hong Kong raises $4.3 billion, more than triple government's target price of $1.3 billion; that makes it the largest stock offering in history of Hong Kong stock exchange; success of offering confounds analysts in Hong Kong, who predicted investors would shun a fund that tracks performance of Kong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index; offering comes after two years of economic anguish (M)

headline: Counting Down the Megahertz
abstract: Many Silicon Valley companies are setting up command centers to monitor customers' computers on New Year's Eve; Carly Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, say she will sip champagne with employees at company's Palo Alto command center; photo (S)

headline: Courtship Of Variable Annuities
abstract: Article on Sun America's ad campaign for its investment products, especially annuities, that uses former child stars Brandon Cruz, Paul Petersen and Jon Provost; photos (M)

headline: GOODYEAR TO CLOSE ITALIAN FACTORY AND CUT 500 JOBS
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co is closing its plant in Italy and will eliminate 500 jobs (S)

headline: A Bleak Hour for South Africa Miners
abstract: Future looks bleak for South Africa's gold miners; even though price of gold is going back up, outlook is grim following layoff of 2,895 miners this month; since 1989, number of gold miners has dropped to about 180,000 from about 514,000; photo (M)

headline: Waste Management Names Chief Executive
abstract: Waste Management Inc names A Maurice Myers, chairman of Yellow Corp, as its chief executive; Myers succeeds Robert Miller as chief executive and Ralph Whitworth as chairman (S)

headline: Head to Head In Mexico: D.E.A. Agents And Suspects
abstract: Two American drug-enforcement agents who had been driving around a Mexican border city with an informer were chased, surrounded and nearly killed two weeks ago by a posse of suspected drug traffickers and their heavily armed bodyguards, United States and Mexican officials said yesterday.    After a standoff that lasted for nearly 20 minutes on a busy street in downtown Matamoros, just across the Texas border from Brownsville, the agents finally talked their way to safety by identifying themselves and warning the traffickers that they would never be allowed to get away with murdering American agents.

headline: The Shape Of Justice Is Undefined In Cambodia
abstract: Cambodia is moving toward some sort of trials for some of former Khmer Rouge even though Prime Min Hun Sen had hoped to 'dig a hole and bury the past'; contentious questions still remain over whether any such trials will meet international standards of fairness and legal rigor; critics fear outcomes will be crafted to suit Hun Sen's political needs rather than to examine the deaths of more than a million people by Khmer Rouge (M)

headline: Andersen Consulting's Chief Makes E-Commerce New Goal
abstract: Andersen Consulting says Joe W Forehand, partner with 27 years of experience at firm, will be its new chief executive; Forehand says he plans to make e-commerce central part of consulting firm and that company intends to take stakes in clients more frequently; Forehand replaces George T Shaheen, who resigned in September (M)

headline: HONG KONG INTERNET DEAL
abstract: AT&T Corp to sell its Hong Kong operation that sells Internet services to consumers and small-business customers to Iasiaworks; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: ACNIELSEN ACQUIRES MEDIA MONITORING OF BRITAIN
abstract: ACNielsen Corp acquires Media Monitoring Services Ltd for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Patents; Boxer shorts that double as briefs, hand-shaped hair dryers and other gifts for future holidays.
abstract: Patents column lists some new inventions that could be ready for gift-giving by next year (M)

headline: It's Demons vs. Angels in Computer Game With a Religious Theme
abstract: Robert Westmoreland, part owner of Valusoft, promotes company's first Christian action computer game; game's playful approach to religious instruction is raising skepticism in Christian community and qualms among some retail chains; photo (M)

headline: UNISYS PLANS TO ADD 4,000 TO WORK FORCE IN COMING YEAR
abstract: Unisys Corp plans to add about 4,000 employees next year, expanding its work force by 11 percent; about 85 percent of new employees will work for Unisys's service business; rest will work in computer manufacturing (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COMMODORE HOLDINGS LTD., Hollywood, Fla., a cruise line operator, said it would buy the ship Crown Dynasty from the closely held Neptune Maritime, Helsinki, Finland, for $86.2 million.    DATA SYSTEMS AND SOFTWARE INC., Mahwah, N.J., agreed to sell its stake in Tower Semiconductor to Israel Corp., a holding company that invests in shipping, electronics and other industries, for about $30.9 million.    MERRILL LYNCH & CO., New York, the brokerage firm, agreed to buy 3 percent of Multex.com Inc., the online provider of securities research, and split up to $100 million in revenue as Multex.com develops research Web sites for Merrill.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee prices rise on expectations that prolonged dry spell is damaging crops in Brazil, world's top grower; in New York, coffee for December delivery rises 3.5 cents, or 3.6 percent, to $1.002 a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Creative Turmoil At Arista; Founder and Chief Resists a Successor
abstract: Clive Davis's independent attitude and passion for New York-based company he founded, Arista Records, has drawn Davis into clashes with Arista's corporate parents, BMG Entertainment and its German owner, Bertelsmann AG; tensions reflect broader anxieties in music industry, which, as it consolidates, is being transformed from freewheeling creative playground into more businesslike enterprise; Bertelsmann-BMG executives say with Davis's contract expiring in June, they decided to offer him chairman's position and anoint younger successor, Antonio Reid, of LaFace Records; Davis at age 66 has resisted notion of grooming a successor; chart; photos (M)

headline: Warner-Lambert Signs Up a Partner to Work on Cancer Drug
abstract: Onyx Pharmaceuticals Inc enters collaborative agreement with Warner-Lambert Co to jointly develop and market new cancer drug; Warner will pay Onyx up to $155 million; Onyx has developed novel therapy that uses genetically modified virus to kill cancer cells; drug has been tested in more than 200 patients, and Onyx says it expects to begin Phase 3 trial concerning head and neck cancer by end of year (M)

headline: ENTRADE IN $50 MILLION DEAL FOR NATIONWIDE AUCTION
abstract: Entrade Inc acquires Nationwide Auction Systems for about $540 million in cash, stock and notes (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Dow Takes On a New, High-Technology Look
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average, whose performance has trailed Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in recent years, drops four lagging stocks and substitutes four companies that have done much better; by adding two high-flying technology companies, Microsoft Corp and Intel Corp, editors of Wall Street Journal, who determine index's components, make it likely that Dow will be more volatile than it has been; Intel and Microsoft are first stocks traded on Nasdaq to join Dow average; other stocks being added, effective on Nov 1, are Home Depot and SBC Communications; companies being dropped are Chevron Corp, Sears, Roebuck & Co, Union Carbide Corp and Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co (Market Place column) (M)

headline: VIBRANT FRENCH ECONOMY
abstract: Consumer spending in France grew at an unexpectedly fast rate in October, providing further evidence that Europe's second-largest economy is also its fastest growing. The national statistics office said spending for manufactured goods was 2.3 percent higher than in September. The report excluded spending for services, which account for 40 percent of total consumer spending, suggesting that overall growth was even higher. The French government expects the economy to grow 2.3 percent this year and 3 percent next year, compared with expected growth of 1.4 percent this year and 2.7 percent next year in Germany, the biggest European economy.   John Tagliabue

headline: A JOINT BID FOR NIPPON CREDIT
abstract: Japan's Ito-Yokado, Softbank, Orix and Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance are jointly bidding for failed Nippon Credit Bank (S)

headline: Dow Falls in Mixed Trading As Nasdaq Hits a New High
abstract: Nasdaq composite index is up 1.22 points, to record 2,967.65; Dow Jones industrial average drops 81.35 points, to 10,648.51; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down 8.81 points, to 1,354.12; graph; chart (M)

headline: Opportunity Re-Knocks at Avon; Passed Over Before, a Woman Is Named Chief Executive
abstract: Avon Products Inc's president and chief operating officer Andrea Jung is named chief executive, replacing Charles Perrin; Jung and three other women at company were passed over in favor of Perrin, outsider with no experience in direct selling or cosmetics, 18 months ago; Avon board is counting on Jung to revive business that is facing tougher competition, slowing sales in US and credibility issue with disappointed investors and analysts; graph; photo (M)

headline: Hear, Hear, Please! 'Question Time' in Japan
abstract: The prime minister is at the lectern, struggling to field a series of increasingly challenging questions from the leader of the opposition. Jeers are rising in crescendo from the Parliament floor, and the few spectators allowed in are on the edge of their seats, fairly straining for a view.    The scene, known as question time, has been adopted straight from British politics. On the surface, just two weeks into its existence, it still may seem like a jolting innovation to some in the often soporific world of the Japanese Parliament.

headline: ITALIAN INSURANCE MERGER
abstract: Istituto Nazionale delle Assicurazioni accepts $12.5 billion bid after Assicurazioni Generalei gives INA's management role in combined company and sweetens its offer (S)

headline: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
abstract: Excerpt from earlier article on Powers of Ten Interactive, interactive CD-ROM dedicated to expanding ideas of husband-wife design team of Charles and Ray Eames (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Jobless Rate Stays at 4.1% And Inflation Appears Tame  The nation's jobless rate remained at 4.1 percent in November, matching the 30-year low hit in October. The Labor Department also said that 234,000 new jobs were created, and the average hourly wage for ordinary workers increased by only 2 cents an hour, to $13.41.

headline: KOREAN JOBLESS RATE DROPS
abstract: South Korea's jobless rate fell to 20-month low of 4.8 percent in September, sharp drop from 5.7 percent in August; number of people unemployed fell to 1.07 million from 1.24 million (S)

headline: Germany Proposes Some Tax-Free Stock Sales, Lifting Market
abstract: German Finance Ministry proposes plan to untangle web of cross-ownership in German companies that would allow banks and insurers to sell their huge industrial shareholdings without paying tax on profit, unleashing billions of dollars into German economy; tax, currently at 50 percent, is among highest in the world and has effectively prevented such share sales in past; if proposal becomes law it would reform the core of German corporate structure, which has been built around cross-ownership among banks, insurers and industrial conglomerates; present system has contributed to Germany's postwar economic boom but has been criticized for rigidity and arrogance toward smaller shareholders; banks and insurers have long wanted to prune such industrial shareholdings and reinvest proceeds in their own businesses; proposal sends Germany's stock market soaring; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Official Finishes Talks In Beijing
abstract: US Treasury Sec Lawrence H Summers finishes two days of meetings in China with both sides extolling financial cooperation and exuding friendship; but there is no sign of progress on China's entry into World Trade Organization (M)

headline: Vodafone Puts $127.7 Billion On the Table
abstract: Vodafone Airtouch PLC sweetens terms of offer for Mannesmann AG, bidding $127.7 billion in stock in move that if successful would vastly inflate size of wireless telephone company and fundamentally reshape Europe's rapidly growing telecommunications industry; offer is quickly spurned by Mannesmann; Vodafone chief executive Christopher Gent says no cash will be added to what he calls 'final offer'; Vodafone would acquire Orange PLC, which Mannesmann acquired last month; photo (M)

headline: DELAY IN DAEWOO RESTRUCTURING
abstract: Restructuring of Daewoo Group is expected to be delayed because debt-workout plans for affiliates are behind schedule (S)

headline: Once Again, Inflation Is a No-Show
abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.1 percent in November, smallest increase since June; Commerce Department reports retail sales jumped robust 0.9 percent in November; says nation's current-account deficit, measure of what Americans owe to foreign lenders, rose in third quarter to $89.95 billion, up 11.2 percent from second quarter; graph; chart (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)ú
