headline: CANADIAN AUTO PACT THREATENED
abstract: World Trade Organization rules in interim decision that Canadian law permitting Ford Motor Co, General Motors Corp and DaimlerChrysler to import vehicles into Canada without paying duty violates fair trade practices; Japan and European Union had challenged 1956 law because Canada imposes 6.5 percent import duty on other car makers; final ruling is due on Nov 25, but it can be appealed (S)

headline: Shares Close Little Changed Ahead of Fed Panel Meeting
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 8.57 points, to 10,760.75; Nasdaq composite index declines 1.61 points, to 3,219.54; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 1.67 points, to 1,394.39; graph; chart (M)

headline: In the specialized world of technology, two multimillion-dollar quests for more attention.
abstract: Specialized high-technology magazines PC Computing and Red Herring are waging multimillion-dollar campaigns to broaden their reach; PC Computing will revamp its content and design starting with December issue; will promote changes with $2 million ad campaign; Red Herring is running $5 million ad and promotion campaign to heighten awareness of its brand both in general business community and media buyers (M)

headline: Schwab Web Site Goes Down Yet Again
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp's Web trading site fails for almost two hours, third disruption in three days, because of unspecified software problem (S)

headline: What to Ask the Doctor
abstract: Matt Fleischer letter suggests Dr O Alton Barron, in November 4 article, should have offered suggestions for what to ask your doctor when you have arm pain and some common remedies for overuse strain

headline: Fox Film Group Names a New President
abstract: Fox Entertainment Group says Tom Rothman has been promoted to president of 20th Century Fox Film Group, giving him oversight of studio's two main movie divisions; Laura Ziskin resigns as president for production at Fox 2000 Pictures; she will be replaced by Elizabeth Gabler, while Rothman's position as head of production at 20th Century Fox will be taken by Hutch Parker (S)

headline: The news about industry growth is all good for 1999; forecasts for 2000 call for more of the same.
abstract: HOW upbeat are the two leading forecasters of advertising spending about the prospects for the marketing and media industries in 2000?    At a conference yesterday, they almost warbled a medley of ''Blue Skies'' and ''Cockeyed Optimist'' in outlining their predictions for strong, sustained growth next year.

headline: Air Canada Extends Deadline for Buying Canadian Airlines
abstract: Air Canada extended its offer tonight to purchase its struggling rival, Canadian Airlines International, until Dec. 23 to give itself more time to negotiate with the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, the largest shareholder in Canadian Airlines.    The offer of 92 million Canadian dollars by Air Canada, or $63 million,  had been scheduled to expire at 5 p.m. today. A combination of the two carriers would leave Canada with one coast-to-coast carrier.

headline: NEW FINANCIAL NEWSPAPER
abstract: Brazilian media companies Globo and Folha are investing $50 million to create as yet unnamed business newspaper (S)

headline: At Papal Mass in Caucasus, a High-Profile Orthodox Christian
abstract: Georgia's Pres Eduard Shevardnadze, who is Orthodox Christian, celebrates Mass with Pope John Paul II in capital of Tblisi in poignant reunion for two veterans of tumultous era of Communist rule; Pope's visit is also milestone in Catholic Church history, marking first papal visit to Caucasus and only second time any pope has set foot in predominantly Orthodox country in more than 1,000 years; John Paul's reception from Georgian Orthodox Church has been cordial but guarded (M)

headline: So Easy to Buy, Such a Struggle to Return
abstract: Most reputable online retailers give consumer 30 days to return product for refund, store credit or exchange; some merchants make it easier than others, and some consumers simply do not return items they bought online because procedure is so cumbersome; drawing (M)

headline: Long Term Appears Turbulent for Oil
abstract: Analysts say that of all the pressures on oil industry, one most likely to transform it in next two decades will be campaign to improve the environment; say that in shorter term, trends that will shape the industry will continue to be consolidation, cost consciousness and technology; photo (M)

headline: America Online Buys a Software Company
abstract: America Online Inc purchases closely held Tegic Communications, software company; financial terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Excerpts From Greenspan Talk on Financial Risk
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech Thursday night by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at a Washington conference on risk management sponsored by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency:      The decline in recent years in the equity premium -- the margin by which the implied rate of discount on common stock exceeds the riskless rate of interest -- should prompt careful consideration of the robustness of our portfolio risk-management models in the event this judgment proves wrong.

headline: Safra's Death Not Expected to Delay Big Bank Sale
abstract: Banking officials do not expect death of Edmond J Safra to delay $9.9 billion sale of his banking businesses to HSBC Holdings; although Safra had not been expected to have major role in banks' operations under new ownership, he had been expected to help HSBC hold onto 30,000 very wealthy clients of Republic New York Corp affiliate, Safra Republic Holdings (M)

headline: U.S. SEEKS TO CURB ISRAELI ARMS SALE TO CHINA AIR FORCE
abstract: Israel's sale of sophisticated $250 million airborne radar surveillance system to China raises serious concerns at Pentagon, and Clinton administration has reportedly urged Israel to cancel delivery of additional radar planes and to curb other weapons sales to China; senior Pentagon officials fear advanced radar system in particular will enhance China's ability to extend military might beyond its borders and threaten Taiwan; sale of radar system, as well as other Israeli arms deals with China, have put strain on administration's relationship with one of Washington's closest allies; Israeli government has assured administration officials that sale does not involve American technology, but Pentagon official says given amount of weaponry US shares with Israel, it is difficult to separate American technology from Israel's own; Phalcon radar system designed for Israeli Air Force, will be installed in Boeing 707; China is reportedly seeking four to eight more systems to place aboard Russian aircraft (M)

headline: CANADIAN PACIFIC'S STRONG RESULTS
abstract: Canadian Pacific Railway reports 32 percent gain in third-quarter earnings, to record $270 million (Canadian), or about $181 million (US) (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: Mike Munoz, Texas Rangers pitcher whose team is playing in American League division championship series against New York Yankees, is scratched from series after he drops new computer out of box and onto his foot, fracturing a toe (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Jones Industrials Drop On New Fears of Inflation  The Dow Jones industrial average and other stock market gauges plunged after an inflation report showed the biggest monthly increase in nine years in prices at the producer level and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, alarmed investors by warning that the stock market might be more risky than many people now believe.

headline: Business Travel; A good night's sleep on an international flight is often a top priority for corporate fliers.
abstract: THE personal requirements of hard-core business travelers haven't changed all that much since Chaucer wrote ''The Canterbury Tales'' in the 14th century. Speed and safety may dominate, but getting a decent night's sleep still ranks way up on the list.    ''I don't care who you are, you  re going to be grumpy and out of sorts if you've got sleep deprivation,'' said Dale Moss, the director of worldwide sales for British Airways.

headline: PROFITS AT AIR CANADA
abstract: Air Canada reports third-quarter profit of $124 million (Canadian) or about $83.1 million (US), in contrast to loss of $61 million (Canadian) a year earlier (S)

headline: PECO ENERGY UNIT BUYS UTILITY SERVICE COMPANIES
abstract: Peco Energy Co's Exelon Infrastructure Services Inc unit acquires five privately held utility service contracting companies for $194.5 million in cash, plus stock in Exelon; companies are Chowns Communications Inc, MRM Technical Group, OSP Consultants Inc, Syracuse Merit Electric Inc and Trinity Industries; Peco has agreed to merge with Unicom Corp (S)

headline: Honors
abstract: Howard Roffman, president at Lucas Licensing, part of Lucasfilm Ltd, and Jim Ward, vice president for marketing at Lucasfilm, are named EPM Entertainment Marketers of the Year at annual EPM Entertainment Marketing Conference, Los Angeles (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DYNEGY INC., Houston, a natural gas company, will have its $4 billion acquisition of the Illinova Corp., Decatur, Ill., an electric utility company, delayed until mid-January because the company has not completed its required sale of stakes in 11 power plants.    PAXAR CORP., White Plains, the world's biggest maker of woven labels for clothing, agreed to buy a German label company, Bornemann & Bick, based in Sprockhovel, for an undisclosed cash price.    SAKS INC., Birmingham, Ala., a department-store operator, said it would close two Younkers stores in Milwaukee and a Boston Store in Green Bay, Wis., to focus on other properties in the area.    BEST BUY CO., Eden Prairie, Minn., the largest United States consumer-electronics retailer, said its Internet unit invested $10 million in Etown.com, which provides information on products and retailers to buyers of electronics.

headline: In Chechnya, Its President Vows to Resist Russian Force
abstract: Chechnya Pres Aslan Maskhadov vows to repulse Russian invasion he says has already started; calls for international pressure to end what he says is daily Russian bombing of villages and towns; seeks meeting with Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin to avert full-scale war (M)d

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Nasdaq Sets Its 10th High In Last 11 Trading Sessions  Led by banks and financial companies, the stock market rose after a government report on productivity eased investors' worries that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates for a third time this year when policy makers meet on Tuesday. The Nasdaq composite index closed at its 10th record high in the last 11 sessions, rising 23.86 points, or 0.75 of a percent, to 3,221.15.    The Dow Jones industrial average rallied 174.02 points, or 1.64 percent, to 10,769.32. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 14.60 points, or 1.06 percent, to 1,396.06. [Page C3.]

headline: FRANKLIN SELECT STUDIES SALE OF SOME ASSETS
abstract: Franklÿ

headline: Even if the Fed Is Idle, Rates Are on the Rise
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column describes reasons why yields on US Treasuries are rising in wake of Federal Reserve's slight increase in interest rates; graph (M)

headline: The Real Thing
abstract: Coca-Cola is first soft-drink company to get its own version of Monopoly, called Coca-Cola Monopoly; playing pieces include Coke truck and bottle cap; photo (S)

headline: Blair Gives Ulster Job to Aide Brushed by Scandal
abstract: Britain's Prime Min Tony Blair appoints Peter Mandelson, his closest political confidant who was forced to leave Cabinet in financial scandal in 1998, to strategically crucial position of Northern Ireland Secretary; other Cabinet changes noted (M)

headline: Russia Says Its Forces Have Seized Chechen City
abstract: Russian officials say military forces have largely driven Islamic rebels from Gudermes, second-largest city in breakaway province of Chechnya; propose to move capital there from Grozny, underscoring intention to retake complete control of separatist republic; Deputy Prime Min Nikolai Koshman urges residents remaining Grozny to get out; International Committee of the Red Cross will pull workers out of Chechnya to focus on helping refugees in neighboring Ingushetia because of grave military situation; map; photo (M

headline: School a Rare Luxury for Rural Chinese Girls
abstract: Economics are keeping increasing number of children out of school in many parts of poor rural China as required fees at state schools have grown exponentially since central Govt largely stopped subsidizing primary education decade ago; education is financed by residents of poorest villages only when finances allow and far more often for boys than for girls; experts say aggressive Govt campaign to achieve 100 percent enrollment by year 2000 has pushed attendance up in more prosperous regions, but that only fraction of children are in school in number of poor rural areas; map; photos (M)

headline: An Opponent Of Arafat Is Wounded By Gunmen
abstract: Dr Muawiya Masri, Palestinian physician and legislator who signed petition against Palestinian Authority corruption, is shot and wounded by masked men, Nablus; thousands of people march through Ramallah in support of Yasir Arafat, who has cracked down harshly on dissenters; Palestinian Legislative Council, in emergency session attended by only half its members, scores petititon; Masri's shooting follows his vote against measure; Arafat scores attack on Masri (M)

headline: VODAFONE TO BEGIN OFFER
abstract: Vodafone AirTouch PLC says it will begin tender offer on December 24 for Mannesmann AG, officially starting hostile bid (S)

headline: Media Talk; Setback for a Web Site in Copyright Case
abstract: Federal Judge Margaret M Morrow says she intends to rebuff assertion of conservative Web forum that it has right to post articles from two newspapers to foster discussion; ruling comes in copyright infringement suit filed by Los Angeles Times and Washington Post agaisnt Web site FreeRepublic.com; photo (M)

headline: The Next Waves of Electronic Commerce
abstract: Future developments in Internet commerce are expected to come in waves; next wave, which analysts see coming in year or two, will find traditional businesses increasingly gravitating to making sales and doing procurement online; researchers suggest that in next decade, huge, far-flung, industry-specific marketplaces will emerge; photo (M)

headline: J. C. Penney Delays Drugstore Offering
abstract: J C Penney Co says it will delay plans to sell 20 percent of its Eckerd drugstore chain to public until first half-half of next year; company expected to hold offering for Eckerd tracking stock in fourth quarter of this year (S)

headline: LIBERTY MEDIA TAKING STAKE IN EMMIS COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Emmis Communications Corp agrees to sell 2.7 million class A common shares to AT&T subsidiary Liberty Media Group for about $150 million; Liberty Media will become Emmis's second largest shareholder; stake represents about 14 percent of Emmis (S)

headline: Christmas Trees (Not for Downloading)
abstract: Michelle Slatalla article on shopping for Christmas tree over Internet; photo (M)

headline: Mirror on the Past: Canal's Fate Reflects Shift by U.S.
abstract: News analysis of American transfer of full sovereignty over Panama Canal to government of Panama after nearly century of US control; out of 20th century sense of sovereignty and respect for other nation's national pride, great power is voluntarily giving up piece of valuable national property in small nation with no capacity to seize it (M)

headline: In Clinton's Derailed Proposal for Medicare, a Question of Savings
abstract: CRITICS say the latest Clinton Administration proposal for a new managed care option in the Medicare program -- rebuffed in Congress last week but expected to be taken up next year -- is unlikely to achieve its goals of saving money for taxpayers and improving care for the 39 million older and disabled Americans whose health care costs are covered by the program. But Administration officials say this new option, which is still being developed, is a worthwhile experiment.    Under the plan, Medicare beneficiaries could pay reduced or no deductibles and fees if they chose doctors and hospitals from a list of preferred providers of care, a system that is the most popular and most permissive type of managed care. They would still be able to select any doctor or hospital at any time and pay the traditional patient deductibles and 20 percent share of charges.

headline: Experts Say Test Ban Could Impair Nuclear-Arms Safety
abstract: Scientists in charge of maintaining safety and reliability of United States' nuclear arsenal say that they might not be able to do their job without nuclear tests that would be outlawed under test ban treaty; State Sec Madeleine Albright endorses nuclear test ban treaty, appearing before Senate Foreign Relations Committee; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Bolsters Border Troops In East Timor
abstract: UN-backed peacekeeping mission in East Timor will triple number of troops along border with Indonesian-controlled half of island in effort to thwart attacks by independent militias; expansion follows warnings that militias plan series of new attacks on peacekeepers and on East Timorese as vote in Indonesian Parliament nears on granting independence to East Timor; maps (M)
