headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE GROUP,  San Jose, Calif., California's largest publicly traded water utility, agreed to buy two water systems in Washington for $11.5 million in stock and assumed debt.

headline: In an Inflation Measure, A Way to Pan for Gold
abstract: WHAT makes gold soar will eventually make stocks swoon.    That simple truth explains much about the recent downward path of the stock market. The gold market came to life well in advance of the Dow's most recent correction, which started in late August.

headline: BIG FLOWER HOLDINGS AGREES TO A REVISED BUYOUT PLAN
abstract: Big Flower Holdings Inc agrees to revised terms of its $1.9 billion management-led buyout and warns that third-quarter profit will fall short of estimates (S)

headline: Is the Sun Setting on Farmers?
abstract: Article on what mounting losses, for second consecutive year, could mean for America's independent farmers despite promise of bumper crops and use of latest technology; farmers are concerned over public's wariness about bioengineered crops, huge agricultural mergers and sharp decline in commodity prices; photos; graphs (L)

headline: Online Pioneers: The Buzz Never Stops
abstract: Excerpts of roundtable discussion with four chief executives from dot.com companies--Candice Carpenter of iVillage, Fernando J Espuelas of StarMedia Network, Kevin O'Connor of DoubleClick and Stephan J Paternot of Theglobe.com--who offer their views on managing in Internet age; brief biographical sketches; photos (L)

headline: Thomas Foster, 49, Poultry Farm Owner
abstract: Thomas O Foster, philanï

headline: Looking Ahead As 2 Utilities Continue Talks
abstract: Analysts say if Consolidated Edison Co reaches deal to buy Northeast Utilities, combined company will have 4.7 million customers stretching as far north as New Hampshire and will eventually be able to sell cheaper power in New York region; neither company will confirm merger talks (M)

headline: Hey, Anybody Here Know of a Good Deal on a Company?
abstract: IMAGINE that it is 3 a.m. and you, the chief executive of a large corporation, are wide awake, worrying whether you are paying too much to buy a company you have your eye on.    You could try rolling over or taking two aspirin and calling your investment banker in the morning. Instead, still in your pajamas, you snuggle up to the computer and log on to an exclusive Web site especially for chief executives like you. There you find the newest research on how to price a deal. You scan a list of companies that are auctioning divisions you may want to buy instead. And, if you are curious about whether sharing power with a fellow chief executive in a combined company is a good idea, you dash off an e-mail message to a colleague who has done so and ask for advice.

headline: EUROPEAN BANK DEAL
abstract: Scandinavia's fifth-largest bank, SEB AB, will buy BfG Bank AG of Germany from Credit Lyonnaise SA for 1.6 billion euros, or $1.7 billion; European Commission told Credit Lyonnaise, which owns 50 percent plus one share in BfG, to sell its stake in return for about $25 billion in aid from France; Credit Lyonnaise says it will lose money on sale (S)

headline: Nazi Slave Labor Talks Halt Over Payments
abstract: German and American negotiators, faced by growing differences over compensating Nazi-era slave laborers, abandon plans to meet in Bonn on November 16 and 17; postponement reflects fact that Germany's largest companies and government are not ready to raise $3.3 billion offer; is embarrassing setback in increasingly rancorous negotiations; many German companies feel they are coming under unreasonable pressure over what they see as moral gesture being made without any legal obligation (M)

headline: French Finance Minister Named in Party Scandal
abstract: PARIS—  Allegations of corruption with potentially major impact have begun to wash up close to the government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and its finance minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, French socialism's designated-guarantor of good sense to the international business and investment communities.

headline: NATO Was Closer to Ground War in Kosovo Than Is Widely Realized
abstract: US came much closer to ground war in Kosovo than is commonly understood, despite Pres Clinton's intention not to deploy troops, according to senior government officials from US, Britain, Germany, Italy, France, Finland and Yugoslavia; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report
abstract: Publishers appear determined to find way to charge users to read information on line; obstacles include recalcitrant authors, potential for piracy and reluctance of users to buy information they believe they can find elsewhere on Web; photo (M)

headline: An Eclectic Site for Arts News
abstract: New online arts digest, Arts Journal (www.artsjournal.com) is fashioning daily Web site out of the cultural world's daily jumble; site, developed by Doug McLennan, scans more than 100 online publications each day, selecting 80 to 120 links a week for digest; McLennan photo (M)

headline: In Indonesia, Rebel Leader Gains Forum For His Cause
abstract: Abdullah Syafie, commander ofÿ

headline: AIRCRAFT MAKER DEFENDS SALE PLAN
abstract: Embraer defends plan to sell minority stake to French consortium; responds to criticism from Brazilian military officials (S)

headline: SYRIA AND ISRAEL BEGIN PEACE TALKS AFTER 4-YEAR HALT
abstract: Israel and Syria resume peace negotiations, stalled nearly four years ago, in Washington; Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak and Syrian Foreign Min Farouk al-Shara meet face-to-face at White House and State Department, under auspices of Pres Clinton and Sec of State Madeleine K Albright; Clinton calls meeting first big step along path to peace and urges both sides to seize moment; upbeat mood sours temporarily when Shara reiterated in speech at White House Syria's well-worn grievances against Israel; photo (M)

headline: Serbian Police Block Protesters' March, but Without Violence
abstract: Serbian police block march by anti-Government demonstrators, Belgrade; both sides avoid confrontation; turnout of some 7,000 people is disappointing; opposition leader Zoran Djindjic claims victory, interview; says rallies will continue until mid-Oct (M)

headline: An exhibit by a club that encourages creativity pays homage to a single company: Volkswagen.
abstract: One Club for Art and Copy, which encourages creativity in advertising, will devote exhibit to single advertiser: Volkswagen AG; exhibit offers retrospective of Volkswagen advertising campaigns around the world from 1940's through 1990's; photo (Advertising column) (M)

headline: A New Index Tracks Bribe-Paying Countries
abstract: Transparency International, independent organization that tracks corruption among government officials around world, announces that it has added new index to rank nations that appear to condone bribe paying by their companies doing business abroad (M)

headline: G.M. and DaimlerChrysler Report Weak Monthly Sales
abstract: General Motors and DaimlerChrysler announce November sales figures that are weaker than expected as American automakers continue to lose market share to Japanese rivals, who post big gains; GM says sales in US inched up just one-tenth of 1 percent compared with figures in period year earlier, several points worse than expected, while DaimlerChrysler says its sales fell 1.3 percent, marginally worse than expected; but Toyota Motor, Honda Motor and Nissan Motor all report large increases, while sales for Mitsubishi Motors more than doubled (M)

headline: Why Doesn't Windows CE Get Any Respect?; When It Comes to Personal Organizers, Microsoft's Minisystem Does Not Rule the Market
abstract: Microsoft Corp has not had success with its Windows CE, simplified version of its Windows operating system, intended for use in personal organizers; according to one poll, personal digital assistants running CE account for just 15 percent of PDA's sold; 75 percent run Palm OS; reasons given for lack of interest in CE include: too expensive, too difficult to use, too bulky, poor quality; Microsoft points out that its CE system is popular for some other devices; photos (M)

headline: A Pioneer in Consulting Is Leaving Yankee Group
abstract: Howard Anderson, credited with practically inventing technology consulting industry when he founded Yankee Group Research in 1970, will step down to start new venture capital operation, Yankeetek, which will invest in start-ups focused on Internet and communications; photo (M)

headline: A Flash, and an Uncontrolled Chain Reaction
abstract: Scientists say that accident at nuclear fuel plant in Tokaimura, though serious, was not catastrophe on scale of partial nuclear meltdown at Three Mile Island, near Harrisburg, Pa, in 1979, or explosion at Chernobyl nuclear reactor in Ukraine in 1986; say Japanese accident involves only few pounds of uranium, which should not be enough fuel to sustain prolonged chain reaction or cause widespread destruction; Dr Arjun Makhijani, president of Institute for Energy and Environmental Research in Washington, DC, says Tokaimura plant had other accidents in recent years and should be shut down for independent investigation; map; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Dec 12 On the Job column about odd entries employers have encountered on staff expense reports

headline: STEEL UNITS TO BE SOLD
abstract: Australia's biggest steelmaker, Broken Hill Proprietary Co, plans to cut its steel production in half and sell operations worth around $1.98 billion (US) to make division more profitable (S)

headline: STATOIL GROUP SEEKS BUYER FOR ITS U.S. GAS UNIT
abstract: Statoil Group of Norway is seeking buyer forits Statoil Energy (S)

headline: Europe Says Its Strike Force Won't Impair Role of NATO
abstract: Senior French, German and British defense ministers are trying to reassure United States that rapidly coalescing plans for independent European military intervention force would not weaken NATO; France, Germany, Britain and Italy plan to ask leaders of all 15 European Union nations to lay groundwork by no later than 2003 for European crisis-response force of up to 60,000 troops; Finland has proposed draft accord on 50,000-soldier force (M)

headline: People
abstract: Ronald Yue, president at Lowe & Partners Asia-Pacific, Hong Kong, part of Lowe & Partners Worldwide unit of Lowe Group, is named chief executive for Lowe Lintas Asia-Pacific as Interpublic Group of Cos merges Lowe & Partners with Ammirati Puris Lintas to form Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide; Ian Creasey, president at Ammirati Puris Asia-Pacific, Hong Kong, becomes president of Lowe Lintas Asia-Pacific; Philip Palazzo, president for international operations at Ammirati Puris, resigns; Sal LaGreca, executive vice president and chief financial officer at McCann-Erickson World Group, is promoted to vice chairman; Victoria Fischetti, creative director at Bozell Chicago, is named vice president for advertising at Montgomery Ward, succeeding Susan Ruff, who resigned; Donna Kalajian Lagani, publisher at Cosmopolitan magazine, is named publishing director of new Cosmopolitan Group; Esther Laufer is named associate publisher; Susan Plagemann, associate publisher for advertising at Cosmopolitan, is promoted to succeed Lagani as publisher; Stephen Davis is named publisher at Business Publication Advertising Source; succeeds Leslie Albright, who is promoted to president and group publisher (M)

headline: CANADIAN JOBLESSNESS FALLS
abstract: Statistics Canada says nation's unemployment rate fell three-tenths of percentage point to 7.2 percent in October, its lowest level since March 1990 (S)

headline: B.A.T.'S PROFIT DROPS
abstract: British American Tobacco PLC says charges related to its $8.3 billion acquisition of Rothmans International pushed down its third-quarter profit by 8.3 percent (S)

headline: Storing Data On DVD's
abstract: Answer to reader's question on DVD formats, including DVD-RAM and DVD+RW (S)

headline: Treasuries Decline Further; 30-Year Yield Is Now 6.32%
abstract: US Treasury securities decline further; price of benchmark 30-year Treasury bond declines 20/32, to 97 13/32; yield rises to 6.32 percent from 6.27 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Media Talk; Orders Still Trickling in for Bush Biography
abstract: J. H. Hatfield's biography of George W. Bush may be one publisher's furnace fodder, but the book has continued to sell despite its recall by St. Martin's Press in October after reports emerged about the author's criminal record.    The Borders Group kept selling the book, ''Fortunate Son,'' though it is the only major bookselling chain to do so. ''We decided that it was still legal and appropriate for us to sell it,'' said Ann Binkley, a spokesman for the Michigan-based company. ''One of the things that we've always said is that we want to give customers the depth of selection. We want our customers to be able to choose what they read.''

headline: A Sect's Political Rise Creates Uneasiness in Japan
abstract: Buddhist organization Soka Gakkai (Values Creation Society) claims presence in eight million Japanese homes where adherents gather, using simple themes of self-help and compassion, and building disciplined nationwide organization through small neighborhood groups; photo; group founded in 1930 has risen from small persecuted sect to one of countless 'new religions' that blossomed in postwar era; dramatic step toward mainstream came recently when Prime Min Keizo Obuchi named coalition cabinet, formally allying his Liberal Democratic party with New Komeito, party created by Soka Gakkai in 1964; opinion polls show widespread disapproval among public still shaken by 1995 nerve gas attack in subway by another sect (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: BEEF BAN STANDS -- The Food Safety Agency recommended that the Government maintain its embargo on imports of British beef because of continuing risks of mad-cow disease. European Union officials, who ruled that the three-year old ban be lifted, said they might take legal action if Paris persists in its ban. France's action has infuriated the British authorities.   Marlise Simons (NYT)

headline: Forging Links in Cuba
abstract: More than a dozen Cuban human rights advocates and relatives of political prisoners have held meetings with dignitaries who are in Havana for a summit meeting of Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking nations.  Cuban participants said issues included multiparty democracy, open markets, freedom of expression and ending the United States embargo against Cuba.  Article, Page A10.

headline: Countdown to Pakistan's Coup: A Duel of Nerves in the Air
abstract: Gen Pervez Musharraf, installed as leader of Pakistan after military coup, says deposed Prime Min Nawaz Sharif had forbidden his, Musharraf's, plane to land in Pakistan, imperiling lives of all passengers on commercial flight; says this is what precipitated coup; Sharif is being held incommunicado, so his side of story has not been told; what is known is that enmity between him and Pakistan's military was so well-known that United States State Dept issued highly unusual warning to Pakistan's military in September to stay out of politics; Sharif, who had struck out at his enemies, accomplished something rare in Pakistani politics: he united the opposition in single issue, which was his removal (M)

headline: Synchronize Your Watch Until the Year 20002000
abstract: Eidos Interactive is promoting its Tomb Raider series by releasing special game level showing Lara Croft, popular Barbie-shaped heroine of series, in conversation with Paul Stothard, real-life editor of The Times of London; photo (S)

headline: Newbridge Warns Again About Its Earnings
abstract: Shares of Newbridge Networks Corp fall 25 percent after Canadian maker of communications switches warns of unexpectedly weak fiscal second-quarter results; Alan G Lutz, president and chief operating officer, resigns, replaced by Pearse Flynn (M)

headline: CK WITCO SELLING EUROPEAN INDUSTRIAL DYE OPERATIONS
abstract: CK Witco Corp agrees to sell its European industrial dyes business to Yorkshire Group for $86 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Time of Turmoil at Willy Loman & Co.
abstract: Growing number of salesmen are leaving profession as sales of business-to-business products through Internet-based corporate networks are expected to increase from at least $95 billion this year to $500 billion in 2002; that would eliminate need for many of calls that corporate sales representatives make to purchasing managers; Michael Pusateri, who joined Web developer Proxicom after 10 years in sales at Marriott hotels, profiled; graph; photo (M)

headline: Shares of Unisys Slide 37%; Revenue Figures Are Cited
abstract: Shares of Unisys Corp fall 37 percent after company says revenue in third quarter increased by 4 percent, figure below investors' expectations; earnings were $138 million, up 48 percent from a year ago; revenue rose 4 percent, to $1.87 billion (M)

headline: Drug Maker's Suitors Affirm Bidding Plans
abstract: Pfizer Inc and American Home Products, rival bidders for Warner-Lambert, harden their stances, reaffirming their commitments to complete deal and taking steps to wage proxy and legal fights; investors focus on prospect of sweetened offer from one or more of companies (M)

headline: CARRIER TO ACQUIRE ELECTROLUX REFRIGERATION BUSINESS
abstract: United Technologies Corp says its Carrier Corp unit has agreed to acquire commercial refrigeration business of Electrolux of Sweden for about $145 million (S)

headline: McCann-Erickson And Boston Beer Part
abstract: Boston Beer Co and McCann-Erickson mutually agree to part ways; account, which had billings last year estimated at $11.9 million, has been with McCann-Erickson since August 1998 (S)

headline: Amazon Says Its Losses May Grow Next Quarter
abstract: Amazon.com reports its losses in third quarter were slightly less than analysts had expected; company also warns that it expects to lose far more than it had previously indicated in fourth quarter, as it triples its spending on marketing and advertising to compete vigorously this Christmas; Amazon lost $197 million on sales of $356 million in third quarter, compared with loss of $45 million on sales of $154 million a year earlier (M)

headline: Berlusconi Wins in Court
abstract: Appeals court in Milan upholds acquittal of Silvio Berlusconi, former Italian Prime Minister who was charged with tax fraud, unlawful appropriation and false accounting involving a land deal (S)

headline: Morgan Stanley Sets Price on Japanese Debt
abstract: Tokyo office of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter prices first set of bonds linked to nonperforming Japanese real estate loans, paving way for what may be flood of deals aimed at clearing away bad debt on balance sheets of Japanese financial institutions and banks; deal is worth about 21 billion yen, or about $200 million, making it larger than may in market thought; all but 4 billion yen of bonds has AAA or AA credit ratings (M)

headline: Asians Hedge Bets On U.S. Currency
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  The U.S. dollar has long been the currency of choice for Asia's mega-rich. But these days, private bankers say their clients are casting a slightly more skeptical eye on the U.S. currency, nervous about the future direction of U.S. interest rates and the overall sustainability of the continued American economic expansion.

headline: COMPANY BRIEF
abstract: EMMIS COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Indianapolis, a radio, television and print-media company, bought two radio stations in Buenos Aires for $15 million in its first foray into Latin America.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: GOLD RISES. Gold was higher on expectations that investors in Asia would stock up as prices are close to a two-and-a-half-month low. In New York, gold for February delivery rose $7.20, or 2.6 percent, to $285.40 an ounce.

headline: I.B.M. Invests In Campaign To Promote Its Software
abstract: International Business Machines Corp plans major marketing and advertising campaign to promote its software; effort is intended not only to raise profile of company's $12-billion-a-year software business, but also to highlight striking changes IBM has made in its software division recently and to accelerate its gowth; IBM's chairman, Louis V Gerstner Jr, has singled out software as one of three engines of corporation's growth in future; others are services and sale of technology to other companies; chart (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.31   5.22   5.00        3-month T-bills   4.90   4.86   3.61        6-month T-bills   4.94   4.94   3.87        10-yr. T-infl.   4.14   4.15   3.64        10-yr. T-note   6.08   6.16   4.44        30-yr. T-bond   6.26   6.32   4.98        Telephone bd.   8.07   8.07   6.80        Municipal bds.   6.06   6.06   5.05          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: Exporting a Business Lesson
abstract: Rene Preval, the president of Haiti, was not quite able to keep his appointment last week to visit Dumas M. Simeus, his former countryman, in Mansfield, Tex. ''He has a country to run,'' Mr. Simeus explained. In two previous meetings, Mr. Preval had sought to learn how Mr. Simeus's example as the founder of Simeus Foods International, the largest black-owned business in the state and 11th largest in the nation, could be applied back home. ''He is consumed by entrepreneurship fires in his belly,'' Mr. Simeus said.

headline: JURY CHARGES 3, ONE A BANK AIDE, IN RUSSIAN CASE
abstract: Federal grand jury probing possible money laundering at Bank of New York indicts Lucy Edwards, former bank official, her husband, Peter Berlin, and associate, Aleksey Volkov, on charges of conspiring to take deposits illegally and to transfer money without proper licenses; charges they and their companies, Benex International Co and Becs International LLC, moved almost $7 billion through bank over three and a half years; bank, which fired Edwards in Aug, is not charged; investigators say Torfinex Corp, company controlled by Volkov, executed money movements for Benex and Becs; probe has focused attention on international movement of huge sums from Russia; photo (M)

headline: Markets Turn to Mush in Tumultuous Week
abstract: Sometimes it is best to close the shutters, turn off the lights and call it a day, or so it seemed on Friday as overwrought investors punished stocks in Asia, Europe and the United States, then headed for cover.     To be sure, investors had a lot on their minds in a week that saw a military coup in Pakistan, the United States Senate's rejection of a nuclear test ban treaty and a warning from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, on the risk of rising share prices.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: TALKS WITH U.S. -- Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott discussed arms control and other issues with Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, but the two appeared to make little headway. The Defense Ministry again ridiculed United States proposals to alter the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty to permit a limited defense against rogue missiles, saying the treaty is the basis of arms control.   Michael Wines (NYT)    RUSSIA, BELARUS: PACT APPROVED -- Legislators in Russia and Belarus voted to ratify a treaty moving the two nations closer to economic union, but still well short of political merger. The treaty, signed this month by the Russian and Belarussian presidents, calls for a unified tax system by 2001 and a common currency by 2005, but is mostly short on details. It replaces a similar document signed in 1996.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro surges against US dollar after index of German business confidence rises to its highest level in a year and a half; in New York, euro settles at $1.0163, up from $1.0071; graph; chart (S)

headline: Mercedes and Motorola Revive Idea of Car Phone
abstract: Mercedes-Benz USA and Motorola revive idea of car-specific cell phone that among other things allows drivers to operate phone using controls on steering wheel or dashboard while viewing information, such as stored numbers, on dashboard; cost of phone system in Mercedes-Benz is $1,295, plus $480 for voice recognition; photo (S)

headline: When a Gizmo Can Invent a Gizmo
abstract: Problems related to ownership of items invented by computers are already being debated in preparation for time, probably in about 10 years, when such inventions will be commonplace; computers are already making inroads in area of intellectual property; much of work in field of automatic discovery is preliminary and secret; photo (M)

headline: Thousands Relive the Horror As New Disaster Hits Region
abstract: Thousands of Turks endure another major earthquake, this one centered in Duzce; map; center of once-prosperous town of 80,000, set amid rich tobacco and hazelnut plantations, is ruined, with hundreds of homes collapsed (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Wheat drops about 3 percent after Government report shows larger-than-expected grain stockpiles; wheat for December delivery falls 8.75 cents, to $2.67 a bushel on Chicago Board of Trade; graph; chart (S)

headline: Pragmatists Told to Beware 'Chemically Pure Capitalism' : Trans-Atlantic Visions of a Center-Left Future
abstract: FLORENCE—  America, the practical, and Europe, the rather more theoretical, looked at the future and how to govern it on Sunday, and came out with characteristic answers for the management of economies and nations that seem less and less responsive to ideology.

headline: Fed Governor Says Rates Might Increase
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers may decide to raise interest rates again to keep the United States economy on a low-inflation growth path, a Fed governor, Laurence H. Meyer, said yesterday.    ''The fundamental challenge for monetary policy is to facilitate a transition from the current exceptional but unsustainable state to a more sustainable, though still excellent, state,'' Mr. Meyer said in the text of remarks to be delivered at the Stern Graduate School of Business at New York University.

headline: ESTEE LAUDER BUYS BEAUTY-PRODUCT MAKER, JO MALONE
abstract: Estee Lauder Companies acquires beauty-product maker Jo Malone Ltd (S)

headline: Compressed Data; A Debit Card for Students, With Oversight for Parents
abstract: New type of Visa card, called PocketCard, carries Visa label and is used like other credit cards; it is technically a debit card, financed and guaranteed by sponsor, like a parent, through account set up on Internet; it is being marketed for use by college students; photo (S)

headline: The Real Retail Revolution: It's Wal-Mart, Not the Net
abstract: Greatest revolution in retailing in recent years comes not from much-hyped Internet shopping but from giant discounter Wal-Mart Stores, which is expected to garner roughly seven percent of US retail market in 1999 with a combination of brand products, good merchandising and low prices that has reshaped retail landscape; photos (M)

headline: Agency Seeks Safeguards For Birds on Power Lines
abstract: Comment on problem of birds being electrocuted on power lines; power poles have always been a favorite perch for birds, especially eagles, hawks, owls and falcons, which use them to spot their prey; about 150 of these raptors are electrocuted every year, but now criminal prosecution of Utah utility company for causing deaths of birds raises concerns among power companies, particularly in West; utilities say they could face large expenses, possibly running into millions of dollars, if they are forced to prevent electrocutions; United States Fish and Wildlife Service's successful criminal prosecution of Moon Lake Electric Assn Inc reviewed (M)

headline: Trade Obstacles Unmoved, Seattle Talks End in Failure
abstract: Global trade talks in Seattle end in complete failure, with United States abandoning any effort to put together new round of talks; collapse of talks is serious blow to Clinton administration, which hoped to use Seattle meeting to advance bold agenda for trade talks that would stretch into next millennium; World Trade Organization officials trace failure of talks to disagreements on wide array of issues, including several that were high priorities for Pres Clinton, as well as disruption of violent protests; failure in Seattle means that when talks resume early next year at WTO headquarters in Geneca, talks will cover far narrower group of subjects and will fall far short of goal set by WTO and Clinton administration: beginning of broad new round of global trade talks; photo (M)

headline: TOYOTA SHARES SOAR
abstract: Shares of Toyota Motor Corp, Japan's largest automaker, post their biggest one-day gain in 11 years on optimism that increased investments in telecommunications will help Toyota develop new car-navigation technology (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: Putting a Multimedia Spin On the Ordinary Business Card
abstract: One of hot items at Comdex computer show in Las Vegas is CD-ROM's cut to size of business cards (S)

headline: Passivity Is the Word On Year 2000 Marketing; Most Big Companies Playing It Low Key
abstract: Article in series Counting to 2000 focuse on how nation's large manufacturers and retailers of consmer products have been remarkably restrained about prospects of computer malfunctions; says some big companies have begun promotional campaigns highlighting how their services and products can help protect consumers from Year 2000 troubles; holds such steps are still unusual and most companies with Y2K-linked promotions have been careful to make it clear that they are not predicting how transition to next year will unfold; says most companies are not aggressively promoting stockpiling or other preparedness steps; Gallup poll shows Americans have become less concerned about Year 2000 computer bug, but still worry that problems will occur; graph; photos (M)

headline: NATIONAL CITY ISSUES FOURTH-QUARTER PROFIT WARNING
abstract: National City Corp says fourth-quarter profit will fall short of analysts' expectations (S)

headline: Razzle-Dazzle Look at the Civil War on Disc
abstract: Prof David M Oshinsky reviews SouthPeak Interactive's The Civil War Experience, which combines computer games with extensive and detailed historical data; photo (M)

headline: Sprint's Role in Brazil Venture Is Curbed
abstract: Sprint Corp, in decision that may shake up Brazil's long-distance industry, is barred from managing its Brazilian subsidiary after its partner in company, National Grid PLC of Britain, persuades court that delicate corporate information might be disclosed to MCI Worldcom; ruling, which effectively removes Sprint from participation in day-to-day decisions at Intelig, start-up concern formed with National Grid and France Telecom SA, comes after MCI Worldcom announced plans earlier this year to acquire Sprint; MCI Worldcom already operates Brazil's dominant long-distance carrier, called Embratel (M)

headline: HORACE MANN EDUCATORS WILL NOT SEEK BUYER
abstract: Horace Mann Educators Corp decides against trying to find buyer for company (S)

headline: Germany's Consensus Economy at Risk of Unraveling
abstract: Analysis of possible unraveling of Germany's 'consensus economy'; says consensus capitalism has been assaulted on two distinct but closely related fronts: hostile bid by Vodafone Airtouch PLC for Mannesmann AG, engineering and telecommunications concern, and collapse of Philipp Holzmann, Germany's biggest construction company that Government has bailed out for $2.2 billion (M)

headline: Historians' Report Blames Swiss for Barring Jews During War
abstract: Panel of independent historians concludes that wartime Swiss officials refused entry to thousands of Jewish refugees even after it was known that they faced almost certain death in Nazi Germany; blames anti-Semitism and an entrenched fear of foreigners in Switzrland; says there is no evidence that accepting many more asylum seekers would have put neutral Switzerland in danger of invasion by Axis or caused insurmountable economic difficulties (M)

headline: G.M. to Offer a New Reason To Keep the Cell Phone On
abstract: General Motors Corp, as part its Onstar cellular phone and navigation system, to introduce new service sometime next year that will allow drivers to surf the Internet from a car; service will not include computer screen in interest of driver safety (S)

headline: CON EDISON BUYING A NEIGHBOR UTILITY FOR $3.29 BILLION
abstract: Consolidated Edison Co agrees to buy Northeast Utilities for $3.29 billion in cash and stock; deal, which will give Con Edison access to lower-cost electricity, is company's biggest move so far to protect its base of three million customers, who will be able to buy power at lower rates from outside companies as New York deregulates its utility market; Con Edison will raise its customer base to 4.7 million and extend its reach as far north as New Hampshire; Eugene R McGrath, chairman and chief executive of Con Edison, will have those positions in merged company while Michael G Morris, chairman, president and chief executive of Northeast, will become president (M)

headline: Bell Atlantic-Vodafone Venture Clears a Hurdle
abstract: Bell Atlantic and Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. of Britain won conditional approval from the Justice Department yesterday for their September deal to combine their United States wireless operations.    But the two companies, along with GTE, which has agreed to merge with Bell Atlantic, will have to get rid of billions of dollars worth of cellular systems and millions of customers before they allowed complete the merger.

headline: People
abstract: Jeannette McClennan is named president at Ogilvy Interactive North America, succeeding J G Sandom, who resigned (S)

headline: COMPUTER LEARNING CENTERS HIRES INVESTMENT BANK
abstract: Computer Learning Centers hires US Bancorp Piper Jaffray to help it explore options, including possible sale (S)

headline: CHESAPEAKE BEGINS TENDER FOR SHOREWOOD PACKAGING
abstract: Chesapeake Corp begins tender offer to shareholders of Shorewood Packaging Corp, in bid to buy company for $17.25 a share in cash, or $500 million, plus assumption of $270 million in Shorewood debt (S)

headline: WIND RIVER MAKES STOCK DEAL FOR INTEGRATED SYSTEMS
abstract: Wind River Systems Inc plans to acquire rival Integrated Systems for $437 million in stock; plans to keep all 700 employees of Integrated Systems (S)

headline: E*Trade Loss Not as Deep As Forecast
abstract: E*Trade Group Inc reports smaller-than-expected fourth-quarter loss; company lost $26.7 million compared with loss of $15.2 million a year ago; revenue rose to $173.2 million from $94.2 million but was down from $177 million in third quarter (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; BP Amoco Withdrawing From Natural Gas Fields in Ukraine
abstract: BP Amoco has decided not to develop series of natural gas fields in Ukraine, dealing blow to country's hopes of decreasing its dependence on Russian gas; decision opens way for other companies to explore vast region in central and eastern Ukraine with potentially huge deposits (M)

headline: Hesitating Beside A Shallow Labor Pool; Will Fed Take Plunge and Raise Rates?
abstract: Shrinking pool of available labor, and possibility that upward pressure on wages could spur inflation seem to be biggest issues on minds of Federal Reserve officials as they debate whether to raise interest rates a third time this year when they meet on Nov 15; so far, employment cost increases have remained restrained despite drop in unemployment; businesses have proved remarkably successful in absorbing employment costs without sacrificing profits or raising prices; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Syria Says Peace Deal With Israel Could Be Reached Soon
abstract: Foreign Min Farouk al-Shara of Syria expresses confidence that a peace deal with Israel can be concluded quickly, perhaps in a matter of months; Prime Min Ehud Barak tells Israeli cabinet that negotiations with Syria can be completed in a few weeks; Pres Emile Lahoud of Lebanon, however, says new talks are bound to be difficult (M)

headline: Russians Hunt Rebel Leader, But Shoot Chechen Villagers
abstract: Russia presses missile strikes against Chechen villages of Dargo and Benoy, territory of rebel commander Shamil Basayev, killing and injuring many Chechen villagers; officials hint they will continue assault, and may even send ground troops, until they can create buffer along border with southern republic of Dagestan to protect it from Basayev and militants, who want to establish independent Islamic state; photo; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises after International Energy Agency says production cuts by big exporters are eroding global inventories; in New York, crude oil for December delivery rises 76 cents, to $24.03 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: GALLAHER WON'T MAKE OFFER
abstract: British cigarette maker Gallaher Group says it will not make bid for French tobacco maker Seita; bid could have scuttled Seita's proposed merger with Tabacalera of Spain; that merger is set to be completed at end of November (S)

headline: BRIGHTER BRITISH FORECAST
abstract: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown increases his growth forecasts to 1.75 percent for this year--from previous 1 percent to 1.5 percent--and up to 3 percent for next year, compared with his earlier forecasts of 2.25 percent to 2.75 percent (S)

headline: CONGRESS PASSES WIDE-RANGING BILL EASING BANK LAWS
abstract: Congress approves landmark legislation that opens door for new era on Wall Street in which commercial banks, securities houses and insurers will find it easier and cheaper to enter one another's businesses; measure, considered by many most important banking legislation in 66 years, is approved in Senate by 90 to 8 vote and in House by 362 to 57; decision to repeal 1933 Glass-Steagall Act provokes dire warnings from handful of dissenters that deregulation of Wall Street will someday wreak havoc on nation's financial system (M)

headline: Union Pacific Gives Big Lift To G.M. Unit
abstract: Union Pacific Corp orders 1,000 locomotives worth more than $2 billion from General Motors Electro-Motive Division in London, Ontario; it is Union Pacific's biggest step yet to improve railroad network; Union Pacific will replace about 1,500 older locomotives in its current fleet of 7,000 with new ones; company is currently investing about $2 billion a year in new equipment to try to become more competitive (M)

headline: Schroder Dismisses Demands To Enlarge Fund for Nazi Slaves
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder says Germany and German corporations will not further raise their offer to contribute $4.1 billion to fund to compensate Nazi-era slave laborers, television interview; Otto Lambsdorff, Germany's lead negotiator, says German companies might start withdrawing from proposed settlement of class action suit brought by American lawyers for Jewish organizations and strike individual deals (M)

headline: Compressed Data: Y2K Pulse; Year 2000 Campaigners Take to the Streets
abstract: Brief, naked San Francisco march led by Dr Patch Adams and Helen Caldicott to call attention to concerns about Year 2000 computer readiness of nuclear power and weapons systems has spurred interest of Year 2000 campaigners elsewhere; Jay Golter, Virginia activist, comments; drawing (M)

headline: Canadian Regulators File Charges Against Executive at Corel
abstract: Ontario Securities Commission charges Michael Cowpland, president and chief executive of Corel Corp, one of nation's largest computer software makers, with unlawfully profiting from insider trading in company's shares and lying about his activities; charges relate to sale in August 1997 of one-third of Cowpland's Corel shares for about $13.9 million (US), shortly before unexpectedly poor financial results were released; Cowpland denies all accusations of insider trading (M)

headline: EURO DISNEY PROFIT FALLS
abstract: Euro Disney says its profit in second half of fiscal year fell 8.7 percent after paying royalties to Walt Disney Co, its largest shareholder; net income fell to 68.9 million euros, or $72.6 million in six months ended Sept 30 (S)

headline: House Passes Compromise Bill for $13.5 Billion in Foreign Aid
abstract: House of Representatives, 316-100, passes compromise foreign aid bill; $13.5 billion measure includes $779 million more than Republicans wanted to spend; will advance to Senate, where approval is expected; Pres Clinton says bill meets US commitments in key policy areas; diplomats and international aid experts voice skepticism over debt relief for poor countries (M)

headline: Ziff-Davis to Sell Division That Publishes PC Magazines
abstract: Ziff-Davis Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its publishing division, whose magazines include PC Week and PC Magazine, to the closely held investment firm Willis Stein & Partners L.P. for $780 million as it sheds assets to cut its debt.    The unit is one of the nation's largest publishers of computer magazines, printing more than 80. Once the sale closes, Ziff-Davis, which is majority owned by the Softbank Corporation of Japan, will be left with its trade show division, the producer of the Comdex technology shows. It also owns ZDNet, a publicly traded online unit, and SmartPlanet.com, an Internet-based learning service.

headline: New Indonesian Leadership Stirs Financiers' Skepticism
abstract: Indonesia's new Government is getting skeptical reception from foreign investors; they wonder whether newly chosen Pres Abdurrahman Wahid and 35 Cabinet ministers he just named have expertise and cohesion needed to become efficient crisis managers; they fear that Government, in its attempt to use unfamiliar democratic institutions to eradicate corruption of its predecessor, may sacrifice economics in name of popular justice; Indonesia remains dependent on emergency financing from International Monetary Fund and World Bank; that help has been suspended until banking scandal that helped undermine previous administration is resolved; graph on recent strength in Indonesian currency (M)

headline: Hope for Family Farms
abstract: Letter from Chuck Hassebrook comments on Nov 28 article on future of family farms (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: P.T.A.'s Tap Into E-Commerce As a Fund-Raiser for Schools
abstract: Web sites like Escrip, Schoolpop and Your School Shop let schools raise money without door-to-door solicitation; parents can use on-line and credit-card purchases to help their children's schools; merchants agree to kick back small percentage of sale to school; photo (M)

headline: 234,000 NEW JOBS IN NOVEMBER KEPT ECONOMY HUMMING
abstract: Labor Department report for November assures robust economic growth in final months of century; in addition to 234,000 new jobs in month, people are working longer hours; stock prices shoot up in reaction to job growth and fact that hourly wage for ordinary workers rose only 2 cents, to $13.41; combination of healthy economic growth and modest wage gains suggests likelihood of little inflationary pressure; unemployment rate remains at 4.1 percent, matching 30-year low hit in October, suggesting that labor shortages must eventually become inflationary; Wall Street is convinced that Federal Reserve would refrain from any further increase in interest rates this year; with November new-jobs figure, job creation during Pres Clinton's nearly seven years in office passes record 20 million mark; graph (M)

headline: Signatures on Cyberspace's Dotted Line
abstract: Bill to create uniform federal law recognizing validity of digital signatures, various technologies used to verify one's indentity in cyberspace, has spurred partisan political battle in Congress; opponents fear bill could wipe out some basic consumer protections; at issue is provision that would end requirement that institutions like banks and insurance companies keep paper records and let them notify customers of loan defaults, changes in terms of financial agreements, other situations electronically if contracts were made online; Sen Patrick J Leahy blocks bill in Senate, charging Sen Spencer Abraham offers bill far different than temporary compromise measure approved by Commerce Department; similar bill is pending in House, offered by Rep Thomas J Bliley Jr; photo (M)

headline: CANADA JOBLESSNESS DECLINES
abstract: Canada's unemployment rate fell three-tenths of 1 percent in September, to 7.5 percent, lowest level in more than nine years; number of new jobs created--63,800---is more than had been added over previous six months and twice what economists had expected (S)g

headline: Many Shoppers Won't Do Today What They Can Do on Dec. 24
abstract: Visa USA, based on statistics compiled on 1998 shopping season, finds that, despite merchants decorating for Christmas holidays earlier each year, American shoppers are buying presents later; December 24, rather than Friday after Thanksgiving, proved busiest shopping day in 1998; graphs (M)

headline: Mergers Bring Luxury Goods To the Global Middle Class
abstract: ROME—  Well-heeled customers searching for Gucci shoes or Louis Vuitton luggage in earlier days had to venture to the most exclusive shopping districts such as the Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore in Paris or Bond Street in London.

headline: Corporate Contributions And the Asbestos Debate
abstract: Martin Fass letter on October 17 article on GAF Corp's lobbying for law that would limit liabilities of former asbestos producers; supports Owens Corning for its settlement program (S)

headline: Broadcom's Founders Sell Shares
abstract: Co-chmn of Broadcom Corp, Henry T Nicholas III and Henry Samueli, and others execs and directors sell $266.3 million of shares of company, leading maker of cable-modem chips, in October and November (S)

headline: NBC Is in Command of Sunday Morning Talk Show Circuit
abstract: NBC's Meet the Press is clear front-runner among Sunday morning political discussion programs on television; ABC's This Week, once hottest show, has slid backward and is now being challenged for second place in ratings by Face the Nation on CBS; overall audience is not large, but Sunday talk programs are considered critical inside network news divisions and corporate offices; in election years, programs take on importance even beyond their profit figures; booking candidates and having them make news on programs becomes primary goal; Meet the Press has scored major coup with its upcoming joint appearance by Al Gore and Bill Bradley; Tim Russert, moderator, says it will follow Lincoln-Douglas Debate format; photos (M)

headline: KENNEDY-WILSON BUYS JAPANESE PROPERTY LOANS
abstract: Kennedy-Wilson Inc, Los Angeles-based property management and investment company, buys $250 million of nonperforming Japanese property loans for less than 10 cents on the dollar, as it continues to scour Japan for real estate bargains; purchase brings to more than $1 billion face amount of Japanese loans Kennedy-Wilson has bought in last 12 months (S)

headline: Compressed Data; In a World of Chips, A Man for All Modems
abstract: Eicon Technology, maker of wireless and cable modems that enable machines to follow orders, acquired Trisignal, small company that develops modems that can be worked into appliance's microprocessor, making it possible for machine in remote location to respond to directives from far away; Gad Elmoznino, director of Eicon's Trisignal division, says any appliance can have communications with proper modem; photo (M)

headline: APPROVAL IS WON FOR JOINT PURCHASE OF ICO GLOBAL
abstract: Cellular-phone pioneer Craig O McCaw and Subhash Chandra, who runs India's most popular television network, win United States Bankruptcy Court approval for joint purchase of satellite-telephone company ICO Global Communications Ltd; ICO filed for bankruptcy protection in August, days after rival, Iridium LLC, did same (S)

headline: Waste Industries Expands
abstract: Waste Industries acquires Southern Waste Services Inc, Quick-Way Salvage Inc, Jerry's Sanitation and Matthews Sanitation Service for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: But High Costs Deter Investors : Japanese Begin To Open Market
abstract: TOKYO—  Workmen are digging up streets in Tokyo's central wards, laying a fiber-optic cable network that MCI Worldcom will use to provide telecommunications services for commercial enterprises at prices below those of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp. and other carriers.

headline: Mannesmann May Consider A Deal Fortified With Cash
abstract: Mannesmann AG may be willing to consider friendly takeover deal from Vodafone Airtouch PLC if Vodafone adds cash sweetener to its hostile all-stock offer; executives say Mannesmann management seems to be divided over issue (M)

headline: Beyond Testing: Senators' Views on U.S. Role in World
abstract: Excerpts from remarks by five Senators during debate on nuclear test ban treaty; photos of Jon Kyle, Trent Lott, Joseph Biden, Daniel Moynihan and James Inhofe (M)

headline: Awaiting Verdict, Microsoft Starts Lobbying Campaign
abstract: Microsoft Corp, awaiting verdict in its antitrust trial, has begun lobbying for laws to protect company in areas where it is being challenged in court; Robert Herbold, chief operating officer, has sent letters to two million shareholders asking them to join in lobbying effort to protect company's 'freedom to innovate' (M)

headline: CENTURY HIGHLIGHTS
abstract: Stock market highlights of 20th century noted; photos (M)

headline: Shares Surge Again, With Nasdaq in Lead
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 91.21 points, or 3.17 percent, to record 2,966.43; Dow Jones industrial average rises 107.33 points, or 1 percent, to 10,729.86; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 20.49 points, or 1.53 percent, to 1,362.93; price of benchmark 30-year bond rises 1 5/32, to 99 16/32; yield falls to 6.16 percent from 6.25 percent on Oct 28; graph on Dow Jones industrial average; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: BIRMINGHAM STEEL, UNDER PRESSURE, EXPLORES SALE
abstract: Birmingham Steel Corp hires Credit Suisse First Boston to explore sale of company (S)

headline: Deutsch Gets A Domino's Account
abstract: Domino's Pizza Inc awards its national creative part of its advertising account, with billings estimated at $100 million to $120 million, to Deutsch Inc; Campbell Mithun Esty was Domino's previous agency (S)

headline: From the Drawing Board To New Life on Computer
abstract: David Kirk, author and illustrator of children's books, has long been admired by computer-assisted artists because his creations look remarkably like computer-generated images; they are, in fact, oil paintings; his work begins with hand-drawn sketches that help guide team of computer-graphic artists that creates backgrounds and characters using sophisticated computer-generated imagery, known as CGI; photo (M)

headline: Revitalized, For Work And Play
abstract: Joel Kotkin Grass-Roots Business column focuses on evolution of Dallas's Deep Ellum neighborhood from industrial area to thriving entertainment and creative business center; transformation started with cheap rents and old buildings; developers comment; map; photo (M)t

headline: COX BROADCASTING TO BUY SAN FRANCISCO TV STATION
abstract: Cox Broadcasting Inc acquires independent station KICU-TV, which broadcasts in the San Francisco Bay area; terms of agreement with KICU Inc are not disclosed (S)

headline: NEW AIR RIVALRY IN CANADA
abstract: WestJet Airlines, fast-growing discount airline serving western Canada, will begin flying to eastern Canadian cities next year to compete with Air Canada (S)

headline: Want to reach female viewers? The N.F.L. asks marketers if they're ready for some football.
abstract: Advertising column on marketing of ads aimed at women who watch NFL games on television (M)

headline: CISCO DEAL WITH PIRELLI
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc will acquire optical systems unit of Pirelli SpA for $2.15 billion in stock; graph (S)

headline: Venezuelans Give Chavez All the Powers He Wanted
abstract: Venezuelans vote overwhelmingly in favor of new Constitution that gives Pres Hugo Chavez sweeping powers he says are needed to transform country's political and social structure in 'peaceful revolution;' new Constitution, drawn up by assembly in which Chavez supporters hold more than 90 percent of seats, increases his term of office from five years to six and allows him to succeed himself; eliminates one chamber of Congress, reduces civilian control of military and significantly expands government management of economy--which is based on largest reserves of oil outside Middle East (M)

headline: RICE TAX SOUGHT
abstract: Indonesia will ask International Monetary Fund to let it tax imported rice at up to 35 percent to protect its farmers (S)

headline: Russia Sends Force to Cut Off Chechens' Route Into Georgia
abstract: Russian paratroopers cut road between Chechnya and Georgia in effort to block southern escape routes for Islamic rebels in Chechnya; move underscores that Russia is determined to win a decisive, if bloodly, victory over rebels; photo (M)

headline: Sullivan & Cromwell Names New Chairman
abstract: H Rodgin Cohen is named chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell, replacing Ricardo Mestres Jr, who will vacate chairman's office next year (S)

headline: At Bush's Ear, A Supply-Sider With a Heart
abstract: Profile of Lawrence B Lindsey, former Federal Reserve governor who is now Republican presidential candidate George W Bush's chief economic adviser; focuses on Lindsey's $483 billion tax-cutting proposal that is centerpiece of Bush's economic platform; photos (M)

headline: Favorable News on Jobs and Inflation Lifts Equity Prices
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 46.34 points, or 1.5 percent, to record 3,102.29; Dow Jones industrial average rises 64.84 points, or 0.61 percent, to 10,704.48; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 7.59, or 0.56 percent, to 1,370.23; US bond yields move lower, continuing dramatic downward spiral that began less than two weeks ago; 30-year Treasury bond rises 19/32, to 101 1/32; yield falls to 6.05 percent from 6.10 percent; graph on Dow Jones industrial average; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: Management; Forsooth, Check This Consultant
abstract: Article on Shakespeare as latest inspiration for executives in search of leadership skills; Northrop Grumman executive James G Roche, in costume, rallies his troops at retreat with famous words of King Henry V, coached along by consultant Kenneth L Adelman; photos; Adelman, former arms control director, and wife, Carol, run company called Movers and Shakespeare, which offers leadership training and impromptu playacting; Adelman explains Shakespeare's timeless inspiration; his book, and others, using historical and literary figures as inspiration noted (M)

headline: JAPANESE CHIP VENTURE
abstract: NEC Corp and Hitachi Ltd agree to form joint venture to cut costs and accelerate process of developing future generations of computer memory chips; venture, NEC-Hitachi Memory Inc, will start by year-end with aim of developing 256-megabit and 512-megabit dynamic random-access chips; venture plans to sell chips by end of March 2002 (S)

headline: When Rain Does Not Fall in Spain, the Farmers March to Protest
abstract: Spanish farmers from Andulasia province stage noisy demonstration in capital of Madrid, demanding that government take action to build more dams and pipelines to ensure steady flow of water to increasingly arid region, which is experiencing second severe drought since 1992 (M)

headline: NAVIGANT REJECTS MERGERS AND WILL REMAIN INDEPENDENT
abstract: Navigant Consulting Inc decides to remain independent after completing review of alternatives that included sale to another company; says it will seek to increase profits by expanding its existing business and making acquisitions (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Many Year 2000 Worriers Starting to Close Up Shop  After devoting months and sometimes years to raising consciousness about potential Year 2000 disruptions, many prominent worriers are folding up their tents. For example, Peter de Jager, the Canadian programmer who became a Year 2000 Paul Revere in 1993, has put Year2000.com, the popular Internet site he created, up for sale at eBay.com.    ''The crusade part of this is just about over,'' said Edward Yardeni, a Wall Street economist who still thinks there is a 70 percent chance that Year 2000 breakdowns will usher in a worldwide recession. ''Now it's just a matter of what happens. There's no point in being alarmist anymore.''   [Page C4.]

headline: Another Giant Seeks to Deflect Cable TV Criticism
abstract: AT&T Corp, facing persistent criticism for failing to give independent Internet service providers direct access to its far-flung cable television systems, will offer such access within few years and is trying to find concrete ways to demonstrate commitment; move may deflect potentially onerous conditions that could be placed on its cable operations by regulators (M)

headline: People
abstract: Sinead Clancy is named to new position of president at Jumpstart Media; Laurel Rossi, executive vice president at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, is named managing director for relationship marketing; succeeds Don White, who resigned; Jack Maged is named to new position of senior vice president and director for client services at Gigante Vaz Partners; Richard Lobel is named to new position of senior vice president for marketing and media communications at SFX Entertainment; Greg Jones is named to new position of director for corporate communications at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG (S)

headline: Britain, Land of 'le Rosbif,' Is Irate When Paris Keeps Ban
abstract: Britain reacts with fury to France's surprise announcement that because of continued fears over so-called mad-cow disease, it will not, after all, lift its ban on British beef (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Major Stock Gauges Finish 3d Quarter on Positive Note  Stocks ended the third quarter on a positive note, as a rally in the bond market helped to push major market indexes higher. They also benefited as mutual fund managers bought shares of companies that have done well to make end-of-quarter reports look better to their investors.

headline: TARMAC TALKS END
abstract: South African mining company Anglo American PLC says negotiations to acquire Tarmac PLC, Britain's largest maker of asphalt, have ended after Tarmac rejects its offer of $1.85 billion (S) (S)

headline: HONG KONG INTERNET VENTURE
abstract: Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa Ltd and Global Crossing Ltd say they will form $1.2 billion venture to offer Internet-related services in Hong Kong; new 50-50 venture will be called Hutchison Global Crossing (S)

headline: Rite Aid Restates 2 Quarters' Results
abstract: Rite Aid says it had second-quarter loss that was not as wide as it forecast, and it restates financial results for two quarters; its loss was $15.4 million in period ended Aug 28, and included $29.3 million in pretax charges for impaired assets and closing of 57 stores; last month, Rite Aid forecast loss of $67.9 million; Rite Aid restates results for year-earlier quarter and first quarter of this year (S)

headline: British M.B.A. Courses Shake Up Old School
abstract: Remarkable proliferation of business education in Great Britain has unleased cutthroat competition among growing number of schools for talent, rankings, big-name gurus and money; since 1985, number of institutions offering MBA courses has increased from 28 to 116; over same period, number of graduates has almost quadrupled, from 2,260 in 1985 to 8,752 in 1998; during past few years, Oxford and Cambridge universities have embraced business or management schools that are openly competing for students, faculty and acclaim with such established institutions as London Business School, which in one recent survey ranked as Europe's premier business school; value of business education is being questioned in light of increased number of schools and graduates; photo (M)

headline: NIELSEN PAYS $246 MILLION TO RAISE NETRATINGS STAKE
abstract: Nielsen Media Research Inc increases stake in NetRatings Inc to 54 percent from about 11 percent for $246 million (S)

headline: 14-Hour Days? They Have Other Ideas
abstract: Young lawyers, grunt workers of trade, are abandoning employers in droves, either moving to other firms or jobs or leaving profession altogether; pushing trend is profession's hunger for billable hours to offset starting average salaries of $85,000 nationwide; big firms often push new hires to work upwards of 70 hours per week or more, and many are becoming burned out; photo (M)

headline: Crazy, Sexy, Cool: Virtual Beauty Makeovers
abstract: J D Biersdorfer reviews software Istyle Personal Makeover, from Sierra Home, and Cosmopolitan Virtual Makeover 2 Deluxe, from Broderbund; notes both programs allow user to load photograph of herself from scanner or digital camera and then try on variety of cosmetics and hairstyles; photos (M),

headline: Compressed Data; A Dot-Com Takes Aim At Market for Green Power
abstract: Add another product to the lengthening list of things you can buy with a mouse click. Now it's green energy: power derived from windmills, solar panels, anything that does not pollute the air.     GreenMountain.com plays middleman between wind farms and other clean sources of electricity and consumers who want to feel guilt-free when they flick an electric switch.

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.31   5.21   5.05        3-month T-bills   4.92   4.95   4.47        6-month T-bills   5.09   5.09   4.48        10-yr. headline: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF GATEWAY TO STEP ASIDE
abstract: Gateway Inc says its chief executive, Theodore W Waitt, founder of company, is stepping aside and will be replaced by company's president, Jeffrey Weitzen; Waitt remains chairman and Weitzen will retain his president title (S)

headline: NO BID BY DELLA VALLE
abstract: Diego Della Valle, Italian businessman who owns maker of J P Tod loafers, has decided against bidding for Church & Co PLC, 126-year-old British shoemaker, because he considers current price too high; photo (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    PAKISTAN: MORE CHARGED FOR CORRUPTION -- Shahbaz Sharif, left, has joined his older brother, the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, on the list of those accused by the new military government of treason and hijacking. ''I am innocent, why am I in police custody?'' the younger Mr. Sharif said in a court appearance. Two other Sharif family loyalists have also been accused in the case -- Saifur Rehman, the former chief of the government's anti-corruption unit, and Saeed Mehdi, who was Nawaz Sharif's principal secretary.   Barry Bearak (NYT)    INDIA: MORE MILITARY SPENDING SOUGHT -- The military budget should be increased from 2.3 percent of India's gross domestic product to 3 percent, the defense minister, George Fernandes, told a military conference in New Delhi, according to the Press Trust of India. The conflict with Pakistan in Kashmir this year demonstrated the need for more spending, he said.   Barry Bearak (NYT)

headline: G.M. Wants Daewoo Motor But Not Its Billions in Debt
abstract: General Motors Corp makes official its desire to buy Daewoo Motor Co, but says it is unwilling to assume any of automaker's $16 billion in debt; GM executive vice president Louis R Hughes, who is in Seoul, delivers letter of intent containing company's investment plans to South Korean committee that represents domestic creditors of troubled Daewoo group; photo (M)

headline: Assignments Traded On 2 Unilever Brands
abstract: US home and personal care unit of Unilever will switch advertising accounts of two large detergent brands between two roster agencies; All detergent, handled by Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, is moving to J Walter Thompson, and Wisk detergent is moving to Ammirati Puris from Thompson (S)

headline: Scratching the Popular Itch to Switch Jobs
abstract: Article on risks of changing career in midlife; focuses on Sally Poliak, former political consultant in Washington State who is now manager at Microsoft Corp; Poliak comments; photo (M)

headline: Online Investors Grasping Initial Offerings
abstract: Growing number of small investors are exploiting extraordinarily buoyant market for new stocks by buying and quickly reselling shares of initial public offerings; demand is so great that services have sprung up to keep investors posted on latest news about offerings and established brokerage firms are changing their businesses to cater to people who want to actively trade these and other stocks via computer; graph of average first-day gains for initial offerings; table of best offering months; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises after industry report shows US fuel inventories dropped more than expected last week; in New York, crude oil for January delivery rose 63 cents York, crude oil for January delivery gains 63 cents, to $26.36 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Rite Aid Names a New Management Team
abstract: The Rite Aid Corporation, the troubled drug store chain, has chosen a new top management team, the company said yesterday. The new chief executive wasted no time in saying he would try to sell fewer assets than had been expected.    Robert G. Miller, 55, who will take over today as chairman and chief executive, said Rite Aid would continue to try to sell PCS Health Systems, a company that administers pharmacy benefits. But he said he would halt efforts to sell some of the 1,000 West Coast drug stores owned by Rite Aid. ''We think the best approach is to fill the stores up with merchandise, clean them up and take care of the customers,'' Mr. Miller said in a telephone interview.

headline: EXPORT SUBSIDIES CRITICIZED
abstract: US Agriculture Sec Dan Glickman says changes in global trade of farm products are 'extremely high priority' of US government; says increasing market access and eliminating trade-distorting domestic supports and export subsidies are important American goals in next round of negotiations by World Trade Organization, set to begin in Seattle on Nov 30; photo (S)

headline: A Medicine Chest or a Grocery Shelf?
abstract: Article on health benefits of 'functional foods,' being marketed by drug and consumer-goods companies; says grocery aisles are stacked with rows of margarines, breakfast cereals, salad dressings and snacks that promise to fight heart disease, osteoporosis and other ailments; in some cases, products are billed as alternatives to medicine; says critics contend that some manufacturers exaggerate products' health benefits, especially when brand may contain ingredients that do as much harm as good; Michael F Jacobson, executive director of Center for Science in the Public Interest, says there is a lot of quackery; photos (M)

headline: Webvan Is Delaying Its Offering of Stock
abstract: Webvan Group, on-line grocer, temporarily shelves public offering of its stock, apparently running afoul of regulators by giving out unpublished information in conference call; lawyers and Wall Street analysts say disclosing information not in public filings may violate securities laws; Webvan and its underwriter, Goldman, Sachs, issue statement saying Securities and Exchange Commission and Weban have agreed to cooling-off period prior to commencement of offering (M)

headline: MEAD SELLS ITS 50% STAKE IN NORTHWOOD TO CANFOR
abstract: Mead Corp says that it has sold its 50 percent stake in Northwood Inc to Canfor Corp for $216.3 million in cash and securities (S)

headline: European Union's Tough but Relentless Drive to Expand
abstract: Europe will enter new year and new millennium on a mission of staggering scale: expansion of European Union by 13 countries and some 170 million people, even as feuds and competition have marked integration of current 15 members; charts of current members countries, countries in membership negotiations, and countries that may start membership negotiations; map (M)

headline: Robert A. Swanson Dies at 52; Early Leader in Biotechnology
abstract: Robert A. Swanson, who co-founded Genentech Inc. and is considered the father of the biotechnology industry, died Monday at his home in Hillsborough, Calif., after a yearlong battle with brain cancer. He was 52.     Mr. Swanson was a 29-year-old venture capitalist in 1976 when he started Genentech, the first company formed to exploit the then new technology of genetic engineering. Now, there are more than 1,000 biotechnology companies in the United States alone, but Genentech has remained one of the two or three most successful.

headline: Khartoum Journal; Artist Returns From Europe to Rediscover Sudan
abstract: Rashid Diab, 43-year-old Sudanese artist, abandons good life in Madrid to return to Sudan; he left as promising art student two decades ago and has now come back with his wife, two children and an ambition: to create a culture of art inside Sudan, nation that produces many fine artists but cannot seem to keep hold of them; he wants to make Sudan self-reliant artistically by teaching young artists to mix their own paint, to make their own materials for etching, to find local stone for sculpture; photo (M)

headline: DIEBOLD TO BUY BRAZILIAN A.T.M. MAKER
abstract: Automated teller machine manufacturer Diebold Inc acquires Procomp Amazonia Industria Electronica SA, Brazilian maker of ATM's, for $225 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Central Banker, An Inflation Foe, Resigns in Israel
abstract: Israel's long-serving central bank chief, Jacob Frenkel, announces that he will step down in Jan; unexpected move could give Prime Min Ehud Barak opportunity to cut steep interest rates that bank's critics say have unnecessarily slowed Israel's economic growth; Frenkel is credited with wrestling down double-digit inflation, but he has been criticized for refusing to ease high real interest rates (M)

headline: Shell Account Shifts to Thompson
abstract: Joint venture companies that market Shell brand of gasolines, lubricants and other products and services at Shell stations in US have awarded their advertising account to new Houston office of J Walter Thompson; billings estimated at $60 million; Houston office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide had handled account since 1960 (S)

headline: Croatia Mourns Founder of the Nation
abstract: Croatia declares three days of mourning for Pres Franjo Tudjman; his death comes at time of economic troubles and widespread allegations of corruption that have put both Tujdman and his party, the HDZ, at low points in their popularity; HDZ is expected to continue to use the aura of Tudjman to try to improve its chances in Jan 3 parliamentary elections, where it appear to face defeat (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: COCOA FALLS. Cocoa prices fell after growers in the Ivory Coast ended a protest that had disrupted exports from the world's biggest grower. In New York, cocoa for March delivery fell $32, or 3.6 percent, to $867 a metric ton.

headline: NORTEL TO CUT AS MANY AS 1,000 JOBS NEXT YEAR
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp will cut as many as 1,000 jobs, or 1.5 percent of its work force, next year to reduce overlap and contract out more business (S)

headline: The Piano Man Sings For Baron Shareholders
abstract: When it comes to having a party, mutual fund types have never been able to hold a candle to Hollywood -- or even to high-spirited accountants who want to celebrate a revision in the tax code.    Ronald Baron of Baron Capital, a money manager, wants to change that. A case in point is the annual investment conference he held on Friday in Manhattan for current and prospective shareholders.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Oracle Net Tops Estimates, Lifting Stock After Hours  Shares of Oracle, the maker of database software, soared in after-hours trading after the company reported second-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street estimates by 4 cents a share. Oracle's stock had dropped $2.875, to $76.9375 a share, in regular trading, but it jumped to $84 a share after the close.

headline: Safety and the S.U.V.
abstract: Thomas E Salyers letter on October 3 article on safety concerns over sport utility vehicles notes that their poor fuel efficiency is another reason to reject them (S)

headline: Air Express Deal Gets Clearance
abstract: Deutsche Post, Germany's government-owned mail service, receives US clearance to proceed with its $1.14 billion purchase of Air Express International Corp (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: NATURAL GAS SLIDES. Prices for natural gas prices fell as mild weather in large United States markets reduced heating demands. In New York, natural gas for January delivery fell 7.8 cents, to $2.444 a million B.T.U.'s.

headline: WARNACO TO BUY AUTHENTIC FITNESS FOR $426.1 MILLION
abstract: Apparel maker Warnaco Group agrees to acquire Authentic Fitness Corp for $426.1 million and assumption of $105 million of debt (S)

headline: The Screech of a Broken Record
abstract: Roundup of week's stock market activity, which marked end of largely negative third quarter; graphs (M)

headline: NO INTEREST IN KOREAN STEEL MAKER
abstract: South Korea's state-run Korea Development Bank has failed to sell its 12.8 percent stake in the Pohang Iron and Steel Company, one of the world's biggest steel makers. An auction on Saturday failed to attract bidders, and the bank said it is unclear whether another auction will be scheduled.     Samuel Len

headline: Who, What, When, Where and Y2K; Watching for Bugs
abstract: Opportunities abound to watch arrival of new century on Web as it occurs across earth's 24 time zones; there are Webcams around world, Y2K information sites, news sites and many other relevant places online; photos (M)

headline: C.I.A. Papers Show Struggle to Keep Pace as U.S.S.R. Unraveled
abstract: Declassified United States government documents show that analysts at CIA were deeply pessimistic about of success for Pres Mikhail Gorbachev's efforts to reform Soviet Union's Communist system even in final days of cold war; CIA experts in late 1980's and early 1990's came to believe that Gorbachev was genuinely interested in reform, yet agency remained concerned that political instability could lead to return to hard-line Communist rule or anarchy (M)

headline: TV RENTAL MERGER
abstract: Granada Group, Britain, operator of television networks and hotels, to merge its television rental unit with division of Thorn UK, forming new company called Box Clever; Box Clever will acquire Granada's operation for $966 million and buy Thorn UK's rental unit for $612 million; merged company will be largest renter of television in Britain (S)

headline: Memo From Islamabad; Why Democracy Means Little to Pakistan's Poor
abstract: Fates of Saidpur and Bani Gala, rural villages on outskirts of Islamabad, that are respectively impoverished and affluent, could serve as metaophor for failings of democracy in Pakistan, where law is believed to absolve high and mighty while it wantonly crushes poor; even though residents of both were accused by authorities of inhabiting villages illegally, bulldozers destroyed Saidpur after politicians and bureaucratic appointees felt it was eyesore on route used by very important people; nearby Bani Gala, whose stately villas were slated for demolition because government felt their sewage polluted water supplies of Rawalpindi and Islamabed, used money and political pull to stave off destruction and save their grand mansions; photos (M)

headline: Credit Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and an auction of two-year notes on Wednesday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.91 percent, and a six-month bill was 5.04 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.90 percent.

headline: Despite appearances, dot-com companies try to spend advertising dollars effectively.
abstract: Media Edge, one of largest agencies devoted to media services and part of Young & Rubicam, is forming unit called Digital Edge, which will focus on planning and buying Internet media, electronic commerce, fledgling technologies like video on demand and so-called convergence of new and traditional media (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Mozambique Enlists Healers in AIDS Prevention
abstract: Curandeiros, traditional healers banned by government of Mozambique for nearly two decades of civil war, are being embraced as vital bearers of safe-sex message in fight against AIDS; government will link teams of trained healers directly to hospitals, which have been overwhelmed by influx of patients infected with HIV; healers will begin treating patients at home, freeing up hospital beds for other sick people; will use herbs and plants that health officials say effectively treat opportunistic diseases that afflicts those whose immune systems are impaired by AIDS; photos; map (M)

headline: ENRON IN TALKS TO BUY CANADIAN PULP AND LUMBER MILL

headline: William Nickerson, 91, Writer Of Popular Investment Books
abstract: William E. Nickerson, who made millions of dollars from real estate investments and millions more writing books telling others how to do the same thing, died on Oct. 19 at his home in Capitola, Calif. He was 91.    Reflecting his strong religious beliefs as a lifelong Congregationalist, he gave away his entire estate to pay for student scholarships and professorships to divinity and religiously oriented schools that he considered ''ecumenically and pluralistically minded.''
