headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: BOMB ALERT  Scotland Yard has added street patrols, tightened security in cities and issued warnings to major companies, utilities and military and political figures for fear of a possible bombing campaign by renegade groups opposed to the Northern Ireland peace accord. ''There is a genuine and credible concern about the increased threat of violence'' in Britain and Ireland, a spokeswoman said.     Warren Hoge (NYT)    NORTHERN IRELAND: QUEEN HONORS POLICE  The Queen awarded the George Cross, one of the monarchy's highest honors, to the Royal Ulster Constabulary for its ''courage and dedication.'' The award to the mainly Protestant force was praised by the Ulster Unionist Party, which this weekend will decide whether to enter government with Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. A Sinn Fein spokeswoman branded the action ''grossly offensive.''     Warren Hoge (NYT)    ROMANIA: 5,000 IN PROTEST  At least 5,000 workers gathered in Bucharest to demand the resignation of the government, in the latest protest fueled by frustration with plummeting living standards. The demonstrators chanted ''Resignation!'' and ''You thieves!'' in a protest organized by a trade union that says it has three million members. The government says it cannot afford to improve living standards.     (AP)    FRANCE: McDONALD'S FIGHTS BACK  McDonald's restaurants, the repeated focus of anti-American protests, are fighting back with an advertising campaign highlighting a policy of buying French farm products. Using the slogan ''Born in the U.S., made in France,'' the ads promise McDonald's will not buy American beef, and guarantee its ''basic products'' are not genetically modified. ''Not bad for a company accused of poisoning its clients,'' the ads read.     Suzanne Daley (NYT)    RUSSIA: JEHOVAH VICTORY  The Constitutional Court struck down a key part of a law that had kept some religions, including Jehovah's Witnesses, from legally operating in Russia. The court waived for some non-traditional religions a rule barring their registration unless they could prove they had existed in Russia for 15 years -- a difficult hurdle because the Soviet Union banned many faiths. The court left other curbs on smaller groups intact, and the Jehovah's Witnesses called the ruling only a partial victory.     Michael Wines (NYT)    ASIA    EAST TIMOR: FILIPINO OFFERED COMMAND  General Kofi Annan, responding to Asian requests for an Asian commander of the United Nations force that will take over peacekeeping in East Timor from an Australian-led international force next year, has decided to appoint a Filipino officer. The Philippines said it would nominate Maj. Gen. Diomedio Villanueva, a provincial military commander.     Barbara Crossette (NYT)    AFGHANISTAN: TALIBAN OFFER  The new foreign minister, Wakil Ahmad Muttawakil, renewed the Taliban's offer of unconditional talks with the United States over Osama bin Laden, the Saudi-born militant who has been given refuge in the country. Mr. bin Laden is wanted by Washington on charges that he was involved in the bombing of two American embassies in Africa last year. There have been no American contacts with the Taliban since sanctions were placed on Afghanistan on Nov. 14.     Barbara Crossette (NYT)    PAKISTAN: SHARIF DAUGHTER'S PLEA  In a plea for her father's life, a daughter of the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, called on rights groups to monitor his coming trial on accusations of treason and conspiracy to murder. ''My innocent father does not deserve hanging or any punishment because he has not committed any crime,'' Marryam Nawaz, 25, told Agence France-Presse.     Barry Bearak (NYT)    THE AMERICAS    MEXICO: 'PEACE' PARTY FIGHT  A split in the Green Party, whose slogan is ''peace and respect for life,'' set off a vicious attack. Dissidents organized a rump assembly to challenge the presidential candidacy of the Green Party's founder, Jorge Gonzalez Torres, who has often thrown the party's weight behind President Ernesto Zedillo's governing PRI in exchange for political favors. Fifty thugs loyal to Mr. Gonzalez invaded the assembly, beating dissidents with chairs.     Sam Dillon (NYT)    AFRICA    NIGERIA: EX-ARMY CHIEF CHARGED  The former army chief, Gen. Ishaya Bamaiyi, was charged with the attempted murder of a newspaper publisher in 1996 during the rule of the dictator Gen. Sani Abacha. General Bamaiyi, who was forced to retire by President Olusegun Obasanjo immediately after the inauguration of the civilian government on May 29, was charged with four others in the shooting of Alex Ibru, publisher of The Guardian.     Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)    BURUNDI: 22 DIE IN CLASHES  A grenade attack killed at least four people in the central market in Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi. Other clashes on the city's outskirts killed some 15 rebels and at least four soldiers, Government and relief officials said. Violence has been intensifying in Burundi, a small nation bordering Rwanda, in which Hutu rebels have waged a six-year civil war against the Tutsi-dominated government and its army.     Ian Fisher (NYT)    MIDDLE EAST    JORDAN: TOY GUN ATTACK  The Jordanian police shot a man they thought was attacking the Israeli Embassy in Amman when he brandished what turned out to be a toy pistol. The 20-year-old man was wounded in the hand and overpowered 30 yards from the embassy, the Interior Ministry said. It turned out that ''the shots fired were only sound blasts,'' said a ministry statement.     (AP)

headline: Auctions of Bills Are Scheduled by the Treasury for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and tomorrow's sale of 52-week bills.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 5.08 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.28 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 5.36 percent.

abstract: PARIS—  Does John Galliano know more than we do about the financial strategy at Dior? Is a merger with Hermes (not to mention Gucci and Versace) really on the Tarot cards? And was that why the designer sent out denim skirts dangling drunkenly over laced-up boots, all tricked out with prints for which Hermes might sue for copyright? headline: SHORT-TERM RATES ARE RAISED BY FED A QUARTER-POINT
abstract: Federal Reserve raises short-term interest rates to 5.5 percent from 5.25 percent, saying combination of strong growth and low unemployment has left economy vulnerable to inflation; move follows two previous quarter-point increases in June and August; agency also increases largely symbolic discount rates on loans to financial institutions from Federal Reserve system to 5 percent, from 4.75 percent; removes formal bias toward higher rates, adopting neutral stance that analysts believe rules out further increases for remainder of year; Dow Jones Industrial surges 171.58 points in reaction to decision, closing at highest level in more than two months at 10,932.33; photo; graph (M)

headline: Sweden, the Welfare State, Basks in a New Prosperity
abstract: Profile of Sweden, largely unreconstructed welfare state and one of Europe's most vibrant economies; after nearly three decades of sluggishness in which output per person slumped from third-highest in world to 18th, just behind Italy, Swedish economy is in midst of powerful transformation; Sweden's recent boom is in part a cyclical recovery from back-to-back recessions; but it also reflects wider pattern in Europe and a particularly nuanced reaction to robust United States economy of 90's; for even as Sweden, like many countries in Western Europe, is continuing to preserve traditional European social programs, it has also been embracing entrepreneurship and unrestricted competition; while Government continues to finance health care, education and many social services, Sweden has deregulated industries from telecommunications to airlines and banking; as result, new companies and high technology have flourished; graph, chart on Sweden's economy (L)

headline: BIG SELLOFF CAPS DOW'S WORST WEEK SINCE OCTOBER '89
abstract: A jittery stock market dropped sharply yesterday after an inflation report showed prices rising at an unexpectedly rapid rate and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, alarmed investors by warning that the stock market might be riskier than many people believe. The market suffered its worst week in a decade.    The Dow Jones industrial average traded below 10,000 for the first time since April. It rallied a bit, to close at 10,019.71, but still was down 266.90 points, or 2.59 percent, for the day. The weekly decline of 5.9 percent was the worst since a fall of 7.8 percent in the week ended Oct. 13, 1989. That problems are happening again in October -- a month that has recorded steep drops before -- added to the market's nervousness.

headline: Frontrunner In Indonesia Seems to Fall Off the Pace
abstract: Megawati Sukarnoputri, front-runner in race for Indonesian presidency, has suffered startling string of defeats in pivotal meeting of nation's Consultative Assembly; anaylsts cite her unwillingness to make deals with rival parties; some say she will not be able to assemble enough votes to secure presidency; there are signs that she is finally confronting problem; photo (M)

abstract: PARIS—  Quietly propelled by the return of an elegant femininity, after a long period of retirement, a former prima donna of fashion — the little black dress — is making a comeback as a chic and timeless uniform for fashion-jaded consumers.

headline: Blood, Gore, Sex and Now: Race
abstract: Series of rapid developments, both technological and sociological, are allowing blacks and members of other minority groups to be represented in more and more computer games as fully realized characters; in a broad range of new releases, nonwhite characters are stars rather than players in variety of action games; new technology has enabled software firms to draw computer game characters of identifiable races, including voice; some players see new games as favorable sign that race and sex have come to have less signifance in society; contrary view is expressed by others, including Adam Clayton Powell 3d, vice president for Freedom Forum, advocacy group for journalists and journalism education; Powell expresses concern about threat of further racial stereotyping in computer games, which he calls 'high-tech blackface'; photos, including some of games that feature minority-action characters (L)

headline: U.S. Seeks Missile System Despite Treaty Risk
abstract: Clinton administration says it mat forge ahead with new national missile defense system, even if it means withdrawing from 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty; defense undersecretary Walter B Slocombe says administration will not allow any country to have veto power on actions that may be needed for defense of nation; Russia wins support from many of Washington's allies for keeping treaty intact in largely symbolic vote at UN; Russia-sponsored resolution opposing any new missile defense system that attempts to undermine or circumvent ABM treaty wins lopsided committee vote of 54 to 7, with all members of European Union either voting with Russia or abstaining (M)

headline: Signs of Landmark Accord In U.S.-China Trade Talks
abstract: US and China seem near accord on international trade pact on sixth day of talks in Beijing that would grant China membership in World Trade Organization (S)

headline: Navigating the Economy of a Changing Germany
abstract: Entering the new home of Germany's Ministry of Finance here is like walking into a time warp. Situated in a Nazi-era building east of the old Berlin Wall, the facade features a huge mural celebrating the founding of Communist East Germany. In the mural, women in blue uniforms march proudly with banners celebrating socialism, flanked by smiling factory workers and sturdy farmers.    Hans Eichel, the German finance minister, took up quarters here when the government officially moved from Bonn to Berlin late in August.

headline: Judge Dismisses Incest Case Against Swiss Boy of 11
abstract: GENEVA—  A judge in Colorado has dismissed charges against an 11-year-old Swiss boy accused of molesting his sister, ending a dispute over differences in the way the United States and Switzerland handle possible juvenile offenders.

headline: A $6 Billion Merger Would Create a Transcontinental Railroad
abstract: Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corp and Canadian National Railway Co announce $6 billion merger that would create largest railroad in North America; Burlington will own two-thirds of new company, North American Railways, and Canadian National stockholders will receive 1.05 shares of North American for each of their shares; Burlington stockholders will get share of new company for each of their shares; combined company will employ 67,000 people and have annual revenue of about $12.5 billion; will have 50,000 miles of track connecting every state west of Mississippi and every major city across Canada; will be based in Montreal, but Burlington will run some of operations from offices in Fort Worth; Canadian National chief executive Paul Tellier will head new company; Robert Krebs, Burlington Northern chairman, will be nonexecutive chairman; deal faces regulatory scrutiny in US and Canada; photo; map (M)

headline: ABC Executive Will Head CNN's Financial Network
abstract: ABC Executive Will Head CNN's Financia

headline: TOYOTA OPERATING EARNINGS FALL
abstract: Toyota Motor Co says first-half earnings rose 4.7 percent; net income rose to 201.66 billion yen ($1.91 billion) in six months ended Sept 30 from 192 billion yen a year earlier; pretax profit fell 1 percent, to 404.54 billion yen because of 12 percent rise in yen (S)

headline: Senate to Begin Debate on Nuclear Test Ban Treaty Next Week
abstract: Senate to Begin Debate on Nuclear Test Ban

headline: Indonesia Cabinet to Include Ousted Party
abstract: Abdurrahman Wahid, Indonesia's new President, concedes he will have to include members of President Suharto's discredited administration in Cabinet; seeks to assure business sector that country will play by rules of international marketplace and welcome foreign investors; says foreign investment is most important for Indonesia's economy; map (M)

headline: Dow Watchers' Alert: Here Comes October Dread
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer Portfolios etc column, recalling Dow Jones industrial average's poor performance in past Octobers, speculates on what may happen this year; graph (M)

headline: A Gift or an Estate? That Is the Multimillion-Dollar Question
abstract: Article details case of Paula Kennedy and her siblings, who Internal Revenue Service has been pursuing for 13 years in attempt to collect $12 million tax lien on boys' camp and undeveloped property they inherited from their mother, Elizabeth Boyer; photos; case raises questions about competence of Government lawyers and unwillingness of IRS to close cases that have little chance of generating money; photos; graph (L)

headline: Romania Sees Promise of Prosperity Slip Away
abstract: Romania's economic prosperity, which almost vanished under dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu, grows even more remote 10 years after revolution that toppled Communism; often-overlooked agrarian country of 22 million, bigger than most Eastern European neighbors, is going through harder times than most; economy, in which any capitalist initiative was throttled by Stalinist system more severe than any East European regime outside Albania, has been unable to adapt to free-market system; middle class, vital for carrying out capitalist reforms, numbers less than 5 percent of population, compared with 30 percent in Czechoslovakia, 20 percent in Hungary and 15 percent in Poland; country's average wage has slipped, to $80 per month, and one-third of population lives on less than $2 per day; violent strikes reminiscent of Ceausescu's waning days have returned; government of Pres Emil Constantinescu--fragile and bickering multiparty coalition elected in 1997 with great hopes for change--is in turmoil; has been accused of corruption and of bungling economy; has not planned 10th anniversary celebration of revolution out of fear that any spark could set off rioting; photos; map (M)

headline: Senate Backs Lower Import Tax On Africa and Caribbean Goods
abstract: Senate, 74-23, votes to end filibuster led by Sen Ernest F Hollings, and to approve bill to reduce or eliminate duties on wide range of goods from sub-Saharan Africa, Central America and Caribbean Area (M)

headline: Big Consultants Woo Employees by Offering a Piece of the Action
abstract: Presigious firms, already offering six-figure salaries, will now let employees take up to two months off each year to get special access to Internet investment funds; world's top consultants are resorting to special perks as they battle tide of E-commerce that is stealing many of their best job candidates and employees; consulting firms are trying to hire and keep people by emphasizing advantages of secure job while trying to copy some of perquisites of start-ups; incentives offered by firms, including McKinsey & Co, Mercer Management Consulting, Andersen Consulting and Deloitte Consulting, discussed (M)

headline: Making Alterations For the New Dow 30
abstract: Dow Jones Industrial average completes overhaul by dropping Union Carbide, Goodyear, Chevrolet and Sears Roebuck and adding Microsoft, Intel, Home Depot and SBC Communications; mutual fund co-manager Richard Moroney and others predict increase in fund turnovers (M)

headline: Ailing Foreign Policy
abstract: News analysis: some members of Clinton Administration and Congressional officials wonder if Pres Clinton's authority on foreign affairs has been prematurely crippled by his failure to win nuclear test ban treaty; Administration has not made any sustained preparations for realizing short list of major foreign policy goals still cherished by President (M)

headline: 3 Executives Promoted at Bates
abstract: Bates Worldwide promotes executives Jean de Yturbe, Ian Smith and Bill Whitehead to new positions in management reorganization; their new posts described (S)

headline: After 8 Days of Bombing Chechnya, Moscow Cuts Links
abstract: Prime Min Vladimir V Putin, in move that could intensify conflict in northern Caucasus, cuts Russia's last links with elected government of breakaway republic of Chechnya; photo (M)

headline: Intrepid Helmsman At St. Martin's Press; Publisher's Unit Sails Through a Storm
abstract: Profile of and interview with Thomas Dunne, who has guided St Martin's Press to string of publishing successes; Dunne, 53, has created his own literary fief with an imprint that scorns snobbery, prizes the quirky and commercial, and flourishes through a unique form of high-volume publishing that has occasional perils; Dunne has penchant for publishing reprints of British literature; photos (L)

headline: Business Travel; The latest surcharge at many hotels intends to make guests pay for using phone lines too long.
abstract: Growing number of hotels are imposing new fees on extended use of local and toll-free telephone numbers to keep guests from plugging in their laptops for hours and tying up trunk lines; Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide chains are latest to charge fees; Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is eliminating 540 parking spaces in parking lots of Terminal C at Newark International Airport as it begins $1.5 billion redevelopment program there (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: DIMINISHED BRAZILIAN INFLATION
abstract: Brazil's benchmark inflation rate slowed to its lowest level in three months in September; consumer prices rose 0.31 percent, compared with 0.56 percent increase in August (S)

headline: Maytag's Net Income Shows Rise of 5.6%
abstract: Maytag Corp says third-quarter profit rose 5.6 percent, exceeding reduced estimates; net income rose to $81.9 million compared with profit from operations of $77.4 million a year ago; revenue rose 3 percent, to $1.07 billion from $1.04 billion (S)

headline: Productivity Grew Sharply In 3rd Quarter
abstract: Worker productivity grew at a faster pace in the third quarter than originally estimated and labor costs fell for the first time in more than two years, government figures released today showed.    Productivity -- an index of output per hour worked -- rose at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the third quarter, up from initial reports of a 4.2 percent increase, the Labor Department said today. That follows a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter and is the biggest gain in almost seven years.

headline: Toronto TV Station Adopts Web-Page Format
abstract: Cable Pulse 24, a Chum Limited television station in Toronto, offers round-the-clock news in format that looks more like a World Wide Web page than a traditional video screen; photo (M)

headline: Morton Making Two Acquisitions
abstract: Jack Morton Co is acquiring Creation Communications in London and De Otter & De Vries Live Communications in Berlin (S)

headline: For Hard Hats, a Confusion of Tongues
abstract: Article on ways of keeping lines of communications open in building construction industry as more immigrants work in construction trade; says communicating with each other in industry where misunderstandings can set in motion million-dollar mistakes--or cost lives; says language training programs are offered to construction workers, especially in English and Spanish; photo (M)

headline: Kroger Earnings Rise 23%
abstract: The Kroger Company, the largest United States supermarket operator, said fiscal third-quarter profit rose 23 percent as sales of store-brand goods increased and acquisitions helped it negotiate lower prices from suppliers. Profit from operations rose to $202 million, or 24 cents a share, from $164 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the quarter ended Nov. 6 fell 10 percent, to $10.3 billion from $11.5 billion. Kroger bought Fred Meyer Inc. in May for $13.5 billion.

headline: Management Changes For McCann-Erickson
abstract: Don Dillon regional director for McCann-Erickson North America, is named regional director at McCann-Erickson Africa, Europe and Middle East; Dillon succeeds Jim Heekin, who was recently named president and chief executive at McCann-Erickson Worldwide; Tony Miller will assume Dillon's duties (S)

headline: ONEX ACQUIRES CORDENA CALL FOR $51 MILLION
abstract: Onex Corp says its Clientlogic Corp subsidiary has acquired Cordena Call Management BV for $51 million (S)

headline: Tokyo Further Clouds Issue Of What's Up With the Yen
abstract: Bank of Japan moves to expand range of tools it can use to increase supply of money in economy to help weaken resurgent yen; currency initially tumbles more than 1 percent in response to action, taken by central bank after unusually long monthly meeting of its policy board; there is considerable confusion in markets about whether bank's action represents policy change or something less significant; yen's strength is threatening to undermine Japan's slow recovery from its worst recession in half-century by hurting sales and profits of Japanese exporters; yen recovers from low of 107.96 to dollar immediately after bank's meeting to 106.60 to dollar by end of trading in New York; graph; chart (M)

headline: Small Entrepreneurs Tired of Russian Politicians
abstract: Small entrepreneurs in Voronezh, Russia, are approaching parliamentary elections with feelings of apathy and disgust at power struggle under way in Kremlin; feel politicians have done little to help them and have little use for vote-seeking politicians as they once did for Communist apparatchiks; feel best they can hope for is to be left alone; map; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: American Home Products To Settle Fen-Phen Cases  American Home Products agreed to pay $350 million to settle 1,400 cases brought in Mississippi over its diet drug combination fen-phen, a liability that could endanger its proposed $70 billion merger with Warner-Lambert.    The company moved to settle the cases after a Mississippi jury had awarded $150 million in compensatory damages to five plaintiffs, four of whom said the drugs had caused them to develop an often fatal lung illness.   [Page C2.]    Egypt to Ship Natural Gas to Israel  Egypt will provide natural gas to Israel through a long-delayed pipeline in a deal that will radically change Israel's energy policy and its economic relationship with its most powerful neighbor.   [C2.]

headline: Morgan Stanley to Offer On-Line Trading to All Its Customers
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, in major strategy shift, plans to overhaul its brokerage business and offer all its clients option of trading stocks on line at discount prices; reportedly plans to offer on-line option immediately, beating Merrill Lynch & Co by at least six weeks; envisions rolling its existing on-line discount brokerage unit, Discover Brokerage Direct, together with traditional Morgan Stanley brokerage services; will convert its 450 offices nationwide where brokers work into walk-in retail centers (M)

headline: People
abstract: Recent appointments and assignments in advertising industry noted (M)

headline: A Kodak-Matsushita Deal
abstract: Eastman Kodak and Panasonic Disc Services, unit of Matsushita, form venture to make DVD's and blank CD's; Panasonic will hold 51 percent stake in new company--Matsushita Media Manufacturing LLC of America--and Kodak will have 49 percent stake (S)

headline: Internet Group Approves Domain Registration Rules
abstract: Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or ICANN, approves terms for opening network's address registration businesses to full-scale competition, ending six-year monopoly that enriched Network Solutions Inc; landmark document marks victory for group, whose first year has been rocked by dissension and controversy; agreement spells out terms under which Network Solutions will open its business to more than 80 companies around world already approved to compete in registration of Internet addresses, or domains, that end in popular .com, .net and .org suffixes (M)

headline: China and U.S. Resume Talks On Trade in a Hopeful Spirit
abstract: Senior American and Chinese trade officials, expressing optimism, meet in Bejing in renewed negotiations over China's entry into World Trade Organization (M)

headline: Cap Gemini Is in Talks With Ernst & Young
abstract: Cap Gemini S.A., Europe's largest computer services company, said here today that it was in talks that could lead to a venture with the management consulting unit of the American accounting giant Ernst & Young L.L.P.    A British newspaper, Sunday Business, reported the day before that Cap Gemini was in talks to acquire Ernst & Young's consulting business for 3 billion [pounds], or about $4.8 billion.

headline: Expatriates Take Over in West : Shifting Scene In Chinese Art
abstract: NEW YORK—  Slowly, irresistibly, the Chinese art scene in the West, from auction houses to museums, is passing into the hands of the multifaceted expatriate Chinese elite.

headline: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
abstract: Brief excerpt from earlier article on The Library of Congress: Eyes of the Nation, interactive CD-ROM exploring American experience through documents from Library of Congress; photo (S)

headline: INVESTING; Seeing Value in a Stake, And Even in the Steaks
abstract: Real estate mogul and value investor Sam Zell's role in attempting to revive lagging Chart House Enterprises, which owns chain of 52 steak and seafood restaurants, described; photo (M)

headline: What to Ask the Doctor
abstract: M Meryle Secrest letter takes exception to Dr O Alton Barron's November 4 view that overuse accounts for upper arm pain among computer users

headline: Behind a Thud in an Internet Stock Price
abstract: Plunge in InterTrust Technologies Corp stock after analyst from Salomon Smith Barney, one of four original underwriters of stock, gave it lowly 'hold' rating offers insight into how analysts deal with challenge of valuing companies in evolving Internet market; analysts say valuing early-stage companies like InterTrust is more art than science; graph (M)

headline: MCI Worldcom Stock Falls More Than 5%
abstract: Shares of MCI Worldcom fall more than 5 percent amid fears that revenue growth is slowing as a price war continues in residential long-distance telephone market (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Cracks in Canada's Glass Ceiling; Women Get Some Top Posts, but Few Boardroom Keys
abstract: Women have suddenly begun appearing in pinnacles of corporate Canada in last decade, as social and economic changes have swept country; by some measures, they have been more successful than their American counterparts; women now run two of three largest companies on Canada's Financial Post 500 list: General Motors of Canada and Ford Motor Co of Canada; over all, women run 10 of largest companies in Canada; by comparison, just three of companies on Fortune 500 list--and none of top three--are run by women; number of women entrepreneurs tripled over last two decades, to 777,000 in 1997; with only 6 percent of boardroom seats occupied by women, Canada lags behind 11 percent rate in US; of 13 largest Canadian companies with women as chief executives, 9 are subsidiaries of US companies; some women executives, including Barbara G Stymiest, president of Toronto Stock Exchange, and Sheelagh D Whittaker, chief executive of EDS Systemhouse, Canadian subsidiary of Electronic Data Systems Corp, comment; chart; photos (M)

headline: Now China Suggests Fate of Nation Depends on Defeating Sect
abstract: Article in People's Daily, Chinese Communist Party daily, says fate of nation hangs on struggle against Falun Gong, banned spiritual movement; article is latest in series of increasingly fiery official diatribes against group in last two weeks (M)

headline: October Data Disappointing For Retailers
abstract: Goldman, Sachs retail composite index shows growth in retail sales eased in October; sales in stores open at least a year, key comparison in industry, rose 4.1 percent, smallest increase in six months, leading many analysts and economists to predict possible drop-off in consumer buying; graph; chart (M)

headline: Executive Change At Bozell Chicago
abstract: Mike Powell is named exú

headline: Free Software Sounds Alerts On Sites' Use of Personal Data
abstract: Enonymous.com, in raising question of whether shoppers using Internet sites such as Amazon.com really know what that company plans to do with their personal information, is distributing free Internet utility called Enonymous Advisor, which can be downloaded from www.enonymous.com; utility detects sites that request personal information and rates sites' privacy policies; Amazon.com, Yahoo.com and Expedia.com are among two dozen sites receiving one star each--lowest rank, which means site may share personal data without permission (M)

headline: Media Talk; 'Role of a Lifetime,' Reagan Biography, Will Be Reissued
abstract: Public Affairs will publish updated paperback version of Lou Cannon's 1991 biography, President Reagan: The Role of a Lifetime; holds Edmund Morris's new book, Dutch: A Memoir of Ronald Reagan, fails to give definitive account of Reagan's life; Cannon and Morris are critical of other's book; photo (M)

headline: INACOM PLANS TO CUT 1,000 MORE JOBS FROM WORK FORCE
abstract: Inacom Corp plans to eliminate 1,000 jobs in coming year, or about 10 percent of its work force, in attempt to cut costs; expects to take charge of $100 million to $150 million in fourth quarter; expects to save $100 million a year (S)

headline: A Millennial Free-for-All: Who's on First?
abstract: Article on rough-and-tumble competition among islands of South Pacific for claim of being first inhabited place to witness dawn of new millennium on January 1, 2000; Fiji, Tonga, Kiribati and New Zealand's Pitt Island are main contenders, while Katchall Island in Indian Ocean is using different theory of time to claim first island sunrise; dawn of new millennium will occur near uninhabited Dibble Glacier in Antarctica at edge of international dateline--14 hours before ball descends to mark New Year in Times Square, and 21 hours before sun rises in New York; photo; map (M)

headline: MAIL.COM TO BUY NETMOVES FOR $173 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Mail.com Inc acquires NetMoves Corp for about $173 million in stock (S)

headline: Holbrooke Accuses House of Hurting U.S. Role in the World
abstract: Richard C Holbrooke, US representative at United Nations, says Congressional tampering with budget bills covering foreign operations and payments to United Nations is damaging US national security interests; says Pres Clinton vetoed foreign spending bill because House Republicans had effectively rigged legislation with provision that would have guaranteed loss of US seat in General Assembly by delaying allocations past Dec 31 payment deadline (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Circuit City Group names W Alan McCollough chief executive, succeeding Richard Sharp, who remains chairman (S)

headline: Terrorists Said to Hide In Canada's Melting Pot
abstract: terrorists said to hide in canada's melting pot**Ahmed Ressam, Algerian who was arrested last week for smuggling bomb-making materials from Canada into United States, appears to have had little problem remaining in Canada after his application for asylum was rejected and even after nationwide warrant for his deportation was issued; Ressam seems to have simply melted into immigrant comunity in Montreal, which includes more than 15,000 Algerians; critics of government say that Canada's openness to immigrants, particularly those speaking French, has helped make it haven for terrorists; say thousands of people a year who are seeking asylum simply vanish from official view, some crossing porous border and disappearing into US population; photos (M)

headline: ING Withdraws Its Offer For Midsize French Bank
abstract: Shares in Credit Commercial de France surge after ING Groep first makes and then withdraws $20 billion takeover bid; ING withdraws bid after detecting 'lack of enthusiasm' on part of Credit Commercial management (M)

headline: How to Miss a Big Bull Market: Invest in Perelman Stocks
abstract: Floyd Norris article profiles problems at Revlon Inc, noting that in week since company disclosed inventory problems, its stock price plunged 41 percent, to $10.75; says that Revlon is in this condition is testament to how poorly things have gone for the company in the 13 years since Ronald O Perelman took control; graph (M)

headline: Ford Planning To Spin Off Parts Division
abstract: Ford Motor Co plans to spin off its giant auto parts division directly to shareholders and give wage and job guarantees to division's factory workers in contract under negotiation with United Automobile Workers union; company had considered selling unit, called Visteon Automotive Systems; labor issues along with tax considerations have instead persuaded Ford to spin off Visteon; future of unit has been main point in talks with union (M)

headline: Nasdaq Index Ends Session At New High
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 5.94 points, or 0.15 percent, to close at 3,975.38; Dow Jones industrial average closes down 14.68 points, or 0.13 percent, at 11,391.08; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 1.24 points, or 0.09 percent, to 1,457.10; graph; chart (M)

headline: BROWSER
abstract: An eclectic selection of Web events and sites.    EVENTS    FRIDAY, 5 p.m.    www.onhealth.com/ch1/index.asp  A moderated chat on how to eat in a healthful way over the holidays.    SUNDAY, 1 a.m.  www.babycenter.com/chat/  A chat group for military mothers.    SUNDAY, 10 p.m.  modelrailroad.about.com/hobbies/modelrailroad/  Chat about toy trains with other enthusiasts.    TUESDAY, 7 p.m.  www.talkcity.com  Stressed out by Thanksgiving? Chat with others about ways to cope.

headline: FEWER BAD LOANS IN THAILAND
abstract: Nonperforming loans at Thailand's banks fell nearly 4 percent between October and November to 2.36 trillion baht, or $62.8 billion; about 42.3 percent of all Thai bank loans are still considered problem loans, down from 43.8 percent month before; economists say clearing bad loans from banks balance sheets is key to restoring sustainable economic growth to Thailand (S)

headline: KOREAN STOCKS SURGE
abstract: South Korean share prices surge 5.5 percent as foreign investors return to volatile market in search of bargains after steep falls in recent days (S)

headline: Holbrooke Urges Foes in Congo to Comply With Peace Accord
abstract: Richard C Holbrooke, chief US delegate to United Nations, calls on warring parties in Congo to live up to peace accord they signed several months ago (M)

headline: Business Travel; On-line reservation systems appear poised to shake up the traditional travel agent business.
abstract: Internet travel sites like Travelocity and Expedia that establish themselves as trusted brands will dominate new on-line reservation market and furiously shake up traditional travel agency business; Wal-Mart says it is developing its own on-line travel site (M)

headline: Israel to Import Natural Gas From Egypt
abstract: Egypt will provide natural gas to Israel through long-delayed 'peace pipeline' across Sinai Desert; deal will radically change Israel's energy policy and its economic relationship with its most powerful neighbor (M)

headline: New Yule Log Tradition Glows With Eerie Light
abstract: WPIX's original Yule Log tape, presented on television at Christmas until 1989, is available for viewing on Internet at www.wb11/yulelog.htm; photo (S)

headline: MERGER POSSIBILITY DENIED
abstract: Allied Domecq PLC denies reports that it has been approached by Pernod-Ricard SA of France about a merger (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil falls on signs that some producers are pumping more than they pledged in output-cutting agreement; in New York, crude oil for November delivery falls 82 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $22.45 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: 2 Executives Leaving TBWA/Chiat/Day
abstract: Peter Angelos and Rob Siltanen, creative executives at two offices of TBWA/Chiat/Day, are leaving agency (S)

headline: The Same Old Old Faithful, With a Newfangled Twist
abstract: National Park Service sets up Old Faithful WebCam, to offer still image of country's most famous geyser, Old Faithful, that is updated every 35 seconds; geyser, in Yellowstone National Park, erupts every 80 to 90 minutes; photo (S)

headline: Demetrio Lakas, 74, Panama Leader Who Had Role in Shaping Canal Pacts
abstract: Demetrio B Lakas, president of Panama from 1972 to 1978 during government of Brig Gen Omar Torrijos Herrera, dies at age of 74; photo (M)

headline: Packard Bell NEC Plans Layoffs Of Up to 88% of Its Work Force
abstract: Packard Bell NEC Inc will slash its payroll in US from 2,600 jobs to 300 to 400 positions by end of first quarter 2000; chief executive Alain Couder will step down, as will other senior members of his team; company will stop selling Packard Bell brand in US (M)

headline: From I.M.F. to IMF: A Trademark Battle
abstract: Here's a trademark dispute with a difference: A small California mortgage bank and brokerage is being sued by, of all things, the International Monetary Fund.    The problem is the brokerage's name: IMF Loans Inc. ''My maiden name is Eisenberg, which is German for 'iron mountain,' '' said Jan Pasternak, the company's owner. ''So we started as Iron Mountain Financial. But that is too long to be an Internet domain name, so when we went on line, we shortened it.'' Ms. Pasternak didn't think there would be any confusion. ''Nobody in the United States knows what the I.M.F. is, or cares,'' she said.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BORG-WARNER AUTOMOTIVE, Chicago, named Lawrence Skatoff chief financial officer. He had been chief financial officer and senior vice president at Premark International.

headline: Creative Writing
abstract: Some of the most imaginative flowerings of modern literature are in a special genre: the personal expense account. What has been the wildest, woolliest item you have tried to put on your account? And for how much? How did you explain it, and what happened? Or if you're a boss, what has been the most striking item you have encountered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: U.N. Tribunal Wrong to Free Top Suspect, Rwanda Says
abstract: Joseph W Mutaboba, Rwandan representative to United Nations, says decision of UN tribunal to drop its case against Jean-Bosco Barayagwiza, former official in Rwanda accused of helping to organize 1994 genocide there, has angered Rwandan government and threatens to unravel efforts to bring most prominent suspects to justice (M)

headline: Italy's Semi-New Government, 57th Since the War, Is Sworn In
abstract: Acting Prime Min Massimo D'Alema of Italy presents new, lightly shuffled cabinet that mostly underscores fierce infighting within his center-left majority that forced him to resign; new government is Italy's 57th since World War II; key members of D'Alema's team, including Foreign Min Lamberto Dini, Treasury Min Giuliano Amato and Economics Min Vincenzo Visco, remain in place; Sergio Mattarella is new defense minister (M)

headline: Trapped in the Web Without an Exit
abstract: J D Biersdorfer discusses dirty tricks used by some Webmaskers to keep people from going to places on Internet where they want to go and, once at a site not of their choosing, they cannot get out of it easily; says that while some side trips are result of mistakes by Web surfers, many are the work of Webmasters who manipulate HTML code into trapping people in one spot; says sites that specialize in pornography are most obvious practioners of user manipulation; describes some of more frustrating dirty tricks in use; photos of some Web sites (L)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BOSNIA: COOPERATING WITH TRIBUNAL  The prime minister of the Bosnian Serb republic, Milorad Dodik, left, will make his first visit to the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague today, a move that the tribunal hailed as a sign that Mr. Dodik's republic is ready to cooperate more fully with investigators. The Bosnian Serb justice minister, Milan Trbojevic, who has already visited the tribunal, said that the republic's parliament in Banja Luka would debate a proposed law on cooperation with the tribunal on Dec. 27.    (Agence France-Presse)

headline: Satellite TV Bill Advances in Congress
abstract: House and Senate negotiators agree on legislation aimed at giving satellite television companies like Hughes Electronics' DirecTV assistance in competing with cable TV; bill would clear way for satellite TV companies to add local TV signals to their service immediately, matching what cable competitors provide (S)

headline: Sleepy Steps For Japan After a Long Hibernation
abstract: Excerpts from interview with P Nicholas Edwards, managing director and head of Warburg Pincus Japan Growth Fund, on Japan, which seems to be emerging from major recession; photo (M)

headline: INSMED PHARMACEUTICALS AGREES TO ACQUIRE CELTRIX
abstract: Insm

headline: Rebels Say Congo Is Violating Cease-Fire by Bombing Towns
abstract: Jean-Pierre Bemba, leader of Uganda-backed Movement for Liberation of Congo, accuses Pres Laurent Kabila of violating three-month-old cease-fire by sending airplanes to bomb town in northwestern Congo (M)

headline: Jenne-Jeno Journal; Mali's Present Is Poor. Can It Build Future on Past?
abstract: Dusan Vukovic has become popular figure in Serbia after denouncing war in Kosovo, in which his son, Aleksandar, died; angrily rejecting his son's posthumous medal at televised ceremony, Vukovic wanted it sent back to Pres Slobodan Milosevic; photo (M)

headline: Global Economy Dances to Political Tune
abstract: David E Sanger article on increasingly obvious interplay and tension between global economics and global politics; discusses backlash against globalization, digital divide around world, and US economy as linchpin of world economy; chart traces growth of world trade over last 50 years; maps show presence of McDonald's restaurants and personal computers worldwide; chart of worldwide Internet usage by region; photo (M)

headline: MOUNTAIN TOURS IN NORTH KOREA
abstract: South Korea's largest business group, Hyundai Group, receives official letter from North Korea, giving it exclusive rights to develop tours to scenic Mount Keumkang in North Korea until 2028; Hyundai chairman Chung Mong Hun says his group will hold 'road shows' later this year to encourage investment in Mount Keumkang projects (S)

headline: IN MY...BRIEFCASE: PETER W. MAY
abstract: Contents of briefcase carried by Triarc Companies president and chief operating officer Peter W May described; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: DOWN TO THE WIRE -- Former Senator George J. Mitchell began the last days of his eight-week- old effort to salvage the sinking peace accord, with frosty relations between rival parties thawing but no breakthrough reported. ''No one should underestimate just how important are the next few days,'' said Peter Mandelson, the new British Secretary for Northern Ireland.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Patents; Just the thing for the holiday rush: a shopping bag that can be worn like a backpack.
abstract: Robert Mentken wins patent for shopping bag that has back pack straps instead of handles; Jordan Glogau receives patent for software program that evaluates contents of Web site and yields relevant registration forms for US Copyright Office, to give site creator greater reassurance that compositions are safeguarded against copying (M)

headline: Rheingold Shifts Its Account Again
abstract: Rheingold Brewing Co awards its advertising account to Ryan Drossman/MARC; billings estimated at $1 million to $2 million; account was handled by DeVito/Verdi (S)

headline: Pfizer Seeks Ouster of Warner Board
abstract: Pfizer Inc files plans with Securities and Exchange Commission to replace board of Warner-Lambert Co with directors who do not oppose Pfizer's $72 billion hostile takeover bid; it is expected that commission will take several weeks to review filing (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil gained almost 2 percent after an industry report showed that United States inventories fell for a second consecutive week. In New York, crude oil for January delivery rose 43 cents, to $26.87 a barrel.

headline: HEALTHIER OUTLOOK FOR BRAZIL
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp changes it outlook on Brazil's credit rating to stable from negative; move comes after Brazil exceeded goals set with International Monetary Fund to create budget surplus before interest is paid on government bonds (S)

headline: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; An Epiphany About Lawyers
abstract: Steven Keeva My Money, My Life column describes how fellow lawyer helped him to reach understanding about how practice of law should include compassion, mindfulness and deep commitment so that it it can become healing profession; drawing (M)

headline: DAVID FILO
abstract: Contents of My Yahoo personal Web site of Yahoo co-chief David Filo described; photos (M)

headline: A HALF-CENTURY IN CHINA: THE WITNESS; Watching the Old Order Collapse, and the Communist Revolution Take Hold
abstract: Seymour Topping article recalls fall of Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Government in April 1949 and arrival of first Communist troops in Nanjing; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Chap Stick Chat And Other Connections
abstract: Internet support group, Chap Stick Addicts, links people who feel they are addicted to lip balm; unrelated site, Lip Balm Anonymous, is based on premise that balms eventually dry out lips, forcing users to apply more; Whitehall-Robins, American Home Products unit that makes Chap Stick, holds product is not addictive; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Is Trying To Put Teeth In Inspections Of Iraq Arms
abstract: United Nations Security Council puts off vote on arms-inspection plan for Iraq at request of China, which, along with Russia, has reservations; independent disarmament experts are divided over how important it is to try to put in place an airtight monitoring system if he cost is council's unity against Pres Saddam Hussein; council does extend 'oil for food' program in Irraq for six months (M)

headline: Eager Palestinians Seek New Millennium's Fruits
abstract: Yasir Arafat, Palestinian leader, inaugurates Bethlehem 2000 celebrations in Manger Square, which he is promoting as centerpiece of a fledgling Palestinian tourism economy and as potential model of urban redevelopment (M)

headline: Primedia Unit in Deal
abstract: Primedia Inc says its Intertec Publishing unit has acquired Multimedia Publishing Corp; terms not are disclosed (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls against the dollar; graph; currency table (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Blazing Hot and Highly Volatile
abstract: Nasdaq composite index, which began in 1971 at 100 points, closes above 3,000 for first time; index now features some of largest and hottest stocks in the world; it is computer revolution that has remade Nasdaq; total value of stocks traded on Nasdaq amounts to $3.7 trillion; index is weighted by market capitalization, and third of it now is accounted for by just five of 4,842 companies in index: Microsoft, Intel, Cisco Systems, MCI-Worldcom and Qualcomm; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: U.S. JUDGE DECLARES MICROSOFT IS A MARKET-STIFLING MONOPOLY; GATES RETAINS DEFIANT STANCE
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issues broad denunciation of Microsoft Corp in landmark antitrust case, ruling that company is monopoly that uses power to stifle innovation, reduce competition and hurt consumers; 207-page findings of fact says company, through its conduct, demonstrates it will use prodigious market power and immense profits to harm any firm that insists on pursuing initiatives that could intensify competition against one of its core products; finds government's case against company credible and rejects as 'specious' virtually all arguments Microsoft offered in defense; his findings detailed; Justice Department is jubilant; Atty Gen Janet Reno hails ruling as great day for American consumers; Microsoft chairman William Gates says he disagrees with many of court's findings; says company operates within laws and in way that is beneficial to consumers; says it competes vigorously and fairly and is committed to resolving case in fair and equitable manner; photos (L)

headline: Gustavo Leigh Guzman, 79, Who Served in Chilean Junta
abstract: Gen Gustavo Leigh Guzman, who was key figure in Chile's four-man military junta led by Gen Augusto Pinochet but who later broke with junta, dies at age 79; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Insurers Changing Tactics But Keeping Cost Controls  Some of the nation's biggest health insurers say they are changing their tactics as they face a backlash against managed care, eliminating or cutting back on unpopular rules.

headline: Chicago Hiltons Select Bozell
abstract: Three large Chicago hotels that are part of Hilton Hotels Corp award their regional advertising account to Chicago office of Bozell Worldwide; billings estimated at $1 million to $3 million (S)

headline: Media Talk; Comings and Goings At Conde Nast Raise In-House Questions
abstract: Rumors are circulating about possible changes in likely succession at Conde Nast and parent Advance Publications, both headed by chairman S I Newhouse; factors include Advance's acquisition of Fairchild Publications, Newhouse's reported firing of Conde Nast executive vice president Catherine Viscardi Johnston, ally of Conde Nast chief executive Steven T Florio, and his retention of Richard D Beckman as Vogue magazine publisher after June shoving incident in which female advertising executive was badly hurt and won big financial settlement; photos (M)

headline: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
abstract: Excerpt from earlier article on The Supreme Court's Gratest Hits, interactive CD-ROM that includes 70 hours of often passionate legal debate recorded on tape in Supreme Court, as well as pictures and biographies of justices since 1957 (S)

headline: White House and Business Groups To Push Congress on China Pact
abstract: Clinton administration and business groups prepare intense campaign to win Congressional approval of China's entry into World Trade Organization following landmark trade agreement with US; pact faces opposition from conservatives who object to almost any dealings with China and liberals who say trade pact would be bad for workers; approval seen in House, most difficult of two Congressional battlegrounds; many industries hail agreement as opportunity to expand rapidly into giant Chinese market, but AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney denounces it as grave mistake; he accuses Clinton administration of hypocrisy; opposition by human rights advocates noted; administration officials vow to press hard to get deal approved, probably in first few months of 2000 (M)

headline: POTOMAC ELECTRIC ACQUIRES DUTCH GAS DISTRIBUTORS
abstract: The Potomac Electric Power Company bought 17 natural gas distribution networks from four local governments in the Netherlands for $525 million in cash, its second investment in the Dutch gas market in four months. Potomac, a Washington-based utility with 700,000 electricity customers, acquired 21 Dutch gas networks for $724 million in August. Both purchases will add to earnings this year, the company said. Potomac and other United States utilities have expanded into Europe to find new sources of revenue as they lose their monopolies over power sales at home.

headline: GERMAN BUILDER ON BRINK
abstract: Future of Germany's biggest construction company, Philipp Holzmann AG, is uncertain after its main creditor bank, Deutsche Bank AG, disagrees about plans for bailout; Holzmann says it suddenly discovered 2.4 billion marks ($1.3 billion) in possible losses from soured real estate projects (S)

headline: Filings, Hearings and Decisions: Next Phase of the Case
abstract: Microsoft Corp antitrust case moves to next phase after publication of Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's findings of fact; he is expected to issue his final verdict in January (M)

headline: Lloyd's Wins U.S. Judgment
abstract: A New York court ruled last week that Lloyd's of London, the British insurance market, was entitled to collect $769,000 from two of its investors.    Lloyd's depends on its investors, who are known as names, to pledge their personal wealth to back insurance policies in return for a share of underwriting premiums. A series of natural disasters in the five-year period through 1992 led to losses of more than 8 billion [pounds], or about $13 billion, for the names, ruining many of them. Some in the United States sought protection from American courts.

headline: Labor Market Even Tighter As Jobless Claims Decline
abstract: Labor Dept reports that fewer workers are seeking jobless benefits than at any time in more than quarter-century; number of new claims fell by 9,000, to 274,000, in week ended Dec 25 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Path to Untold Riches Branches Off Wall Street  For the first time since Wall Street became the surest professional path to riches during the frenzied 1980's, those with the biggest paydays are not investment bankers but former investment bankers.

headline: Opus360 Files for Offering
abstract: Opus360 Corp files for initial public offering of $65 million (S)

headline: The Overstuffed Briefcase: Few Have the Time to Open It
abstract: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column on why growing number of commuters carry computer laptops to and from their jobs; says workers have so much more work that they cannot do it during confines of traditional workday, so they have to do it at home, on the way home, and on the way back to work again; says corollary to this is that workers have shaped their world so that they can work anywhere--which also means they have no excuse not to work everywhere; drawing (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of November 14 Market Insight column on views of J P Morgan's Latin American equity strategist, whose name, Carlos Asilis, was misspelled (S)

headline: The V-Chip Arrives With a Thud
abstract: V-chip, circuitry that can be used to block television broadcasts according to a ratings system that Federal Communications Comm, under Congressional directive, required manufacturers to include in television sets, has few users; even groups that support V-chip acknowledge that it has yet to catch on with public; reasons appear to be lack of consumer awareness, difficulty in use or because parents do not feel they need it; photo (M)

headline: Patents; A system of curtains adapted from theater and film sets may help in controlling forest fires.
abstract: Brent Lee Farley discusses his newly obtained patent for system of curtains adapted from theater and film sets for use in controlling forest fires, phone interview; Albert Montague patents car alarm designed to eliminate false alarms triggered when car is merely nudged (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Judge Contends Microsoft Stifled Tech Innovation  The judge in the government's antitrust trial against Microsoft issued a broad denunciation of the software giant as the first part of his verdict in the case. The judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson of Federal District Court, said that the company used its monopoly power to stifle innovation, reduce competition and hurt consumers.

headline: BRACKNELL BUYING NATIONWIDE ELECTRIC FOR $76.7 MILLION
abstract: Bracknell Buying Nationwide Electric For $76.7 Millioü

headline: LIBERTY MEDIA TO INVEST IN CENDANT INTERNET OPERATIONS
abstract: Liberty Media Group will spend $400 million to help Cendant Corp develop Internet operations related to Cendant's travel, mortgage and real estate businesses; Liberty Media will receive 18 million Cendant shares and rights for two years to buy about 29 million Cendant shares at $29 each (S)

headline: Cuts by Nissan Are Deeper Than Foreseen
abstract: Nissan Motor Co surprises Japan and auto industry with details of radical overhaul plan that wil make unexpectedly deep cuts at company and reverberate more broadly through economy; Nissan's new chief operating officer Carlos Ghosn announces that three plants will be closed and 21,000 jobs eliminated, most of them in Japan; president Yoshikazu Hanawa says company must implement plan to survive; Jason Vines, American spokesman for Nissan, says 1,400 cuts will come in US through attrition and sale of divisions; about 500 parts and materials suppliers will lose Nissan's business, and communities affected by plant closings, still rarity in Japan, could feel most acute impact; Nissan also plans to sell most of shares it holds in companies that have been linked through loans and cross-shareholding; Renault SA, French car maker that purchased 36.8 percent stake in Nissan in March, will take $317 million accounting charge related to its Japanese partner's restructuring; graph; photo (M)

headline: New Alliance Will Promote Wireless Access to Internet
abstract: Group of technology companies, led by Cisco Systems Inc and Motorola Inc, says it will form alliance to create products that will allow consumers to get high-speed Internet access through wireless system within next year; consortium is essentially backing alternative to delivering broadband Internet access through underground cables and wires (M)

headline: Nigeria Gets U.S. Help, but Bigger Plan for Africa Snags
abstract: Pres Clinton meets with Nigerian Pres Olusegun Obasanjo and pledges a tripling of aid to Nigeria, his Administration's biggest initiative for Africa; bill that could ease Africa's access to American market is seen imperiled in Senate; Obasanjo's main goal is to reduce or reschedule more than $30 billion in debt; photo (M)

headline: HILLENBRAND REDUCING STAFF IN ITS HEALTH CARE UNIT
abstract: The holding company Hillenbrand Industries Inc. said yesterday that its Hill-Rom Company health care unit would cut about 350 positions, or 5 percent, over nine months. The reduction will primarily eliminate administrative positions, Hillenbrand said. The unit employs approximately 6,600 people worldwide, with about 2,000 in the Batesville, Ind., area, where it is based. As a result of the work force reduction and other charges, Hillenbrand expects to take a fourth-quarter charge of $30 million to $35 million. On the New York Stock Exchange, Hillenbrand's shares fell $3.8125 each, to $32.

headline: A New Idea For Unions: Forget the Past
abstract: ASIDE from driving to work and perhaps breaking for lunch, what do more than 90 percent of private-sector employees in this country have in common?     The answer: They are not union members. The A.F.L.-C.I.O., groggily awakening to its increasing irrelevance, has lately been calling for stepped-up organizing efforts. But it might as well lobby for a ban on fax machines, for all the good it will do.

headline: Comcast to Purchase Lenfest Communications
abstract: Comcast Corp agrees to buy cable television company Lenfest Communications Inc from AT&T Corp and Lenfest family for $6.71 billion in stock and debt, adding 1.25 million subscribers in greater Philadelphia area; agreement overrides AT&T's plan to buy 50 percent of Lenfest that it does not already own (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: Honors
abstract: * The Internet Advertising Bureau, New York, re-elected its officers for 2000. Rick LeFurgy continues as chairman; he is general partner at WaldenVC, and president at LeFurgy.com, both San Francisco. And Susan Bratton continues as vice chairwoman; she is vice president for market development at Excite@Home.com, Redwood City, Calif.

headline: Monsanto Sued Over Use of Biotechnology in Developing Seeds
abstract: Some of nation's most prominent antitrust lawyers file class-action lawsuit against Monsanto Co, accusing it of rushing genetically engineered seed to marketplace without properly testing them for safety and of forming international cartel that conspired to control world's market in corn and soybean seeds; lawsuit, filed on behalf of six farmers, is latest skirmish in debate over use of bioengineered seeds, which are popular among American farmers but troubling to consumers in Europe and environmental groups who contend that they are potentially dangerous to humans and environment; suit contends Monsanto is at hub of international conspiracy to control large part of world's seed supply (M)

headline: DERLAN OF CANADA BUYING BOEING AIRCRAFT GEAR HOLDING
abstract: Boeingp

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; After a year on the credibility trail, a columnist finds that the Internet industry is still dangerously self-indulgent.
abstract: FINALLY, the Internet's growing lack of credibility among consumers is becoming a cause celebre.    Just last week, two organizations -- one grass roots, the other representing industry -- announced their intentions to bring some balance and intellectual rigor to a debate that has been almost completely lopsided toward unfettered growth at any cost.

headline: Amazon Wins Court Ruling to Protect Patent on Order System
abstract: Federal Judge Marsha J Pechman orders Barnesandnoble.com to stop using 'one click ordering' system patented by Amazon.com--online store that pioneered many common techniques for retail sales on Web (M)

headline: Mexican Pollsters Challenge Size of Turnout in the Primary
abstract: Several independent pollsters challenge official results of presidential primary of Mexico's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party,held on November 7, that showed huge turnout of voters; suggest party may have axaggerated turnout, perhaps greatly, to enhance image of invincibility in 2000 presidential race (M)

headline: Sleepless in San Jose
abstract: Jet collector Larry Ellison takes exception to airport regulation in San Jose, Calif, that he says unfairly restricts nighttime use of his Gulfstream GB; photo (S)

headline: Talking to the Web On Your Telephone
abstract: Nuance, voice-recognition firm in Menlo Park, Calif, develops Web browser called Voyager that responds to voice commands instead of pushed buttons to enable people using device to dial into audible bookmarks: for example, a favorite search engine or news page; Nuance officials are now talking with Web site representatives to format their Web pages to handle voice-based browsing (S)

headline: Dow Finishes a Bit Lower After a Day of Big Swings
abstract: Stock prices see-saw on New York Stock Exchange in session punctuated by the Federal Reserve's decision to leave short-term interest rates unchanged; Dow Jones industrial average rises as much as 107 points and falls as much as 123 before ending at 10,400.59--down 0.64 point; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 3.25 points, to close at 1,301.35; Nasdaq composite index gains 3.70 to 2,779.67; Russell 2000 index falls 0.6 point to 426.01; graph (M)

headline: EU Looks for Ways To Protect Shoppers
abstract: BRUSSELS—  It seems basic, but it's a piece of advice often ignored, according to consumer experts: When buying on the Internet, as anywhere else, always make sure you know exactly with whom you are dealing.

headline: Treason Charge For Pakistan's Ousted Premier
abstract: Pakistan's ousted Prime Min Nawaz Sharif is accused of hijacking and kidnapping for what military officials say was treasonous refusal to allow plane carrying army chief of staff Gen Pervez Musharraf, who later deposed him, from landing at airport in Karachi shortly before October 12 coup; he is charged with endangering lives of general and about 200 passengers on commercial flight by refusing plane permission to land; he faces death penalty on conviction; charges are at heart of armed forces' justification for coup and revolve around still murky events that precipitated takeover (M)

headline: VENEZUELA CHANGES PLAN
abstract: Venezuela abandoned a plan to invest $200 million to expand production at the idled Cienfuegos oil refinery in Cuba, citing high costs. Venezuela will instead seek a venture with Cuba's state oil company, Cupel, to bring Cienfuegos back on line, refining 70,000 barrels a day. The country plans to pump its own crude to Cuba and sidestep a United States trade embargo against Cuba, which has had oil shortages since the early 1990's, an official said.

headline: Talks on Compensating Nazi-Era Slaves Turn to Sour Haggling
abstract: Mood of exasperation grips German industry after additional offer of $4.4 billion to compensate Nazi-era slave laborers is rebuffed by lawyers for plaintiffs; Manfred Gentz, chief financial officer of DaimlerChrysler, blames lawyers for asking large sums which he maintains nobody else finds constructive; Deputy Treas Sec Stuart Eizenstat will meet with German mediators in US to discuss problem (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: CURB ON BEEF SALES TO END -- A two-year-old ban on sales of beef on the bone is to end Dec. 17 after assurances from medical officials that there is no longer any risk that certain cuts may be contaminated with the infective agent that causes mad-cow disease, which attacks the brain. The action was unrelated to the continuing French blockade of all British beef imports in defiance of the European Commission's decision to lift its worldwide ban last Aug. 1.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    NORTHERN IRELAND: ASSEMBLY APPROVED BY LORDS -- A bill to transfer home rule to the new Northern Ireland Assembly passed the House of Lords and is expected to clear Commons today. The process was speeded up to enable the Protestant-Catholic coalition for Ulster to start work on Thursday.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Court Silences Iran Reformist With Jail Term
abstract: Iranian court imposes five-year jail term and five-year banishment from political activity on Abdullah Nouri, Muslim cleric who is ally of Pres Mohammad Khatami and has won wide popular support with demands for end to authoritarian rule by religious hierarchy; orders closing of Nouri's newspaper, Khordad, which has been one of most effective voices of country's increasingly impatient democratic movement, and imposes fine of 15 million rials, equivalent to $5,000; photo (M)

headline: Welcome to Paradise
abstract: Many young people at Internet and high technology start-ups are using workplace to look for mates; such companies, often populated by young workers, are throwing out corporate rules that discourage dating and fraternization among employees; are finding that new conduct codes can lead to problems; photo (M)

headline: Silence, Please
abstract: George Dunbar letter on October 31 article on wireless office technology sees possibility that solitude will become extinct (S)

headline: From Five Retirement Portfolios, Another Vote for Diversification
abstract: Article assesses third-quarter performance of diversified portfolios held by Sheldon Jacobs, Eric M Kobren, Jack A Brill, Susan Dziubinski and Harold R Evensky; charts; photos (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Can Nissan Turn on a Centime?; Trying to Revamp a Company and a Corporate Culture
abstract: Article on Nissan Motor Co focuses on expected reorganization plan to be announced by chief operating officer Carlos Ghosn; says Ghosn not only must restore profitablility to lumbering, heavily indebted company that has not made money on its core operations in years, but he must do so under circumstances radically different from those he has faced in past corporate overhauls; layoffs are still anathema in Japan; closing plants is considered symbol of failure; outsourcing is rare, and concept of pay for performance, not seniority, has only begun to catch on; chart; photo (M)

headline: I Call You at Dinner Time
abstract: Article by Angelo L Morales describing his job as telemarketer (My Job column); photo (S)

headline: Raytheon Further Reduces Forecast of Profit, and Shares Fall 43%
abstract: Raytheon Corp reduces its forecasts again, sending shares plunging 43 percent after delayed opening on New York Stock Exchange; says sales will grow 3 percent this year and next, half its earlier forecast; also says profit margins at its Raytheon Systems Corp unit, which accounts for three-quarters of its revenue, will be about 12 percent instead of expected 15 percent; chairman Daniel P Burnham comments on forecast; says aggressive acquisition strategy might have stretched company's management team beyond its limits (M)

headline: OBJECTION TO EMBRAER DEAL
abstract: Brazil's Defense Minister Elcio Alvares opposes plans by Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica (Embraer) to sell minority stake to French consortium consisting of Dassault Aviation, Thomson CSF, Aerospatiale-Matra and Snecma for more than $200 million; believes military would become subordinated to concerns of French aerospace industry; Alvares photo (S)

headline: Meeting in Oslo on a Mideast Settlement in a 'Last Sprint'
abstract: Pres Clinton begins 'last sprint' with Prime Min Ehud Barak of Israel and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to devise peace settlement as two-day summit in Oslo, Norway, ends; holds discussion with both leaders and says they pledged to meet regularly in coming 100 days before mid-February deadline for framework agreement; administration officials, as well as Israeli and Palestinian delegates, say they feel imbued by occasion that brought them to Oslo, namely, fourth anniversary of assassination of Yitzhak Rabin, Barak's mentor and Arafat's partner in historic agreement negotiated there in 1993; photo (M)

headline: Trickle of Chechen Refugees Brave a Risky Escape Route
abstract: Four hundred Chechen refugees leave Grozny and make their way along escape corridor to Russian military checkpoint in Tersky hills three miles outside capital; some who feared being shot at by Russian soldiers are attacked instead by gangs of marauders who cruise the area; say sizable population still lives in city, including many elderly; Prime Min Vladimir V Putin says he is in contact with Chechen republic government, which is led by Aslan Maskhadov, and has met with one of its deputy premiers; photos (M)

headline: SINGAPORE'S MALAYSIAN SHARES
abstract: Malaysia's Effective Capital Sdn Bhd and Bingtang Melewar Sdn Bhd, pitching for disputed Malaysian shares that once traded in Singapore, say they hope Malaysia will extend Dec 31 deadline it has set to resolve dispute; if participant cannot agree on what to do with shares, which once traded on Singapore's over-the-counter Central Order Limit Book system, Malaysia has said it will hand responsibility for them to Malaysia's finance ministry (S)

headline: UNITED STATIONERS SEEKS DAISYTEK INTERNATIONAL
abstract: United Stationers Seeks Dais

headline: AIR CANADA COUNTERPROPOSAL
abstract: Canada's largest airline, Air Canada, announces $628 million plan to repurchase 35 percent of its own stock and acquire its main domestic rival, Canadian Airlines; plan is Air Canada's attempt to thwart hostile takeover proposal made two months ago by Onex Corp, which wants to buy both airlines and combine them; UAL Corp and Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Air Canada's global airline alliance partners, agree to help finance airline's proposal to defeat takeover by Onex, which is getting help from UAL's main American rival, AMR Corp (S)

headline: CALMED BY BARAK, RELIGIOUS FACTION STAYS IN THE FOLD
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak persuades Shas, third-largest party in Parliament, to stay in his coalition by offering increased funding and debt relief for its state-subsidized religious schools; Shas, ultra-Orthodox Sephardic party, says it will vote for Barak's fiscally conservative budget; photo (M)

headline: Creative Writing
abstract: Some of the most imaginative flowerings of modern literature are in a special genre: the personal expense account. What has been the wildest, woolliest item you have tried to put on your account? And for how much? How did you explain it, and what happened? Or if you're a boss, what has been the most striking item you have encountered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: CLINTON OPPOSES A PLAN BY ALLIES TO GIVE SERBS AID
abstract: US and European allies are deeply divided over whether to increase isolation of Yugoslavia and leader, Pres Slobodan Milosevic, or to offer some aid to ease hardships of Serbs in hope of encouraging more vital opposition; Clinton Administration, on eve of meeting of European Union foreign ministers, outlines strong opposition to plans by group to provide heating oil and other aid to certain Yugoslav cities controlled by opposition parties; under program, European Union would initially supply two cities with about $5 million in heating oil to help cope with shortages caused by destruction of Yugoslav refineries during NATO's air war over Kosovo; aid would be first part of broader package; US officials fear assistance could shore up Milosevic by alleviating public discontent, which they hope could lead to protests in Yugoslavia, early elections or even Milosevic's ouster or resignation (M)

headline: Ad Age Group Appoints a Team
abstract: Ad Age Group in New York promotes executives David Klein, Jill Manee and Allison Arden to form its new management team (S)

headline: Luddites at the Gas Pump
abstract: Marvin Spiro letter on Oct 14 article on possible risk of accidents involving use of cellular telephones near gasoline pumps; offers some tongue-in-cheek concerns about other auto hazards at service stations

headline: ADAPTEC LOOKS TO STRENGTHEN DATA-STORAGE LINE
abstract: Adaptec Inc acquires Distributed Processing Technology for about $235 million to bolster its data-storage product line (S)

headline: On the Acquisitions Road, Stay Alert to the Hazards
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column focuses on Mattel's problems with recently acquired Learning Co subsidiary; graph (M)

headline: New Stock Rides a Rocket and Then a Parachute Into the Market
abstract: Sycamore Networks Inc's highly anticipated initial public offering is priced at $38, but begins trading at $270.875 and closes at $184.75, increase of 386 percent; company ends day with market value of $14.4 billion; Sycamore is considered leader among new breed of companies that are developing equipment to enhance efficiency and functionality of optical communications networks, which transmit bits of data using pulse light rather than electricity; chart (M)

headline: SEVERN TRENT TO CUT 1,100
abstract: Britain's second-largest water company, Severn Trent PLC, will cut 1,100 jobs in next three years to meet price targets set by British regulators (S)

headline: A Grand Idea That Went Badly Awry
abstract: Article on failure of Los Angeles Community Development Bank, which provides federal funding to businesses in depressed areas of city; $435 million program has had negligible impact, even during economic boom, its loan default rate is 32 percent and it has created only tiny fraction of jobs promised; graph; chronology; photos; maps (L)

headline: At Last, Timorese Can Pray and Count the Costs
abstract: Hundreds of residents of Dili, East Timor, celebrate Mass in courtyard of devastated home of Archbishop Carlos Felipe Ximenes Belo who fled for safety to Australia, seeking comfort denied them in ashes of their ruined houses and absence of abducted relatives; toll of wave of terror by armed militias opposed to independence from Indonesia remains unclear; UN moves to open investigation into atrocities; maps; photo (M)

headline: What to Ask the Doctor
abstract: John Bloomfield letter takes exception to Dr O Alton Barron's November 4 analysis of overuse syndrome for computer users (S)

headline: Europeans Have Deferred to U.S. in Microsoft Litigation
abstract: Europe's competitiveness authorities of European Commission have generally chosen to steer clear of questions involving Microsoft Corp and Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's ruling that Microsoft is monopoly; European competitiveness officials five years ago cooperated with American regulatory authorities in antitrust investigation company settled by changing contracts with personal computer producers and eliminating some restrictions on software makers; in addition, European Commission is investigating at least two formal antitrust complaints against Microsoft, one from personal computer manufacturer and other from software maker (M)

headline: What Is a Minority-Owned Business?
