abstract: Increased demand for medium-size aircraft contributed to a 33 percent gain in third-quarter earnings at Bombardier Inc., a Montreal-based aerospace company. Bombardier, which also makes passenger trains and recreational vehicles, earned 167 million Canadian dollars, or $113.6 billion, on a 21 percent increase in revenue to 3.2 billion dollars, or $2.2 billion. Bombardier said its order backlog as of Oct. 31 totaled 26.7 billion dollars, or $18.2 billion, 25 percent more than a year earlier.   Timothy Pritchard

headline: KOREAN AIR CHAIRMAN TO BE CHARGED
abstract: South Korean prosecutors say they will seek arrest warrant for Korean Air Lines chairman Cho Yang Ho on charges of evading taxes and embezzlement; prosecutors say they have confirmed most allegations leveled against Cho, including evasion of 67.3 billion won in taxes and creation of 168.5 billion won slush fund; his brother Cho Soo Ho, president of Hanjin Shipping Co, will be indicted without detention, as will their father Cho Choong Hoon, Hanjin Group's founder and honorary chairman (S)

headline: Online Journalists Keep Their Eyes on Daily Numbers
abstract: Online magazines like Salon and Slate can track not only how many people are reading them but also how long people are reading any given article; information is far greater than that provided by old-fashioned focus groups; keepers of journalistic ethics worry that instantaneous reader surveys will bend online magazines to mercenary will of their business sides and encourage pandering to sex-obsessed technogeeks; Michael Kinsley, editor of Slate, calls ability to count page views 'insidious'; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Neuberger Berman is ready to go public, but at what price?
abstract: Market Place column on outlook for Neuberger, Berman's planned initial public offering; stock is coming to market at time when investment management company stocks are slumping (M)

headline: Agents' Dismissals Signal New York's Fade-Out in Film Business
abstract: Recent dismissal of two major New York film agents from William Morris reflects firm ascendancy of Los Angeles and view in film industry that New York has lost its viability as base to represent film clients; departures of Johnnie Planco and Gene Parseghian from William Morris come four months after Sam Cohn lost his role as head of New York office of International Creative Management, another top talent agency; virtually all studios have scaled back number of their executives based in New York in recent years; photo (M)

headline: Shaky Congo Peace Pact Grows More So
abstract: Congo Pres Laurent Kabila's Government and rebels say peace accord is not dead yet, but it will not take much for fighting to flare once again; rebels say Kabila's troops have bombed or invaded several towns in remote areas; Kabila officials make same assertions; map (M)

headline: CHS ELECTRONICS AGREES TO SELL EUROPEAN OPERATIONS
abstract: CHS Electronics Inc to sell its European operations to senior management in transaction valued at about $300 million (S)

headline: Bigger Media Voices
abstract: Ian Alterman letter on September 12 article disputes contention by conglomerates that Internet ensures that media will always remain diverse (S)9

headline: Shares Surge in Broad Rally; Dow Climbs 187.75 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 187.75 points, or 1.81 percent, to close at 10,588.34; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 24.05 points, or 1.85 percent, to 1,325.40; Nasdaq composite index climbs 57.54 points, or 2.06 percent, to 2,857.21, about 1 percent shy of its closing high, set on Sept 10; graph; chart (M)

headline: MANAGEMENT: A Network of Their Own; From an Exclusive Address, a Group for Women Only
abstract: Janet Tiebout Hanson, former vice president at Goldman, Sachs, has created women's organization called 85 Broads, playful reference to Goldman location at 85 Broad Street; about 70 former Goldman women have joined club; last month, group started its own Web site as a way for women to connect outside of special events; graph shows current breakdown for managing directors or their equivalent at some major investment firms where women are still minority at top levels of Wall Street; photo (M)

headline: When dot-coms want to build up their images, they hitch their Web sites to a star.
abstract: Article on growing number of dot-com companies that are using celebrities in their ads to build up their images (M)

headline: RALSTON PURINA TO SPIN OFF BATTERY UNIT IN APRIL
abstract: Ralston Purina Co will spin off its Eveready and Energizer battery unit in April; Ralston shareholders will get one share in battery business for every three Ralston shares they own; new company, Energizer Holdings Inc, will be led by Ralston chairman William Stiritz (S)

headline: Basque Rebels in Spain Ending Cease-Fire After 14 Months
abstract: Basque separatist group ETA says it will end 14-month-old cease-fire in its long struggle for independence from Spain; blames governments of Spain and France, as well as moderate Basque nationalists, for failure to work out lasting peace to conflict; Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar accuses rebels of intransigence and of being solely responsible for breaking cease-fire (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.38   5.29   5.24        3-month T-bills   4.94   4.98   4.30        6-month T-bills   5.07   5.09   4.29        10-yr. T-infl.   4.11   4.12   3.61        10-yr. T-note   6.11   6.19   4.50        30-yr. T-bond   6.25   6.32   5.08        Telephone bd.   8.19   8.28   6.94        Municipal bds.   6.14   6.16   5.11          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: Grasping for Air in Sports Broadcasting
abstract: Article on growing opportunities for sports broadcasters; Lou Schwartz, president of American Sportscasters Association, estimates number of professional sportscasters in US has grown by more than 25 percent in last five years, to about 3,000 today; says there can never be enough jobs to satisfy all people who want to work in field; Mario Diaz, sports reporter in Las Vegas, comments; photo (M)

headline: European Central Bankers Raise Key Rate a Half-Point
abstract: European Central Bank, declaring that Europe's economic outlook has turned 'far more favorable,' reverses course and raises interest rates for first time in its short history; increase in benchmark refinancing rate, to 3 percent from 2.5 percent, has been expected and still leaves European interest rates below those of US; bank chief Wim Duisenberg explains move; euro slips to six-week low and settles at $1.0377 in New York, down from $1.0485; graphs; chart; photo (M)

headline: Two U.S. Drug Giants Planning to Merge in a $70 Billion Deal
abstract: American Home Products and Warner-Lambert agree to merge in deal that would form world's largest drug company; merger of equals, valued at about $70 billion, will create new company called AmericanWarner; company will be based in Madison, NJ, headquarters of American Home Products and have market capitalization of about $140 billion; American Home chairman-chief executive John R Stafford will become chairman of AmericanWarner, but for only 18 months; he will then be succeeded by Warner-Lambert's chairman Lodewijk J R de Vink, who is to serve as chief executive; graph; chart photos (M)

headline: A Clinton Critic Pushes For a High-Stakes Vote
abstract: Interview with Sen James Inhofe, conservative Republican and harsh critic of Pres Clinton, who is leading charge in Senate to defeat nuclear arms control treaty, as well as any effort to withdraw it; photo (M)

headline: MODERATION SOUGHT IN BANK BATTLE
abstract: Speaking out on Nedcor's hostile bid for Standard Bank, Tito Mboweni, governor of the South African Reserve Bank, implored both sides to temper their verbal sparring. Nedcor, the country's fourth-largest bank, has been after Standard, the country's second-largest bank, for months. Nedcor has applied to officials for permission to proceed with the $2.4 billion bid; a ruling is expected next year.     Henri E. Cauvin

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Morgan Stanley Finds Its Dream Address Taken  Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, trumpeting its new on-line stock trading service, has discovered that somebody already has its desired Internet address, www.msdwonline.com.

headline: I.B.M. to Announce New, Flexible Transistors
abstract: IBM researchers will report in journal Science that they have developed flexible transistor that can be embedded in curved surfaces or even in thin, foldable materials (M)

headline: Catering to Wall Street
abstract: For Martha Stewart, even a stock certificate, issued for the initial public offering last Wednesday of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, must have just the right, homey touch. Known for what some call attention to detail, and others call obsessive control, she had the stock certificate designed in-house, featuring a cheery sunburst on top.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON, New York, named Jack Kirnan director of United States equity research. He had been deputy director of United States equity research, sharing the job with Al Jackson.    CUMMINS ENGINE CO., Chicago, named Theodore Solso chairman and chief executive, succeeding James Henderson, who plans to retire. Mr. Solso had been president and chief operating officer.

headline: SAMSUNG DEAL WITH NORTH KOREA
abstract: Samsung Electronics Co signs contract with North Korea to develop computer software (S)

headline: Defending the Stone
abstract: Letter by Lori Ann Palisi on Oct 21 article on computer game The Stone; says she is an avid player of game and disagrees that puzzles are too hard for average player

headline: Where Is Today's Child? Probably Watching TV
abstract: How much media do children actually digest?       To find the answer, the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, a nonprofit organization based in Menlo Park, Calif., conducted a study of the role of media in the lives of children. It released its report last month.

headline: S.E.C. Takes Aim at How Companies Report Revenue
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission issues guidance that could lead to some companies' being more conservative in reporting revenue; SEC is concerned that some companies book revenue--and thus profits--before they should be able to do so (M)

headline: A Need for Fashion
abstract: Paul M Lurie letter on Oct 14 article criticizes implication that users of cochlear implant technology are cyborgs; says cochlear implant and other hearing aid makers need someone to bring sense of fashion to the industry

headline: Merger Deal Falls Apart
abstract: Euro RSCG Worldwide, which said in February that it planned to acquire majority stake in Citron Haligman Bedecarre, says deal has been called off (S)

headline: PROCTER & GAMBLE SELLS SHAMPOO UNIT TO PRESTIGE
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co sold its slow-growing Prell shampoo business on Nov 1 to Prestige Brands International Inc for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Top Posts Are Filled At Four Agencies
abstract: Ken Kaess is named to new post of president of DDB Worldwide; Tom Block is named president of Illusion Fusion; Eugene F Bartley Jr is named chief executive of Bozell Group; Barry Toiv is joining Burson-Marsteller in new post of managing director of Washington office (M)

headline: CAIS SAYS KOHLBERG WILL INVEST UP TO $200 MILLION
abstract: CAIS Internet says Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co will invest as much as $200 million to finance expansion (S)

headline: Mirage Resorts Profit Falls in Quarter
abstract: Mirage Resorts Inc sys third-quarter profit fell 10 percent; net income fell to $27 million from $30.1 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 82 percent to $606.5 million from $332.6 million (S)

headline: Lawsuits, Politics And the Fate Of Tobacco
abstract: ARGUABLY, it was the export that made America. On a per-acre basis, it is the nation's most profitable cash crop. And one of its offspring is the world's most heavily taxed consumer product.    That product, the cigarette, is also other things. Like smelly, addictive and potentially lethal. Just now, it is also the best friend of many who practice liability law.

headline: Final Answer: Quiz Show Put In ABC Lineup
abstract: Who Wants to Be a Millionaire, ABC television game show that has risen to phenomenal success in two short limited runs, will become three-times-a-week regular series starting in January 2000; show could transform competitive landscape of prime-time television and strongly enhance ABC's economic position by allowing it to more than double price it has charged for advertising in time periods where show will be placed; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; A Satellite Model For Streaming Media
abstract: iBeam, new company backed by Intel, Liberty Media and venture capitalists, plans to deliver high-quality streaming media over Internet, using satellite broadcast technology to take single stream of data and direct it to network server computers spread around Internet; its servers are on edges of Internet, avoiding costs and congestion associated with so-called Internet backbone networks; iBEAM plans to charge only content providers, not Internet service providers; photo (M)

headline: A Mutual Fund Rival on the Trading Floor
abstract: Article describes exchange-traded funds, relatively new type of investment product that is adding to mutual fund industry's woes over competition; photo; graph; chart (M)

headline: With a Turkish Town in Agony, Fellow Citizens Rush to Help
abstract: Distraught residents in Kaynasli, Turkey, which was devastated by earthquake on November 12, bury 60 of their dead; hopes of finding more people alive under rubble fade; death toll officially put at 374, but seems sure to rise; photos; map (M)

headline: Syrians Say Sky Is Clear On Horizon For New Talks
abstract: Syrian government and its Arab allies speak with customary caution even as they welcomed planned resumption of peace talks between Syria and Israel; but across Arab world, there are also rare hints of haste to learn whether breakthrough might bear real fruit (M)

headline: Arterial-Device Patent Suit
abstract: Cordis Corp unit of Johnson & Johnson is accused of infringing on patent of Medtronic AVE, unit of Medtronic Inc; Medtronic contends it owned patent issued year ago for placing stents--used to hold open arteries--with tiny balloon at end of wire (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.31   5.16   4.57        3-month T-bills   4.65   4.71   4.02        6-month T-bills   4.85   4.90   4.15        10-yr. T-infl.   4.12   4.10   3.65        10-yr. T-note   6.02   6.03   4.39        30-yr. T-bond   6.17   6.17   4.86        Telephone bd.   7.95   7.95   6.78        Municipal bds.   5.94   5.93   4.98          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: NO OFFER FOR AEROLINEAS ARGENTINAS
abstract: Argentina's flagship airline, Aerolineas Argentinas SA, will return to Spanish Government management in January because its current manager, AMR Corp, has not made Spain a purchase offer (S)

headline: VIACOM TO DELAY BLOCKBUSTER SPINOFF FOR HIGHER PRICE
abstract: Viacom Inc says it will not go ahead with planned spinoff to shareholders of its Blockbuster Inc video-rental chain until Blockbuster's price exceeds $20 a share; plan to distribute depends on ruling from Internal Revenue Service that distribution will be tax free to Viacom and its shareholders, considering Viacom's planned acquisition of CBS Corp (S)

headline: 22 Die as France Is Hit by 2nd Part of Weather's One-Two
abstract: France is hit by second fierce storm that kills 22 people, raising death toll from storms to at least 66; gale-force winds tear through southern half of nation; new storm heaps new trouble on emergency repair crews working to restore services knocked out by first storm; storms have killed over 100 people in Western Europe in last four days, with France hardest hit; map; photo (M)

headline: Dun & Bradstreet Will Spin Off Moody's
abstract: Dun & Bradstreet Corp intends to separate its Moody's Investors Service credit-rating subsidiary and its operating company into two publicly traded concerns (M)

headline: People
abstract: Recent appointments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: Russia Uses a Sledgehammer In Chechnya War This Time
abstract: Russian forces are using sledgehammer approach in breakaway province of Chechnya, applying overwhelming and massive firepower in efforts to rout Islamic rebels; while Western critics complain that artillery and air strikes have unnecessarily harmed civilians, they have been important part of Russian military's strategy, unlike 1994-96 war, to limit its casualties and maintain support at home; capture of village of Primykaniye after furious 10-hour firefight described; photos; map (M)

headline: BRAZILIAN AUTO SALES FALL
abstract: Automobile sales in Brazil fell 6.1 percent to a nine-month low in November, pulled lower by high financing rates and the expiration of an accord providing tax breaks on new car purchases. For the first 11 months of 1999, sales slumped 10 percent from the same period of 1998, in a reflection of Brazil's overall sluggish economy following a currency crisis earlier this year. Nonetheless, November's sales climbed 15 percent when compared with November 1998.     Simon Romero

headline: Moving to the Top Of the Stocking; The Year's Hot Toy? Anything Pokemon
abstract: Article discusses this year's popular toys as Christmas season approaches; Pokemon figures and cards are expected to be top sellers; other popular toys noted (M)

headline: NICKEL DISPUTE WORSENS
abstract: Inco Ltd, which fills more than quarter of global demand for nickel, says that problems beyond its control has forced it to renege on some contracts (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: France is considering European Commission proposal to allow meat to be labeled in way that indicates it comes from Britain, which may end feud with Britain over France's refusal to import British beef (S)

headline: Concerns Raised Over Encryption Report
abstract: As the Clinton administration began circulating its long-awaited plan yesterday for easing export controls on encryption technology, industry representatives and privacy groups said the proposal fell short of promises made by the White House two months ago.    The draft, floated to industry representatives and groups, puts into writing the plans that Vice President Al Gore announced during a trip to  Silicon Valley in September to ease the administration's controversial controls on the data scrambling technology. Encryption is widely used to keep computer data and online communications like e-mail private.

headline: Compressed Data; OfficeClick Offers Aides A Clique of Their Own
abstract: OfficeClick.com, new Web site, describes itself as first e-commerce specifically aimed at estimated 10.5 million administrative assistants in United States, who procure office goods on behalf of some 70 million colleagues (M)

headline: Yeltsin Admitted to Hospital for Influenza
abstract: Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin is admitted to Central Clinical Hospital in Moscow suffering from flu; photo (M)

headline: London Journal; On Seeing the Elgin Marbles, With Sandwiches
abstract: International academic symposium on Elgin Marbles at British Museum, designed to soothe wounded national feelings, has only deepened ownership dispute between Britain and Greece; many delegates are outraged when drinks and sandwiches are served alongside treasures; photo (M)

headline: Vodafone Gets Political in Its Bid for Mannesmann
abstract: LONDON—  The battle for dominance of mobile telephony in Europe turned political Tuesday as Vodafone AirTouch PLC claimed the support of Prime Minister Tony Blair for its bid to acquire Mannesmann AG of Germany.

headline: INFLATION IN BRAZIL
abstract: Institute for Economic Research says inflation in Brazil's largest city, Sao Paulo, rose 1.13 percent in month ended Oct 29, compared with 1.18 percent increase in previous four weeks (S)

headline: G.E. MAKES DEAL TO BUY MECON, A SOFTWARE MAKER
abstract: General Electric Co acquires Mecon Inc for about $81.2 million in stock (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: S.& P. 500 Gains 18 Points On Bargain Hunting Spree  The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 18.38 points, or 1.39 percent, to 1,336.02, in reaction to a buying spree by bargain hunters. The market was also responding to the mixed jobless report for September. The unemployment rate remained at 4.2 percent last month, but the report signaled that wages are rising at a faster-than-expected clip.

headline: Encyclopedia Britannica on Line, But Its Site Is Quickly Overrun
abstract: Encyclopedia Britannica says all 32 volumes will be available on Internet at www.britannica.com, free of charge; says site will also feature news feeds and list of Web sites chosen by Britannica's editors; photo (S)

headline: Ebay in Dispute With Listing Site
abstract: Web site Auctionwatch.com, in developing dispute over Internet auction listings, says it will continue to provide lists of items for sale on site of Ebay Inc, which has been trying to stop practice (S)

headline: Taking His Work Home
abstract: We have regional marketing managers and they travel to Detroit to discuss future marketing plans. Then everyone goes out to dinner.    For me, it was just one more night away from home. So I said, ''Tell you what. Why don't we have dinner at my house, and when I say dinner, I mean pizza and beer. I've got a pool table, I've got a football table.''

headline: BRIGHT ERICSSON OUTLOOK
abstract: Ericsson AB raises its estimate for 1999 sales and posts better-than-expected earnings; third-quarter net income fell 16 percent, to 2.6 billion kronor ($321 million), from 3.1 billion kronor a year ago; graph (S)

headline: MANAGEMENT: In Language You Can Understand; S.E.C. Edict Revives Push to Keep Documents Simple
abstract: A streamlining process designed to add value for consumers of content by reducing their comprehension experience is currently being efforted by public-sector entities and bleeding-edge corporations.    Huh?

headline: Impasse in Senate Delays Action On Africa-Caribbean Trade Bills
abstract: Senate temporarily sets aside package of trade bills for African and Caribbean nations while Republican and Democratic leaders try to break partisan impasse over several unrelated amendments; bills would reduce or eliminate duties on wide range of goods made in sub-Saharan Africa, Central America and Caribbean, mostly those assembled with American-produced fabrics; Pres Clinton and large majority of legislators support measures, but Senate Republicans who support them fall 15 votes short of 60 needed to cut off filibuster led by Democratic Sen Ernest F Hollings of South Carolina, who fears African imports will hurt state's textile industry (M)

headline: SOLUTIA TO BUY VIANOVA RESINS FOR $640 MILLION
abstract: Solutia Inc acquires German chemical company Vianova Resins for about $640 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pursuit of Stock Wealth Brings a World of Swindlers  Along with the greatest bull market in American history comes a world of low-priced stocks and high-priced dreams, of grimy offices and sham companies, of swindlers who bilk Americans out of roughly $2 billion a year, securities regulators say. The problem is so severe that regulators and prosecutors have made it one of their chief goals to crack down on what they used to dismiss as ''penny-stock fraud.''

headline: Nitzana Journal; A Limitless Dream for the Desert of Tomorrow
abstract: Interview with Lova Eliav on his proposal to develop Israel's sparsely populated Negev desert region with high technology and modern farming; he sees Nitzana growing into 'peace city' and hub of regional development; map; photo (M)

headline: Voters Send Two to a Runoff as Chileans Try to Shake the Past
abstract: Ricardo Lagos, Socialist-Christian Democratic candidate, and Joaquin Lavin, conservative, finish in virtual tie in first round of Chile's presidential election; four minor-party candidates win about 5 percent of vote (M)

headline: RUSSIA ARMY OPENS FIGHT TO CONTROL CHECHEN CAPITAL
abstract: Russian forces advance into Grozny, capital of Chechnya; immediate goal is to establish control over key junctions in city and to prevent militants from moving freely within city; longer-term objective is to use Russia's overwhelming advantage in firepower and take the city back neighborhood by neighborhood; escape appears over for the 50,000 people still in city; only 8,000 people used exit corridors opened by Russian forces; photo (M)

headline: FRENCH BID IS PREFERRED
abstract: Directors of United Biscuits PLC, Britain, urge shareholders to accept $2.03 billion bid from French-led investment group that includes Banque Nationale de Paris SA instead of lower offer from Nabisco Holdings Corp and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Ltd (S)

headline: Asian Stock Issues Find Halting Demand
abstract: Asian companies are rushing to raise billions of dollars with Asia's stock markets shaking off two years of near-paralysis; surprise is how hard they are finding the job; last week, third-largest Chinese petroleum company, China National Offshore Oil, postponed $1 billion share offering--a day after it cut size of sale by more than half; that came after leading Thai bank shelved its plan to raise $760 million in stock sale; latest reversals have unnerved Asian government officials, corporate executives and investment bankers, none more than in China and Hong Kong; flood of new Chinese and Hong Kong shares is scheduled to reach stock market in Hong Kong over next six months; some bankers express fear that they have missed window to cash in on Asia's improving economies; others worry that raft of offerings--$30 billion or more in Hong Kong alone--could overwhelm demand (M)

headline: U.S. Backs European Effort To Send Heating Oil to Serbs
abstract: Clinton administration, worried about being blamed if Serbs freeze to death in winter, will support European-run pilot program to send millions of dollars worth of heating oil to Serbia; earlier opposed European proposal, fearing that Pres Slobodan Milosevic would divert oil to business cronies or to Serbian military and that deliveries would alleviate hardships of cold winter and diminish public protests against his government; directs that oil will go to two cities in southern Serbia governed by opponents of Milosevic's Socialist Party (M)

headline: 2 FBC Executives Given Promotions
abstract: Sam Gulisano, group creative director, and Rich Russo, worldwide creative director, are named executive vice presidents and executive creative directors at FBC Worldwide; Russo and Gulisano assume duties of senior vice president Ted Littleford, who resigned (S)

headline: For Hotels, Quiet Bells and Whistles
abstract: Hotel industry is not straying far afield in designing hotels of the future; most changes under review involve using new technologies in incremental ways to improve guest security and comfort; drawing (M)

headline: EL PASO ENERGY CUTS 607 JOBS AFTER ACQUIRING SONAT
abstract: El Paso Energy Corp cuts 607 jobs in reorganization that accompanied its acquisition of Sonat Inc; El Paso completed $6 billion purchase of Sonat on Oct 25 (S)

headline: GERMAN BROADCASTER SALE
abstract: CLT-UFA, Europe's biggest television broadcaster, to buy News Corp's 49.9 percent stake in German channel Vox for $338 million (US) to gain control of channel; CLT-UFA already owns RTL, Germany's most-watched commercial TV station and has stakes in other free over-air broadcasters (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS: for MARK MILLMAN; London Fog: The Lessons Are Clear
abstract: Mark Millman, president of Search Group, retail consultant and outlet store personnel recruiter, answers questions on problems besetting London Fog since its retail expansion; photo (M)

headline: World's Worth of Black History and Culture
abstract: Michel Marriott reviews Encarta Africana 2000, updated CD-ROM encyclopedia covering black culture and history from Microsoft; photo (M)

headline: Advanced Micro Says Loss Is Smaller Than Expected
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc reports loss for third quarter ended Sept 26 that is smaller than expected; reports loss of $105.5 million in contrast to earnings of $1 million in year-earlier period; sales fell 3 percent, to $662.2 million from $685.9 million in 1998 quarter; company says it has asked investment bankers at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and at Salomon Smith Barney to find buyer for its telecommunications product group (M)

headline: AT&T AND BRITISH TELECOM ADD TO JOINT VENTURE
abstract: AT&T Corp and British Telecommunications PLC will invest $3 billion in their Concert venture over next five years to transmit voice, data and video faster between large cities (S)

headline: BRITISH TELECOM SHARES SOAR
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC's shares soar to all-time highs after company reports 21 percent gain in second-quarter sales, to 5.3 billion pounds ($8.75 billion); pretax profits rose 3 percent, to 832 million pounds ($1.37 billion) (S)

headline: Outside the Comfort Zone
abstract: Interview with A Barry Rand, new chief executive of Avis Rent A Car; comments on being eliminated from race for chief executive at Xerox Corp, which led to his resignation there as executive vice president; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Natwest's hostile bid for the Bank of Scotland is turning out to look like an overly long soap opera.
abstract: Hostile bidding war for National Westminster Bank that Bank of Scotland started last month is turning out to be not much of war at all; no other suitors have emerged; Natwest announces its defense strategy, hoping to thwart Bank of Scotland's $34 billion hostile bid and any other bid from friendlier suitors that have been taking wait-and-see approach (Market Place column) (M)

headline: No Small Change as Pension Plans Are Converted
abstract: HUNDREDS of companies have switched to cash-balance pension plans. But outraged employees who have seen the value of their pensions shrivel have spurred lawmakers to investigate and have pressured some companies, including I.B.M., to reverse themselves. Here are some common questions about the plans:    Q. How do cash-balance plans differ from traditional pensions?

headline: U.S. WEIGHS USING FOOD AS SUPPORT FOR SUDAN REBELS
abstract: Pres Clinton will sign bill allowing administration to pursue controversial strategy giving food assistance directly to rebels who have been fighting Islamic overnment in Sudan; advocates in State Department and National Security Council say plan will strengthen military operations of Sudan People's Liberation Army and isolate government, which US accuses of backing international terrorism; critics, including some administration officials and major aid groups, say providing sustenance to fighters by using food as weapon of war contravenes long-held principle of neutrality in food assistance during conflicts; photo (M)

headline: Ashkelon Journal; The Ever-So-Quiet Exodus: Israeli Cubans' Story
abstract: Four hundred Jews from Cuba are living in immigration center in Ashkelon, Israel; Israeli censors banned those who knew of Cubans' existence from publishing or broadcasting information about them; Government lifted ban on Oct 10, after Sunday Telegraph in London disclosed hidden immigration program; Cuban leader Fidel Castro in 1994 agreed to grant exit to any member of Cuba's dwindling Jewish population who wanted to move to Israel; his only condition was that program maintain lowest possible profile; map; photo (M)

headline: A Wing-and-Wing Race; Boeing Is Seeing Its Lead Over Airbus Slip Away
abstract: Boeing, proud company that has dominated commercial aviation since 1950's, is seeing its lead slip away to Airbus Industrie, European consortium that is Boeing's sole rival; so far this year, Airbus has outsold Boeing by more than two to one, largest gap since Airbus was founded in 1970; lopsided orders have prompted many in aviation industry and on Wall Street to consider what would have been unthinkable decade ago: that Boeing is in danger of slipping behind Airbus for years to come; at Frontier Airlines, Samuel D Addoms, chief exec, is replacing Boeing 737s with competing Airbus planes; photos; charts (L)

headline: Concern Over Year 2000 Remains Low in Surveys
abstract: Each new survey or poll adds to evidence that Americans are confident that computer glitches related to new century will not have much impact on their lives (S)

headline: NATWEST REJECTS OFFER
abstract: National Westminster Bank, the target in Britain's largest banking takeover battle, said it rejected hostile offers from Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland. during meetings with their boards. NatWest said its senior managers had met with directors from Bank of Scotland on Friday and with Royal Bank directors on Nov. 28. The NatWest chairman, Sir David Rowland, says shareholders will get the most value out of NatWest's remaining independent.

headline: In Bots We Trust?
abstract: Automated shopping robots, or bots, can instantly scan hundreds of merchants to help online shoppers find best goods at lowest price; consumers should be aware that some bots have loyalties to merchants, and list their products first, even if they are not cheapest; some bots will not even list merchants that do not pay for exposure; chart (M)

headline: Left Field Partners Form New Group
abstract: Kevin Burke and Fred Schwartz form advertising agency named Tonic 360 as successor to Left Field, shop where they had been managing partners until Ocotber (S)

headline: Microsoft Case Gets U.S. Judge As a Mediator
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is overseeing Microsoft antitrust trial, names mediator in effort to bring about settlement talks; all sides say they welcome action; mediator is Richard A Posner, chief judge for United States Court of Appeals for Seventh Circuit, in Chicago; Judge Jackson says mediation will be voluntary and nonbinding, and that it is up to Judge Posner, acting in private capacity, to schedule any talks (M)

headline: BROADBASE TO BUY MAKER OF ONLINE MARKETING SOFTWARE
abstract: Broadbase Software, maker of software for integrating and analyzing customer data, agrees to pay $331.2 million in stock for Rubric Inc, maker of software for automating online marketing (S)

headline: Gift of Connecting: Clinton Shows Skills, From Babies to Diplomats
abstract: Pres Clinton's legendary ability to connect with people is on display during his trip to Turkey, to visit earthquake-shattered town of Izmit and to attend summit meeting of Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe; vignettes from trip; photo (M)

headline: Treasury to Auction New Five-Year Note
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills as well as the quarterly refunding made up of a new five-year note and the reopening of the April 10-year note due 2009.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.97 percent and a six-month bill was 5.10 percent. In when-issued trading, the five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.81 percent, while the current 10-year issue was trading at a price to yield 5.91 percent.

headline: A Book That Teaches Children How to Read
abstract: Leap Frog, educational toy company, Emeryville, Calif, offers Leap Pad, learn-to-read tool for children 4 and older; product resembles an iBook laptop computer that when used with electronic pen becomes interactive storybook; Leap Frog is available in two versions; basic, which costs about $60, and deluxe, about $90 (S)

headline: Conservative Panel Member Leaving 'This Week' Program
abstract: In the first move of a promised makeover of ''This Week,'' the troubled ABC Sunday morning political discussion show, the network has parted company with the conservative commentator William Kristol, a member of the program's weekly roster of pundits.    Eileen Murphy, the vice president for communications at ABC News, said the network had decided not to offer Mr. Kristol a new long-term contract. His current contract ends on Jan. 1.

headline: Origami Sites Show How to Fold Them
abstract: Joyce Cohen reviews Web sites on origami, art of paper folding; photo (M)

headline: Better Late Than Never
abstract: Larry Augustin joined ranks of Internet billionaires when his company, VA Linux Systems, went public last week; Augustin's 16 percent share of company is worth $1.44 billion; five years ago, Augustin, who was graduate student at Stanford, and his friends David Filo and Jerry Yang came up with directory to World Wide Web that they ultimatedly called Yahoo; three men talked about writing joint business plan at one point, but Augustin dropped out to earn his doctorate in electrical engineering (S)

headline: Crisis Points Up Tough Choices for Tribunal on Rwanda
abstract: International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda faces dilemma of either prosecuting suspects in 1994 Hutu slaughter of Tutsi as harshly as Rwanda wants, which would risk its judicial integrity, or pursuing prosecutions with strict eye to legal issues, which would risk having Rwanda cut off its help permanently; analysts say Rwanda's leaders are intent on showing their power over the tribunal and keeping at bay any prosecution for their own excesses; crisis began in November, when appeals judges ordered release of Jean-Bosco Barayagwiza, a minister in previous government who helped set up a radio station used to incite violence against Tutsi, because tribunal held him too long before charging him; decision prompted new government to temporarily suspend cooperation with tribunal, which is heavily dependent on it; photo (M)

headline: Asian Telecommunications Venture Formed
abstract: Hong Kong's main telephone company, Cable and Wireless HKT, and Asia's leading satellite-television company, Star TV, say they will form company to deliver entertainment and information sevices to subscribers in Hong Kong and elsewhere in Asia; joint venture will combine Star TV's 30 channels, which is controlled by News Corp, with Cable and Wireless HKT's Internet-access and interactive television services; partners plan to issue shares in venture and will begin offering service in 2000 (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
abstract: Excerpt from earlier article on Country.Com's century of country, interactive CD-ROM focusing on country music (S)

headline: Fears Grow Over the De Facto Partition of Kosovo
abstract: Senior Western and UN officials are worried about de facto partition of Kosovo, and fear that Serb Pres Slobodan Milosevic may be using north of province to undermine international efforts to bring about peace and normality; note that Serbia proper actually begins at heavily-guarded bridge in Kosovska Mitrovica, where French troops guard boundary between Serbs and ethnic Albanians; photos; map; what began as effort to prevent violence has turned into strategic problem for peacekeeping force, which has not extended its authority in any meaningful way north of bridge; there is evidence that Milosevic is helping to organize security and ordinary life in Serb section; UN administrator Bernard Kouchner says bridge cannot be permanent border, but that forcing opening could cause more Serbs to flee (M)

headline: Runner-Up in Mexican Primary Says He Won't Protest Results
abstract: Roberto Madrazo Pintado, candidate who finished second in governing Institutional Revolutionary Party's first presidential primary in Mexico after rancorous campaign, acknowledges defeat by Francisco Labastida Ochoa and says he will not protest results or leave party (S)

headline: An All-Time Hit Parade
abstract: Article on greatest media hits of 20th century, or part of 20th century in which a particular medium even existed; charts of top films, music, television programs, computer software, video games, and media and technology stocks (M)

headline: RealNetworks Is Target of Suit In California Over Privacy Issue
abstract: California lawyer Jeffrey Spencer files $500 million class-action lawsuit against RealNetworks, leading maker of Internet multimedia software, charging that company violated state's unfair business practices law by distributing software that secretly gathered data about users and transmitted it back to company on Internet; lawsuit comes to light only hours after RealNetworks and TRUSTe, nonprofit group that awards privacy seals of approval to Web sites, announce new plans to address consumer privacy concerns (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TEXTRON INC.,  Providence, R.I., bought a French subsidiary of the German pump maker KSB A.G., to add to its line of oil and gas pumps. Terms of the purchase of KSB Annecy were not disclosed.

headline: IRON MOUNTAIN TO BUY A RIVAL FOR $630 MILLION
abstract: Iron Mountain Inc acquires Pierce Leahy Corp for $630 million in stock; Iron Mountain will also assume about $570 million in Pierce Leahy debt (S)

headline: Los Angeles Times Staff Protests Magazine Deal
abstract: Senior editors at Los Angeles Times meet with publisher Kathryn M Downing and express sense 'of betrayal' after disclosure that newspaper shared $2 million in advertising revenue from special magazine section, the Staples Center sports arena; about 300 editorial staff members demand apology, contending in petition that financial deal compromised newspaper's integrity; Downing apologizes for way she handled arrangement (M)

headline: NOVACARE SELLING OUTPATIENT OPERATIONS
abstract: Novacare Inc to sell its outpatient physical rehabilitation and occupational health operations to Select Medical Corp for about $155 million and assumption of $45 million of debt (S)

headline: OUTLOOK 2000: TECHNOLOGY & MEDIA: The Economy Transformed, Bit by Bit; Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
abstract: the economy transformed, bit by bit** Internet has become a powerful symbol of society's expectations about a future of fast-moving, disruptive technology that is shifting the terrain not only in business and stock markets, but also in politics and culture; whether labeled a revolution or an evolution, Internet's impact on US economy seems destined to keep growing, and to make organizational bureaucracies of every kind seem increasingly vulnerable to entrepreneurship; chart of investment in information technology; photo (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of October 3 item about election of Christine Legarde as chairman of Baker & McKenzie, which incorrectly referred to her status; she is not the only woman to lead one of 20 largest law firms in US; Debora de Hoyos is managing partner at Mayer Brown & Platt (S)

headline: THE BOSS; A Son With a Conscience
abstract: The Boss column on Amy Domini, managing principal of mutual fund Domini Social Investments, which selects companies that are good citizens and display social ethic; Domini comments on influence of her son, Jotham Kinder; photo (M)

headline: Micron Reports Return to Profit
abstract: Micron Technology Inc., a leading maker of computer-memory chips, had a fiscal first-quarter profit after two money-losing quarters as makers of personal computers bought more of its chips at higher prices.    Net income was $341.3 million, or $1.19 a share, for the quarter ended Dec. 2, compared with a loss of $46.2 million, or 19 cents, in the period a year earlier. Sales doubled, to $1.58 billion.

headline: Pimco to Sell A 70% Stake To Allianz
abstract: Allianz AG to buy 70 percent of Pimco Advisors Holdings for $3.3 billion (M)

headline: Auditors in Deep Disguise Crack Pension Computers
abstract: Security experts easily broke into computers at the federal agency that guarantees pensions, acquiring the power to create fictitious beneficiaries and send them money, a report to be made public today shows.    For three months beginning in May, the auditors rummaged through high-level administrative and financial system computer files at the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation in Washington, their activities undetected.

headline: Quarterly Net More Than Triples at Tyco
abstract: Tyco International Ltd says fiscal fourth-quarter profit more than tripled; profit rose to $782.7 million from $207 million a year earlier (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A New System For Nasdaq Is Disclosed
abstract: NASDAQ chairman Frank G Zarb discloses details of electronic system he says will make trading shares more efficient and fairer for investors (Market Place); electronic system, scheduled for introduction in summer 2000, addresses some concerns expressed by SEC chairman Arthur Levitt, who has challenged market participants to change with times by developing electronic and centralized market for stock trading to eliminate fragmentation caused by fledgling electronic stock markets; new system aims to link disparate markets by displaying prices offered to buy and sell stocks by traditional market firms (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: China to Open Its Economy Under Landmark Trade Deal  United States and Chinese negotiators agreed to open China's economy to foreign competitors and make the world's most populous nation a full partner in international commerce.    Under the deal, Beijing would reduce tariffs on industrial and agricultural products and lift many of the barriers in the way of American companies. In exchange, the United States agreed to support China for membership in the World Trade Organization.   [Page A1.]    Mike Moore, the head of the World Trade Organization, cautioned that several steps remained before China could become a full-fledged member.   [C11.]

headline: Clinton Seeks an Opening to Iran, But Efforts Have Been Rebuffed
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say White House has tried to achieve politically risky opening to Iran before Pres Clinton leaves office, but its efforts have been rebuffed; say most dramatic of initiatives was secret message sent in Aug seeking cooperation of Pres Mohammad Khatami in solving 1996 bombing of Khobar Towers in Saudia Arabia, which killed 19 US servicemen and wounded hundreds; administration also sought talks on reopening consular offices in Tehran for first time since relations were cut after 1979 Islamic revolution (M)

headline: Creative Writing
abstract: Some of the most imaginative flowerings of modern literature are in a special genre: the personal expense account. What has been the wildest, woolliest item you have tried to put on your account? And for how much? How did you explain it, and what happened? Or if you're a boss, what has been the most striking item you have encountered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: France Takes Steps to End Feud With Britain Over Beef Imports
abstract: France, acting to end feud over British beef imports, recommends its food safety agency lift 1996 ban imposed because of concern about mad cow disease; officials of both nations say dispute, which has severely strained British-French ties, will not derail talks on making Western Europe less militarily dependent on United States (M)

headline: Tudjman Is Dead; Croat Led Country Out of Yugoslavia
abstract: Pres Franjo Tudjman, onetime Communist general who led Croatia in 1991 into secession from Yugoslavia, and from there to independence and war, dies at age 77; no cause of death is given, but there have been reports that cancer for which he was treated in 1996 spread to his brain; Vlatko Pavletic, parliamentary speaker, assumed presidential power on Nov 26; photos (L)

headline: INDONESIAN CAR TALKS
abstract: Group of investors led by Newbridge Capital Ltd and Gilbert Global Equity Capital may buy 19.9 percent stake in PT Astra International, Indonesia's largest car maker (S)

headline: COLE TO CLOSE OPTICAL DEPARTMENTS IN WARD STORES
abstract: The Cole National Corporation, a retailer of eyeglasses and lenses, said yesterday that it would close its 150 optical departments in Montgomery Ward stores to focus on businesses like Pearle Vision and Sears Optical stores. Cole said it would take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $2 million to $2.5 million for the Wards closings. Cole, which had sales of $1.07 billion last year, operates optical departments for big retailers and stores under the Pearle name. The company warned that expenses would rise for initiatives, including franchisee support and advertising for the Pearle chain, before sales improved significantly. It also said fourth-quarter earnings might be hurt by manufacturing and distribution problems for a new system at Pearle stores.

headline: Birchtown Journal; For Nova Scotia Blacks, Veil Is Ripped From Past
abstract: Nova Scotia is now unearthing its black history, after two centuries of neglect bordering on denial; in Halifax, 250-year-old city, Nova Scotia Museum researchers win $114,000 federal grant to research black history; black history slide shows has toured traditionally black communities; investigators from new provincial black history project come up with Book of Negroes, list of African-Americans who had escaped slavery to fight with British during American Revolution; photo; maps (L)

headline: EL AL-BOEING DEAL SIGNED
abstract: Israel's national airline, El Al, signed a $400 million order for three new Boeing 777's, under an agreement announced in October. But El Al postponed a planned $350 million parallel purchase of three Airbus A330-200's, after the minister of transportation, Yitzhak Mordechai, said he needed more time to review the purchase. The government is now expected to delay the Airbus Industrie decision until it fills eight vacant seats on El Al's board. The A330 purchase, announced with the Boeing 777 order, would have been the airline's first Airbus purchase.   William A.Orme, Jr.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: It's Make-or-Break Season at One Young Online Company
abstract: GiftCertificates.com, Internet startup retailer that markets gift certificates, is engaged in daily frenzy placing orders during hectic, make-or-break year-end holiday season; company's fortunes, like those of competitors, will be determined largely by how well it copes with mundane matters such as order handling, packing, shipping and answering customers' questions over phone--tasks done mostly by high school graduates; photos (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Prices for crude oil continue to rally on expectations that low OPEC production will deplete supplies; in New York, crude oil for December delivery rises 76 cents, or 3 percent, to $26.56 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: G.M. Official Gives Upbeat Review of Year
abstract: G Richard Wagoner, president of General Motors Corp, gives upbeat assessment of 1999, year in which his company earned record profits even as its market share declined; some Wall Street analysts have had growing concerns about GM slide in market share; Wagoner photo (M)

headline: Analysts Are Forecasting a Stock Split by G.E.
abstract: The General Electric Company, which last split its shares in 1997, is likely to declare a stock split and raise its quarterly dividend as much as 15 percent at its board meeting on Friday, analysts said.    The split, which is intended to make the shares more affordable, would be the company's ninth and would be the fifth since John F. Welch Jr. became chief executive in 1981.

headline: Why Clinton Plea on Pact Left Lott Unmoved
abstract: Senate majority leader Trent Lott's opposition to nuclear test ban treaty, which helped secure its defeat, resulted from angry reaction by conservatives after he voted for Chemical Weapons Convention in 1997; he has been accused by hard-liners of preferring to cut deals and keeping comity, instead of sticking to conservative principles; photo (M)

headline: Web Is No Place for Last-Minute Gift Buyers
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (Online Shopper) column on her experience with on-line shopping; says, induced by an offer of $10 off her next purchase at Buy.com, she experienced delays in obtaining item; leads her to question Web as source for last-minute holiday gift buyers and to recall all customer service problems she experienced while shopping online during this holiday season; she describes some (M)

headline: Celebritystores Awards Its First Account
abstract: Celebritystores.com awards its first advertising account to Beber Silverstein & Partners; billings estimated at $4 million (S)

headline: CHARTER TO BUY TV BOXES FROM GENERAL INSTRUMENT
abstract: Charter Communications Inc, cable-television operator controlled by the billionaire Paul Allen, will buy one million digital set-top TV boxes from General Instrument Corp for about $300 million; boxes let standard televisions connect to Internet (S)

headline: French Find Cigarette Maker Partly Liable in Cancer Death
abstract: French court rules that Seita, maker of Gauloise and Gitane brand of cigarettes, is partly responsible for death of Richard Gourlain, three-pack-a-day smoker who died of lung cancer earlier in the year; decision is first time that a tobacco company has been held liable in health liability case in France; court, in reaching complicated formula for responsibility, also said that Gourlain was to blame for his illness; held Seita was respopnsible for years that Gourlain smoked when he was teenager and partly responsible for years he smoked as an adult before company put health warnings on cigarette packs in 1976; Seita to appeal ruling (M)

headline: Gros Morne Journal; Town Struggles to Keep From Being Washed Away
abstract: Residents of rural Gros Morne, Haiti, whose homes lie in path of encroaching soil erosion are pressing government for retaining wall to save houses and protect national highway, town square and marketplace, but pleas have gone unanswered as government has been paralyzed since 1997 from political infighting; environmental calamities and administrative neglect that have plagued much of country are abundantly evident in area; for years Haitians have cut down trees for charcoal, deforesting 97 percent of nation's land; rainy season brings mountainside erosion, rivers gorged with water and more erosion along water's path; maps; photo (M)

headline: No Longer Tolerant of Official Misconduct, Brazilians Now Demand Accountability
abstract: Suspect that bankers may have illegally profited from Brazil's currency devaluation last January? Convene a congressional investigation to look into it. Worried about organized crime? Order a second legislative inquiry. Fearful of corruption in the judiciary? Get yet another committee to examine the issue.    Almost everywhere Brazilians turn these days, one parliamentary commission of inquiry or another seems to be investigating some form of official misconduct. What is more, many of these C.P.I.'s, as they are called by their Portuguese initials, are actually yielding results -- forcing policy changes and unmasking offenders and sending them to court.

headline: Agreement Has Led to Boom In U.S.-Canada Air Traffic
abstract: The last time President Clinton came to Ottawa, Canada's capital, was in 1995. He visited the neo-Gothic Parliament building to witness the signing of an abstract piece of economic diplomacy: an open-skies agreement with Canada.    When Mr. Clinton returned there last week, the benefits were as concrete as the direct flights between Ottawa and Reagan National Airport in Washington that began two months ago, just in time for the President's advance team.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Volatility Isn't What It Used to Be (It's Worse)
abstract: Stock market volatility has grown to point that most investors have become inured to big daily moves; only a decade ago, Nasdaq composite averaged about one big day--defined as a close at least 1 perent above or below previous day--each month; so far this year, it is averaging three such days every week; some causes for volatility discussed; graphs (M)

headline: Gasoline Prices Fall a Bit
abstract: Survey of 800 gasoline stations nationwide shows retail price of gasoline fell to $1.269 per gallon during week ended December 21, dropping from level that was highest in three-and-a-half years (S)

headline: New Battles Erupt In A.T.M. Fee War As Banks Retaliate
abstract: Recent skirmishes over automated teller machine surcharges may be breaking into full-fledged war amid rising public resentment; other cities and states are moving to enact ban following passage in Los Angeles of nation's first local ordinance banning banks from charging noncustomers from using their ATM's (M)

headline: DAEWOO RECEIVERSHIP DELAYED
abstract: Lee Hun Jai, chairman of financial watchdog agency Financial Supervisory Commission, says South Korean government will delay until late January decision on whether to place Daewoo Corp under court receivership, while continuing talks with foreign creditors (S)

headline: Nextel Planning a Hostile Bid for NextWave
abstract: Nextel Communications plans $3-billion hostile bid for bankrupt NextWave Telecom Inc (S)

headline: Conceding Nothing, Gates Sees Finding As Only One Step
abstract: Microsoft chairman William Gates defiantly takes issue with findings of fact by Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, denouncing company as monopoly that uses power to stifle innovation, reduce competition and hurt consumers; reiterates at news conference at Redmond, Wash, headquarters that Microsoft competes vigorously and fairly; says lawsuit is fundamentally about whether successful American company can continue to improve its products for benefit of consumers; William Neukom, general counsel and architect of company's legal strategy, says company's position will be fully vindicated at end of legal process, which has only just begun (M)

headline: Shifts Are Made At MacManus Units
abstract: Two units of MacManus Group make changes (S)

headline: Where the Wildebeest Roam, on CD-ROM
abstract: Appraisel of new CD-ROM, Nature: Virtual Serengeti, which offers virtual safari through parts of Serengeti National Park; photos (M)

headline: In 'New' Mexican Politics, Some Old Tricks
abstract: Mexico's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party has pledged to turn over new leaf in 1999 by making its first presidential primary open, clean and fair, but since Francisco Labastida Ochoa seems to be choice of Pres Ernesto Zedillo many old guard party leaders are backing him with dirty electoral tricks that have kept party in power for 70 years (M)

headline: BRITISH MEDIA MERGER
abstract: Two British media companies, Carlton Communications and United News and Media, merge in deal valued at 4 billion pounds ($6.5 billion); merger would make combined company largest commercial television concern in Britain; analysts say merger will face tough regulatory hurdles; companies say they might sell assets to appease regulators; graph (S)

headline: Deregulation to Unleash New Competition : Giant Banks Prepare For a U.S. Onslaught
abstract: The global financial industry, fresh from a round of megamergers, now must brace for another jolt of competition in the wake of a historic change in U.S. banking laws, executives said over the weekend.

headline: G.E.'s Profit Rose 16% in Third Quarter
abstract: General Electric Co says third-quarter profit rose 16 percent to $2.65 billion, compared with $2.28 billion a year earlier; revenue rose 13 percent, to $27.2 billion from $24.14 billion; figures for specific divisions noted (M)

headline: A Nigerian State Turns to the Koran for Law
abstract: Nigeria's northwestern state of Gusau announces it will introduce Islamic social and penal code, raising biggest challenge to fragile national unity and causing panic in country equally divided between Muslim north and Christian south; photos; map (M)

headline: Canada's Private Control Towers; Sale of Air Traffic System Has Led to Technical Advances
abstract: Canadian Government's sale of air traffic control system has led to technical advances; in 1996, Transport Canada, Government agency that had run system for decades, sold it to nonprofit company created by Parliament, whose directors represent airlines, general aviation, unionized workers and public; most constituencies think new arrangement called Nav Canada is going well, though controllers are having some second thoughts; some airline delays and budget overruns to finance system discussed; Nav Canada has cut its payroll, lowered cost of flying in Canada, raised salaries and increased productivity; Clinton administration in US is watching experiment in Canada and is weighing reorganizing American system; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Grey Replaces Managers in Brazil
abstract: Grey Advertising in New York says it has replaced top managers of its agency in Sao Paulo, Brazil; Jose Luiz Grellet is named president; Jose Chicau executive vice president; Fernando Luna creative vice president; new managers assume duties from partners Sergio Guerreiro, who had also been president, and Zezito Marques da Costa, who resigned (S)

headline: Fight Is Promised Over G.M. Plan to Buy Dealerships
abstract: James A Willingham, president of National Automobile Dealers Association, one of nation's wealthiest and most powerful business lobbying groups, bitterly criticizes General Motors Corp for its plan to buy 5 percent to 10 percent of its dealerships and operate them itself; hints that dealers might try to use their political influence to stop company; criticism sets stage not only for fight over how automobiles are sold in US but also over development of electronic commerce and the Internet; GM and other auto makers have been trying to market vehicles over Internet, but dealers have been blocking many of those initiatives, using state franchise laws that require that all vehicles be sold through dealerships; GM could get around those laws by owning dealerships (M)

headline: Kinder Dyes Bolster a Global Trend That Appeals to All Ages : Now It's Natural to Color Hair
abstract: PARIS—  Not so long ago, only "loose" (or aging) women dyed their hair. Today, fewer and fewer women can remember their original hair color. Globally, hair coloring is turning into a fashion phenomenon.

headline: Indonesian Leader Forms 'Mixmaster' Cabinet
abstract: Indonesian Pres Abdurrahman Wahid names Cabinet; appoints former Education Min Juwono Sudarsono as Defense Minister and shifts command of armed forces from politically aggressive and tainted army to navy; names Gen Wiranto, chief of armed forces, as coordinating minister and Adm Widodo Adisutjipto as Wiranto's successor; other appointments noted; photos (M)

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Gets PUR Account
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co expands its relationship with Saatchi & Saatchi in New York by naming agency to handle account of PUR line of drinking-water filters; billings have not been determined (S)

headline: For Indian Nations, Virtual Trade Routes
abstract: Internet is marketplace for modern version of trade among Indian nations; Keller George, president of United South and Eastern Tribes, estimates that 60 to 70 percent of member tribes are on line; those who are not can market their products to different Indian nations through tribal organization's Web site; drawing (M)

headline: Surprises from Jakarta to Wall Street
abstract: Funny how the election of a new president can send financial markets roiling, especially when it isn't the president everyone is expecting.      Indonesia, whose population and economy make it too big to ignore but whose financial crisis and turbulent politics have long given investors palpitations, took a big and surprising step last week along a road that many think can lead to stable democracy and growth. Its parliament chose a moderate Muslim theologian, Abdurrahman Wahid, over Megawati Sukarnoputri, the fiery daughter of Sukarno, the former president, even though her political party won more seats than Mr. Wahid's in recent elections. The Jakarta stock market reacted mainly with enthusiasm, rising 6.39 percent for the week on 10 times the usual trading volume.

headline: U.S. Deal on Caspian Oil Still Faces Problems With Bottom Line
abstract: Oil executives and Clinton administration officials say agreement to build pipeline to carry Caspian Sea oil across Turkey, avoiding routes through either Russia or Iran, is far from being reality, for both financial and political reasons; at issue is whether route, which is strategically advantageous to United States but costly for oil companies, can be made profitable quickly; another issue is political fallout with Russia, the loser in the deal; Clinton administration's main concern is guaranteeing that any pipeline would skirt Russia or Iran and deny them choke-hold over new energy supply for West; map (M)

headline: MAYTAG TO BUY BACK AS MANY AS 10 MILLION SHARES
abstract: Maytag Corp plans to buy back as many as 10 million shares; buyback is valued at about $456.25 million; represents about 8.4 percent of 83.9 million shares outstanding (S)

headline: Israel Details Pope's Visit in March
abstract: Israel confirms that in March Pope John Paul II will make first official visit to Israel by a pope; his six-day visit will take in Christian holy sites, Yad Vashem, the Holocaust memorial, and perhaps the Western Wall in Jerusalem; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WELLS-GARDNER ELECTRONICS CORP., Chicago, a video products company, plans to acquire the assets of American Gaming and Electronics Inc., North America's largest independent distributor of gaming parts and service. Terms were not disclosed.    GEMSTAR INTERNATIONAL GROUP , Pasadena, Calif., which makes the VCR Plus software and software for interactive programming guides, will split its stock two shares for one. Shareholders of record on Nov. 29 will receive an extra share on Dec. 13.

headline: INFLATION SIGNAL IN GERMANY
abstract: German import prices rose 1.4 percent in November, highest in more than decade, putting pressure on European Central Bank to raise rates early in 2000 (S)

headline: Bosnia Is Peaceful Now but Will It Stay That Way?
abstract: Bosnian Serb, Muslim and Croat populations in Sarajevo, driven apart by war, still remain wary of each other and are not yet reconciled; Radovan Karadzic and Gen Ratko Mladic, two of most notorious Bosnian Serb leaders who have been indicted on war crimes charges, have not been apprehended and still exercise power behind the scenes; map; photo (M)

headline: Trying to Turn Stocks Into a National Pastime
abstract: On-line investment firms, many of which did not exist two years ago, have collectively bought more World Series advertising time than any other industry; spending binge is part of investment world's attempt to turn stock trading into new national pastime, perhaps with room for baseball, too; photo (M)

headline: A Virtual Oasis For Morocco Stocks; Trading Going on Here? Shocking!
abstract: The trading floor of the Casablanca Stock Exchange, with just 30 traders working in little computer cubicles, is as quiet as a church. And it is about to get even quieter.    Early next year, the trading floor is shutting down, exchange officials say, thrusting Casablanca's small, young, but technologically hip stock market into the growing ranks of virtual exchanges around the world.    As in London, Paris, Brussels, Toronto, Sao Paulo, Brazil, and a rising number of other places, brokers here will be trading directly from their own offices in a kind of miniature Nasdaq.

headline: Clinton Tries To Subdue Greeks' Anger At America
abstract: Pres Clinton, in Athens, moves to defuse anti-American sentiment in Greece by suggesting that Washington had erred in supporting military junta that suppressed democracy there from 1967 to 1974; Clinton, alluding to democracy's origin, says 'we are all Greeks'; Clinton defends NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia in war over Kosovo; war was deeply unpopular in Greece, which shares Serbia's Orthodox faith; Clinton makes remarks day after virulent anti-American protests in center of Athens timed to coincide with his visit; Clinton urges Greek and Turkish leaders to resolve their territorial disputes, especially over island of Cyprus, which has been divided since Turkish troops landed on its northern half in 1974; photo of Pres Clinton and daughter, Chelsea, exploring Parthenon (M)

headline: Bermuda Exchange Idled
abstract: Trading on Bermuda da Stock Exchange is shut down because of computer problem as technicians upgrade operating system software (S)

headline: Just Imagine ...
abstract: Over this past century, business has given us the car, the radio, the television, the personal computer, the jet, the trash compactor and shampoo combined with conditioner. Imagine that you could ask for one equally huge innovation in the coming century, to improve your own lot or that of all mankind. What would you ask for? Send your ideas to Outlook 2000, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to Outlook-2000@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TEXAS UTILITIES CO., Dallas, said it plans to buy back more than $800 million of its common stock next year. The buyback will involve approximately 7.5 percent of its 276.4 million shares outstanding.    DUPONT PHOTOMASKS INC., Round Rock, Tex., said it will acquire the European photomask operations of International Business Machines Corp., New York, and supply the semiconductor templates to the world's largest computer maker.

headline: Japanese Fuel Plant Spews Radiation After Accident
abstract: Out-of-control chain reaction at nuclear fuel plant in Tokaimura releases high levels of radiation in air in worst accident in Japan's troubled history with nuclear power; 35 people are exposed, three of them seriously injured, and 300,000 residents are ordered to stay indoors; officials say reaction was set off when workers accidentally poured more uranium than usual into purification tank containing nitric acid; say it was brought under control; plant is owned by Sumitomo Metal Mining Co and operated by JCO Co; diagram; graph; photo (M)

headline: Yeltsin Hospitalized; Pneumonia Is Suspected
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized for second time in less than two months after checkup after doctors detected what might be pneumonia (S)

headline: From the Economy, a Familiar Song
abstract: Weekly round-up of stock market performance focuses on latest quarterly preliminary gross domestic product figures, which reflected 4.8 percent rise in economic growth and helped indexes to increase; charts (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for JIM STRUPP; Thinking Smaller About Beer
abstract: five questions for jim strupp: thin

headline: Deutsche Telekom's Trans-Atlantic Strategy Hits a Snag
abstract: Wild bidding for Sprint Corp has left Europe's biggest phone company, Deutsche Telekom AG, grasping for trans-Atlantic partner; company, which owns 10 percent of Sprint, has been hampered by accord with France Telecom SA, which also owns 10 percent, that neither can raise their stake without other's permission; is also limited by Sprint's daunting stock price (M)

headline: BEA-Warburg Venture Formed
abstract: BEA Systems Inc and Warburg, Pincus Ventures are forming independent electronic commerce software development company; new concern, which has not yet been named, is expected to begin operation in January; companies agree to acquire Internet Tools unit of Symantec Corp for $75 million in cash (S)

headline: Albanians in Kosovo Grateful U.S. Army Is There
abstract: Braving the first snow of the year, hundreds of Kosovo Albanians packed the main street here today to try to glimpse President Clinton.    Blocked by American soldiers standing atop armored troop carriers, many of the Albanians could see only the presidential helicopter lifting off behind the trees, but they were in happy mood and cheered and whistled.

headline: Obuchi Picks Aide Linked To Buddhists For Cabinet
abstract: Prime Min Keizo Obuchi of Japan extensively shuffles his Cabinet, adding member of party backed by controversial lay Buddhist group Soka Gakkai to broaden coalition; move should enable him to push through rapidly series of major bills on Japan's economy and role in world; Obuchi retains top economic advisers, including Finance Min Kiichi Miyazawa; names Yohei Kono Foreign Minister (M)

headline: Credit Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and a 30-year treasury inflation pegged securities on Wednesday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.72 percent and a six-month bill was 4.79 percent.

headline: I Stare Death in the Face
abstract: Profile of Caryn Platt Tatelli, who is hired by lawyers and in most cases conducts prison interviews and searches some of Midwest's most violent neighborhoods for mitigating factors to save inmates from execution; Tatelli, daughter of Lewis E Platt, outgoing Hewlett-Packard chairman, comments; photo (M)

headline: Extraterrestrial Sounds From the Red Planet
abstract: Planetary Society will post sounds and video images captured by Mars Polar Lander on its Web site; photo (S)

headline: Using Linux To Run a PC
abstract: Q.  What exactly is the Linux system and what can the average person do with it?     A.  Linux, a computer operating system created by Linus Torvalds, a Finnish programmer, has been getting a lot of attention as an alternative to Windows. Linux is open-source software, which means that the program's source code is made public. It is available free to anyone who would like to use it or modify it. Commercial versions of Linux, like one released by Red Hat, can be purchased from software vendors, and many Linux books also include a CD-ROM containing the program.

headline: November a 'Funny Month' For the Nation's Retailers
abstract: Unseasonably warm weather put damper on retail sales for much of November, but exceptionally bullish week of shopping after Thanksgiving helped get nation's merchants back on track for strong Christmas season; sales rose 2.9 percent in November--smallest since September 1997 (M)

headline: East Timor Leaders Oppose a Malaysian-Led Force
abstract: SINGAPORE—  The East Timorese leadership has effectively vetoed a proposal by Malaysia, which prides itself as a champion of Third World causes, to take command of the United Nations-sanctioned force that will help prepare the territory for independence within three years, diplomats said Tuesday.

headline: PHELPS DODGE WILL NOT RAISE OFFER FOR ASARCO
abstract: The Phelps Dodge Corporation said yesterday that it would not raise its bid to acquire the New York-based copper producer Asarco Inc. in response to a rival bid from Grupo Mexico S.A. that was submitted on Thursday. Grupo Mexico said it would pay $29.50 in cash for Asarco, up from its previous offer of $26 a share and topping a $28.21 cash-and-stock bid by Phelps Dodge that Asarco accepted on Wednesday. The Grupo Mexico bid is worth about $1.174 billion, compared with $1.12 billion for the Phelps Dodge offer. Asarco said yesterday that its board would consider the Grupo Mexico offer.

headline: Whose $1 Is It, Anyhow? A Defense of an A.T.M. Fee
abstract: Donald G Ogilvie, American Bankers Assn executive vice president, answers five questions on consumer complaints about automated teller machine fees; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Co

headline: A Global Cell Phone That Can Entertain You
abstract: Ericsson of Sweden produces T28 World digital phone, which accepts series of snap-on attachments that can turn it into tiny personal electronic companion; photo (S)

headline: Internet Makes an Easy Target For Lobbyists and Lawmakers
abstract: When it comes to cyberspace, the mantra of politicians vying for the title of most e-friendly, Republicans and Democrats alike, has been ''Hands off and go slow.'' Yet lawmakers have already passed a laundry list of bills that leave the federal government's fingerprints all over the Internet, and more are in the pipeline.    The efforts include inventing rules against the peddling of Internet addresses, granting legal standing for digital contracts, proposing bans on the Internet programming known as Webcasts, prohibiting online gambling and regulating ''spam,'' the junk mail of cyberspace.

headline: PALM TO PALM COMBAT
abstract: Psion PLC to offer new hand-held electronic organizer this month, offering Internet access through mobile phone or wireless modem and linked to free Internet-service provider (S)

headline: CHRIS-CRAFT IN TALKS ON TV STATION OWNERSHIPS
abstract: Chris-Craft Industries, owner of 10 television stations in US, says it is in talks about possible transactions after rules governing ownership of multiple stations in large cities are relaxed; hires investment bank Allen & Co as adviser (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of September 26 article about health concerns over heavy exposure to carbonless copy paper, which misstated class of chemicals used in such paper; alkyl biphenyls, not alkyl biphenols, can be transferred to human skin (S)

headline: California Property Deal
abstract: Equity Office Prope

headline: Enemy or Friend?
abstract: Steven A Ludsin letter on Nov 25 article cites benefits of being able to write on laptop computer8

headline: Serbs Reject U.S. Plan Linking End of Sanctions to Free Vote
abstract: Yugoslav government dismisses new American proposal for partial suspension of sanctions in return for early elections (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RAYTHEON CO., Lexington, Mass., the military contractor, received a $1.1 billion contract to build two power plants in Massachusetts for Sithe Energies Inc., New York.    COPPER MOUNTAIN NETWORKS INC., Palo Alto, Calif., a provider of high-speed Internet access, said it would split its stock two for one. The new shares will be issued Dec. 9 to holders of record as of Nov. 24.

headline: 2 Retailers Post Increases In Earnings
