The group agreed to pay $18.25 a share for Wilmar of Moorestown, N.J., which distributes building maintenance supplies. Wilmar shares were up $3.1875, or nearly 23 percent, at $17.1875.

headline: PHILIPS PROFIT DOUBLES
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics says profit more than doubled in third quarter, beating analysts' expectations; profit soared to 374 million euros, or $403 million, from 147 million euros (S)

headline: Held Accountable
abstract: California court has ruled that promotional copy on book jackets is not entitled to unlimited First Amendment protection and that publishers can be sued over its veracity; case involved Beardstown Ladies' Investment Club, published by Disney unit Buena Vista Books (S)

headline: The Workplace Can Be Threatening, Especially for Women
abstract: Society for Human Resource Management survey of human resource professionals shows 57 percent of respondents reported incidents of violence or threats involving employees over previous 43 months; 1996 survey yielded lower figure, 48 percent, but because it covered shorter period; 'personality conflicts' played role in 55 percent of violent episodes in 1999, down from 62 percent three years earlier, while 'relationship problems' influenced 36 percent of all cases, up from 27 percent; women accounted for 45 percent of victims in latest survey, up from 41 percent in 1996, while portion of victims who were men fell to 49 percent of total from 59 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: France Presses For a Power Independent Of the U.S.
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac, speaking at inte

headline: TIBCO BUYING XEROX'S INCONCERT UNIT FOR $34 MILLION
abstract: Tibco Buying Xerox's Inconcert Unit Forï

headline: The Airline Industry May Get a Little Smaller So It Can Get Bigger
abstract: Trend in airline industry for next decade will likely be split between gigantic planes, like Boeing 747 and planned Airbus A3XX, and smaller, more efficient planes that can make longer direct flights; big or small, some planes will have a lot more creature comforts, including live satellite television; photos (M)

headline: Dow and S.& P. Both Gain But Nasdaq Falls Slightly
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 92.76 points, to 10,394.89; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 14.80 points, to 1,296.71; Nasdaq composite index falls 8.95 points, to 2,802.52; graph; chart (M)

headline: PARK NATIONAL SET TO ACQUIRE BANK HOLDING COMPANY
abstract: Park National Corp to acquire SNB Corp and its Second National Bank unit for $96 million in stock (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Post-Mortem Of a Highflier: Boston Market
abstract: Market Place article on rise and fall of Boston Market, which for time in 1990's convinced investors it would be new fast-food giant, offering healthier menu to aging baby boomers; McDonald's is now buying most assets, including 751 restaurants, franchise rights for additional 108 restaurants and Boston Market brand; some branches may become Chipotle Mexican Grill or Donatos Pizza outlets; sale is subject to bankruptcy court approval; price of $173.5 million is small fraction of $900 million Boston Market owes (M)

headline: Nasdaq Conversion Plan Wins Approval of Governing Board
abstract: Board of National Assn of Securities Dealers agrees to preliminary plan to convert Nasdaq stock market to private for-profit company; also, Nasdaq and Wall Street's largest brokerage firms reach preliminary agreement to provide electronic trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks (M)

headline: Clinton Sends Envoys to Try to Close a Deal on Opening Chinese Markets to the U.S.
abstract: Pres Clinton, after telephone call to Pres Jiang Zemin of China, sends trade representative Charlene Barshefsky and Gene Sperling, top economic adviser, to Beijing to try to close deal to bring China into World Trade Organization; move suggests Administration now believes agreement is within reach; deal would represent one of most important American accords with China since resumption of diplomatic relations two decades ago; would also give Clinton long-sought foreign policy accomplishment, namely, claim to have helped integrate world's most populous nation into global economy--putting it under rule of international law with accord that could also spur country's faltering economic reforms (M)

headline: Mesa Plans Stock Buyback
abstract: Mesa Air Group plans to buy back 10 percent of its common shares; names Robert Stone chief financial officer (S)

headline: MIDCOAST ENERGY SETS DEAL TO ADD KANSAS PIPELINE
abstract: Midcoast Energy Resources agrees to buy Kansas Pipeline Co for about $190 million in cash (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: ATTACK ON MONEY LAUNDERING -- Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin pledged to crack down on money laundering. Although he did not offer any specifics in a speech at the start of a conference in Moscow of justice and law enforcement ministers from leading industrial nations, Parliament is expected to try to pass a law this year against money laundering. The United States Attorney General, Janet Reno, was at the conference and signed several crime-fighting agreements.   Michael R. Gordon (NYT)

headline: The Computer as Post Office
abstract: Peter H Lewis (State of the Art) column evaluates computer-generated Internet postage sites in terms of user convenience; recalls that earlier this year Postal Service approved plan to sell postage stamps over Internet so people can avoid going to post office if they do not want to; says plan allows users to buy digital postage online and print stamps--technically known as Information Based Indicia; says two leading providers of such sites are E-Stamp Corp and Stamps.com; says in general neither of new Internet-based postage services is really practical for such things as Christmas cards and that they are more useful for Internet-connected small offices and home offices that send out lots of letters and packages (M)

headline: For China's Rural Migrants, an Education Wall
abstract: Tens of millions of rural Chinese who seek better lives in cities are shortchanged on education; cities like Beijing permit children of migrants, most of whom are actually longtime resident working low-end jobs, attend public schools only if they pay stiff fees that few can afford; unlicensed schools, some run by people with no more than a junior high school education, have grown up to serve these families, but they receive no government aid; China's system of residential permits and the privileges of official urban residents, who make up less than one-third of national population, seem certain to rankle more and more in the years ahead, especially as global competition kills off marginal producers and forces more Chinese from farms and to the cities; photo (M)

headline: The Euro Slips Briefly Below Dollar's Value
abstract: Europe's single currency declines to symbolic and political low point, dropping briefly below value of dollar for first time since its introduction in 1998; value of euro, after months of decline, slipped to 99.96 cents before edging back just above parity, settling in New York foreign-exchange trading at $1.0018; currency has declined about 15 percent against dollar and more than 30 percent against Japanese yen since introduction; graphs (M)

headline: Hasbro to Cut 20% of Its Jobs and Take $97 Million Charge
abstract: The toymaker Hasbro Inc. said yesterday that it was eliminating 2,200 jobs, or more than 20 percent of its work force, and taking a restructuring charge of $97 million, or 50 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1999.    Hasbro hopes to increase sales by expanding its offerings of electronic toys and CD-ROM games and its popular Pokemon line. But analysts said retail sales of Hasbro's ''Star Wars'' line were sluggish as the latest movie failed to meet the hype-induced expectations at the box office. The company, based in Pawtucket, R.I., hopes to compensate with Pokemon trading cards, one of this year's sensations.

headline: Xerox Shares Shake Off Friday's Jitters
abstract: Xerox Corp shares rise $1.0625, to $21.125, despite analysts' downgrades (M)

headline: It's Often Hard to Find Help Behind the Cybercounter
abstract: Deficiencies in customer service remain an obstacle to e-commerce, and a growing number of businesses seek to address problem; Robert LoCascio has started a company called LivePerson.com, which makes it possible for Web sites to have their customers chat via written notes in real time with customer service representatives; some Web retailers are improving their service, among them Lands' End; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises against Japanese yen as traders wait for signals from Bank of Japan on whether it will move to weaken the yen; in New York, dollar settles at 107.35 yen, up from 106.60; graph; chart (S)

headline: Media Talk; Entertainment Web Site Will Offer News Hybrid
abstract: Financial news and information sells on the Web, but can entertainment news sell, too?     Today, a handful of magazine-industry expatriates will announce the plans for their new Web venture, Powerful Media, a company that has attracted advance attention because its founders are from the core of Manhattan's ever-churning, self-scrutinizing media world.

headline: Blasts in Chechen Capital Unleash New Wave of Refugees
abstract: Fresh flood of Chechen refugees sweeps westward down main highway into Ingushetia, neighboring republic, propelled by fear of a widening war with Russia afer explosions kill scores in Grozny, Chechnya's capital; day after blasts flatten downtown market and destroy car carrying five passengers, Ingush officials say 3,000 more Chechens had arrived, which raises count to about 185,000; photo; map (M)

headline: AutoNation To Close Stores And Cut Jobs
abstract: AutoNation Inc says it is closing most of its used car superstores immediately and laying off their 1,800 employees, while taking one-time charge against fourth-quarter earnings of $430 million to $460 million; will suspend further purchases of new car dealerships and concentrate instead on reducing costs at existing dealerships; has begun eliminating 225 of 600 jobs at its corporate headquarters in Fort Lauderdale, Fla, and plans to cut pay and advertising at poorly performing dealerships (M)

headline: Growth in Japan Is Expected To Lift World Rate in 2000
abstract: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development says world economy is growing at unexpectedly fast pace because of surprisingly strong expansion in Japan and South Korea, more modest upturn in Europe and economic resilience in US; expects global growth rate to reach 3.5 percent next year; suggests Japan's economic recovery in particular has been more vigorous than anticipated; says in long term Japan faces risks from continued appreciation of the yen; says Europe is showing signs of expansion and in 2000 and 2001 is expected to grow 2.8 percent in 11-nation euro currency zone; forecasts 3.1 percent growth for US in 2000; graph (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Adero Inc., Boston, an Internet content and application distribution services company, to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

headline: U.S. to Aid Iraqi Opposition To Develop a Military Cadre
abstract: Clinton Administration authorizes first direct military training for opponents of Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein; four Iraqi rebel leaders will attend 10-day training course at Air Force's special-operations headquarters in Florida, where American officials will school them on how to organize military in emerging state (M)

headline: U.N. Panel Agrees On Two-Year Budget
abstract: General Assembly committee reaches agreement on two-year budget for organization that American diplomats hope will fall within 'nominal no-growth' spending demanded by United States Congress in return for releasing money to pay overdue American debts; budget is expected to be approved by full General Assembly; it calls for spending of $2.535 billion, $2 million more than previous budget; figure does not include money spent on UN agencies that raise their own funds, like Unicef (M)

headline: Plans Are Set For New Agency
abstract: Gil Bashe is named president and chief executive of GTCR Golder Rauner, Chicago, health care communications company; resigns as chief executive of CommonHealth (S)

headline: PHONE COMPANY PROFIT FALLS
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd posts its first profit decline since it went public in 1993; profit, before a gain, for six months ended in September fell 3.1 percent, to 966.2 million Singapore dollars ($578.6 million) from 997.6 million dollars a year earlier (S)

headline: Of 'Me' and 'We' Moments
abstract: The Boss column on Michael R Bonsignore, chairman of Honeywell Inc, which is merging with Allied Signal Inc; Bonsignore will be chief executive of new Honeywell; he comments; photo (M)

headline: 54,000 Swiss Accounts Tied To the Nazis' War Victims
abstract: International commission report says three-year audit of Swiss banks found records of 54,000 accounts that were probably linked to victims of Nazi persecution; says some banks issued 'deliberately misleading statements' for decades to Jews who had come looking for their family's assets; says there is 'no evidence of systematic destruction of records of victim accounts'; photo of commission head, Paul A Volcker (M)

headline: TENNECO AUTO AND PACKAGING UNITS BECOME INDEPENDENT
abstract: Tenneco Inc separates its final two businesses as Tenneco Automotive and Pactiv Corp become independent companies (S)

headline: In Praise of Floppies
abstract: R Bhwanai Prasad letter on Nov 25 article cites use of floppy

headline: Plaintiffs' Rift Disturbs Microsoft Judge
abstract: The trial judge for the Microsoft antitrust case said he appointed an  outside mediator partly because of ''disturbing reports'' that the Justice Department and the 19 states suing the software maker were split on the issue of what sanctions to seek against the company.    Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson made the comments in a meeting last Thursday involving lawyers for the Microsoft Corporation, the Justice Department and the 19 states in the judge's chambers in Washington. It was at that meeting that Judge Jackson surprised both sides by telling them he planned to appoint Richard A. Posner, a highly respected Federal appeals court judge and an antitrust scholar, and asked both sides for their ''voluntary'' agreement. Judge Posner will serve as a mediator in efforts to reach an out-of-court settlement.

headline: INVESTORS TO ACQUIRE MICRO WAREHOUSE FOR $725 MILLION
abstract: Micro Warehouse Inc agrees to be bought by investors group for about $725 million; group includes Freeman Spogli & Co, Gary L Wilson, Jerome B York, Alfred Checchi and Michael Ovitz (S)

headline: PACTIV, THE TENNECO SPINOFF, SELLS 4 BUSINESSES
abstract: Pactiv Corp, maker of Hefty garbage bags, will sell four businesses, for gain of $100 million in cash and tax benefits, in reorganization following spinoff from Tenneco Inc (S)

headline: North Korea, Apparently Seeking to End Its Isolation, Agrees to Resume Talks With Japan
abstract: North Korea has made unexpected diplomatic overtures in recent months, apparently seeking to end its self-imposed isolation in order to gain more economic aid, which it desperately needs to rebuild shattered economy and feed its starving people; leaders from North Korea and Japan announce breakthrough agreement to resume talks on establishing diplomatic relations; talks had stopped in 1992; their resumption may lead to reinstatement of Japan's food aid to North Korea; Kim Yeon Chul of Samsung Economic Research Institute does not expect North Korea to change its fundamental hard-line principles (M)

headline: Lois Chapter 11 Signals a Shift In Ad Industry
abstract: Decision by Lois/USA advertising agency to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection is indicative of intensifying competitive pressure in advertising industry; in the past, agencies that lost large clients could retrench, regroup and recover; but that has become increasingly difficult in recent years, as shown by swift closings of some other agencies; agency's owner George Lois comments (M)

headline: Nike to Sell Custom-Design Shoes on Web
abstract: Nike Inc., the world's largest athletic shoemaker, said this week that it would sell custom-designed men's and women's shoes to American customers over the Internet.    Consumers can place orders for customized Air Turbulence running shoes and Air Famished cross-training shoes at the Web site Nike.com under the program that started today, Nike said.

headline: Russian Officials Tell Grozny Civilians It's Too Late to Leave
abstract: Russian officials say residents of Grozny have missed their chance to leave and should hide in their shelters until Russian forces secure Chechen captial; warning is fresh indication that climactic battle for Grozny is finally at hand; it also reflects Russian determination to quickly subdue Grozny even if it means fighting in city still occupied by tens of thousands of civilians (M)

headline: GERMAN TAX-CUT PLAN
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder proposes to cut corporate and individual taxes to stimulate economic growth and job creation; photo (S)

headline: Pro Bono Accounts
abstract: American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons pro bono advertising account to August, Lang & Husak; Amistad America's pro bono account to Donahue Advertising; Boys and Girls Clubs of America pro bono account to Publicis, New York (S)

headline: Needle Use Sets Off H.I.V. Explosion in Russia
abstract: Needle sharing among intravenous drug users has set off an explosive increase in H.I.V. infections, with the number of new cases reported in Moscow so far this year more than four times greater than in all of 1998, the World Health Organization said today.    The United Nations agency's principal AIDS expert in Russia, Arkadiusz Majszyk, said the rapid increase was quite likely to continue for at least two or three years, spreading to sexual partners before leveling off.

headline: ASIAN BANK PACT
abstract: The central banks of Malaysia and China agreed to let each other's banks set up branches in their countries, in a move that will partly liberalize their financial services industries. The pact was signed after China's premier, Zhu Rongji, met the Malaysian prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, in Kuala Lumpur. It will pave the way for the Bank of China to open a branch in Malaysia. Malaysia's banks will be allowed to convert their representative offices in China into full-fledged branches. The pact comes after years of talks between the two nations to set up financial institutions in each other's territories.

headline: STOCK OFFERING TRIMMED
abstract: CNOOC Ltd, China's largest offshore oil producer, cuts size of its planned $2.5 billion share sale by more than half because of weak demand from investors; initial public offering is now likely to raise about $1 billion after company reduces stake for sale to 13.88 percent from 25 percent (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    THE NETHERLANDS: APPEAL IN LOCKERBIE TRIAL -- Lawyers for two Libyans accused of planting the bomb that downed Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland asked the court to drop conspiracy charges. The hearing was the first appearance of the suspects, Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah, since they were handed over in April. They are to be tried under Scottish law in the Netherlands, a neutral venue, on charges of murder, conspiracy to murder and other violations in the 270 deaths. Their lawyers argued that the alleged bomb preparations did not occur in Scotland.   (AP)

headline: Chase Posts Better-Than-Expected Earnings in 3d Quarter
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp says third-quarter earnings were 67 percent higher than last year; net income was $1.19 billion, compared with $738 million a year ago (M)

headline: A Rising Israeli Political Star Threatens Barak's Majority
abstract: Eli Yishai, who heads Israel's Shas political party, is youngest member of Prime Min Ehud Barak's cabinet and also one of most powerful; Yishai is linking his party's support for Barak's peace efforts to government financial support for Shas's debt-ridden religious schools; Shas has already joined opposition to defeat string of government initiatives; Yishai's joisting with Barak about how to deal with poverty has highlighted delicacy of their interdependent relationship; photo (M)

headline: Mozambique Says President Is Re-elected; Rivals Protest
abstract: Pres Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique is declared victor after three days of voting, touching off cries of protest from opposition leaders who say balloting was rigged; leaders of opposition, known as Renamo, say they will petition Constitutional Court for recount and that their newly elected legislators would boycott Parliament until their concerns are addressed; fraud allegations mar election that many had hoped would solidify fledgling democracy (M)

headline: Items Found on the Internet Dress Up a Museum's Exhibition
abstract: Maurice Berger, guest museum curator, comments on his use of Ebay and other Internet auction sites to gather objects needed for Whitney Museum show American Century: Art and Culture, 1900-2000; says on-line auctions proved more efficient and saved on his traveling costs; photo (M)

headline: Dell's Webcentric PC's In Anything but Beige
abstract: Dell Computer Corp's new Webpc is a low-cost, colorful desktop PC designed for easy Internet access; photo (M)

headline: Rebuffing West, Russia Pounds Chechnya
abstract: Russia continues its attacks in Chechnya, rebuffing Western appeals that it seek political solution; more than 160,000 people have fled fighting, but Russian soldiers are blocking long lines of vehicles and refugees waiting to get out of or back into Chechnya; West is alarmed at possibility that Russian soldiers and Chechen rebels might replay their bloody confrontation of 1994-96 in Chechen capital of Grozny; photo (M)

headline: Iranian's Career: From Hostage-Taker to Reformer
abstract: Abbas Abdi, one of student leaders who masterminded seizure of US Embassy in Teheran in 1979, is influential figure in May 23 Movement, group of moderate Muslim clerics, scholars, journalists and others who campaigned for election of Iran's reformist Pres Mohammad Khatami; photos (M)

headline: RealNetworks Suit Defends Its Copyright on Audio Files
abstract: RealNetworks Inc, whose products deliver audio and video content over the Web, is suing company that makes software that converts RealNetworks' products into format marketed by rival, Microsoft Corp; RealNetworks' suit accuses Streambox Inc of violating several laws intended to protect intellectual property, including Digital Millennium Copyright Act; federal judge in Seattle, where RealNetworks is based, has issued temporary restraining order preventing Streambox from developing, producing or selling software; hearing is scheduled for Jan 7 (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising assignments are announced by KeyCorp, OpenTable.com, Modern Maturity magazine, AARP Bulletin and American Management Assn (S)

headline: Early Count Hints at Fewer Kosovo Deaths
abstract: Report by Carla del Ponte, chief UN war crimes investigator, says 2,108 bodies were found in grave sites throughout Kosovo, Serbia, during five months of investigation of atrocities and exhumation of dead; says bodies were found at 195 sites before work stopped for winter, and that there are total of 529 sites reported to investigators thus far; even though other sites remain to be examined, number of dead found so far seems significantly lower than estimate of 10,000 ethnic Albanians killed by Serbs issued by Western officials, or suggestion by American and allied officials during war that up to 100,000 were being killed; photos; map (M)

headline: Angry Democrats and G.O.P. Trade Blame on Test Ban Pact
abstract: The Clinton Administration and Democratic leaders today intensified their attacks on Republicans for defeating the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, but Republicans answered that the oratory showed once again that Democrats were more interested in a political issue than a treaty.    President Clinton's spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, had ''fixed the process'' to keep public pressure from influencing Senators while the Republican party committed itself to ''Fortress America isolationism.''

headline: Koreans See Dark Scenario in a U.S. Precaution
abstract: US decision to distribute 14,000 protective gas masks to dependents of American soldiers and embassy staff members living in Seoul raises concerns among South Koreans that despite its new diplomatic tone, North Korea is planning a major assault that will include chemical warfare; US insists that decision is not tied to any increased threat or impending attack by North Korea, but is rather part of Pentagon's effort to improve protection of noncombatants stationed overseas (M)

headline: U.S. Expelling Russian Diplomat in Bugging of State Dept.
abstract: US State Department says that it has ordered expulsion of Russian diplomat, Stanislav Borisovich Grusev, who was apprehended outside dept's headquarters with electronic equipment for monitoring a listening device hidden in conference room used by senior diplomats; order to expel Grusev, employee of Russian embassy in Washington, comes after long investigation that also uncovers tiny sophisticated transmitter on top floor of State Dept (M)

headline: Public Relations Firm Acquired in Chicago
abstract: Publicis Dialog acquires Selz/Seabolt, public relations firm; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: List of day's closing prices on major exchanges

headline: A Retiree's Work: How to Break the Nest Egg
abstract: MANY Americans have taken to heart the advice to save for retirement, socking away some $2.61 trillion in defined-contribution plans like 401(k)'s, according to the Spectrem Group, a business research and consulting company in San Francisco.    Now, as the first members of the generation responsible for their own retirement savings begin to leave work, comes the second part of the equation: withdrawing money from these plans.

headline: Schroeder's Bailout of Holzmann Earns Little Praise From Skeptical Markets : Reform vs. Reality In Berlin and Tokyo
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's role in the bailout of a major German construction company gives him a populist victory of uncertain duration. But, more significantly, his gesture sustains a crisis of disbelief in the German economy that affects confidence everywhere else in Europe.

headline: Anger on Agenda for World Trade Meeting
abstract: Dispute over agenda that appears to pit developing nations against US has injected tense atmosphere into preparations for World Trade Organization's annual summit meeting next month; nonindustrialized countries in group that makes rules for global commerce had drafted detailed list of priorities for Seattle meeting agenda, determined to rectify what they see as bias in current trade rules that have benefited larger economic powers at their expense; but their two-page list was mysteriously deleted from first format draft of agenda that circulated at organization's Geneva headquarters earlier this week; some developing nations say US deleted list (M)

headline: NORTH KOREAN TV VIEWED IN SOUTH
abstract: South Korean Government is allowing domestic news corporations to show North Korean satellite TV broadcasts; private citizens can also view North Korean satellite broadcasts at special sites; in the past, South Korean Government selected and filtered North Korean programs for domestic television stations and newspaper companies, citing national security concerns (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: Pacific Exchange Approves Issuing Shares
abstract: Pacific Exchange members approve plan to convert their stock-trading floors in Los Angeles and San Francisco into for-profit subsidiary in effort to keep money-losing operation alive; restructuring would let exchange sell shares in itself to public, cut costs and make floors more attractive relative to other regional exchanges (S)

headline: An abortion rights coalition hopes its campaign will get young women to discuss their choices.
abstract: Pro-Choice Public Education Project, consortium of abortion rights groups nationwide, will resume television advertising for first time in several years to expand its efforts to reach young people; television spot was created by DeVito/Verdi (M)

headline: WINDFALL SCANDAL IN SPAIN
abstract: Spain's Prime Min Maria Aznar fends off sharp criticism in Parliament over $190 million in stock option earnings for 100 top executives of Telefonica, whose chairman, Juan Villalonga, was appointed by Aznar's government before telecommunications giant was privatized in 1997; Joaquin Almunia, leader of opposition Socialist Party, has seized on issue as elections must be held by April (S)

headline: Treasuries Rise as Sellers Pause for Rest
abstract: US Treasury bond prices are up for first time in four days; 30-year bond is up 1 4/32, to 101 5/32; yield drops to 6.04 percent from 6.12 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DELL COMPUTER CORP., Round Rock, Tex., announced plans to build a second manufacturing operation in the Nashville area, adding about 650 jobs.    BROCADE COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS., San Jose, Calif., a maker of hardware for computer networks, said it will split its stock two shares for one on Dec. 2 for shareholders of record on Nov. 18.

headline: Alfred Hassig, 78; Target of Tainted-Blood Trial
abstract: Dr Alfred Hassig, who was convicted last

headline: Clear Finding in Blunt Language
abstract: News analysis of findings of fact by Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, denouncing Microsoft Corp as monopoly that uses power to stifle innovation, reduce competition and hurt consumers; even though decision is preliminary step and not final ruling, it forms all-but-unshakeable foundation and framework for outcome of case--either legal judgment or settlement; while court's legal judgment can be routinely overturned by higher court on appeal, findings of fact can be overruled only in rare instance when higher court finds 'blatant contradiction' between written record of case and judge's finding (M)

headline: Staying Upbeat About Stocks
abstract: Investors Intelligence newsletter survey finds that financial advisers remain optimistic over US stocks (S)

headline: Lowe Lintas Declines Four Seasons Review
abstract: Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide declines to participate in review for creative portion of account of Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts (S)

headline: G.M. to Take Quarterly Charge
abstract: General Motors will take $444 million fourth-quarter charge to reflect increased retiree pension costs of contract it reached with United Automobile Workers in September; GM agreed to raise wages of about 150,000 hourly workers by 3 percent in each of next four years and pay each a $1,350 signing bonus (S)

headline: PLACER DOME TO BUY 50% OF CHILEAN COPPER MINE
abstract: Placer Dome Inc agrees to buy 50 percent of Chilean copper mine that it does not own from Finnish venture partner Outokumpu Oy for $251 million, its first acquisition under its new president Jay Taylor; agreement comes nine months after Canadian miner Aur Resources Inc withdrew its $265 million bid for stake, partly because of low copper prices; copper has since risen about 19 percent (S)

headline: Loggers Find Canada Rain Forest Flush With Foes
abstract: Canadian logging companies, after cutting 70 percent of old-growth forest from Vancouver Island--forest that has never been logged--are now moving into what environmentalists call 'Brazil of the north'--vast, barely disturbed sea of trees, one-quarter of world's remaining temperate rain forest; over next 25 years, 50 of coastal forest's largest valleys are to be logged; now, a collision of powerful forces is taking place on remote coast, near Bella Bella, archipelago where 4,500 people live, largely in Indian villages; on one side is logging industry of Canada, world's largest exporter of timber, pulp and newsprint; logging campanies now face trio of new players determined to defend what many call the Great Bear Rain Forest: tour operators, Indian tribes and cross-border alliance of environmentalists; photo; chart; map (L)

headline: Vibe/Spin Ventures Faces Possible Sale
abstract: Miller Publishing Group hires Salomon Smith Barney to explore possible sale of Vibe/Spin Ventures LLC; Vibe/Spin is partnership of Robert L Miller, Freeman Spogli & Co, Quincy Jones and David Salzman (S)

headline: Minimum Wages, City by City; As More Local Laws Pass, More Businesses Complain
abstract: Small but increasing number of employers who do business with government are suddenly finding themselves required by local ordinances to grant big raises and benefits to their low-wage workers; forty cities and counties in 17 states, particularly those with large constituencies of low-wage workers, have enacted wage laws since movement began five years ago; movement has begun to broaden from simple emphasis on higher wages into wide range of requirements involving health insurance, vacations, sick pay, job security and incentives to unionize; as ordinances spread, business opposition and complaints about higher costs and patchwork regulation are on rise; vast majority of companies in Los Angeles area have generally lived with law rather than give up profitable contracts, subsidies and leases on choice city-owned properties; 'living wage' movement is increasingly popular tool for improving workers who earn less than $8 an hour; that group represents 25.7 percent of work force, or 28.5 million people; University of Massachusetts economist Robert Pollin says cost increases for companies in Los Angeles are only 1 to 1.5 percent of their total expenses; Madeline Janis-Aparicio, director of Los Angeles Living Wage Coalition, comments; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PLM INTERNATIONAL INC., San Francisco, an equipment-leasing company, will sell a subsidiary, American Finance Group Inc., to Temple-Inland Inc., Diboll, Tex., for $29 million in cash.    TEXTRON INC., Providence, R.I., agreed to buy Benzlers, of Helsingborg, Sweden, a unit of Atle Karolin Group, for an undisclosed price to expand its power-transmission product line.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: KOHL INQUIRY BEGINS -- Parliament began an investigation into allegations that former Chancellor Helmut Kohl's party accepted bribes. Mr. Kohl has admitted he used secret accounts to pay for campaign activities of his Christian Democratic Party, a violation of finance laws. The inquiry will also examine allegations that Mr. Kohl's party received a $1.6 million donation in exchange for the sale of a group of state-owned apartments, which went for well below a rival bid.   Victor Homola (NYT)

headline: Russia Raids Bank in Laundering Inquiry
abstract: Russian police raid politically well-connected Sobin Bank as probe into possible money laundering through Bank of New York seems to be gathering momentum; arrest crew from state-owned television network for entering site and filming against police instructions (M)

headline: Akio Morita, Co-Founder of Sony and Japanese Business Leader, Dies at 78
abstract: Akio Morita, co-founder of Sony Corp, dies at age 78; photo (M)

headline: When Dials Were Round and Clicks Were Plentiful
abstract: Interest in vintage rotary telephones is largely restricted to collectors, some of whom use Web sites to sell their offerings; Dr Jonathan Finder comments on his collection and his sale of vintage phones through his site, www.oldphones.com; photo of Finder with some of his telephones; chart on Web sites devoted to vintage telephones (M)

headline: Privacy Was a Double Loss
abstract: Barbaranne M Warner letter on November 11 article on protecting personal information; recalls receiving numerous coupons and catalogs just days after her daughter was stillborn

headline: Long Wary, Buffett Dips A Toe Into Technology
abstract: In the past, Warren E. Buffett, chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., said he avoided technology stocks because he didn't understand them. No more. Mr. Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, has invested in a computer services company, buying a 5.3 percent position in Bell Industries.    Mr. Buffett said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he held 506,700 Bell shares as of Dec. 1. At Friday's closing price of $6.25, the stake is worth $3.2 million.

headline: Acquisition by Cooper
abstract: Cooper Industries agrees to acquire Crompton Lighting for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Local Signals May Be Costly For Satellite TV Providers
abstract: Nation's big satellite television companies, DirecTV and EchoStar Communications, may have to spend as much as $1 billion to deliver local stations, including local affiliates of four big broadcast networks, to dozens of markets nationwide; Satellite Television Home Viewers Act that Pres Clinton signed into law on Nov 29 lifts restriction against local broadcasting by satellite television companies; Federal Communications Commission has not yet written rules for implementing new law; both DirecTV and EchoStar say they should not be compelled to rebroadcast dozen or more less-watched stations in some big metropolitan areas; photos; chart (M)

headline: Nisource Increases Its Bid for Columbia Energy to $6.2 Billion
abstract: Nisource Inc raises its bid for Columbia Energy Group to $6.2 billion from $5.7 billion; Columbia chairman Oliver G Richard 3d has refused to discuss deal; Nisource president Gary L Neale comments (M)

headline: New Programs in the Works For Handspring's New Visor
abstract: New competitor to Palm Pilot is Handspring's Visor; it will depend on independently developed programs and devices that will fit in Visor's expansion slot; photo (S)

headline: Hit TV Quiz Show Spawns a Popular Book
abstract: Hyperion is publishing official game handbook of answers to questions on hit ABC program, Who Wants to Be a Millionaire; Hyperion and ABC are both units of Walt Disney Co; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies column; dollar edges lower against euro; graph (S)

headline: Increasingly, Traditional Retailers Take That Internet Plunge
abstract: National retailers like Circuit City, Home Depot and Wal-Mart are joining Internet fray, introducing Web sites that benefit from companies' name recognition (S)

headline: UNOCAL TO SPIN OFF SOME OIL AND GAS EXPLORATION UNITS
abstract: Unocal Corp will split off its oil and natural gas exploration operations in Texas and New Mexico into company that will buy Titan Exploration Inc; Unocal will own 65 percent of new company, Pure Energy Resources Inc (S)

headline: Panel Backs British in Beef Dispute With France
abstract: Britain wins major victory over France when panel of European Commission scientists rule that British beef is safe to eat despite French arguments for continued ban to guard against so-called mad cow disease (M)

headline: Games to Suit Every Platform and Every Taste
abstract: Game Theory column on strengths and drawbacks of video-game consoles on market from Sony, Sega and Nintendo; photos (M)

headline: Crackdown on Sect Yields 111 Arrests, Beijing Announces
abstract: Chinese Govt offers first official tally of crackdown on banned Falun Gong spiritual movement; says 111 people have been formally arrested on variety of criminal charges; figure does not include larger number of Falun Gong members who face other forms of detention; Li Bing, spokesman for China's Cabinet, says vast majority of those detained in Beijing in past two weeks were not arrested; officials deny reports that some members were beaten to death while under arrest or detention (M)

headline: Buying Groceries Online? Forget About Lamb Shanks
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (Online Shopper) evaluates Internet grocery shopping; finds her great expectations of avoiding checkout line diminished by poor distribution system in New York area; also notes online grocers may not offer generic and store brands and do not ship fresh or frozen food through mail; photo of some Web sites (M)

headline: Chief Executive of Hertz Is Set to Retire
abstract: Hertz Corp says Frank A Olson will retire as chief executive at end of year, and it names president, Craig R Koch, as his successor; Olson will remain nonexecutive chairman; company reports third-quarter earnings climbed 17 percent; net income rose to $139 million from $118.7 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 9.8 percent, to $1.34 billion from $1.23 billion (S)

headline: BAYER BUYS LYONDELL UNIT
abstract: Bayer AG agrees to buy Lyondell Chemical Co for $2.45 billion; Bayer says operating profit fell 18 percent, to 624 million euros ($644.5 million) in third quarter (S)

headline: Gallaher of Britain Considers Bid for French Tobacco Rival
abstract: Gallaher of Britain Consider

headline: Scent of a Man: Fragrance Sales Boom; Spritzers Abound, Much to the Delight of Designers and Department Stores
abstract: Perfumes are being used routinely as grooming products by growing group of young American men; men's fragrance sales, expected to reach $1.6 billion in 1999, are still only third of total fragrance purchases, but sales of prestige perfumes have been gaining at rate of at least 5 percent annually for last three years even as sales of all women's perfume have stalled; industry followers say women have moved from drenching themselves in perfumes because they no longer consider them appropriate for daily routines, while men are paying more attention to appearance than ever; photos; chart (M)

headline: 30-Year Treasury Yield Declines to 6.13%
abstract: Treasury securities prices rise slightly after rebounding from early weakness; price of benchmark 30-year bond rises 2/32, to 99 28/32; yield falls to 6.13 percent, from 6.14 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: 8 Held in Russia Bombings
abstract: Russian security official announces that 8 people accused of being involved in bombings that rocked Moscow and other cities last September are in custody; says three suspected masterminds of attacks are hiding in Chechnya; more than 300 people were killed in bombings (S)

headline: U.N. Plane With 24 Aboard Crashes in Kosovo
abstract: UN aircraft with 24 people aboard crashes in northern Kosovo, Serbia; wreckage spotted near village of Slakovce; no survivors reported; twin-engine ATR-42 aircraft was on daily charter flight for World Food Program; normally carries UN officials, aid workers and sometimes journalists from Rome to newly reopened Slatina airport in Pristina; map (M)

headline: Investors Continue to Be Hesitant As Stocks Finish the Day Mixed
abstract: Stock prices are mixed, but investors remain hesitant and analysts say there are no indications that recent steep slide in market has ended; Dow Jones industrial average is up 96.57 points, or 1 percent, to 10,116.28; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 6.72 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,254.13; Nasdaq composite index is down 42.68 points, or 1.6 percent, to 2.689.15; graph; chart (M)

headline: Type-Casting Our Children
abstract: Letter from H Buff Herr expresses reservations about teaching young children to type, fearing it will keep them from learning how to write (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: A study by McCann-Erickson finds that many consumers bristle at millennium hype.
abstract: McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising surveys of consumer attitudes show that many are already tired of hoopla surrounding countdown to millennium and that promoting it will irriate consumers; find some consumers--mainly outside US--automatically associate millennium with Year 2000 computer problem and serious havoc, not exactly kind of association an advertiser wants to make (M)

headline: World Trade Group Inspires Protesters
abstract: In what is shaping up as one of the biggest protest efforts in years, people from more than 500 organizations have poured into Seattle. They accuse the World Trade Organization, the 135-nation, Geneva-based group that is holding its ministerial meeting in the city this week, of favoring free trade at the expense of the environment, consumer safety and workers' rights.

headline: Vodafone Will Sweeten Bid for Mannesmann
abstract: Vodafone Airtouch PLC's directors sweeten their all-stock bid for Mannesmann AG raising it as high as $125.3 billion; new offer is nearly 18 percent higher than bid Mannesmann rebuffed on Nov 14; Mannesmann's lawsuit seeking to disqualify Vodafone's investment banker, Goldman Sachs, is thrown out by London judge, who harshly chastises Mannesmann for bringing it (M)

headline: Russia Investigating Its Own Banks for Role in Suspicious Cash Movements
abstract: Aleksandr Pochinok, chief of Russian State Tax Service, says that his investigation is pointing to single Russian bank as the architect of transfer of billions of dollars into accounts under investigation in United States; declines to identify bank, but says that small group of Russian businessmen appears to have pioneered practice of sending money through Bank of New York accounts that are under investigation by FBI; photo (M)

headline: European Central Bank Leaves Interest Rate Unchanged
abstract: European Central Bank leaves its core interest rate unchanged at 2.5 percent; bank's president Wim Duisenberg says 11-nation euro zone needs to be cooled down and that tighter monetary policy is almost inevitable (M)

headline: Van Gogh Print Or Original Oil: The Web Has It
abstract: Christine Bourron is among number of entrepreneurs and artists who are selling art over the Internet; Bourron's company, PaintingsDirect.com, operates Web site (www.paintingsdirect.com) that allows browsers to search art not just by artist or style, but also by price, size, color and by more than 200 keywords; some other sites noted; sudden proliferation of sites has alarmed some people in art world who question not just what protections buyers have but whether what is being offered by some sites can even be called art; however, noted firms such as Sotheby's, in partnership with Amazon.com, is planning to hold auctions on its site by beginning of next year; photos, including Bourron (L)

headline: Coca-Cola Bottler Discusses Its Price Increase
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises, Coca-Cola Co's largest bottler, tells investors and money managers in rare conference call that its decision to raise retail prices earlier this year should improve company's cash flow and profitability despite drop in volume (M)

headline: All Groups in Indonesian Province See Referendum as Secession : In Aceh, It's Independence or Nothing
abstract: BANDA ACEH, Indonesia—  The rallying cry of "Referendum!" is painted in block letters throughout this restive province of rice paddies, coffee plantations and overt poverty. But for the leaders of the movement calling for a vote on Aceh's future, "referendum" means secession from Indonesia.

headline: Graduates Cut a Path in a Risky Trade
abstract: LONDON—  Although she insists she is a control freak, Meg Andrew is the sort of person that things happen to. Since she started her design business, mca, a few months ago, the things that have happened to her have been almost all good.

headline: AMERICA ONLINE IN BRAZIL
abstract: America Online begins its first Portuguese-language service in Brazil; America Online will lend its brand name and technology top venture, while its partner in Latin America, Cisneros Group of Venezuela, will inject $100 million of investment; America Online plans Spanish-language services in Argentina and Mexico (S)

headline: SOUTH KOREA SEEN TRYING TO EXTEND RANGE OF MISSILES
abstract: US intelligence analysts discover evidence that South Korea is trying to develop longer-range ballistic missiles, while keeping some of program's aims secret from US; satellite evidence and missile test this year cited; Pres Clinton and Sec William Cohen have raised concerns with South Korean leaders, injecting uncertainty into relations at time when two countries are warily watching North Korea's arms program; satellite photos showed last year that South Korea built rocket motor test station without notifying US (M)

headline: Pro- and Anti-Barak Settlers Play a Game of King of the Hill
abstract: Jewish settlers near Shvut Rahel on West Bank defy their leadership and Israeli Govt, staging peaceful demonstration and blocking initial efforts to dismantle hilltop settlement under terms of peace accord with Palestinians; map (M)

headline: EL PASO ENERGY IS ADDING CRYSTAL GAS STORAGE
abstract: El Paso Energy, one of the largest United States operators of natural gas pipelines, said yesterday that it would buy Crystal Gas Storage Inc. for about $208 million in cash and assumed debt. El Paso will pay $57 for each share of Crystal common stock and $1 for each share of Crystal preferred stock and assume about $40 million in debt, a Crystal Gas spokesman said. Crystal, based in Shreveport, La., owns two gas storage operations near Hattiesburg, Miss., and stakes in other gas properties in Arkansas and Louisiana. Shares of Houston-based El Paso Energy fell $1.0625, to $40.375. Crystal was up $1 a share at $46 before its trading was halted.

headline: New Chairman of KPMG Takes Over
abstract: Stephen Butler takes over as chairman of KPMG International; replaces Colin Sharman, who will be outside adviser (S)

headline: Facing Jail, Vichy Aide Says He'll Go Into Exile
abstract: Maurice Papon says he will flee France rather than start serving 10-year jail term for complicity in Nazi war crimes, statement to newspapers; says he will ask European Court of Human Rights to condemn France for denying him fair proceeding; has disappeared from Paris home; French officials seek his capture; Prime Min Lionel Jospin scores flight; photo (M)

headline: Cola Makers Leave Their Bottlers Flat
abstract: Shareholders of big soft-drink bottling companies have suffered sharp losses this year, in part because of rising concentrate prices; Coca-Cola and PepsiCo have increased concentrate prices by 7 percent; graphs; photo (M)

headline: CITADEL BROADCASTING TO ACQUIRE 36 RADIO STATIONS
abstract: Citadel Broadcasting Co acquires 36 radio stations from Broadcasting Partners Holdings LP for $190 million (S)

headline: Rebel Chief, Denying Terror, Fights to 'Free' Chechnya
abstract: Spitting sunflower shells or plucking them from his broad, black beard, Shamil Basayev evinced little concern for the reports from Moscow branding him an Islamic terrorist and the mastermind behind the bombings of apartment buildings that killed nearly 300 people last month.    ''I do not care what they say,'' Russia's most wanted man said on a recent afternoon, sitting on the doorstep of his house in the Chechen capital. ''Part of me wants people to know the truth and why we fight. But people are all confused about terrorists and explosions now.''

headline: China Tells Southeast Asia It Will 'Never Seek Hegemony' Over Islands : Beijing Tries to Cool Spratlys Dispute
abstract: MANILA—  China has indicated that it wants to avoid further conflict with Southeast Asian countries over the Spratly Islands dispute in the South China Sea even though it opposes their plan for a code of conduct in the area, Southeast Asian officials said Sunday.

headline: Microsoft Objects to an Analyst In U.S. Antitrust Case Against It
abstract: Microsoft Corp officially objects to selection of Harvard law professor, Lawrence Lessig, to write analysis of antitrust law in government's suit against company, contending Lessig is biased; Judge Thoms Penfield Jackson, who is presiding over case, rebuts allegation; says court is confident of its ability to assess Lessig's submission critically (S)

headline: BRITISH PRICES UP SLIGHTLY
abstract: Britain's inflation rate remained in check during September, with prices rising just four-tenths of 1 percent from August, to 2.1 percent, still below Bank of England's target of 2.5 percent (S)

headline: Minna Journal; Butting Their Heads Against Religion and Men
abstract: Nigerian girls wanting to play soccer face obstacles despite strong showing by Nigerian team in this year's women's World Cup competition; soccer is associated with the barefoot poor; Muslims in northern part of country fear that soccer, with its revealing shorts, will encourage immorality or that playing might injure girls or make them infertile; photo; map (M)

headline: Toys 'R' Us Falls Behind On Shipping
abstract: Toys 'R' Us says its Internet site will be unable to fulfill all orders promised by Christmas; sends affected customers $100 gift certificate by overnight courier (M)

headline: No Takers Yet for 'Dream Job'
abstract: Steven Roth's two-year search for director of development for his Vornado Realty Trust includes entreaty to John E Zuccotti, former deputy mayor, who rebuffed him (S)

headline: After Test Ban Vote: Politics and Foreign Policy Tangle
abstract: Analysis: proposal by national security adviser Samuel R Berger to provoke national debate on foreign policy is suspect to many Republicans because of its timing, coming after Senate rejected test ban treaty; most startled reaction comes from Republicans who see themselves as supporters of American involvement abroad but who do not believe that opposition to test ban treaty should be used as litmus test of isolationism (M)

headline: American Home to Settle Some 1,400 Fen-Phen Suits
abstract: American Home Products Corp will pay $350 million to settle 1,400 injury cases brought in Mississippi over its diet drug fen-phen--liability that could endanger company's proposed $70 billion merger with Warner-Lambert; moved to settle cases after jury awarded $150 million in compensatory damages to five plaintiffs (M)

headline: Index of Consumer Confidence Falls for 4th Consecutive Month
abstract: Conference Board says consumer confidence in economy has fallen in October for fourth consecutive month amid concerns about falling stock prices; index dropped to 130.1 from 134.2 in September; that is 3.5 percent below 30-year high of 139 in June and index's lowest level since January (M)

headline: Popular New King Has a Goal: A Modern Morocco
abstract: Morroco's popular new king, Mohammed VI, who succeeded to throne in July when his father, Hassan II, died after reigning for 38 years, has emerged as powerful advocate of social change; map; photo (M)

headline: UPN Encourages 'Moesha' to Find A New Direction This TV Season
abstract: Three new executive producers of UPN program Moesha agree to move program into 'new creative directions'; show's original executive producer, Vida Spears, is said to have been so opposed to requested changes that she was fired two weeks ago; Jacques Edmonds, one of new producers, denies show is moving away from its earlier image as wholesome show about middle-class black family life; photo (M)

headline: Havana Journal; Game Produces 28 Hits, And Political Home Run
abstract: Baseball game between teams from Cuba and Venezuela draws 25,000 spectators to stadium in Havana; teams are composed of former players from both countries' national teams; Pres Fidel Castro is manager of Cuban team, and Pres Hugo Chavez of Venezuela is pitcher for his team; Cuba wins game, 5-4; crowd at game appears to be enamored of solidarity between two countries; photos (M)

headline: African Is Among 4 Named Trade Group Deputy Chiefs
abstract: World Trade

headline: Microsoft Adds To McCann Work
abstract: Microsoft Corp expands its relationship with McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising by awarding new account to McCann-Erickson Europe; billings estimated at more than $50 million (S)

headline: The Index Monster In Your Closet
abstract: Article explains 'closet indexing,' in which some mutual fund managers mimic benchmark index by investing bulk of assets in particular index while charging fees that are 3 to 10 times higher than those of basic index fund; drawing; graphs (M)

headline: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
abstract: Intriguing educational titles are still being released on interactive CD-ROM's, even though Web gets most of attention (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of October 24 article on investing in Apple Computer for its Internet potential, which misidentified Adobe Systems software program GoLive, which contributed to popularity of Apple's Macintosh computers (S)

headline: Like a Miner's Canary?
abstract: Letter by James B Francis responds to Oct 21 article on fuel cells; offers example of possible benefit of fuel cell

headline: Golfer's Doomed Flight Still Mystery to Officials
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Investigators were sifting Tuesday through a small, blackened crater in a South Dakota pasture where the private jet carrying the golfer Payne Stewart and five other people had crashed, ending an eerie flight that millions of people, including Mr. Stewart's wife, had followed live on television.

headline: MARKETING RESEARCH COMPANY TO CUT STAFF 10 PERCENT
abstract: Information Resources Inc plans to eliminate 325 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force by end of next year, as part of series of moves to improve profits; expects to save $15 million a year (S)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Plans Campaign
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co is spending $200 million over next year on advertising to increase awareness of what company considers its record of innovation and inventions; television and print campaign is being created by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners; Saatchi & Saatchi will adapt ads for markets outside US (S)

headline: Just Imagine . . .
abstract: Query asks readers to offer suggestions for major 21st century innovation that would improve their own lot or that of all mankind (S)

headline: 'God's Parking Lot' Is in Conflict With Rome's Ancient Past
abstract: Italian Prime Min Massimo D'Alema will hold special meeting of his ministers on Dec 3 to decide whether construction of Vatican garage access ramp can resume; construction was stopped after archeologists uncovered ancient walls and frescoes at site (M)

headline: Pearl Harbor Truly a Sneak Attack, Papers Show
abstract: Newly discovered Japanese diplomatic papers published in Japan seem to refute widely held belief that Japan attacked Pearl Harbor in Dec 1941 without official warning of break in ties only because of fateful accidents and bumbling that delayed delivery of document to Washington hinting at war; indicate Japan intentionally sought to conceal its hostile intentions from US after vigorous internal debate over how and whether to notify US of plan to start war; photo (M)

headline: Theodore Hall, Prodigy and Atomic Spy, Dies at 74
abstract: Theodore Alvin Hall, who was youngest physicist to work on atomic bomb project at Los Alamos during World War II and was later identified as Soviet spy, died on Nov 1 at age 74; photo (M)

headline: Caterpillar Shares Battered After Warning About Profit
abstract: Shares of Caterpillar Inc plunge 12 percent after company warns that fourth-quarter earnings will not meet expectations; shares fall $6.75, to $49.1875 (M)

headline: Spiritual Group Meets in Hong Kong
abstract: Nine hundred members of Falun Gong, spiritual movement that has been outlawed in China, gather in convention hall in Hong Kong, where it is legal, for a tranquil demonstration of its breathing and meditation exercises; Chinese authorities believe group is using Hong Kong as a base to expand its activities within China; Pres Tung Chee-hwa of Hong Kong warns Falun Gong against doing anything that is against Chinese interests (M)

headline: Fuel Cell May Be the Future 'Battery'
abstract: Fuel cells are nearing development point that will enable them to replace not only batteries used in laptops or cell phones, but even the recharger; some experts say latest fuel cells may provide power source that weighs far less and lasts far longer than any battery on the market, in part because of their efficient use of hydrogen (M)

headline: EXECUTONE TO SELL PHONE BUSINESS FOR $44.3 MILLION
abstract: Executone Information Systems Inc agrees to sell its Internet telephone unit to Inter-Tel Inc for about $44.3 million in cash; Claircom Inc, unit of Staples Communications, waives its right to buy division (S)

headline: The Internet May Precipitate a Tempest For Traditional Brands and Advertising
abstract: Emergence of the Internet as significant way to sell goods and services is quickly changing relationship between marketers and customers, and with it the nature of advertising; Internet companies are increasing their spending for offline advertising, while online spending is expected to reach $11.5 billion by 2003; photos; chart of ad spending (M)

headline: Earnings Are Up 13% at American Express
abstract: American Express Co says third-quarter profit rose 13 percent, meeting expectations; company earned $648 million, up from $574 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 12 percent, to $4.88 billion, from $4.34 billion (M)

headline: Lawyers File Motion In Coke Bias Suit
abstract: Lawyers for four black employees at Coca-Cola Co file motion that includes invoices from Staples store in Atlanta, showing that someone at Coke ordered shredding machine in late April, after discrimination lawsuit was filed; lawyers for plaintiffs have accused company of destroying documents that might be relevant to their suit (S)

headline: In New Europe, a Lingual Hodgepodge
abstract: Local cultures and languages are re-asserting their strength, in one of most intriguing side effects of uniting Europe; historians say more people are interested in protecting minority languages and asserting local differences than at any other time this century; effort is so strong that European Union has created Bureau of Lesser-used Languages, which finaces projects such as developing Internet browsers in Welsh and cartoon books in Alsation; it has plans for developing news agency; some students of trend believe identity of Europe's ethnic groups is strengthening because anchors like religion and nationality have weakened (M)

headline: STRONG DEMAND FOR THUS
abstract: Telephone division of Scottish Power, Thus PLC raises up to $1.8 billion in initial public offering of 303.6 milion shares priced at 310 pence; shares rise by as much as 25 percent before settling back to 335 pence (S)

headline: TAIWAN BULLET TRAIN
abstract: Seven companies in Japan win right to negotiate to provide Taiwan's first bullet train and related systems, beating bid by Siemens of Germany and Alston of France; Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp awards Japanese group, which includes Mitsubishi Corp, Sumitomo Corp, Toshiba Corp, Marubeni Corp, Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd, Mitsui & Co and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, right to seek contract that could be worth more than 100 billion Taiwan dollars ($3.2 billion) (S)

headline: Charity Concerts to Go on Internet
abstract: United Nations Development Program and Cisco Systems, principal creators and organizers of Netaid, series of international benefit concerts to raise money for world anti-poverty programs, seek to broaden program's reach by setting up Web site (www.Netaid.org) as clearinghouse of information on state of world poverty and agency's programs, as well as a means of raising money; say they hope to draw millions of people to site by using it for Webcast of concerts being held in three countries; concerts will also be broadcast over global network of conventional radio and television stations; photo (M)

headline: Patents; Two partners devise a method for easier collection of sales taxes from the Internet.
abstract: Paul Francisco and Frederick Petschauer receive patent for mthod they devised to collect sales taxes from Internet (M)

headline: Goldman Sachs Foundation Intends to Focus on Education
abstract: Goldman Sachs, which earlier this year set aside $200 million from its public stock offering to endow foundation named after company, says organization, to be called Goldman Sachs Foundation, will focus exclusively on education; says John C Whitehead will serve as chairman of organization; names Stephanie Bell-Rose president; company says it will match foundation's giving in the first year and possibly in future years (M)

headline: Soft Money's Multifaceted Foe
abstract: CHARLES KOLB may be this city's most unlikely champion of campaign finance reform. A conservative lawyer who worked on domestic policy in the Bush White House, Mr. Kolb acknowledges that he never expected to be doing what he is doing now.    As president of the Committee for Economic Development, a group of chief executives and academic leaders committed to public policy changes, Mr. Kolb leads its fight against soft money, those unlimited contributions to political parties that have come to exemplify the capital's cash-flush influence industry.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar slips against Japanese yen as speculation that US interest rate increase is ahead hurts stocks and bonds; in New York, dollar settles at 105.31 yen, down from 105.97 on Aug 22; graph; chart (S)

headline: Column Begins Today
abstract: Starting today, Fred Andrews will write a column every other week. The first topic is Prof. Clayton M. Christensen of Harvard. Management, Page C10.

headline: Treasuries Fall After Release of Price Report
abstract: US Treasury prices fall for second consecutive day; price of benchmark 30-year bond falls 8/32, to 100 16/32; yield rises to 6.09 percent from 6.07 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Europeans Find Their Fear of Unleashing an Ogre Was Misplaced : Mistrust of Unified Germany Fades
abstract: PARIS—  Ten years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, reunited Germany has hardly turned out to be the economic subjugator and tiger shark of European politics France and Britain so feared at first.

headline: BRAZILIAN JOBLESSNESS RISES
abstract: Brazil's unemployment rate increased unexpectedly in October to 8.2 percent from 8 percent a month earlier (S)

headline: Turkish Court Upholds Death Sentence for Kurdish Rebel Leader
abstract: Turkish appeals court upholds death sentence for Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan; Ocalan plans appeal to European Court of Human Rights (M)6

headline: A Japanese Exodus in Reverse; Brazilians Work Their Way Back to the Ancestral Home
abstract: What urges someone like Nobotoshi Uski, a 41-year-old dentist whose grandparents emigrated to Brazil in an exodus that formed the largest community of Japanese descendants outside Japan, to reverse that trajectory and move to the homeland of his ancestors?    ''A lot of yen,'' said Mr. Uski as he waited in a winding line in front of the Japan Airlines counter at Sao Paulo's international airport, where he planned to board a midnight flight to Tokyo. Mr. Uski said he hoped to earn the equivalent of $2,500 a month at a job awaiting him at a Japanese auto parts factory, or about double what he earned as a dentist in his hometown about 200 miles west of Sao Paulo.

headline: World Bank Economist Felt He Had to Silence His Criticism or Quit
abstract: Joseph E Stiglitz, departing chief economist for World Bank, says he resigned instead of silencing his criticism of global economic polices as practiced by US Government; resignation focused attention on uncertain role of academic economists in position of power; Stiglitz's premature departure removes from Clinton administration most outspoken critic of practices that big industrial nations favor in their relations with developing world; those practices emphasize open markets, unrestricted borrowing from foreign lenders, rapid privatization, balanced budgets, minimal government role and various austerity measures when crises strike; photo (M)

headline: Nigeria Leader Amazes Many With Strong Anti-Graft Drive
abstract: After Friday prayers, townsfolk say, Maryam Abacha, the widow of the dictator who ruled and looted this country for five years, has begun opening the gates of the family compound to the city's poor, who fill her courtyard to receive free bags of rice, millet and sorghum.    The practice is regarded here as a crude attempt to burnish the image of the Abachas, who have become the poster family of an unexpected and ambitious drive by the county's new president, Olusegun Obasanjo, to root out corruption.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cendant to Pay $2.8 Billion To Settle Shareholder Suit  Cendant has agreed to pay its stockholders $2.8 billion to settle accusations of accounting fraud that wiped out billions in the company's market value. The settlement is the largest ever in a securities class-action suit.

headline: MINING COMPANIES IN TALKS
abstract: Lonmin PLC, London-listed mining company, says it is in early talks with Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana to purchase 68 percent of company it does not already own in deal valued at roughly $650 million; graph (S)

headline: Stane Dolanc, 74, a Onetime Tito Deputy
abstract: Stane Dolanc, former deputy to Marshal Tito, Yugoslav leader, and later member of joint presidency that governed nation, dies at age 74 (S)

headline: Ferrari Is Disqualified, Making Hakkinen No. 1
abstract: SEPANG, Malaysia—  Hours after being sprayed with champagne and handed their trophies Sunday, Ferrari's Formula One team was stripped of its victory in the Malaysian Grand Prix, catapulting Mika Hakkinen from third to first place and giving him the 1999 championship.

headline: Learning at Mayor's Knee, Mayor La Guardia's Knee
abstract: Interview with David Rockefeller focuses on experience of being unpaid aide to Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia in 1940 and 1941; photo (M)

headline: A Timorese Era Closes Quietly As Army Goes
abstract: Last 900 Indonesian soldiers leave East Timor, ending failed 24-year occupation that culminated in rampage of destruction; Jose Alexandre Gusmao, guerrilla chief freed from seven years in detention in Indonesia, is now effective leader of emerging East Timorese nation; he and his countrymen had battled Indonesians since they invaded in 1975, occupying vacuum left when Portugal abandoned its former colony year earlier; estimated 200,000 East Timorese have been slain or died of disease and starvation since Indonesia invaded; tens of thousands of Indonesian soldiers have also lost their lives; photo (M)

headline: Ulster Unionists Open Way to Govern With Sinn Fein
abstract: Ulster Unionist Party, opening way for new power-sharing arrangement in Northern Ireland, approves entry of its leaders into government with its sworn rivals from Sinn Fein, political ally of Irish Republican Army; vote sets off series of steps by British and Irish governments to transfer power from London to Belfast within days, and marks successful crowning of months of patient mediation by former US Sen George J Mitchell to salvage April 1998 peace settlement; photos (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    PAKISTAN: BHUTTO NAMED IN MURDER CASE -- A murder case has been registered against former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who is accused by the Islamic fundamentalist Jamaat-I-Islami party of ordering the police to fire on its members during a protest in June 1996. Five others were also named. A police investigation is likely to last several months.   Barry Bearak (NYT)    PAKISTAN: SHARIF CASE ADVANCES -- The case against the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, took an important step toward trial when prosecutors finally shared key evidence with the defense, something that had held up the start of the proceedings. Mr. Sharif is charged with hijacking, kidnapping and attempted murder.   Barry Bearak (NYT)

headline: Coke Bottler In Italy Fined $16 Million
abstract: Italian regulators fine Coca-Cola Beverages, Coca-Cola Co's bottler in that country, $16 million after finding bottler engaged in unfair practices; fine is second biggest ever from Italian Antitrust Authority; bottler is also ordered to end some discounts with supermarkets, move that could curb its business; Coca-Cola Co, which owns 51 percent of bottler, to pay fine; fine could also impact planned merger of bottler with Hellenic Bottling of Athens (M)

headline: In Convertibles, a Path To Technology Stocks
abstract: Article describes attributes of convertible bonds, which are seen as slightly risky alternative to investing in technology stocks; graph (M)

headline: The Cup Is Half Full
abstract: Letter from Christopher Gray on Sept 30 News Watch item noting that Europeans spend less time on line than Americans do (S)

headline: Take a Memo: Dictaphone Is Still in Business; Nowadays, Voice Is Just Another Form of Data
abstract: Dictaphone Corp gains new focus under John H Duerden, chief executive for four years; still derives most of its sales from office dictating equipment, but its future lies with medical records-keeping, systems for logging, monitoring and tracing telephone calls to customer help desks, financial trading floors and 911 emergency lines; is developing an Internet-based system in which it will accept dictated files from doctors and return partly edited transcripts; product that converts a doctor's dictation to an e-mail voice attachment was introduced in 1997 and has already captured 55 percent of health care market; Stonington Partners plans public offering of Dictaphone stock sometime in 2000; photo; graph (M)
